column1: Having ‚Äúthree‚Äù days to chill before the boat to Andaman we decided to kill the time in nearby Mamallapuram
column2: an hour and a half bus ride from Chennai. Mamallapuram is home to some of the oldest architecture in India
column3: ranging from circa 1500 - 500 years ago.

column1: The Pallava dynasty (circa 1000-1200 years ago) had an architectural impact throughout southern India
column2: going north as far as Ellora (Near Mumbai
column3: we'll be heading there on our way north)
column4: and due to their excellent maritime capabilities their influence even reached parts of South East Asia. Ankgor Wat in Cambodia (One of the wonders of the ancient world) was influenced by the Pallava dynasty. Although today it's a Buddhist monastery
column5: I believe (I'll find out in a few months time)
column6: it was originally built as a Shiva temple.

column1: The town itself is quite nice
column2: it's been a tourist destination for quite a while
column3: so it's well set up. There's WIFI readily available in most places
column4: you can get all the western food you want
column5: and it's not bad! We ate beef burgers almost every night we were there.

column1: It seems like it's a popular destination for holiday makers and
column2: as is becoming quite common in the south
column3: the mature ‚ÄúIndiana Jones‚Äù traveller crowd. There's loads of resorts between Chennai and Mamallapuram
column4: even a Raddison Blue! Spoiling the area somewhat.

column1: The bus from Chennai left pretty regular and cost 29rs each. The moment we stepped off the bus a man approached us and offered a room near the beach within our budget
column2: so get in his tuk-tuk and head to the guest house. When we pull up there's very promising signs
column3: literally. The beach is less than 100m walk away and the sign says there's a pool! A fact backed up by the guy who took us there. We check in drop our stuff in the room and head to the ‚Äúpool‚Äù to check it out.

column1: Turns out the pool is in a ‚Äúcleaning‚Äù process and we couldn't go near it
column2: typical India. So a few days later when the guys running the guest house aren't around I took a look at the pool
column3: if it had any water in it it would've been class! It was a massive pool and full of broken bricks from the construction site next to it! Unfortunately we had to be content with the Bay of Bengal.

column1: Consulting the guide book to see what ruins to see first etc we see there's a big enclosure just to the back of the town full of old temples and monolithic caves
column2: and best of all....it's FREE!

column1: We decided to check this out first and leave the ones you had to pay entry for 'till the day after because one ticket gets you into both.
Just to the back of the bus stand was the start of the temples/caves etc. The first thing we came across was a monolithic cave
column2: with an amazing wall carving on the outer wall (bas-relief)
column3: this is called Arjuna's penance. It appeared to be a depiction of a war or something...in an attempt to do it justice I'm going to quote the guide book: ‚ÄúOn the left side
column4: Arjuna
column5: one of the Pandava brothers (who ruled the Pallava dynasty) and a consummate archer
column6: is shown standing on one leg. He is looking at the midday sun through a prism formed by his hands
column7: meditating on Shiva
column8: who is represented by a nearby statue fashioned by Arjuna himself.‚Äù

column1: The story depicted is one where Arjuna has gone to the ganges to do a penance
column2: in the hope that Shiva will relinquish his favourite weapon to Arjuna (Shiva is one of the gods
column3: if you're unaware). Arjuna has a fight with an old man over a boar they both claimed to have shot. After Arjuna cannot overcome the old man he realises it's Shiva
column4: who eventually gives up his weapon to the noble warrior. I'll also upload a picture if that's^^ not helping.

column1: There's quite a few caves/temples/bas-reliefs of varying degrees of quality
column2: some of which haven't been finished properly. Some of the rocks just lying around have the distinct evidence that someone has started to carve something and then left it. We were told this was because whoever the dynasty of the time had been
column3: they'd entered a war so had to stop building/carving and then when they came back from the war they didn't have enough money to finish them.

column2: the freedom you get in India to walk around and explore ruins is amazing. Unfortunately the Indian tourist don't seem to have the same kind of respect for things
column3: so the carvings of names etc into the walls spoils the experience slightly
column4: but still not one to be missed out on.

column1: Not only this but because of India's taboo on sex and young Indian couples
column2: you often see used jonny's on the floor and couples sort of hidden away in the bushes. I think some of these Indian parents need to sort their priorities out
column3: because some poor girl has definitely had her first sexual experience on a dusty rock.

column1: The second day we headed out to the Pancha Pandava Rathas and the Shore temple. If you're going to Mamallapuram make sure you do these two in the same day as one ticket gets you into both for 250rs.
The Pancha Pandava Rathas are allegedly 1.5km out of town
column2: so we got a tuk-tuk. Turns out this was some classic Indian overestimation of distance! It's like a five minute walk from the bus stand.

column1: It wasn't quite what I was expecting
column2: but still really cool. A stunning set of monolithic structures from circa 630-670 AD
column3: a set of five free-standing sculptures that imitate temples and some well carved ‚Äúlife sized‚Äù animals
column4: I hope I never see a bull that big!

column1: These structures also appeared to be unfinished
column2: even more so than the others. The rocks they were cut out of were still there
column3: and the middle of the temples hadn't been carved out
column4: so it was more like rocks with carvings and little patios
column5: rather than an actual temple.

column1: You can also find one of the earlist depictions in Tamil Nadu of a dancing Shiva
column2: Nataraja.

column1: The design of these temples has been replicated throughout the south even into modern times as the ‚Äútemplate‚Äù design of a temple
column2: in terms of the carvings and they style they've been done in.
with it's silhouette that can be seen along the beach for miles
column3: dates from the early eighth century. It's considered to be the earliest stone built temple in south India. Unfortunately due to it's positioning wind
column4: salt
column5: and sand has eroded most of the finer details away
column6: but still leaving a pretty impressive structure.

column1: On the last day we decided to head to the nearby tiger cave
column2: 5km away. I wouldn't recommend going here unless you're really into your ancient Indian architecture
column3: the 200rs return tuk-tuk fee wasn't worth it
column4: and apparently we got that price because the guy hadn't had much business.

column1: It was still pretty cool though
column2: a monolithic cave in a similar vein to the others
column3: again not finished...or it looked that way. Massive lion heads surround the entrace to the cave
column4: which did actually make it one of my favourites in Mamallampuram.

column1: Given the lack of tourist here I seized my opportuity to climb on top of the cave and posed next to one of the great lion heads. I wanted to do this at the other places but sensed there would be judgement...or security would get involved.
We spent the afternoon on the beach being pestered by gypses (they're here too) who were walking up and down the beach selling trinkets and necklaces etc.
The current in the sea was too strong to comfortably chill in the sea
column2: although it did make for a decent suft which some people were taking advantage of. I think I'll save that for Andaman
column3: which is apparently a new found surf hub.

column1: We got the bus back to Chennai that evening
column2: ready for the boat the day after (6th). In hindsite we should've stayed put and got the bus to Chennai the morning of the boat
column3: because in true Indian fashion I got a text the day later saying the boat's been delayed 'till the 8th! Nice one!

column1: It's a good job we love Chennai so much....or not.
Steaming frothy cup of tea to start the day. With the blessings from rising Sun God
column2: we commenced our long drive to Cape Comorin
column3: the present day Kanyakumari; the southernmost rocky tip of the peninsular India. The estimated distance from Varkala was 140 km and the travel time of 4 to 5 hours. Barely 12 km from the Black Beach
column4: we reached the NH-47. The traffic was sparse and the chauffeur kept us engaged in his lively chatter.

column1: The interaction with the chauffeurs I find
column2: have been very informative
column3: which adds to the knowledge on diverse subjects such as the local culture
column4: customs
column5: cuisines
column6: lifestyle
column7: history
column8: do‚Äôs & don‚Äôts
column9: and above all the local politics. They have tremendous experience of ferrying tourists on a day-to-day basis
column10: and their exposure makes them very resourceful. As an icing on the cake
column11: the interaction keeps them in good humor throughout the trip. One cannot wish to have a better travel companion.

column2: large housing and commercial complexes consisting of skyscrapers became visible for the first time in Kerala. The chauffeur informed us that this is the Techno Park and all major software companies like TCS
column3: Infosys have their

column1: large establishments there. On seeing the large number of cars parked on the multi-storied car parks
column2: the magnitude could be easily gauged. The road-widening work coupled with the peak-hour city traffic slowed our pace drastically. The office-goers were seen rushing to their glass-clad workplaces. We moved on ‚Ä¶ though at a snail‚Äôs pace.

column1: We passed the diversions towards famous beaches - Kovalam
column2: Vizhinjam
column3: Poovar
column4: and witnessed many shops selling fruits. During our road journey in the last 4 days
column5: we noticed that many varieties of exotic fruits are grown in Kerala
column6: particularly banana
column7: pineapple
column8: papaya
column9: guava
column10: mango
column11: and jackfruit. We were told that there are more than 80 varieties of banana alone
column12: yellow
column13: purple and red
column14: having different sizes and tastes. The most favorite among them was red banana
column15: which has sweet taste similar to strawberries. From time to time
column16: we kept on refilling our fruit basket for the periodic consumption during our long surface travel.

column1: No sooner we crossed the cluster of backwater cruise jetties on Neyyar
column2: the inter-state permit was required to be taken to seek entry in the state of Tamil Nadu. Surprisingly it was swiftly issued after receiving the personal details of all passengers
one side of the road was the state of Kerala and on the other side the state of Tamil Nadu. The road doubled as the border for neighboring states. Though narrow
column3: the quality of road has been good throughout and well maintained too.

column1: The journey continued and we spotted a vendor selling Neera
column2: palm nectar
column3: or a sap extracted from the inflorescence of toddy palms. It was sweet
column4: delicious
column5: translucent in colour
column6: and high in nutritional value. The nectar was served in a cone made from green palm leaf. We could get 2-litres of real good stuff for mere Rs.100/-. A glassful
column7: highly diluted Neera costs Rs.10 ‚Äì 15
column8: back home. The pit stop was really heavenly and it could certainly give a skip to Kingfisher Premium this afternoon.

column2: with the vibrant signboards and colourful billboards in Tamil language
column3: it was evident that we have formally entered the state of Tamil Nadu. There was not much of a difference otherwise on the streetscape. As the traffic slowed down
column4: we reached one of the major town on this route .. Nagercoil. Since the breakfast was skipped in the morning
column5: we halted for

column2: TN

column1: an early lunch at Chitra Hi-Tech Pure Vegetarian Restaurant.
It was a large dining room like restaurant. We could not fathom as to what the ‚ÄúHi-Tech‚Äù meant. In order to receive prompt services
column2: we opted to sit in non-AC section. The thali meal consisted on Sambar
column3: Rasam
column4: Potato Gravy
column5: Dry Vegetable (boiled raw banana) with liberal sprinkling of Coconut
column6: Curd
column7: Papad
column8: Pickle and Rice. Everything unlimited. The delicious Payasam (in limited quantity)
column9: for the desert was excellent. The pricing was reasonable. ‚Ä¶ while exiting the question still lingered as to what is ‚ÄúHi-Tech‚Äù about it.

column1: The ambient temperature had crossed 30 degrees and it had become unbearably hot. The car air conditioner was not able to give us the desired cooling and comfort. Yet
column2: the efforts to avoid dozing off
column3: in the front seat of the car
column4: were in vain. The intermittent short nap was over when we approached large lotus plantations. We were hoping to see blooming lotus flowers
column5: floating on the lake. The plantations were in place sans blooming flowers. Probably it was a wrong season or the wrong time of the day ‚Ä¶. Not sure.

column1: We reached our today‚Äôs destination little after 2:00 pm.

Hotel Tri Sea. The south-facing room on the higher floor ensured that we have an uninterrupted view the famous landmarks of Kanyakumari. The road below had constant movement of tourists from all over the country. Unlike other destinations visited in the current trip
column2: most tourists were domestic and hardly any international tourist could be spotted. From the balcony of the room
column3: we could see the Arabian Sea and the Bay of Bengal meeting the Indian Ocean. The glare on the water was simply unbearable for the naked eyes. We decided to take a short nap till evening ‚Ä¶ it was much needed for the fatigue-ridden body.

column1: In the evening we took a small walk towards the Beach Road and visited high-domed Mahatma Gandhi Memorial. This beautiful structure was constructed in commemoration of the immersion of the ashes of the father of the nation in 1948.

column2: at the edge of the ocean on the rocky mainland
column3: we visited the beautiful Bhagavati Amman temple. This temple is dedicated to the Goddess Parvati as a virgin
column4: who is also known as Kanya Kumari Amman
column5: the presiding deity of the sea. Many legends are associated with Kanya Kumari. In the vicinity

column1: we also visited Adhi Shankar Temple. The tourists had gathered in large number at Triveni Sangham
column2: as the time of sunset was nearing. This area had hundreds of shops selling touristy articles and wares. The flow of tourists was unabated. The last minute rush to take selfies before the actual dusk was visible at the site.

column1: As we moved little away from this tourist market
column2: a battery-operated bus was beckoning us to board for the sunset point
column3: near Kovalam Beach ‚Ä¶. not to be confused with Kovalam Beach in Kerala. The fare was either Rs.10 or 20 one-way ‚Ä¶. not to sure. The environment-friendly mode of transportation facility by Kanyakumari Special Grade Town Panchayat
column4: the local authority was highly appreciable. The short 2-km ride took us to sunset point. Midway
column5: there was a view tower
column6: and was full of tourists seeking panoramic view of the sea and surrounding landscape. The promenade at sunset point was full of large groups of tourists
column7: from almost every state of the country. All had their sights sharply focused on the setting sun. Many were struggling to fit into the cellphone camera frame along with the sun
column8: singly
column9: jointly or with the entire family.

column1: The clouds were overcast and the visibility was little poor. As the glow on the sky diminished
column2: we returned to the beach in the same battery-operated vehicle.

column1: A short walk towards Kanyakumari Railway Station
column2: brought us to Mayapuri ‚Äì The Wax Museum. The entrance fee was Rs.100/- per head. It was a small place
column3: which housed well-made realistic statues of famous personalities. Amitabh Bachchan
column4: Mahatma Gandhi
column5: Barack Obama
column6: APJ Abdul Kalam
column7: Manmohan Singh
column8: Rabindranath Tagore
column9: Albert Einstein
column10: Mother Theresa
column11: Michael Jackson ‚Ä¶ to name a few ‚Ä¶. all of them housed under the same roof without any individual ‚Äòsecurity cover‚Äô. In an adjoining hall
column12: there were aesthetically lit 3-D paintings. The uniformed staff was quite friendly and helped the tourists to click photographs with the statues or 3-D pictures in the background. Young and old
column13: both were delighted with the visit to this place and have their pictures clicked.

column1: The evening was well spent and it was time to return to the hotel room. The tourist flow to the beach was getting diminished with every passing hour. The brightly lit islands
column2: housing Thiruvalluvar Statue and Vivekananda Memorial
column3: were now deserted. The roar of the ocean could be clearly

column1: heard from the balcony. We did not venture out for dinner and the same was ordered from the hotel kitchen. A small ‚Äòspirited‚Äô relaxation was followed by the dinner consisted of Prawns
column2: Dal-Fry
column3: Chapatis and Rice
column4: with Pickle and Papad. The spicy aromatic prawns curry satiated the hunger to a very great extent. A brief walk

column1: Thiruvalluvar was the highly respected and celebrated poet from Tamil Nadu. He composed Thirukural
column2: which is one of the most important literary work in Tamil language. This literary work was arranged in 133 Adhikarams
column3: each with 10 couplets. The 133 Adhikarams were divided into three major groups known as ""Aram""
column4: ""Porul"" and

column2: Porul defines the principles of Life for common people as well as the State.The last section deals with aspects of Love.

column1: It was in his memory this 133 ft tall grand structure was erected. The 95 ft. tall statue of this poet stand atop 38 ft. pedestal known as Atharapeedam. The pedestal is surrounded by Alankara Mandapam
column2: which has 10 elephant statues signifying 10 directions. The 38 ft height of pedestal represents 38 chapters in the Book of Aram in Thirukural and the statue of 95 ft represents the total chapters in Porul (70) and Inbam (25). Thus the statue symbolically signifies that the theme of Porul and Inbam are based on Aram.

column1: This morning Ginnie was unable to join me for the walk because of her broken toe. My guide was Kingsley and he is keen totake visitors to a place where tourists do not usually go. The mode of transport was a good start. I rode on the back of Kingsley's scooter to the bus station in Conoor and then we took the service bus to a small village. The walk climbed up to a fort which was used by Tipu Sultan 400 years ago. Very little now remains of the fort except a few low walls now overgrown. The first part of the walk was a climb through the tea gardens. Trees are grown in the tea garden to absorb the dew. In the tea gardens I saw different tasks including picking
column2: pruning
column3: pruning the trees
column4: spraying and collecting dead wood as firewood. Some of the tea is now picked by machines and this makes straight lines. The tea picked by hand has circular irregular patterns. In the tea we encountered wild bison. These can be quite dangerous if they are startled. On the way back we took a slightly different route to avoid one particular bison who might have become aggressive. There was a short section up through native wood to reach the fort. On the return walk we met several tea workers whoI were stopping for their lunch break. We very nearly missed the bus and had to run!

column1: In the afternoon our driver to us on an excursion to a wildlife reserve. The drive was first up to Ooty and then down by 36 hairpin bends. Each hairpin bend is numbered. My photos didn't work out great
column2: but we did see deer
column3: wild pigs
column4: peacocks and a large group of elephants. This group of elephants included a male
column5: several females and one baby. In the dusk as we were returning we saw a solitary male elephanby just by the side of the road. The journey back was a reverse including those hairpin bends.

column1: We had one day at sea between Singapore and our next port of call
column2: Phuket. Our normal routine was followed. We went to the quizzes and though we got close we were still one or two off the pace. We sailed through the Straits of Malacca where there were rows of ships all traversing the waters. It was great watching the traffic from our balcony and we were amazed at the number of ships going in the same direction as ourselves. This ship has been sailing at a much faster pace than the Astor. It is also amazing to observe the varying colours of the sea.

column1: We arrived at Phuket Port about 6-30am on Saturday
column2: 16th January. We watched from our balcony as the ship backed into the quay. There were several resort hotels scattered around the bay with rich greenery and white beaches. After breakfast we left the ship about 9-20am. At the port there were many market stalls set up for our perusal. We changed some money
column3: looked through the stalls and then engaged a taxi driver to take us into Phuket town. We organised that he would pick us up about 4pm to take us back

column1: to the ship. Then it was about a 30 minute drive into the main city.

The weather was overcast but very humid. Our driver had an ""arrangement"" with a jewellery shop in the town and he dropped us off there and we went in to look around. We were effusively greeted by the manager who kept trying to sell me a pair of sapphire earrings. Everything was ‚Äúhalf-price‚Äù but they had some nice bags and other souvenirs there so we did end up buying some things as gifts etc. From there we walked along the street towards the markets. Though some of the town's buildings could do with some paint the streets were very clean and there were some buildings which were very attractive. We found a caf√©
column2: The Circle
column3: and even though it was only 10-30am we settled in with a beer and used their free WiFi. It was very overcast and the day was humid but there was a fan so we spent an hour or so quite pleasantly.

column1: We then walked down to the Market. This was a typical Asian market with open shop fronts selling all manner of goods. Food
column2: clothes
column3: shoes were all on sale and there

column1: were a couple of motor bike repair shops and others with household goods. We then walked up a side street and along a parallel street. Here there were some smarter looking hotels with restaurants and other small boutiques. We went into an Antique shop. In the window Fletcher's eye had been caught by 8 Chinese figures
column2: in porcelain. We asked the owner about them and were told they were the 8 lucky men. They were a set and we could have them for $A720. If we could have bought one or two we would have but we don't have room for all eight.

column1: In the same street we happened across a Buddhist temple. This was called Sam Thang Shrine and had been founded by Hokkien Chinese in 1891. It had been recently renovated and was resplendent in its red and gold colouring. We walked down the alley way and explored inside. Typical of these places there were many statues of gods and small buddhas with a main altar behind the front table ladened with fruit and food offerings. We had to take our shoes off to go in and a small boy came in with us
column2: to check up on us

column1: I think. The main doors were carved into spectacular statues of angry looking gods.
We then went back to one of the nice restaurants we had seen
column2: The Baba. This was part of the On On Hotel. We dined here in air conditioned comfort. We had several small dishes of Thai food including spring rolls
column3: four types of fried seafood
column4: Thai sausage in pastry
column5: a red duck curry and stir-fried beef. All were excellent. We washed it all down with Chang beer. Having used their free WiFi too we walked back the way we had come.

column1: Past the jewellery stop at the next intersection there was a main roundabout which looked like the centre of the town. Across the road there was another shrine which we also explored. This was more rundown than the first one but it was larger. A lady attendant smiled at us and made sure we took off our shoes before entering. Again the many statues had their offerings and looked down on us

column1: We chose a walk around the lake here. We had a guide to help us across the river and for the initial route finding. After that it was easy around the lake. There was a range of agriculture including rice paddies
column2: coconut plantations and mango trees. We saw the irrigation system being used for the coconuts. There were birds

column6: but now work in Singapore. At the temple we met many more people. A young boy had just had his hair cut off as an offering and his head was covered in sandalwood. All the children were keen to practise their English and for us to join the blessing ceremony at the temple. Lots of photos were taken of course. The adults also wanted photos. We averted our eyes just a little to the slaughter of chickens at the temple. All through the walk the next door dog was our companion. She was very good and waited patiently when we were talking and taking photos. We didn't take a wrong turn

column1: We are staying at Cardamon house which has attractive gardens and a swimming pool. It is green and quiet here
column2: and it makes you feel a little sleepy. There are sunbirds in the garden
column3: they have a yellow breast and long slightly curved beak.

column1: This morning was a surprise late addition to our journey. The Madurai tourist board invites foreign and domestic tourists to a local village for a Pongal celebration. The village this year was Thenkarai. This is special for the village and they all were enjoying the event and wanting to meet all their guests. We were given flower garlands. Inside the temple there was a welcome from the village and dancing. The main dance was with a metal cooking vessel balanced on the head. There were also two horse dancers on stilts. There was an opportunity to taste Pongal and to watch it being cooked. It is like rice pudding
column2: with less milk. The village temple is an old Chola temple with inscriptions using a very old Tamil script on the walls. There was more dancing and village games.These included a strength competigon huge stones and dropping them over your shoulder. More than I could lift at the gym! The last game involved the participants blindfolded and given a stick to strike an earthenware pot. I had a go and was fairly close
column3: but I failed. A tall young Californian won. The village also provided a very enjoyable lunch. I particularly enjoyed the chance to try the sugar cane. This is the special Pongal sugar cane which is black. It had a very fresh taste
column4: sweet
column5: but quite different from refined sugar.

column1: After lunch we continued the short journey to Cardamon House. From here we can see the mountains
column2: but we haven't yet started to climb.

column1: Today was a very early start at 5.45am. This was for a walking tour in the old town in Madurai before the traffic and crowds arrive. We joined six other Indian Panorama travellers. The first part of the walk focused on the houses and particuladrawing the coloured drawings outside the door of each house. These drawings are made twice a day in the early morning and again in the evening. They are made of white and coloured powders that are sprinkled to create patterns. Today the drawings were particularly elaborate because of the Pongal harvest festival. They included representations of the rice cooking pot and the sugar cane palms that are used to decorate homes. We saw a lady cooking various breakfast food for sale and then tasted her cooking- a little like the inside part of a do-nut but less sweet and with a slightly crisp coating. We walked through various markets selling fruit
column2: coconuts
column3: onions
column4: vegetables and a huge collection of bananas. The bananas are smaller and there is also a red variety which apparently has special properties. The final part of the tour was a climb up for a view of the temple. On this tour the town had a festival holiday feel with lots of people sayin Happy Pongal.

column1: After a late breakfast at the hotel we returned to the temple. The temple has ancient foundations and was the centre of the old city of Madurai 1600 BC. This is the old part of the city where our walking tour took place. The temple is a mixture of old and new. It was built over a period of 500 years up to C19. The new within the temple highlighted by our guide includes the ceiling painting which is regularly repainted and an optical illusion Shiva ligngam which turns to face you as you change direction. The temple is based on the story of Meenakshi. There are representations of the marriage of Shiva and Meenashi. From the temple tank there was a very impressive view across to one of the towers. It was also possible to see the two anctums covered in gold. Although these are lower then the painted towers
column2: they stand out because of the gold. The 1
column3: 000 pillar hall is a highlight. This is the museum area and has better lighting than some areas of the temple. I enjoyed the Yali with a crocodile sculpture and one of a female goddess who looked so fierce she could have been Amazonian. The ivories were interesting
column4: but not well displayed.

column1: After a thali lunch at the hotel we explored the local area. The hotel is in the financial district and it is also a residential area for doctors
column2: lawyersand other professionals. The houses were luxury modern. Most shops were closed for Pongal
column3: but we found a supermarket. In one of the residential streets a temple elephant was wandering with her mahout. We sawhere eatfruit and sugar cane presented by a man in one of the houses and receive a blessing from the elephant - a sort of trunk raising over the head. We paid 20 rupees for our blessing. The elephant received the note in her trunk exactly the same as food and passed it up to the Mahoot.

column1: On the way to Madurai we stopped at a bird sanctuary. My binoculars would have been useful here
column2: but they were not easily accessible. We could identify ibis and egrets
column3: and there were other unidentifieds. In Madurai our first visit was to the flower market. This was very busy because of Pongal. We saw the expensive jasmine
column4: roses in different colours which are imported and garland making. We made a brief photo stop at the tank. Alongside this tank the process of drying cotton after it has been dyed takes place. The tank os a good place for this task because ther is a long enough space without too many people. The main visit was to the palace. This is full of pigeons and not very well looked after
column5: but it is worth taking care of. This is a Nayac palace. Originally it was much larger
column6: but two main halls remain. The columns in the halls are rather stocky
column7: but it is worthwhile to raise your eyes to see the decoration in the Hindu saracenic style. The last part of the sight seeing was to the Ghandi museum. Ghandi visited Madurai several times and on one occasion he decided to adopt the dhoti as his dress - this was part of his connection with all sections and castes of Indian society. The story told in the museum is
column8: as you might expect
column9: not flattering to the British.

column1: After a break at the hotel we took a tuk tuk with our guide for the evening temple procession. We opted to see the procession outside the temple. Before the procession there was time for shopping. Madurai is famous for its tailors. For Westerners the tailors will make up a dress/top or simple trousers. You choose the style and material. The tailors section is in a Mandapan of the temple. I had a dress made up and collected it the same evening. The temple precession included a camel and a bull. The photo shows the image of Meenakshi being carried into the temple.

The first temple in Tanjore is known as the big temple because of it's large sculptures. It is not the biggest temple In the area - see later. The photo shows the two ladies who helped us. We had come from the sanctorum behind and had received from the priest the redscored. The ladies helped us to tie these on correctly. The big temple has an elegant design with sharp corners of the central vimana. At the front there is a huge Nandi (bull) which is a monolith carved from a single piece of stone. The huge cupola on thetool of the vimana is made from eight pieces of granite which were carved in situ. At this temple I particularly noticed that above the carved figures there are mini temples above as a sort of architrave or decorative feature. Our guide also pointed out ""magic"" sculptures. The most famous of these is one showing an elephant and a bull with the head of the elephant and the head of the bull is one head identifiable from a different perspective.

After this temple we visited the palace and library in Tanjore. The library contains early writing carved into palm leaves. I have seen very similar in Buddhist monasteries. The museum in the palace included a collection of bronzes and sculptures. There was more to see here
column2: but the museum was closing for lunch. We drove to Trichy and visitedthe Sri Ranganathaswamy temple. This temple is enormous. There are seven entrance towers. In the outer three areas the Brahmins live and there are shops and businesses. We climbed up for a view that could only capture some of the huge scale of this temple. In this temple the highligwhereas the hall with thepillars carved pillars. These have horses at the top and scenes of fighting below. There is also a small museum with ivories. This museum would benefit from an upgrade.
but there was time for me to climb up to the rock fort for a view over the city. It was rather hazy.

column1: Sore throat so difficult to talk today. On the way we stopped to watch rope being made in a village. I acquired a piece of rope. Im not sure yet what to do with it. his was a day of temples - five in total. I will write about the two that stand out for me. The first is one with a most impossible name Gangaikondacholapuram. Try to say that one out loud a few times! The story behind this temple relates to the river Ganges. This is a Chola temple preserved in green gardens as a UNESCO site. The story of the temple is symbolised by the image of Shiva holding up Ganges. The special feature of this temple is the quality of the carvings.

The second is at Darasuram. Here the special feature is the small size of many of the sculptures. This includes small scenes from the Hindu epics carved into a square panel on the pillars. This temple also included the running elephant as shown on the photo and chariots.

I was sorry to leave Mahaburipuram. I would go back there. We had a friendly guide for Auroville and Pondicherry. Auroville is a strange place- a sort of social experiment that has not really succeeded. There is little to see
column2: but you walk to a viewing point for the Matrimandir which is a gold circular shaped building which is intended to symbolise the heart of the community. Our hotel was in the Tamil Nadhu area of the town
column3: but not far from the French quarter. The hotel was a heritage house with a courtyard at the centre and stained glass window sections over the courtyard. Our afternoon tour of Pondicherry included fairly modern RC churches
column4: French mansions now used for government buildings and posh shops
column5: the Ganesh temple
column6: the ashram and the beach. We were able to go to the sanctum of the temple for the ritual with lamp
column7: bunches of grass or flowers and the priest blessing. For a treat we dined in the hotel. Before dinner there was a cooking demonstration making a dish Okra. We tasted the results. There was another couple at the tasting and we had dinner with them. Sunday is a day for fish in India
column8: so the main course was two types of fish
column9: one was a red snapper or similar. Pondicherry in the tourist areas is green and clean and fairly quiet
column10: so it has a different feel. Indian tourists from the big cities also come for this reason.

column1: I was woken at 7 by drumming and took myself on an exploration before breakfast. I found the procession in the butter ball park. The butter ball is a large boulder which appears to be balanced
column2: but easily moved. This is deceptive
column3: it has stood the test of time. The procession was a small group of men. They collected flowers and leaves and lit a lamp at the Ganesh Ratha. After completing their chants and circle of the Ratha they continued the procession.

column2: Mr Ragu
column3: we visited the main sites
column4: starting with Aruja's penance. This is the famous bas relief with animals including elephants
column5: deer
column6: monkeys
column7: birds
column8: dwarves and the cat echoing Aruja's pose surrounded by mice who just might be deceived. The river Ganges is the natural fissure in the rock. We also visited cave temples. A memorable image was of a cow being milked with cows and cowherds nearby and a young flautist above. We continued with a visit to the five Rathas
column9: that can be described as the chariot temples all carved from the same piece of rock. Animals featured here too
column10: a bull
column11: an elephant and a lion. After visiting another cave temple and a viewpoint we finished with a visit to the shore temple. Although this temple was damaged by the Tsunami it has been restored. This temple is the final development of temple architecture to a constructed temple with its vimana tower over the sacred shrine.

column1: This concluded the Mamellapuram tour. We had a short drive to visit a Muslim fishing village. Families were enjoying themselves on the beach and in the water.

After my coffee break (a return to the German bakery cum Napalese tea house) I found myself drawn back to butterball park. I explored the area at the back of the site. This area is popular with Indian tourists but off the beaten track for Westerners. There was a good view from the ""old lighthouse"".

Kanchipuram has over 100 temples. It is not a huge city like Chennai so some of the temples are close neighbours. The first temple was dedicated to Vishnu - Devarajaswami. This temple has a marriage hall with carved pillars (horses) on the left after you pass the entrance tower - gopuram. This is a C16 temple and there are Portuguese influences in the dress of some of the carvings. At the back of the marriage hall you can see the temple tank. This is used for festivals when images of the gods are floated in the tank. It is more like a small lake than a tank. The story associated with this tank is that precious images were hidden in the tank at the time of war to protect them. The temple waited 40 years to drain the tank and uncover the image
column2: but this only lasted 48 days because of another invasion. This is now commemorated by draining the tank every 40 years. The next temple Sri Ekambaranathar has a famous mango tree.

column1: The Kailasantha temple is unlike the other two temples because it is more a monument and less a living temple. This is from the much earlier Pallaver time like tha temples at Mallarapuram. Although this temple has been restored there are many original carvings left and traces of fresco painting.

After visiting a silk weavers the drive to Mahallapuram was not long. We arrived in time to explore. I found somewhere to eat a snack and found myself wondering why it seemed familiar. I saw the Tibetan prayer flags and pictures and found Nepalese food on the menu. Here it is easy to walk around unlike Chennai where the roads are impossible. I took a first look at some of the sights including Arjuna's penance. The late afternoon light highlighted some of the temples. More to come tomorrow. Malabar fish for dinner.
We met our guide and driver this morning. Tamil Nadhu exports flowers
column2: particularly jasmine to South East Asian countries. At the temples flower garlands are for sale. At the first temple which is the oldest in Chennai we learned about Shiva and Parvarti. The information was useful in the evening because there was a music and dance festival. We attended a very professional performance at the music academy with classical Indian music and dancing by a solo female dancer. In one of her dances she took the role of Parvati admiring the form and formlessness of Shiva. Another dance was composed by the flautist in the music group. The dancer had paint on her fingers and toes. Her fingers appeared to bend backwards in some of the gestures. We also visited the modern Roman Catholic cathedral linked to a story about St Thomas and Fort George. Little remains of the fort
column3: but the museum has a collection of portraits of the great and the good from the British Imperialist period balanced by information about some of those who fought for Indian Independence. This included a woman who was involved in the development of the Indian flag. The jewel in the crown of Chennai is the Chola bronzes - lots of them and quite well displayed in the National Museum. In the afternoon we drove out to the Chennai equivalent of Beamish. I expected this to be low key
column4: but it was not just reconstructions. There was architecture and door carving from old mansions and houses. An impressive piece was a chariot with wooden wheels used to pull images of the gods through the town at festival time.

column1: Jet lag today. Journeyed by auto - which I know as a tuk - from the hotel to the sea. Took the lift to the top of the modern lighthouse for a view over the beach and the city. Ginny had made friends with an unusual couple
column2: a glamorous beautifully attired doctor from Uruguay and her young Indian IT specialist friend who is local to Chennai. We had dinner with them at the hotel and ate our vegetarian curries Indian style. A wedding was taking place in the hotel and the lifull and lobbies were full all evening with bright and patterned saris.

column1: After a brilliant week with our tour group we were back on our own. We took a night bus to Kodaikanal via Palani. It rained heavily as we left and we passed an ambulance on its side in the middle of the road! Only in India!
We arrived at 4am into Palani which wasn't pleasant
column2: strong urine smells
column3: rubbish everywhere
column4: dodgy and drunk people all around and a guy hitting a lady in the face.

column1: We got to Kodaikanal in the western ghats where the altitude increased to 2000 masl.
I guess we had high expectations of Kodaikanal but we found that the room was damp and cold
column2: that shops don't open until 11 and to find a non Indian breakfast is a struggle.

column1: We didn't have a very good first impression and after a nap and lunch
column2: it rained heavily for hours.

column1: It wasn't all bad and we liked it a bit more the following morning.

Clear blue skies greeted Kodaikanal which was above the clouds. We went to the lookout near town for some nice views. On a clear day you can apparently see the valley below. We took a walk to the lake which was nice and quiet and offered
After a brief city tour we headed by bus to Madurai. There were some nice views on the way down of the mountainous western ghats.

Once we arrived we went and visited the Gandhi museum which was great to learn about India under English rule and what Gandhi's role in an independent India was. Very interesting! We visited the main temple complex in which there are five temples
column2: the second highest in India. These temples are extremely detailed and colourful. Entry is free but knees and shoulders need to be covered and cameras aren't allowed but phone cameras are! strange!

column1: We then took our last long hall bus ride to the tip of India
column2: Kanyakumari! We liked Kanyakumari
column3: there is some nice scenery
column4: it's where three seas meet and you can see the sun rise and set over the sea. Many locals come to visit the temples and there is heaps of accommodation. Some of the houses are quite colourful but it is also quite windy.

column1: We upgraded to a hotel with a pool and after a hot day walking around
column2: we enjoyed a pool to ourselves with great views on top of the roof.

column1: We Stayed in Varkala in a nice hotel
column2: with a swimming pool

column4: chillout
column5: shopping
column6: lunch
column7: chillout
column8: swimming pool
column9: cliffside relaxing
column10: yoga (mostly Anna)
column11: dinner then bed.

column1: As the days grew closer to Xmas
column2: it was evident that there were more tourists arriving
column3: foreign and local. On one of the days we did a backwaters tour in a canoe.

column2: Pineapple
column3: Papaya
column4: Jack fruit
column5: Vanilla
column6: Coconut
column7: Pepper and a few more. All that in one area makes for quite a resourceful place.

column1: Varkala is a great place to relax
column2: we were glad to make the decision to come back after the tour.

column1: For our final three nights we stayed in Kovalam just south of Trivandrum. We had just stepped out of the taxi when we bumped in to an old friend randomly
column2: it was a quick but great little reunion.

column1: Kovalam is also a nice area to stay for
a few days. There are a few coves
column2: we stayed at lighthouse beach. There is lots of accommodation
column3: seaside restaurants and shopping opportunities. Even surfing!

column1: Christmas was a bit strange there. There were no real menus available for a Christmas meal in the restaurants and the beach was completely packed with locals going on dangerous boat trips whilst drinking. Apparently one person had their arm cut by the motor propeller and we saw one boat capsize.
We did spend a little bit of Christmas Day doing Christmas shopping. Talk about last minute!
In the evening we had a great seafood feast along the beach
column2: a different Christmas meal but amazing!

She warned that great crowds of people cram the streets around the Koodal Azhagar Temple in the evening

Ooty !! A place which is much attracted by tourists. We had heard of Ooty many times
column2: especially
column3: when we learn about Ooty flower shows in botanical garden or about rose garden. It was a place which I wanted to see once in my whole life time.

column2: I waited for the opportunity and it came. It was when Tamil Nadu Government announced its 117th flower show in 2013. I was eagerly waiting to visit it. So
column3: I booked an indica from Coimbatore. I had planned for 3 days trip. One of my friends
column4: Mahima also joined me.

column2: the day came. We both landed at Coimbatore Airport. our driver was waiting for us. We directly moved to Ooty. In around 1 hour we had reached Mettupalayam
column3: where we started feeling the chillness. We were moving up towards Ooty. We encountered the first thing was the hair pin bends which was 14 in total. We climbed up; we could see the hills covered with forests and the clouds. It was an amazing view. In around 3 hours we reached Coonoor. We broke our fast in Coonoor with hot idlis and coconut chutney.

column1: After that our driver took us to visit Dolphin‚Äôs nose Point and SIMS Park before moving up to Ooty. We moved towards Dolphins nose view point. We end up at a point. From there we saw a whole range of hills in front of us
column2: from where many little falls where flowing. We could see Catherine falls from here. It was covered with clouds and mist. It looked amazing.

we moved to SIMS Park. SIMS was another great attraction. We saw lot of people in SIMS park. It was flooded with trees and shrubs and etc. There we saw a tree which has turned into a rock and also a Rudraksha tree among the various trees. It was quite a big park. At the bottom
column3: there was a lake with boating facility. Then
column4: we moved to rest a while
column5: so
column6: we booked with a hotel and spent our night there.

column1: The next day from there we climbed up to Ooty. It was around 20 kms. Coonoor to Ooty gives an amazing view. We faced problems with the road conditions at some places and also it was very narrow way. We went through Wellington ground (where army men were playing).
When we reached Ooty it was past noon. We had our lunch at Saravana Bhavan. Mahima ate little because she had vomiting issues. So
column2: we moved to Government rose garden. After paying the entrance fees of Rs. 30 we stepped into Rose garden. It was a big garden
column3: filled with rose flowers of different ranges and colours. It was amazing to see. After clicking lot of pics of roses we sat at the park for some time.

column2: the place of our interest was next destination
column3: the Government Botanical Garden. It was a huge garden. A big board with ‚Äò117th Annual Flower Exhibition‚Äô welcomed us. We went through the isle of flowers kept in a neat manner. We were gazing through each variety. There were many people
column4: it was so much crowded. We saw many varieties of exotic flowers. It was really a vast area. There was a house inside where the authorities were selling seeds and saplings. There was also a glass house (which we had seen in many movies) in which we could see some rare kind of flowering plants. They were beautiful to see. We bought a hot chocolate each from the kiosk and sat down on the lawn.

column1: After relaxing there for hours we moved to boat house. After buying the tickets we moved in. There was a tiny counter for the ticket for boating. There were four types of boating
column2: row boats
column3: pedal boats (one with 2 seater and another 4 seater) and motor boats (8 seater). We booked for pedal boat. We were looking through the sceneries and the people of other boats
column4: waving hi! to them. 2 hours just passed by.

column1: We then moved out towards the Ooty bus station. We then quickly moved forward to Doddabetta Peak. It was a steep way. My driver found difficult to move up with the fog covered the place. Somehow
column2: we reached up to Doddabetta. We parked our vehicle at the base from where we had to go by walk. We climbed up steps to reach the top. It was so much tiring. But the the chillness made us to move forward to keep our body warm. We reached the top. The scene from here was beautiful. We went to the tip of the peak (so much rocky which was slippery due to fog). From the tip of the peak we saw a deep valley. It was so much cold that we were literally shivering. But
column3: it was the beauty of the place which grabbed us to stay. After a while when the mist became so dense that it hit us as a drizzle
column4: we quickly moved out of that place.

column1: The climate was dropping down. We reached Ooty and booked a room in a hotel. We really were in need of hot water bath.

column2: we headed towards Mudumalai Tiger Reserve. On the way
column3: we saw a falls called
column4: Pykara. It was a breath taking falls. the water flow was heavy. It was a thrilling experience. the drizzles were hitting us and made chill.

column1: After about more than an hour
column2: we moved towards Mudumalai National Park through Gudalur. When we reach there a big entrance named Mudumalai Tiger Reserve welcomed us. The forest officer told us that they have safaris only twice a day. We waited for our turn. When our turn came we were all carried by a jeep towards the jungle.

column1: The jungle safari was amazing. Initially we saw some wild rabbits and then wild squirrel. After driving through for some minutes we heard the elephants. Woow.. !! Thrilled totally thrilled. Then we realized the guide was actually taking us to place where elephants were. We were ready with our cameras and a bit scared. As we neared the voice of elephants increased. The guide was telling us something but nothing I heard. I was fully focused into the elephants. Then
column2: they showed up. they were 4 in total with a small bay elephant that looked so cute. The elephants looked majestic. T'was a great experience to see the animals in their own habitat. Then
column3: We moved forward to see wild boars
column4: spotted deer
column5: peacocks
column6: stag
column7: langurs and yeah a bison. The noises of birds and other creatures surrounded us. The journey to jungle to see 'Jungli' animals ended with a spot of a snake that crossed the road just in front of our vehicle.

column1: While returning we came through Masinagudi
column2: where we found a steep road ahead. It was like a roller coaster ride. So
column3: our driver was moving slowly.

column1: Then with this whole journey and adventure we headed back to Coimbatore via Kotagiri (as the roads were diverted towards Kotagiri at night). At Kotagiri we had our dinner. From Kotagiri we again moved towards back home to Coimbatore through Mettupalayam.
NB: Just wanna say that the whole trip was a successful because of a man who was keen in our safety and a fun packed tour. Mr. Nirmal (08682947494)
column2: the one who arranged a safe vehicle with reliable driver for us. Thank him...

column1: Ooty is the most attractive place places in India. Known as Queen of Hills
column2: it is covered with mist and clouds most of the time. It also looks good when it drizzles. So
column3: ‚ÄòQueen of Hills‚Äô is famous as Tourists destination. Here is my first time experience with Ooty. it was my cousins and me who planned the trip to Ooty. We were totally 6 people. At first we planned the routes to reach Ooty.

column1: Then we found to reach Ooty there are five ways:
1) Through Mettupalayam- Coonoor to Ooty (96.6 kms
column2: 2 hrs 45 mins)

column1: 2) Through Mettupalayam ‚Äì Kothagiri to Ooty (93.7 kms
column2: 2 hrs 48 mins)
3 hrs 33 mins)

column1: 4) Through Bandipur- Gudalur to Ooty (80 kms
column2: 2 hrs 20 mins)

column1: 5) Through Bandipur- Masinagudi to Ooty (49.7 kms
column2: 1 hr 37 mins)

column1: People usually take Mettupalayam- Coonoor or Bandipur-Gudalur/Masinagudi routes very often.
We were not intended to take the usual route (We booked with a travel (08682947494)
column2: who gave this advice of taking the other route). So
column3: took the Karamadai- Mulli- Manjoor route. We started early from Coimbatore in

column1: our Innova and travelled through Anaikatti and Manjoor. The road was awesome. We went through a deep jungle and the view was breathtaking. There were 43 hair pin bends but not very dangerous. We also saw a dam at a hair pind bend which was quite far away.

column2: we stopped at Manjoor to have our refreshment though we carried lots of snacks with us and we have preserved them for future need. Three of my cousins vomited. So
column3: we got into a local stall. We had our chaya with some buns. Then
column4: we proceeded on. The Manjoor-Ooty route is the most beautiful route and less populated. Most of the time we found ourselves alone on the route
column5: only accompanied by some bikers
column6: who were crossing us most of the time.

column1: It was 9 am when we reached a two way road. The left one went to Avalanche lake and another straight to the Ooty. We chose the left one. We passed by a Forest rest/guest house. we had to drive through a forest to reach the lake. As
column2: we reached there
column3: we found the whole paradise in front of us. We hopped to the bank of the

column1: lake. It was beautiful. It was silent and isolated. We were all in our early 20s so
column2: we feared a bit. But
column3: elder ones like me took the in charge and warned all not to do anything that could land us in danger. They all agreed. After taking lot of pics we moved to our vehicle. We drove back to the main road.

column2: when we saw Emerald Lake and stopped our vehicle there. It was as beautiful as Avalanche Lake. after taking pictures we started moving forward. We were bit hungry at this juncture. So
column3: grabbed some biscuits and chips packets to fill our stomach
column4: hoping it will help. Then
column5: we moved forward.

column1: It was about 11 when we reached Palada

column3: we saw an arch on which ‚ÄòGood Shepherd International School‚Äô was written. We were astonished. We kept staring at the school. We then moved from there with an awe. We entered into Ooty.

column1: We went through Muthorai to reach Fernhills Palace. It was wonderful and splendid. it was built in a huge area and covers acres of land
column2: which includes garden and in the middle

column2: when we were stopped by the magnificent Avalanche hill. We took lot of shots. Then
column3: we moved to Ooty main area. There we found the one
column4: which we were pleased to see. It was Thendral restaurant and we were starving. We rushed to the restaurant. We had breakfast of idli

column3: we had to move from one section to another. There were sitting areas too. Most of the people were resting there. we went through each section with taking pictures as much as we could. We sat on the grass at the last section of the garden which gave a beautiful image of Ooty. Most of the people were staring at us. after spending some time we came out.

column2: headed towards the Boat house. it had started raining. When we reached
column3: we were told
column4: that it was due to rain. We were disappointed.

column2: we headed to our next destination

column10: were enjoying at the most. We played cricket there
column11: then
column12: tree to tree. We had become children. After all that cousins‚Äô time we spend together
column13: we moved out of the garden.

column1: We drove to our hotel Willow hill. It was an isolated hotel. we had booked two garden room. Perfect for us. We checked in. The staff was courteous and nice. He first was stunned seeing our group. Then
column2: we told him not to worry we were cousins. He was quite convinced that we called each ‚Äòbhaiya‚Äô and ‚Äòdidi‚Äô and even the way we behaved. We moved to our respective rooms. We girls first had our relaxing hot water shower

column4: our staff called us for lunch

column7: we spend most of the time in the garden. The most amazing part the sunrise and the place becoming dark with lights getting on. Wow.. amazing one.

column2: we got ready early. We had planned to go towards Pykara and Mudumalai which were far then
column3: visit the places nearby. We had our breakfast before leaving. We started at 8 towards Pykara. It was drizzling. We had readhed in around 1 hr and 15 mins (we should have taken only 50 min

column5: the way gave a beautiful view with mountains and lake flowing by. Anyways we had now reached the lake. we were pleased to see the lake. It was quiet and away from city‚Äôs hustle-bustle. We ran to the bank. There was a jetty with around 5-6 boats. We booked a motor boat. It was 1 hour trip with surrounds all the area. we got into the boat. Our boat driver started talking to us. He asked where we were from
column6: how we came etc. Most of the time he talked to the boys. We all were then
column7: got busy in taking pictures while others checked out the place. With a peaceful and calm 1 hour boating we moved to bank. We spend some time at bank playing and talking. We were happy
column8: because we were on our own with leaving parents behind at home. We got to know more about each other. Paresh who we have known as the naughtiest one
column9: took responsibility of all the girls and was quiet most of the time. We started understanding each other.

column1: We moved to our next destination
column2: Pykara falls. it has stopped raining. We could see the whole place more clearly but wet everywhere. We enjoyed the climate. It was an awe-inspiring view. We were not allowed to go near the falls. but
column3: the water splashed on us
column4: which gave a chill experience. The flow was moderate contrasting to the rainy weather.

column2: moved towards Mudumalai Tiger Reserve. We drove to Theppakadu via Masinagudi which has the reception for Mudumalai Tiger Reserve. The way is fully covered with forests. The whole place was scaring. I held my sister‚Äôs hand tight. As we drove

column5: we saw some deer

column5: then

column9: he showed us pond where a couple of elephants were drinking water. My gosh. We had never seen elephants so close in their habitat. All were silent. We took some pictures Zoom in plus Zoom out. It was just speechless. Suddenly

column11: when stared at us. We got even more scared. I started taking long breaths. Our guide told we were at a safer distance so not to worry and not to get scared especially. After seeing elephants we moved forward and saw dead animal alongside the road. Our guide told
column12: it might be a Tiger‚Äôs prey. Hearing that

column3: we didn‚Äôt want to be killed by an elephant or a tiger. It was getting darker. My cousin drove quickly out of the forest. We had now

column7: we couldn‚Äôt see anything because of the fog. Then

column6: we saw sun setting down behind the beautiful mountains. One of the unforgettable moments in my life. Overall it was an amazing experience.

drove back to reached Sims Park. After buying the tickets we went in. It was another version of Botanical Garden but

column1: My close lads Ankush and Devsingh joined me at the last moment. Our adventurous tour began. We landed at the Coimbatore Airport. at the parking our driver was waiting for us with his Qualis. He gave a grin to us and we moved. Coimbatore

column2: we saw a pujari getting ready for the arthi. So
column3: we joined him. After getting the Prasad we came out and sat for a while at the premise. The temple was neatly managed. Anyone would like to stay for a while to see the beauty of the temple and the surrounding nature. We wanted to visit Sholay dam and Chinna kallar waterfalls but
column4: our driver said they both are in different directions and would take more time so to choose either one. So
column5: we decided to go Chinnakallar waterfalls. It took us nearly an hour to reach the waterfalls. We had to park our vehicle and step down to reach the waterfalls. We were so much happy to visit this waterfall. It was an amazing view. We started jumping and screaming and got off our shirts to jump into the water. It was so cold. Our driver was looking and laughing at us. We came to the bank to change our clothes. People around us were laughing at us too as we shivered and screamed out of cold. Once we were finished changing we moved to our vehicle and headed forward. From there we came to Nirar dam. It was quite an old dam (i guess). There was less water. But the scenery from the place was great. Having spend our half an hour there we headed back to our hotel. The room boy got us hot tea
column6: as soon as we reached
column7: which was so much relaxing. We spent the remaining hours at hotel room only.

column1: The next day we travelled to Athirapally. On the way we stopped at Sholayar dam. The dam was so much long. we finished our lays packet here and moved forward. We witnessed the whole nature unbounded in this way. The deep forests covered with mists. Wow. We had to pay at check post at Tamilnadu- Kerala border. Then a huge deep dark forest welcomed us. It was bit scaring but was thrilling experience. we reached Athirapally nearly afternoon. We had our lunch at a local eatery and moved to our resort- Riverok Villas. The resort was surrounded by a park of trees and plants. After checking in we went out to visit Athirapally falls
column2: which was at a walkable distance. We took our camera and headed to falls. we heard the sound of the waterfalls from way far. It thrilled us. When we saw the falls we went mad. It was just breathtaking. What a scene it was. A huge waterfall. We stepped down to it. As we were nearing it
column3: our heart started beating faster and faster. It looks amazing from close. The whole trip was made worth with this falls. we spent as time as possible till the keeper whistled to move out. Having saved the picture of the falls we came back and spent our night talking about the whole trip.

column1: The next day- we packed our bags back to Coimbatore. on way we had a glimpse of Vazhachal Falls. its an another beautiful witness of nature. We stopped for a while and then moved forward. we took the same route via Valparai to reach Coimbatore (not adding the Topslip).
After lounging in Pondicherry for a week or so
column2: it was time to get on the road to explore what South India had to offer. We had planned ten day‚Äôs travel with the first five to focus on historical places of interest
column3: with the next five being focused more on scenery and relaxation.

column1: We fit a lot into a relatively short period of time but are happy to be settled back into some home life at my Dad and Step Mother‚Äôs house in Gujarat for a bit of normality (and clean clothes) after a couple of weeks on the road.
Booking through a good tour company is a great way to explore unknown areas of the world.
We had previously booked most of our trips through online resources like Trip Advisor and the like. For this trip
column2: we wanted to make sure we had someone who understand what we like (a mixture of good food
column3: a bit of history
column4: and a lot of peace and quiet) so met with a friend of the family (Suresh at Sovereign Travel in Pondy) who did a great job understanding what

column1: we were after and then booked a ten day tour where we didn‚Äôt have to worry about anything.
Loose fitting local wear is the way to go.
Rachel has always tried to avoid the appearance of ‚Äògoing native‚Äô after seeing folks come back from Mexico for the weekend dressed in full sombrero and poncho gear. However
column2: in the case of traveling around India
column3: local wear has many benefits; Firstly
column4: it is cool (if you go for natural cotton) and keeps the wearer cool (or at least cooler than close fitting man made fiber. Secondly
column5: you get a lot less unwanted attention and the locals tend to assume you are to be respected. Thirdly
column6: they cost very little - per the last blog
column7: very good quality clothes can be found for under $10. Fourthly
column8: Rachel looks ace in a punjabi top - you will see photographic evidence of this throughout.

column1: There is a life lesson here. While in the mountains
column2: we had a tour of a tea museum scheduled and we weren‚Äôt excited about it and were going to skip. How much do you want to know about tea? However

column1: we took a life lesson from my mother and step-dad (the awesomely named Barry Barry Holgate after a moment of confusion at the birth registry). They tend to agree to go see anything that‚Äôs suggested. That leads to us making fun of their trips to salt museums and such
column2: however they lead more active
column3: educated and fun filled life than most folks we know. It was with that spirit we agreed and had one of the more interesting times on our tour. Did you know
column4: for example that ALL tea (white
column5: black
column6: green
column7: oolong etc.) comes from the same tea plant. It is just processed differently. This begs the question why Teavana charges so much for various teas (also
column8: the best green tea at the plantation costs under $2 - a far cry from $80+ at stores in the US.).

column1: To lean heavily on the gonzo journalist; it was in the backwaters of Kerela when the toddy started to take hold. Rather than the nicely flavored whisky
column2: hot water
column3: lemon and honey drink I‚Äôd been used to drinking for colds since childhood (thanks Mum) - toddy here is a moonshine

column2: left to ferment for a day in the sun. We were called by our driver one night to be told he had ‚Äòa guy‚Äô who made toddy and do we want some. Per the above
column3: we said yes and were given two Aquafina bottles of a cloudy grey mixture. We then had a ‚Äòtoddy‚Äô night on a house boat. What did we learn? You‚Äôre only ever 24 hours and a coconut away from getting tipsy.

column1: The first time it happened was in the Gangaikondacholapurum (good luck with that one) temple - there were some kids who were sheepishly throwing glances at Rachel before their teacher came over and asked whether she minded if the kids got their photo taken with her. Then they all ran over and we super happy about it. This happened twice again when random folks asked Rachel to have their photo taken. She always said yes and we got some fun friends out of it.
Christianity hit India before it arrived in Western Europe.
This may be obvious to some readers
column2: but we found a church where the

column1: Vineyard in the foothills of the Western Ghats
sign said it was built in 407AD. We figured it was a misleading misprint because Europeans didn‚Äôt arrive until roughly a thousand years later. However
column2: the first church in India actually dates back to 57AD (we didn‚Äôt see it) and Jews
column3: Muslims
column4: Hindus & Christians have been living peacefully (with some exceptional years) in places like Kerela for over a thousand years.

column1: October is a great time to visit India.
The high season runs from November through April here
column2: so in October the places we visited were very quiet and we didn‚Äôt feel hassled or rushed while we toured around. The weather has started to get more manageable (cooler) and it rained most nights meaning the days were a little less muggy. Due to the out-of-season aspect of the timing
column3: along with Suresh booking us into mainly boutique style hotels
column4: in four of the seven hotels we stayed at we were the only guests. We both could get used to the ratio of 15 staff to take care of us.

column1: What have we been up to?
We got picked up from Pondicherry by our awesome
driver for the next ten days
column2: Jeevan. We then took a couple of hour‚Äôs drive towards the center of Southern India stopping at various temples along the way
column3: many of which dated back a thousand years. The history of most of them is fascinating but their real draw is their ornate carvings of gods
column4: deities and stories from folk law. Some of them stand 260 feet tall and must have been something to see if you came across them out of what was essentially jungle a thousand years ago. We had some excellent guides
column5: Rachel‚Äôs favorite being Paneer
column6: due to his cheesy name. Although a Brahmin
column7: we were told by our next guide that Paneer was something of a local celebrity on the late night bar scene.

column1: Chettinad (where we stayed the second night) was one of the highlights due to it being a small town that trains many of the best chefs in India. Their cuisine is unique to the region and some of the spices can only be found locally. I took the opportunity to do a cooking class
column2: and we both took the opportunity to stuff our faces.

column1: trip to Madurai we headed to the Western Ghat mountains for a stop on an island in the middle of a lake in Thekkady. This was probably the most peaceful part of the trip. We had the place to ourselves and did nothing except eat
column2: read and sit on our porch watching the wildlife. We saw various types of deer
column3: warthogs
column4: monkeys
column5: peacocks and wild elephants. One night we were drinking our new ‚Äòempty the pantry‚Äô cocktail - a mix of vodka
column6: fresh pineapple juice and a neon colored orange soda drink over ice - while sat listening to music on our porch when we looked up and saw a grizzly bear listening to the music on the other side of our wooden lattice balcony about ten feet away. We were told we were very fortunate to see a bear. We didn‚Äôt feel overly fortunate at the time and it signaled the evening was going to head indoors.

column1: Driving to the tea plantations of Munnar was an experience in itself. You travel on a road that is only wide enough to fit a bus and it winds up 5000 ft mountains with sheer drops on one side and tea
plants on the other. That on it‚Äôs own would be fine
column2: but when you‚Äôre overtaking one of those busses and another bus comes the other way you discover that the road will actually fit three vehicles
column3: going different directions
column4: at speed. At times like this it is wise to focus on the tea plants.

column1: We did a tour of Munnar with a trek to the second highest peak in South India along with the aforementioned tea museum. We were shown around by a wonderful guide called SriRaj. He knew so much about the wildlife of the area and more than any man we‚Äôve ever met about tea. He was one of the main reasons we had such an interesting trip to Munnar. A good guide makes for a good visit. He left us with a list of Bollywood movies to watch as he was well versed in those as well.

Our trip ended with some days in the scenic backwaters of Kerela. One night was spent on a house boat which gives you a relaxing meander around the rivers and lakes. We had a great chef again so ate well while laying

on cushions at the front of the boat under a traditional thatched ceiling watching river life go on around us. It made us feel a bit like Egyptian royalty headed up the Nile. After spending 24 hours on the boat
column2: we headed to Fort Cochin
column3: one of our favorite places so far in India. It‚Äôs a town that has been a center of the spice trade since 2000BC. The architecture is heavily influenced by the Portuguese (1500 - 1650AD)
column4: the Dutch (1650 - 1800AD) and the Brits (1800 - 1950AD)
column5: and still has wide open spaces
column6: Chinese fishing nets
column7: a palace
column8: and a synagogue dating back to the 1500‚Äôs. However
column9: we had been on the road for quite some time so we were excited to leave Kerela (although we will genuinely miss our driver
column10: Jeevan) to catch a plane up to Gujarat and the comfort of my parent‚Äôs beautiful home
column11: and their washing machine.

column1: The flight‚Ä¶ Long but uneventful. We watched Spy (decent)
column2: Hoff My Chest (a BBC mock-umentary staring David Hasselhoff playing David Hasselhoff in an attempt to revive his career in England) and fell asleep to Mad Max. Obviously things have got civilized again in the world (?) as it was the first flight in years where we had a proper knife and fork instead of their useless plastic cousins.

column1: Chennai itself looked like a city in the midst of modernization. Fisherman‚Äôs Cove (or Vivanti as it is now called) was planned to be a relaxing first stop so we could get over any jet lag and get acclimated to our new time zone (11.5 hours ahead of Atlanta). It was odd to think that although it was early Tuesday morning where we were
column2: Monday night football hadn‚Äôt kicked off yet back home.

column1: We knew that this first stop is not representative of the rest of India. The beaches are raked every morning and the gardens are pruned. Most of India doesn‚Äôt have a swim up bar.
So glad to see English Bacon back on my menu

column2: we‚Äôd been to this hotel when I was a kid so I was looking forward to returning.

column1: We weren‚Äôt sleepy so took the opportunity to watch the sunrise over the Bay of Bengal and after walk on the beach went for breakfast. Hello bacon my old friend. Breakfast was really tasty and included english (hurray) bacon and a buffet of various made to order Idli‚Äôs (Indian crispy pancakes stuffed with potatoes and served with a chimi-churi type ‚Äòsamba‚Äô) and other wonderful things.
In keeping with our relaxing ideas of the next couple of days

column3: then settled into a 90 minute facial. I‚Äôve brought a photo of Olivier Giroud with me so I can show hair dressers an approximation of what to do. It‚Äôll be interesting to see how they turn out when i make the transition from hotel spa barber
column4: to side of the road barber. I also suggested to the barber to do ‚Äòwhatever he thinks makes the most sense‚Äô with my facial hair so I currently look

Due to the jet lag and the extreme relaxation during the spa

column1: Lunch was eaten at the pool and consisted of chili dusted fish and ice cold beer. It‚Äôs nice to arrive on a Tuesday as we pretty much have the hotel to ourselves. There was one other person at the pool.

The day was shaping up perfectly.
Due to the ‚Äòfisherman‚Äôs‚Äô aspect of the hotel
column2: we decided to stick to seafood as much as possible and had south Indian spiced Tiger Prawns and some grilled calamari which were both good and tasty. Rachel also enjoyed some Pineapple martinis while I had a couple of basil / rum / something blue drinks.
a fun / tasty / relaxing kick-off to our adventure. Our next update will be from Pondicherry in a couple of days.

column1: It was a clean ride and we stayed together
column2: only slowing down at the speed bumps when we crossed the villages. The next 50 kilometers was easy and at well past 12 we neared Kanchipuram and just at the entry Jai and Anand were almost about to be stopped by a half naked man whose intentions we did not know but found to be suspicious though he backed away at the sight of the second bullet right behind them ! We took the right turn just before Kanchipuram and followed the military road that led us to Walajabad
column3: the same town where we met Jai
column4: Jag and Anand for the first time on the trip yesterday. Stopping for a brief halt
column5: we pulled on after Walajabad on the vandalur highway
column6: past factories and industrial estates and sleepy villages and the tension slowly eased out of me
column7: when I noticed that we were eating up kilometer after kilometer heading towards home. Jai and Anand were nowhere to be found ahead of us they were too fast and I could not catch up with them. It still made me feel somewhat uncomfortable to contemplate the situation if we had been left alone to manage the journey between Arni and Walajabad in the dark rainy night. It was indeed a perfect decision by Jayaraj that night at Arni ! We reached the manivakkam junction where we turned left and proceeded towards mudichur and the roads brightened up with lights and call taxis with call center employees were travelling on the road which was a welcome sight and we reached Tambaram on to the GST road to Chennai.

column1: It was 25 kilometers to home and the city was alive as ever! We crossed every junction and airport and in no time I was climbing the Kathipara flyover bridge to Ashok Nagar and Nungambakkam. Turning left off the Poonamalle High Road
column2: I stopped my bullet finally to drop off Wesley and it was at that time Anand called me to check on me. It was nice to know that they had reached a little earlier back home and after a brief halt I drove slowly back home at 03.15 am
column3: Monday morning
column4: 13th of July 2015.

column1: Greetings from Cape Comorin ‚Äì the southernmost tip of India. It certainly feels like an achievement to have arrived here

column4: the Bay of Bengal and the Indian Ocean. It is a stunning location

that I was again originally dreading but in the end turned out to be amazing. This was six hours in a non-AC government bus from Madurai to here
