column1: Cape Comorin is the British name for the rocky outcrop marking the southern
column2: triangular-pointed end of India. In India it is now called Kanyakumari ‚Äì Kanya meaning ‚Äúvirgin‚Äù and Kumari being the Hindu goddess of the ocean
column3: and thus the town is dedicated to the Hindu Virgin Goddess of the Sea. Today I think has been the highlight of my trip so far. Not only is this just an amazing location to be in
column4: with waves crashing from three seas all around onto stunning rocky outcrops and islands
column5: I have been really blown away by my visit this morning to the Kumari Amman Temple dedicated to the sea goddess herself. There are very few foreign tourists here
column6: as in the whole of Tamil Nadu
column7: and I noted that this temple seemed to be one of the very few in India to allow non-Hindu tourists into its Inner Sanctum. The Inner Sanctum is the part in the centre of a Hindu temple which is considered the holiest as it houses the ‚Äúmurti‚Äù of the god/goddess to whom the temple

column1: Entrance hall to the Meenakshi Amman Temple
column2: Madurai

column1: is devoted. A ‚Äúmurti‚Äù is a statue believed to be infused with the very spirit of the god/goddess him/herself. This means that when a Hindu looks into the face of the murti
column2: they truly believe that they are looking into the face of a god. The murtis are thus treated with utmost devotion
column3: being washed
column4: clothed
column5: fed in the form of food offerings
column6: and sometimes even put to bed at night. Since the Inner Sanctum is so holy
column7: Hindus rarely allow non-Hindus into this part
column8: but in this temple I was allowed to enter. What an experience! I am mostly aware of people having to cover themselves up in temples
column9: wearing trousers and something to cover the shoulders. However
column10: in this temple
column11: not only did male devotees have to remove their shoes (and socks)
column12: they also had to remove their shirt. This felt very strange
column13: to be in a holy place wearing only my shorts
column14: but actually felt extremely freeing as well as enabling me to fit in with the other worshippers around me. I was lucky to visit during the puja (worship ceremony)
column15: which involved quite frenetic bell-ringing
column16: clapping
column17: horn-blowing
column18: and chanting. There were just so many people
column19: at

column2: Madurai
it became very hot
column3: and in the end quite frenetic with one lady being forcibly removed by the temple priests for pushing in. I initially felt quite ill at ease
column4: wondering what would happen if one of the priests did not know that the entrance guards had let me
column5: a non-Hindu foreigner in

column7: shaking my hand

column6: displaying one of the bone fragments of the apostle.

column1: ECR road is famous for sun sand but there are few places you can do much more than that.
Mudaliarkuppam is one of them. To any north Indian the word is more or less like a tongue twister.

I knew that I won‚Äôt be able to pronounce it correctly and on enquiring about direction from local people I will end up in getting a strange weird look from them as if I am mentally retarded and My IQ level is so low that I can‚Äôt pronounce simple words correctly.
It has been a frustrating experience to keep on repeating the same word again and again and still it doesn't rings a bell to people.
So this time I acted smart and had it googled and Wikipedia page was open so that I can simply flash out my mobile and avoid ignominy.

There are low Floor Buses to Pondicherry plying on the ECR road all the time. I boarded one of them from ECR road. On asking for ticket to Mudaliarkuppam conductor asked driver to stop the bus and asked me to get down and take some other bus. He informed bus won‚Äôt
stop at Mudaliarkuppam. On pleading he finally agreed to get me to the nearest stop to Mudaliarkuppam which will be kalpakkam.

Boarded another bus at kalpakkam which was seriously overcrowded and I was again informed that the bus won‚Äôt stop at Mudaliarkuppam but three KM ahead at Odiyur and I have to take an auto and come back again . I seriously don‚Äôt understand why the government department managing Buses on highway want‚Äôs people to take that much of pain. Why there is no stop near a tourist hotspot.
Mudaliarkuppam is also known as Boat house.
After travelling for 3 hour in scorching heat I was so hungry that I was even ready to eat idly but nothing was available. Yes
column2: there is not a single restaurant in vicinity. The nearest one is a good 2 KM away. So there was no point in contemplating about it.

column1: There is this vast expense of water which is known as Odiyur Lake. This lake is formed by backwater which was brimming with activity. Gull-billed terns flying and hitting water with accuracy and fetching fishes. Local villagers were spreading net in water.it was 3:30 and boat house closes by
Checked the rate list of activities guess what 5 minutes of water scooter for 600 Rs.

column2: you at least need 15 minutes to get a feel of it and good 1 hour to actually experience it but that can cost you 7200.For that money you can actually buy a water scooter on EMI and enjoy i.e. wonder why they have been priced so steep the plausible reason I can think of is ‚Äúto discourage people from hiring scooter for 1 hour because in 1 hour is good enough to run off with the scooter‚Äù.

column1: I always wanted to experience kayaking primarily because it‚Äôs thrilling and secondary because it‚Äôs physically very demanding. I was told that not carry anything as everything will get wet. I though paddling might splash some water but to my horror when I sat in kayak water filled in from the holes in the kayak and it was an awkward situation.
Honestly I have never done kayaking before. My understanding of kayak was a small boat but the case was not so.
Kayak has got holes at the bottom from which some water will rush in once
So basically you will be paddling all wet hence you need extra pair of clothes. Since it‚Äôs a strenuous job
You need to have some water which you can sip and a cap would be great.

column2: I took my kayak in water went for 500 meters and came back.it was serious fun and I thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience. I knew by now that I will be coming to this place quite often for kayaking.

column1: After coming back I saw two families going for motor boat and this was an opportunity to tag along. So on requesting they agreed but the six seater motor boat had no seat vacant for me ‚Äúwe are already six‚Äù
column2: ‚Äúwhere you will sit‚Äù . Deck was the only place I can fit in. It was tough managing there on deck of the boat as there was nothing to latch on to when the boat hit water it was very difficult at times I seriously felt that I might fall in water. I think I was lucky that I survived
column3: won‚Äôt do it again.

column1: I managed to get some beautiful sunset pics

and decided to call it a day. I was informed that the nearest restaurant is 2 km away on ECR road in Chennai direction. Decide to walk down to the place to get a feel of the activity going nearby. Saw a guy in full gear going to coconut tree. Lush green rice farm with aroma in air was very soothing to eyes.
I was walking on the highway at my own leisurely pace taking pics
column2: I heard somebody shouting ‚Äúhey brother‚Äù .I looked back and saw a guy on a bike asking me to take a ride. This was very touching I mean somebody offering lift without even being asked for. I was overwhelmed with emotions and was thinking what a noble soul and how thoughtful. These are the people who are keeping humanity alive.

column1: The guy came close and stopped the bike and asked me to hop on. I was in almost in tears filled with bromance till I could clearly smell the foul odor of wine. The guy was clearly on high and in that state he was driving on highway stopping at will to get killed. But now he was standing close and almost

shouting to sit on his bike. Now the truth dawned on me why he was so eager to give me a ride. The only time my friends would call to enquire whether I have reached home safely was when they were totally drunk.
Such is the effect of this nectar of heaven that it can turn any Stanger in to an ambassador of humanity.
Just imagine the consequence if US government sponsors alcohol party on india-pak border therw will be no border at all.

Not sure why but I couldn‚Äôt say anything and sat on the bike and after that this guy dropped me on an eating joint. Had some bhajji and tea. Again got a lift from a biker who dropped me in middle of nowhere on road and went to a village I couldn‚Äôt see any light in any direction it was like no man‚Äôs land.

There was no sign of civilization. Confession: - I was very frightened. The problem is that buses will only stop at their designated stop. Finally a got lucky when a biker stopped by but this ride was like a nightmare. I am not sure if he was on

drugs or what. This guy had only thing in mind to overtake anything and everything. He had a 100 cc hero bike but he was straining it to the brink and overtaking suv on the highway. It was very dark and visibility was less
column2: single lane road and this guy hell bent on getting me killed. I could see an eminent death at any second. The thought that since I was riding pillion so I might survive as in most of the accidents the pillion rider only receives injuries but then few years back a friend of mine who was riding pillion died in a bike accident. I could see his face and it seemed like that now the time has come to meet him .I was totally hopeless and praying god to save my life and excuse me for all the mistakes. I mean it will be too soon still want to live another decade at least. Then suddenly the grunt of the bike died and it stopped .the engine died and the bike won‚Äôt start. The guy came to me and said ‚Äúsorry bro‚Äù and I was happy
column3: relieved and said ‚Äúthank you‚Äù .Guess what my faith

column1: in god has emboldened. I could see sign of human civilization here. Soon got an auto and reached kalpakam which is famous for atomic energy research. It‚Äôs a small town and has got few good restaurant had dinner here and took bus for Chennai from here.

column2: Displayed: 27

column1: Will the mist ever clear to give us a decent view of the Nilgiri Hills? We set off optimistic as ever
column2: this time to a couple of viewpoints a few kilometres out of Coonoor. First up is Lamb‚Äôs Rock. Mr Hussain enters into heated discussion with a man lurking at the entrance then tells us he will show us round for 100 rupees. On the basis that Mr Hussain usually warns us off guides
column3: we agree. It‚Äôs billed as a trek but in fact consists of a round trip of just a kilometre. As ever
column4: the view into the valleys is shrouded in mist
column5: but the guide does show us lemon grass growing wild. He points out a village that has appeared in the valley a couple of thousand feet below us. ‚ÄúTribal people live down there‚Äù he says disdainfully. ‚ÄúAre you Adivsasi?‚Äù asks David. ‚ÄúNo no no‚Äù he says quickly. ‚ÄúI am a proper Indian‚Äù. He may be a Dalit
column6: but he is not a tribal
column7: tribals being considered the lowest of the low in Indian society.

column1: The next viewpoint has even less of a view
column2: though we are still extorted 20 rupees by an attendant for turning up.

you can tell in one glance that they are not Tamils. However by now the mist is lifting and the scenery as we drive along is beautiful. You can see why the British liked to escape up here in the summer. We wend our way through tea estates
column3: with bright green bushes all trimmed to a regulation height of about three feet
column4: and tiny tracks
column5: almost too narrow to count as a path
column6: winding between the rows of bushes. The tea fields are planted at intervals with a particular type of oak tree that collects rainwater and then releases it into the ground from its roots to moisten the roots of the tea plants
column7: as well as providing shade from the fierce sun. It is early enough in the morning for there to be few other tourists
column8: and we relish the quiet beauty of the place.

column2: we drive through the smart end of town
column3: where old Edwardian bungalows with names such as ‚ÄòFaraway‚Äô or ‚ÄòGlendower‚Äô mingle with large new houses of considerable affluence. Here and there the hillside is being ripped out in big red streaked terraces to make space for

column1: Cutting the tea inot tea dust
a new house. Next stop is Sim's Park
column2: another botanical garden
column3: established during the Raj
column4: by one of Our Chaps
column5: of course. It‚Äôs smaller but better maintained than the one in Ooty and has far fewer visitors. It is peaceful until we near the tiny lake where people have rented pedalos. They make a shrieking creaking noise with every turn of the pedal
column6: drowning out the birds. We amble slowly up and down the hillside. At one point there is an unbelievably strong smell of citronella
column7: but our botanical knowledge does not extend to working out which tree it is coming from.

column2: we head to Highfield tea estate. This was the first tea factory in the Nilgiris
column3: originally owned by the British but sold to an Indian company in 1974. The estate has 300 acres
column4: and employs 300 people
column5: 250 picking tea and 50 in the factory. We learn that the bushes are harvested every 15 days in peak season
column6: but less at this time of year when many of the bushes have suffered some frost damage which means then leaves then burn in the sun. We are shown round the factory. The bright green tea leaves initially

column1: go onto big drying beds where air is pumped up form below for 10 hours to dry them. From there they go to the cutting room. The high quality tea is cut
column2: and the cheaper stuff (which uses the bigger leaves) goes through a series of cutters and rollers to reduce it to dust. The leaves/dust are then soaked in water
column3: dried again
column4: oxidised
column5: and finally roasted. Once roasted
column6: they pass over a series of filters
column7: to separate the different sizes of leaf/dust
column8: and then bagged up. The factory is not big
column9: but it produces 2¬Ω tons of tea a day. The smell of tea is almost overwhelming as you walk through
column10: quite intoxicating.

column1: The tour is free but the quid pro quo is that you are invited to visit the shop afterwards. That is not a hardship
column2: as most of what‚Äôs on sale ‚Äì tea
column3: spices
column4: essential oils ‚Äì is very cheap compared to home. No holiday would be complete without something slightly inconvenient to fit into the luggage
column5: after all! We do
column6: however
column7: steer clear of the essential oils
column8: fearful of the risk of leakage in transit. Nobody wants a suitcase full of clothes reeking of eucalyptus

column2: the hotel garden makes a pleasant place to sit out for the afternoon. The sun is shining
column3: the birds flit in and out of the garden
column4: and David starts to reminisce as he hears the tooting of the steam engine bringing the afternoon train from Mettapullayam into Coonoor station in the valley far below. The sun begins to drop and the mist starts to blanket the Nilgiris again.

column1: The peace is suddenly disturbed by the arrival of two macaque monkeys
column2: attracted by the open bag of nuts being consumed by two Englishwomen sitting at a nearby table. Initially the monkeys limit themselves to threatening calls
column3: and are scared off by the hotel staff throwing stones at them. But gradually they get bolder and shimmy down a water pipe to seize the bag of nuts and a handbag. Fortunately they drop the bag but the nuts are speedily consumed. Thus emboldened
column4: they raid the nearby waste bin which contains the remains of our lunch
column5: and speed off clutching a red plastic bag. The Englishwomen are shocked
column6: to say the least
column7: having not realised how aggressive and thieving macaques are.

column2: only to be disturbed by a thunderclap noise like a firework going off. We peer outside to try to work out the source f the noise
column3: only to smell cordite. One of the hotel staff has been taking pot shots at the monkeys after our neighbours complained. Nobody knows if he got one.

column1: Everton are playing Arsenal so we order room service and eat grimacing in front of the TV.
Another totally awesome experience. From Ooty we travelled by car through more winding roads and 36 hairpin turns on the decent to Mudumalai
column2: which is still in the Nilgiris
column3: but at a much lower elevation. We had booked a one night stay at Forest Hills Farm and Guest House
column4: located of the edge of the sanctuary. Well were greeted at the gate by the owner Savita and her son Sameer. We felt like we were old friends returning after a long absence. Shortly after arrival they arranged a driver and jeep to take us on safari. He took us around the boundary of the park
column5: then into the sanctuary where we boarded a bus to go deeper into the forest. We didn't see any tigers
column6: but we did see a large herd of gaur (Indian bison)
column7: chitral (a type of deer)
column8: languars and macaques (monkeys) and malibar giant squirrels.Following the bus tour
column9: we were taken to the elephant camp where we observed food preparation and feeding of some very large tuskers We then had another ride in the jeep for another spin around the perimiter of the park at dusk
column10: when the animals are on the move. Here we spotted a herd

column1: of wild elephants. So wonderful to see them free and moving around in the forest untethered.

column2: we were treated to a scrumptious dinner
column3: lovingly prepared by our host. We spent a wonderful night in the compound a little away from the main building. It was great to be out there because we could here the calls and movements of the wild animals in the night. All in all this was a fantastic experience
column4: so much so
column5: that we changed our plans and stayed an extra night! This is one place I would go back to in a heart beat.

column2: Displayed: 22

column1: Pictures of the toy train between Mettupalayam and Ooty.

column2: Displayed: 11

column1: We travelled hrs by car from Kodaikanal to Mettupalayum
column2: the starting point for the ""toy train"". This was only an overnight stop
column3: as there is nothing there. Had an early night as we had to be up at 3:30 AM to line up for tickets for the train. We had tried to make reservations two weeks before
column4: but all reserved seats were sold
column5: so we had to line up for two of the 25 standby seats. We were lucky we got there when we did
column6: because some of the people that came behind us didn't get on. It was a very pleasant 5 hour journey up hill all the way to Ooty. The toy train is a small gauge train that was built by the British in the early 1900's to transport people out of the heat of the plains to the coolness of the hill stations. It is pulled (or rather pushed) by a small
column7: specially built steam engine. The total distance from Mettupalayam to Ooty is only 47km
column8: but takes a long time because of the steep grade
column9: and the stops along the way for water for the steam engine. It was very scenic and very enjoyable.

column1: We spent a few days exploring the highlights of Ooty. Took a trip up to Dodabetta
column2: at 2638 meters it is the second highest peak in the western Ghatts
column3: and did a day trip to Coonoor to visit some of the mountain attractions there.

column1: Have a bad internet connection so can't load photos
column2: will put them with the next entry.
after a lovely (sometimes scary) ride through the beautiful hills of Kerala and Tamil Nadu. We hired a car to take us from Munnar to Kodaikanal. A little bit of a splurge
column3: but the alternative was to take an 11 hour bus ride through all the hairpin turns on a very basic
column4: uncomfortable bus. So
column5: the car ride was wonderful; we were able to interact with the driver and he pointed out spots of interest and made stops along the way so we could take photos of the beautiful scenery.

column1: As we pulled up to the hotel
column2: we were stalled by a procession or small parade going by. I have seen documentaries of the things we saw
column3: very interesting. Along with drummers at the front and back of the procession
column4: and many people carrying ceramic bowl of fire there were two men and one women with arrows pierced through both cheeks
column5: and hooks pierced into their backs. Attached to the hooks were ropes and each was pulling a small cart. Another unusual
column6: unexpected event.

column1: Yesterday we went for a walk to the next village
column2: about 6 km (down hill!) through beautiful forest and along

column1: from a hike in the hills
scenic ridges. This is really a very beautiful area of India. We took a taxi back up to the top
column2: no way were we walking back up
column3: very steep.

column1: Today we are moving on to Mettupalayam
column2: not much to see there
column3: but we hope to catch the ""toytrain"" in the morning
column4: so will only over night there.

column2: so don't know if you are all getting the blogs
column3: hope you are. Not much time left here now
column4: so will see you all soon.

column1: Indian hill stations are not what we expected. We had a romanticised mental picture of English style buildings dating back to the Raj
column2: clinging to the hillside in small towns. Well
column3: the houses cling to the hillside all right
column4: but traces of the Raj are few and far between. Coonoor and Ooty are both surprisingly large towns
column5: and the 17km drive between them has few stretches that are not also settled. The houses are brightly coloured boxes of different sizes and shapes
column6: almost filling large sections of the hillside
column7: but often leaving space for a few cultivated terraces in between them. One settlement is
column8: bizarrely
column9: a massive billboard
column10: with dozens of identical homes all painted bright yellow and emblazoned with the logo of a cement company. We are nonplussed to drive past a needle factory ‚Äì why would you site factory here
column11: of all places? At least the finished product is small and therefore easy to transport
column12: I suppose.

column1: The weather forecast for the next two days is not good. It suggests it will rain from lunchtime onwards
column2: and that the cloud and mist will be more or less continuous. We consider getting up early to make the most of

but opt to lie in instead and set off at 9am. But it is sunny as we climb up to Ooty and there is more of a view than we had yesterday. Not that you can take a good photo ‚Äì it‚Äôs not practical to ask Mr Hussain to stop the car
column3: given the narrow road
column4: endless bends and continuous traffic
column5: and most of the shots we take form the moving car feature concrete barriers
column6: trees
column7: electricity cables and other obstructions to the view.

column2: in fact outside the town. Doddabetta Peak is billed as having great views over the town
column3: and the guidebook says you can walk to the top of the peak. David is pleased he has had the foresight to bring his trekking poles
column4: anticipating a stiff climb to the peak. But this is India
column5: and local tourists don‚Äôt expect to have to walk that far. We drive to the top of the peak
column6: and leave Mr Hussain to find a parking space in a heaving car park. A two minute walk gets us to the ticket office
column7: where the fee is a modest 5 rupees per person and

column1: 10 per camera. There is a small paved area
column2: with a coffee shop and some stalls selling herbal remedies
column3: and an incongruous children‚Äôs playground. It takes less than 30 seconds to reach the ‚Äòpeak‚Äô. In fact
column4: we are grateful there is not far to walk. The peak is at 2600 metres elevation and we are both gasping and headachy in the thin air. It is mercifully sunny
column5: which means that Sara‚Äôs failure to put the sweaters in the bag does not matter as it‚Äôs a very pleasant temperature. Many of our fellow tourists clearly do not feel the same way
column6: and are sporting woolly hats that do up under the chin and even
column7: in one case
column8: a hotel towel draped over the shoulders.

column1: Next stop is the botanical gardens
column2: created in 1847 by the Marquis of Tweesdale who brought in a botanist from Kew
column3: Mr McIver
column4: to lay the place out. We spend a pleasant hour walking ‚Äì slowly ‚Äì through the gardens. This is much more what we had expected. The trees are mostly not labelled
column5: but the crowds thin out once we walk more than 5 minutes
column6: and it then becomes a very peaceful place. The book

column1: tells us the must-see highlight is the fern house
column2: modelled on Kew. Well
column3: maybe
column4: but it is on an altogether smaller scale
column5: more like a biggish greenhouse
column6: and lacks any of the giant varieties that we enjoy when we go to Kew.

column2: and we see the toy train pulling in to the station just as we drive past. We originally planned to take the train up to Ooty
column3: but then realised that a) you cannot pre-book
column4: and need to queue up at 5am on the day to buy a ticket
column5: b) the gradient to Ooty is too steep for the steam engines
column6: so they use a diesel engine instead ‚Äì much less fun and c) it‚Äôs very useful to have the car once in Ooty. We stop to take photos. The engine seems already to have been de-coupled by the time we make it to the platform
column7: but Sara points out the loco shed and suggests we visit. ‚ÄòHow do we get there?‚Äô asks David. ‚ÄòWalk along the tracks like you see everyone doing at all Indian stations‚Äô replies Sara. So we do
column8: and get a warm welcome from the engineers hard at work in the

column1: shed. Three of them are in the pit
column2: replacing a wheel
column3: covered in engine oil. Sara
column4: trouser legs rolled up to keep them clear of the oil and grime that covers the floor
column5: locates the only remaining coal-fired steam engine
column6: much to David‚Äôs excitement. It will come as no surprise to learn that we take far too many photos. David has not been in a working steam shed since about 1965.......

column1: Back to the hotel for a late lunch in the garden outside our room. Our timing has been perfect. We hear the roll of thunder soon after we sit down
column2: and the rain starts half an hour later. For a while
column3: we stay outside
column4: sheltered by the table umbrella ‚Äì as we are British a bit of rain is no impediment - but eventually it gets cold and we retire to our room.

column1: chaos on the road to Coonoor
Another cold morning and we are up early in Kodaikanal
column2: ready to set off to Coonoor
column3: a long drive in prospect. The previous evening we have had a club sandwich
column4: unable to face another Indian meal after the burningly spiced thali served to us for lunch. Seems like chef had not served a club sandwich before. He had not done badly
column5: but had not toasted the bread. He appeared at our table
column6: head wobbling from side to side in excited expectancy. ‚ÄúHow was club sandwich flavour good?‚Äù he asks. Such a sweet man
column7: we just reply ‚Äúyes
column8: delicious
column9: very nice‚Äù
column10: and off he goes beaming with pride after first taking our photo.

column1: Off we go from Kodaikanal. We trek along the side of the Ghats
column2: uphill and downhill. The road surface is awful
column3: potholes with the occasional bit of tarmac. The mist boils up over the edge of the roadway
column4: driven by the warmer air in the valley below. At times there is a break in the mist and one can see the hillside plunging precipitately towards the valley floor below. Sometimes the drop is apparently 3000 or 4000ft. Some of the road side barriers could be a little better

column1: indeed in some places it would be nice if there were any at all.
Eventually the road plunges down a series of 14 numbered hairpins to the plains below. The temperature rises sharply. We drive through vast expanses of coconut groves
column2: sometimes with banana plants interspersed. Sugar cane
column3: rice and mangoes are also seen growing here. We see signs warning of ‚Äúelephants crossing‚Äù but sadly see none. Along the roadside are clusters of huts made from palm leaves and woven palm matting that we surmise must be the houses of the plantation workers. Eventually the land becomes less fertile and we proceed through more scrubby countryside.

column1: Everywhere we have been in Tamil Nadu
column2: every other billboard and wall has been plastered by posters featuring a lady Tamil Nadu politician. There roads are no exception. We assume there is a state election pending. We have taken a hearty dislike to the smug overweight woman and her gang of cronies
column3: some 30 or so of whom are pictured alongside her. They all look shifty or dishonest or smug. No idea who they are but we don‚Äôt like them. The only other people who seem to be campaigning are the communist

column1: party of India. The red hammer and sickle makes a nice change when we see their flags flying.

We pass for mile upon mile through an endless landscape of wind turbines covering much less fertile farmland. David begins to mutter about the economic illiteracy of building and operating these monstrosities
column2: and that they are probably built with EU grant money and/or British foreign aid. Humph humph he goes. Eventually they peter out and we witness a bizarre sight in a village where we stop to ask for directions. As the driver is speaking to one of the locals
column3: three men
column4: clad in yellow
column5: walk past. One of them is carrying something that is shaped like a tuba but is not a musical instrument. It is emitting smoke from the open end
column6: the second man is banging the hell out of a big drum he is carrying
column7: and the third is chanting. No idea what that was about....religious observance?

column1: We spend an age crossing the grim city of Coimbatore before taking the road up to Coonoor. The traffic thickens immediately on the narrow road
column2: in both directions. Insanity on the road is displayed by many drivers. We

column1: what happens when you ignore the drive safely signs

know it is dangerous as Mr Hussain is keeping his seat belt on (like most Indian drivers he only wears it when he sees a policeman up ahead). We see three crashes in about ten miles. The rain is coming down. The town when we arrive in a chaotic mess......and then up a hillside road
column2: adjacent to All Saints Church
column3: an Anglican church that could be in England except that it is painted yellow
column4: we arrive at the oasis of calm that is the Gateway Hotel. Originally called the Hampton Manor it was built around 1857. It went through ownership by various colourful characters until it was eventually turned into a hotel. It retains the quirky charm you would expect of such a place
column5: with the reassuring hand of the Taj group to now keeping it running smoothly.

column2: Displayed: 5

column1: The non view from Coaker's walk
The downside of sleeping in a tent ‚Äì even one with a heater- becomes rapidly clear. It is very cold and the bathroom
column2: lacking any heating
column3: is positively freezing. We sleep exceedingly badly. In part
column4: this is due to the altitude. It comes back to us how badly we used to sleep on the first night skiing in Colorado. In part
column5: it is due to the chicken Chettinad we ate at dinner
column6: which burns its way slowly through our guts. Both of us fear that after 2 weeks away
column7: our luck has run out and we are about to get ill
column8: but mercifully this turns out not to be the case. The animals don‚Äôt help either. All night dogs can be heard barking furiously
column9: as if repelling invaders or lining up in pitched battle. When they fall into an exhausted slumber
column10: the cockerel and the pigeons start up. By 7am we admit further sleep is impossible.

column1: As it is far too cold to consider showering
column2: we dress and go to breakfast. This does not go well. We ask for filter coffee. Two cups of white coffee arrive
column3: so Sara asks for a black cup. It eventually arrives
column4: complete with

column1: a jug of hot milk. Meanwhile
column2: we had ordered eggs and toast. The toast and Sara‚Äôs omelette arrive fairly quickly
column3: but David‚Äôs boiled eggs will
column4: we are told
column5: take 15 minutes. Well
column6: we say to ourselves
column7: it does take longer to boil an egg at altitude. 15 minutes pass. ‚ÄòJust 15 minutes more
column8: sir‚Äô. It‚Äôs like the old joke about London buses ‚Äì you wait 30 minutes then three arrive all at once. In this case
column9: shelled and sitting in a bowl of hot water.

column2: the manager appears to tell us that there is a problem with our car. Apparently it would not start this morning. He tells us this because the diesel has frozen in the cold. Even Sara
column3: with her limited knowledge of the workings of the internal combustion engine
column4: knows that this sounds implausible. In any event
column5: our 9am start is pushed back to 10.30. We enjoy the only sun of the day and sit in the garden
column6: both feeling a little under par. At 10.30 we find Mr Hussain fitting a new battery into the car. Seemingly this is not the only problem
column7: but the car will at least start

column1: David enjoying the views of the lake
so he drives us to the start of Croker‚Äôs Walk and says he will pick us up in an hour. We had understood this to be a walk of about an hour
column2: offering stunning views of the valley below. The first and most evident problem is that the valley is filled with mist
column3: which swirls up and across the path. There is no view whatsoever. The second snag is that the walk turns out to take under 15 minutes. Even allowing for walking back slowly
column4: inspecting all the stalls strung out along the route
column5: we face a long wait for Mr Hussain. The stalls cater for every eventuality. You can buy cold drinks
column6: ice cream (are you feeling lucky
column7: punk?) or
column8: strangely
column9: carrots with their greenery still attached. These seem to be the choice of the day judging by the number of people who pass us munching on a carrot. You can get a cushion (why??)
column10: new pair of sandals
column11: an umbrella in case it rains
column12: or a sweater/jacket. The latter are clearly second hand. We are reminded of a trip years ago to Vietnam when our guide told us that distributors bought large consignments of clothes that charity shops could not sell (or else that were fraudulently obtained from door to door collections) then sold them on at a profit in Asia. This looks similar. You can also get your photo taken for 50 rupees. David toys with the ideal of offering to do it for 40 rupees until Sara points out he has no way of printing the photos. Mercifully Mr Hussain reappears early. The car is still not full fixed
column13: so he drops us by the lake and says he will pick us up in an hour. The lake is billed as the most scenic spot in town. Really? The most interesting aspect of our walk is peering in at the huge
column14: expensive villas that line the lake shore
column15: many with heavy security.

column2: but after lunch we opt to go on the valley tour drive. First stop is a ‚Äòwalk‚Äô in the woods. A few vendors are packing up their wares
column3: harassed at every step by a group of aggressive macaque monkeys. We set forth into the wood
column4: which is in fact a forestry department plantation of tall
column5: spindly uninteresting trees. Judging by our fellow visitors
column6: the walk consists of going 50 yards into the wood
column7: taking photos of each other and leaving. We follow their lead
column8: minus the photos. After this
column9: the drive descends into farce. The mist thickens until we can barely see the road ahead. The temperature drops ten degrees and there is a touch of rain in the mist. The highlights of the drive are a series of viewpoints
column10: none of which is visible. By the time we have finished
column11: even Mr Hussain is laughing along with us.

column1: There is nothing else to visit
column2: and it is really rather chilly to sit in the garden. We retreat to our tent and turn the heater on. Every long trip has one bad day
column3: and hopefully this is it for this trip.

column1: Kodaikanal clings to the hillside high in the Western Ghats. Once a colonial hill station
column2: it now sprouts an ever growing spread of modern buildings ‚Äì houses
column3: hotels and shops. But there is still charm and beauty to be found.

column1: Kodaikanal marks the start of the second half of our holiday. The first half was the sea
column2: heat and temples
column3: the second will be cooler with hills
column4: plantations and animals. The journey from Madurai takes three hours
column5: with the best road of the holiday so far giving way to narrow winding roads as we make our way up into the hills. Our average speed drops to 30kph. Mr Hussain ignores the many signs exhorting drivers not to overtake on the bend
column6: which is probably just as well since there is no bend free section for 80 kilometres. Added to the consequent hazard of finding a vehicle coming in the other direction (mitigated by low speed and copious use of the horn) is the risk of not slowing down in time to avoid the sections where a landslide has caused one side of the road to drop off down the cliff. The arid landscape of the plain is replaced by thin

column2: with an occasional spectacular view over two or more ranges of hazy hills. We wind endlessly upwards
column3: with no obvious sense of direction
column4: passing numerous Catholic and Lutheran foundations
column5: including a Carmelite monastery.

column1: Kodaikanal was ‚Äúdiscovered‚Äù in 1821 by one of our Plucky Chaps called Lt. Ward who was looking for somewhere for the colonial administrators and foreign missionaries in Madurai to spend the summer
column2: as they were dropping like flies from the heat and pestilence if they stay down in the plains. Once in town
column3: we face the usual challenge of finding our hotel. It is small and nobody seems to have heard of it. But eventually we find a discreet sign next to a closed gate. We‚Äôve arrived. The Fern Creek is a charming
column4: quiet place in the most literal sense of the word. Slightly out of town
column5: it has just seven tented rooms scattered about a peaceful hillside garden. We are invited into the main building to check in and offered tea. This turns out to be exceedingly strong
column6: with milk ‚Äì not exactly how either of us likes it. We sip tentatively under the steady attentive gaze of three staff members standing

column1: to attention. Either they are incredibly attentive or Europeans are something of a rarity. We suggest going to our room. ‚ÄòNo
column2: no
column3: you drink tea first‚Äô. It is hot and we swallow hard. Sara spills half of hers. We are both desperately suppressing our giggles by now. Eventually we are led off down a path through the garden which culminates in the honeymoon suite (or tent). We enter. It is sepulchrally dark and stiflingly hot
column4: which seems odd as Kodaikanal is at nearly 2000 meters and is a lot cooler as a result. Then we realise the gas fire is turned on. Our host seems surprised when we turn it off. Darkness apart
column5: the room/tent is spacious and comfortable and the bathroom actually looks more modern than the previous hotel. It has curtains draped from the ridge of the tent
column6: and a bed with four posts but nothing attached to them.

column1: Lunch is speedily cooked for us. The waiter (who is probably also the cook) hovers over us
column2: feeling it his duty not to let us ever serve ourselves. As ever
column3: we are offered more of everything
column4: despite the first serving having been generous.

column2: and are presented with a list of places which seem to be grouped into small tours. We decide to opt for the ‚Äòtrekking tour‚Äô and ask them to give Mr Hussain directions. The journey is an interesting one as none of us have a clue where we are going. The road gets narrower and narrower. At one point it is being repaired
column3: and the gap that is left looks to be roughly half the width of our Innova. But with the miraculous ‚Äòmake me smaller‚Äô button that all Indian vehicles seem to be equipped with
column4: we get round it somehow. Sara is grateful that she is sitting in the car on the inside of the bend and not the side with the sheer drop. Eventually
column5: we draw up alongside some stalls selling soft drinks. ‚ÄòWalk there‚Äô gestures Mr Hussain. Having read that the walk to the Dolphin Nose rock is a steep 1km
column6: and David‚Äôs ankle being unstable
column7: we have brought out our walking poles. The first people we pass are two backpackers
column8: wearing shorts and T-shirts
column9: heavily tattooed and with nose rings. We
column10: by contrast
column11: are sporting trekking trousers
column12: long sleeved shirts
column13: hats and walking

column2: with rucksack (Hannah and James will recognise our stylish appearance). Probably being stoned they at least have the grace not to laugh at us
column3: which is more than can be said for the majority of the Indians we meet on our walk. Some smirk
column4: others burst into outright laughter
column5: pointing as they do so. But we are infused with the spirit of John Bull and the Raj so we don‚Äôt care. Besides
column6: the path is not only steep but treacherous
column7: with sections of rock outcrops and others thick with gnarled tree roots
column8: and we are grateful for the poles as we pick our way cautiously down. The path is littered with discarded snack packets and broken and discarded chappals
column9: probably the stupidest footwear to have on your feet on this path. At one point we have to stand aside to let a dozen or more donkeys past. They are all laden down with bags of cement
column10: but move much faster and more sure footedly than we do. The walk is not quite the commune with nature we were expecting
column11: as there is a makeshift stall selling soft drinks every hundred yards. Since we only meet about six other tourists

column2: it‚Äôs hard to see how any of these stalls make money. As we pass one of these stalls
column3: a woman emerges and shrieks with laughter. We turn around and she is mimicking a person walking with poles
column4: swinging her arms back and forth and lumbering her body from side to side and puffing for breath. Actually very amusing but most disrespectful of the former rulers of the Empire.

column1: We reach the Dolphin's Nose. A rocky outcrop with a drop of about 2000m down to the valley floor below. The walk is worth it
column2: as we are rewarded with sweeping views of the hills at the end. Then it is time to retrace our steps
column3: this time uphill ‚Äì harder work on the lungs but easier walking. There is low growling coming from somewhere. Are we about to meet a leopard? Alas no
column4: it is just a troop of macaques in the trees
column5: clearly warning the interlopers passing through their patch. We pass a stall we had noticed before that has a sign saying 'Shalom' and 'kosher food'. Hippies in India these days all seem to be Israelis (why?) and they have clearly made it to Kodaikanal.

column1: Why are they laughing at me
We return to the hotel where we are immediately offered more tea. We accept gracefully and adjourn to our tent. Having opened the ‚Äòwindows‚Äô to let some light in
column2: it now feels distinctly cool
column3: so we close up the flaps and turn the fire back on. Tea arrives. There is a flask
column4: with cups
column5: teabags
column6: sugar and slices of lime. Sara puts a teabag into a cup and starts to pour
column7: only to find the flask contains tea not hot water. What
column8: then
column9: are the tea bags for? We sit on our tiny balcony and read. The sound of the birds is pleasingly louder than that the faint murmur of distant vehicles
column10: punctuated only by the sound of things dropping off the trees and landing on our awning. The smell of wood smoke suffuses the air. Soon the light will go and we‚Äôll need to move inside. We are glad that we brought a pair of clip-on reading lamps
column11: as we‚Äôll need them tonight.

column1: A young man appears five minutes later to ask if we want anything. We cannot think of anything but then he asks if we would like some French fries and coffee? Not what we were wanting until he mentioned it but yes please! So we scoff that down at about 6pm. Not exactly high tea
column2: but perfect as we sit in front of the gas fire in the gloom.
Thirupparankundram temple

column1: It is the perfect temperature at about 7am when we breakfast but unfortunately it does not stay like that for long. The restaurant manager tells us that summer has arrived early this year. This seems to happen every year we go to India....

The sweepers (who all belong to one of the lowest castes) are busy around the hotel going about their endless task of sweeping dead leaves from one place to another. The keeper of the little Shiva shrine has already put the idol's new clothes on for the day and given him a new garland.
As we drive out of the hotel we see a 40 seater coach about to load up its English tour party and take them off to their next destination. Never in one place long enough to see anything properly
column2: no control over where you go or how long you spend anywhere and enforced visits to the ‚Äòcraft workshops‚Äô where the tour guide gets a special commission. And apparently a requirement for the men all to wear non-branded polo shirts tucked into too short shorts and belted tightly
column3: with black socks and sandals. A ghastly way to go on holiday.

column2: if you want to save 50 rupees

column1: off in due course to visit the Thirupparankundram Murugan Temple

column3: offering to the gods

column6: we pay our 50 rupees and join the express

column1: We leave the temple and for some reason forego the opportunity to walk to the top of the baking bare hill behind the temple to visit a small Muslim shrine. Even serious site viewers have their limits.
Unfortunately now David needs a wee. We have smelt the only place in town on the way to the temple. ‚ÄúYou can do it‚Äù
column2: Sara assures him. David approaches with trepidation (at times like this I envy James' ability to go ten hours without needing a toilet). I bind my cotton scarf twice around my mouth and nose. The stench rises like a miasma from hell. The urinal has tiled walls about three

column1: feet high. There is one step in
column2: then another tiled step where you have to take up position to do the needful. The upper step is covered in filthy rag rugs soaked in piss. Oh Lord please do not allow me to slip over. Holding my breath I get on with it. Please do not allow my sunglasses to fall off my face or they will be lost for all eternity. I try not to look at the urinal
column3: or at the fetid green yellow stuff at the bottom of it. Oh no
column4: the sink hole is blocked! Fortunately I am finished. Now I find my flip flops are sticking to the matting. What if they come off my feet?? I curl my toes to grasp the sandals and step back into thin air to step down. Footwear stays on and I do not stumble. I stagger out and gratefully suck in a lungful of delicious diesel fume laden dusty air. I have survived! Sara congratulates me and declines to use the ladies' equivalent.

column5: we are going to leave two cameras worth about four grand hanging out of that locker. So back to the car to find Mr Hussain who quite reasonably has gone off for some tea. Oh dear. column1: After about half an hour we go back to the car

column1: In search of the perfect picture
luck. Further into the temple is a Nandi shrine surrounded by more beautifully carved columns and the temple tree ‚Äì this one of solid gold

column3: only Hindus can enter. In many parts of India 50 rupees to the Brahmin doorkeeper would get you 5 minutes of temporary conversion to Hinduism allowing you to enter
column4: but not in Tamil Nadu
column5: they are serious about their shrines here.

column1: There is a 50 meter square tank
column2: the Golden Lotus Pond
column3: within the temple precincts. In ancient times
column4: the sangam
column5: an assembly of Tamil poets

column2: which by now has heated up in the sun to well over 40 degrees. We crawl through the traffic to the Thirumalai Nayak palace which

column2: it‚Äôs back to the Toyota and time to drive to Madurai. The first hour of the journey is through open countryside and is as restful as any road in India can be. Small sights stick in the mind: the little girl

column1: bowling a lorry tyre along with a stick
column2: the scarecrow incongruously pinned to the wall of a part-built house (why?)
column3: the farmer with his goats disappearing out of view down a trail between two lines of trees
column4: the occasional peasant indulging in what in India is referred to as ‚Äúopen defecation‚Äù at the roadside. The countryside is arid and we pass a number of dried up paddy fields that have gone to ruin. The monsoon has failed for three consecutive years round here
column5: putting huge pressure on the farmers and causing rice prices to shoot up. There are lines of palm trees with tall trunks and leaves that form the shape of a small ball at the top
column6: looking like giant allium plants. We go through small villages where the road is lined by tiny shacks selling food and drink or offering bicycle and motorbike repairs. The landscape is flat
column7: but every now and then is broken up by large sandstone outcrops. Many of these are being quarried
column8: and resemble big Swiss rolls being cut up slice by slice. Huge slabs of rock
column9: a couple of metres on each side
column10: lie piled up in rows along the roadside. It feels

column1: like a very graphic illustration of the fact that natural resources
column2: once used
column3: cannot be replaced.

column1: Gradually the countryside gives way to little box like houses as we approach Madurai. Mr Hussain‚Äôs determination to check our route requires exceptional determination when driving along a double carriageway with no passers by. He winds down his window

column3: and the passing vehicle does the same in order to help out. Can‚Äôt see it working on the M1! All of a sudden he is driving much faster and somewhat more recklessly than usual. This can only partly be accounted for by the better road. We muse on this
column4: then remember he is going to stay with his sister while in Madurai

column1: The traffic in Madurai is as bad as every other big Indian city. It may have been continually inhabited for over 4000 years but it looks like any metropolis ‚Äì billboards

column4: squalor
column5: dust
column6: rubbish on the

column2: rundown streets
column3: cattle wandering where they please......there is no sense of history in an Indian city

column1: Armed with a list of places to see and some directions from the hotel

column6: but cruder versions
column7: some painted and some plain
column8: some broken and some whole
column9: about 3 or 4 feet high. Hundreds of them
column10: side by side. The painted ones have lively expressions and every one is different. Some have garlands or twigs tied to their ears and appear almost pagan. The place has a magical
column11: almost spooky charm. We amble

column2: hello

taking far too many pictures. Ahead looms the backside of a lifesize terracotta elephant with a small carved person clinging on to its bum. At this point we meet an old man who is busy brushing the sand floor with a broom who gestures at us to remove our sandals as we are now entering the temple precinct. We obey
column3: and keep walking down the road. Eventually
column4: we reach a large tree
column5: beneath which are a row of small garlanded figures of gods
column6: each one dressed
column7: with a few lit lamps in front of them and what looks like shards of pottery piled up behind. This is very unusual as it is the first time we have seen idols outside ‚Äì they are always in a shrine of some sort. We are invited to light a lamp and have our faces painted with red and white
column8: but decline. It dawns on us that there is no temple building. We later learn that these Ayyanar temples (Ayyanar being the deity) were built outside villages and the horses are there to scare away the demons. The fierce imagery is part of the cult and devotees offer new terracotta

column2: main hall
tridents and spears to the temple

column4: village people
column5: and it is very much concentrated in southern Tamil Nadu.

column3: Kanadukathan
column4: this one full of old mansions. Sadly most of

column1: them are gradually decaying through neglect and lack of funds

column1: Last stop is a slightly more modest mansion bought by two French architects who spent a year restoring it and turning it into a beautiful hotel. They care passionately about preserving the remaining mansions in the area
column2: and have been battling to persuade the Indian government to apply for Unesco World Heritage status for the area. Inevitably their efforts have been thwarted at every turn. Even when they persuade a local official of the merits of their case

column4: when what they have done with their own hotel
column5: Saratha Villas
column6: shows how such renovation can bring both short term construction work and long term employment and tourist dollars to the region. But hey this is India.

column1: We get back to the hotel in time for a light lunch and an afternoon

column1: Chettinad is the home of the Chettiars
column2: a once prosperous banking and business community. It is also known for its local cuisine
column3: architecture
column4: and religious temples. The area is also known for its 18th century mansions. Our hotel is one of those
column5: now converted. The mansions are all characterised by wide courtyards and spacious rooms embellished with marble and teak. The basic design comprises a ""thinnai"" which is an enclosed courtyard surrounded by family rooms. The walls are smooth and are made of special plaster. This technique keeps the interior of the house cool during the hot and humid Indian summers. High ceilinged
column6: airy and well ventilated
column7: the house has one courtyard near the entrance which leads to the imposing main door
column8: made of wood with extraordinarily intricate carvings of mythological figures.

more a building site

double gopurams

column1: When kings set out to impress

column5: certainly at that early date.

column3: of course
column4: also a Tamil and would really like to see a separate Tamil state. He also says that if the Brits were still in charge the country would be much more developed. Not the sort of thing you expect to hear these days in India.

column4: one of the great Chola temples built by King Rajendra Chola I in the early part of the 11th century. It is a magnificently carved temple

column6: and it is always ‚Äúanother 3 km‚Äù away.......anyway when located it is virtually deserted. It is under the Architectural Survey of India (ASI) so basically it is a historic monument with a small ‚Äúactive‚Äù shrine in the middle. Just as we like it
column7: more carving and history than in a living temple. It‚Äôs one of the ‚Äòwow‚Äô sights of the holiday so far.

column1: Because we like to go off the beaten track

column4: he has none of the false pride that British men

column2: with offerings impaled

column1: are so prone to that stops them from asking for directions. Policemen are addressed as ‚Äòsir
column2: men of his own age as ‚Äòanna‚Äô
column3: older men have a different title and so on. Women
column4: of course
column5: are never asked for directions.

column2: a complete mess of a town
column3: full of ‚Äòliving temples‚Äô i.e. ones that are still in use for worshippers. The ridiculous notion that we could see three or four becomes clear very quickly as we sit in gridlocked traffic. We identify one on our list
column4: the Nageswaran temple
column5: another Chola temple
column6: and scoot round fairly swiftly as time is passing and all temples close at 2pm for the Indian equivalent of a siesta. On to Darasuram. This temple was built by another Chola king in the 12th century. Each king seemed to need to build a new temple and capital to establish his mark on posterity. The heat has really built up now and we swelter our way around
column7: seeking any shade available.

column2: stopping en route at a petrol station for a toilet break. In one of the more bizarre photocalls
column3: as Sara stands guard for David by

column2: Kumbakonam

column1: the non locking toilet door she is approached by a young man with a cameraphone who begs to be allowed to take her picture. It never happens in London......
The hotel in Thanjavur is a fairly new business hotel. For a mere ¬£35/night we have a suite comprising a massive bedroom
column2: bathroom and sitting room. Dinner is taken in the veggie restaurant across the street
column3: where we splash out ¬£4 (between us) for our meal and drinks. We opt to sit inside
column4: to avoid the roar and fumes of the non stop traffic that assail those choosing to sit outdoors

column7: despite being plastered in repellent and covered head to toe in long sleeved shirt

column9: but the waiters stand and watch us for pretty much the whole meal.

column1: Our first stop after leaving Pondicherry is the vast temple at Chidambaram. Another of the important Shiva temples of south India
column2: and considerably less hassling than those we have visited so far. This is clearly a very rich temple. There is an important ceremony of some sort taking place. The temple is full of Brahmins in their distinctive white sarongs
column3: with the Brahmin string diagonally across their chests and with partly shaven heads
column4: and the crowd is massed outside the gold roofed inner sanctum
column5: which on this occasion we are allowed to approach. But given the crush of devotees straining to watch the priests perform the ceremony
column6: we can see very little. Much ringing of bells and clashing of cymbals; somewhere inside there a priceless bejewelled image of Nataraja
column7: but it is not visible. We drift off around the vast pillared walkway around the sanctum
column8: intermittently turning off to visit yet another shrine to a different deity. And always the heavy dominant smell of the temple
column9: a mix of flowers and scented oil and ghee and that indefinable smell of the massed ranks of humanity. We leave the first temple and wander slowly ‚Äì very slowly
column10: given the heat ‚Äì towards

column2: the holy body of water which is almost invisible behind high walls. We find a second temple
column3: with painted ceilings and columns that makes up what it lacks in size and grandeur with the quality of the decoration.

column1: Onwards to Tranquebar. Established by the Danish East India Company (yes they had one too) in 1620
column2: the Danes sought to use it as a trading base with varying degrees of success until 1845 when they rather gave up and sold it to the British for a few bob. It has a ruined fort
column3: and several Protestant churches established in the 17th and 18th centuries. All neat and well ordered
column4: not Indian at all. We stay in a heritage property called Bungalow on the Beach despite having two floors. Nobody can tell us how old the place is
column5: but it looks as if it could date back to Danish times. We visit the Danish fort and ponder how tough the earliest settlers had it. At one point it was 25 years before the next Danish ship made it safely to Tranquebar
column6: by which time there was only one Dane left alive. Luckily he was the fellow in charge of

column1: The village was badly affected by the 2004 tsunami. Over 800 people died
column2: mostly women and children
column3: but there are no obvious signs remaining
column4: apart from a memorial stone.

column2: Displayed: 5
Madurai

column1: We hired a car to take us from Mammallapuram south to Pondicherry. To say that was an adventure would be an understatement! There are no traffic signals and all vehicles are equipped with working horns. The roads were crowded with buses
column2: three-wheeled taxis
column3: motorcycles and bicycles all vying for position. Add the horns into this mix and you have a symphony of sorts
column4: and somehow it all works. Now crossing the street is another story!

column1: Pondicherry was occupied at one time by the French and as a result a strong French influence is still seen today. There is canal that divides the French quarter from the Tamil side
column2: and the differences are quite distinct. The French quarter is very distinct with its white colonial architecture
column3: while the Tamil side is quite colorful with many shades of yellow and blue.

column1: We spent 3 nights in Pondicherry leaving on the overnight bus to Madurai. Madurai is one of the oldest cities in south Asia and the location of the Meenakshi temple
column2: parts of which date back well over a thousand years. The stone carvings are amazing and the vastness of the temple itself is mind boggeling. We only stayed
Madurai
then hired a car for two days to take us to Kanyakumari
column3: the southern most point in India.It is also the meeting point of the Bay of Bengal
column4: the Indian Ocean and the Arabian Sea. People come here specifically to watch the sunrise and sunset. Following a night in Kanyakumari
column5: we rejoined our driver and headed for Varkala
column6: in Kerala
column7: stopping along the way to view the scenery and a few beaches. We arrived here late afternoon yesterday
column8: and will probably stay a few days just to veg on the beach
column9: hike some of the cliffs and maybe take a Keralan Cooking class. Would love to stay in touch
column10: so feel free to leave comments.

column1: Mahabalipuram is a UNESCO world heritage site. In the 7th and 8th centuries the Pallava kings built a number of monuments right on the seashore of what was then a major part. They comprise rathas (temples in the form of chariots)
column2: mandapas (cave sanctuaries)
column3: giant open-air reliefs such as 'Arjuna's Penance' and the Shore Temple.

column1: The Shore Temple is our first stop. We pick up a government guide at the parking lot
column2: with the apparent approval of our driver. The Shore Temple was built out of granite and is on the beach
column3: although fenced off from it and surrounded by grass. The carvings are heavily eroded by wind and sea spray and some are pretty difficult to discern without the guide's help. There were once seven temples
column4: but the other six got swept into the sea
column5: probably by a long ago tsunami. The 2004 tsunami hit the coast here also
column6: killing 27 people and making hundreds more homeless. It feels odd to be standing in the middle of where it swept in.

column1: The rathas come next. They are five temples carved out of granite outcrops
column2: in the shape of chariots and dedicated to different gods. They have figure carvings also

column1: and have not suffered as much erosion as the Shore Temple. Parts are unfinished
column2: as the Pallavas were often away fighting the Chalukya kings and so got diverted from their religious endeavours. By now the hordes are everywhere: it is Saturday so the world and his wife are out visiting
column3: as are innumerable school parties (who are at least engaging).

column1: Off to the open air carvings: Arjuna's Penance was carved by the Pallavas on a large granite outcrop
column2: very detailed
column3: and quite fun
column4: telling suitable moralistic tales. Sara encounters her first acolytes of the trip : ‚ÄúHello what your name where you come from?‚Äù Then there is also ‚ÄúOne photo one photo‚Äù
column5: where the game is to take a photo of a group of grinning schoolchildren
column6: then show them the photo on the LCD display
column7: which sends them away whooping with delight.

column1: At this point our hitherto reliable guide starts behaving suspiciously.....we are suddenly beckoned into a shop. Here we go. ‚ÄúJust looking no need to buy all things made by poor students very cheap price‚Äù. But didn‚Äôt we just see that same tat on a market stall? Out we march resolutely. He takes us next to the

column2: what your name
explains it all
column3: actually quite interesting. Then the killer: ‚ÄúForeigner not allowed in temple
column4: temple donation fee 500 rupees
column5: you pay me I pay to temple‚Äù. Yeah
column6: right. Do we look stupid?? NO. ‚ÄúBut fee is...‚Äù. NO. ‚ÄúMan outside he look after your shoes‚Äù. ‚ÄúBut we didn't have any shoes‚Äù. We give him his agreed guiding fee and off he stomps
column7: without a temple donation or a tip. Why do they do this? Do they never learn? I suppose the answer is if even a few foreigners a day fall for it
column8: it is worth it. Our driver is furious with him.

column1: Back to the hotel. It is probably 35C today so it is an afternoon lazing around. We are on holiday after all and this
column2: we realise
column3: is one of very few days in the course of the four weeks when we can do literally nothing.

column1: Off to Kamakshi temple. This one has the gopuram(or main tower) covered in scaffold. We enter the courtyard

column2: Varadharaja Perumal Temple

column7: as

are often found in temples; and a subsidiary shrine we can visit. Once more however

column1: By now we‚Äôre in the countryside
column2: where we are reminded that you‚Äôre never far from people in most of India. Small villages
column3: shrines and schools pop up every two minutes. We reach Mahaballipuram which seems to comprise a series of resort hotels strung along the beach. Ours is called the Ideal Beach Resort and proves very comfortable. We‚Äôre not used to staying anywhere in India just to relax and read a book

column1: Day 2 in Chennai and the first stop is Fort St George. (Skip the rest of this paragraph if you‚Äôre not interested in history!) The fort was built by the British East India Company on land granted to them by the local Nayak ruler in 1639 and completed on St. George's Day 1640. It was established as a fortified trading post
column2: not as the basis for military expansion or the creation of an Empire
column3: whatever revisionist historians might argue. From its establishment by Royal Charter granted by Elizabeth I in 1600
column4: the Company was only interested in trade. It regarded war as unfavourable to trade. However as events transpired over the next centuries
column5: Fort St. George
column6: which was the foundation of Madras town and became the seat of the Madras Presidency of the Company
column7: was the cornerstone on which British rule in India
column8: and the creation of the British Empire
column9: was built.

column1: History lesson over. The sun is shining
column2: and we imagine there will be lots of walking around the site
column3: visiting all the old buildings
column4: which will be nicely preserved in aspic as they would be in the UK or the US. Wrong. The first hint that maybe the

column1: place was not quite what we thought was when we were asked to record our passport numbers as we entered. Even for a country as fond of bureaucracy as India is
column2: that‚Äôs unusual. It transpires the site is now the home of the army and navy headquarters in Chennai. There are naval officers in white uniforms and female police officers brandishing swagger sticks everywhere. At almost every turn
column3: there is a sign saying no entry. We visit the museum
column4: which has some interesting sections and some exceptionally dull ones. St Mary's church
column5: the oldest Anglican church in India built in 1680
column6: is still intact
column7: and there we encounter our first foreign tourists of the trip
column8: in the shape of a coachload of Brits and one of Japanese. Among the memorial stones is one to the memory of the vicar
column9: who is confusingly described as having shown ‚Äòsedulous and temperate zeal‚Äô in his efforts to convert the heathen. Next we follow a sign hoping to visit Clive of India‚Äôs house
column10: but are turned away on the grounds that it is now an office. We find some of the original buildings but they have been abused and are hidden behind hoardings.

column2: we find Mr Hussain and set off for the government museum. 15 rupees entrance fee for Indians
column3: 250 for foreigners. Now
column4: that it is still cheap if there is something worth seeing.... The museum was opened in 1857 and most sections appear not to have changed since then. The early galleries of sculptures
column5: which seemed a bit dull
column6: prove to be among the highlights of the trip. The zoology section offered light amusement for the sheer awfulness of the exhibits. Cases full of animal skeletons
column7: or parts thereof
column8: are followed by some of the worst taxidermy ever seen
column9: featuring animals that seemed to have died of old age and mange. Even that beats the botany section hands down. We find some nice bronzes but that is a temporary uplift. The next building features anthropology which should have been a warning. Actually
column10: it is a warning
column11: but David likes to get full value from any visit and we certainly didn‚Äôt feel we‚Äôd had much thus far. The building itself
column12: which was built by the British in 1789 is actually quite impressive
column13: though horribly run down
column14: but the exhibits ‚Äì well
column15: let‚Äôs just say that the boomerangs of Tamil Nadu

column1: are possibly one of the more interesting cases.

column2: we retired to the hotel

column9: and traffic continues to flow in at least two of three directions at all times. Eventually

column17: some yelling at him to get out

column5: almost silent
column6: and with a stylish cabin that looks like it has been designed by BMW. And a lovely crew. We don‚Äôt often praise BA

column9: 12.35 in the morning. Only two flights coming in

column3: arrives early to take us out ‚Äì a good sign

column2: we ask to visit the Kapaleeswarar Temple
column3: dedicated to Shiva. ‚ÄòTemple is closed from 2.00 to 4.00‚Äô says Mr Hussain. It is 1.30 and the temple is half an hour away. Note to self

column5: we ask to fill in the time by going to Guindy National

column1: Park. This is less grand than it sounds

column3: now protected as a nature reserve. Mr Hussain nods in approval at our choice. Once there
column4: we find you can‚Äôt walk or drive though it

column6: for the princely sum of 70p including two camera permits. It proves much more interesting than expected. The snakes are all kept safe behind glass walls
column7: but that does not stop the pace being plastered with signs warning of the dangers of touching them! As well as snakes

column1: Next we manage to communicate successfully our desire to go Sao Thome

column1: There is still half an hour to fill in before the temple opens. Mr Hussain suggests a trip to the beach. We concur. At first sight
column2: this looks like a mistake ‚Äì miles of sand with a few empty stalls. We wander slowly towards the water
column3: and find there are fishing boats pulled up at one end. This is our first reminder that in India a picture only tells half the story
column4: as it cannot capture the smells. Here
column5: the good mingles uncomfortably with the bad ‚Äì a strong scent of sandalwood and incense by the boats and their nets piled on the sand (presumably from incense burning to seek blessings before going out to fish) co-exists with the smell of rotting fish from the piles of small dead fish
column6: about the size of whitebait. Unwanted catch? Too small to sell? Who knows...the dead rotting crow impaled on a stick poking out of the sand (explain that one) certainly offers no clue.

column2: a fishing boat arrives back to shore with its catch
column3: crashing through the breakers. This reminds David of the eighteenth century arrivals in Madras from England
column4: who after six months at sea had to clamber down from their ship into a rowing boat and be taken to shore through these same breakers
column5: hoping they would not be tossed into the sea by the pitching of the boat and drowned before they even set foot on land. Anyway the fisherman start pulling the boat far enough out of the water to stop it floating off on the next wave
column6: but this is a harder job than might be expected
column7: taking four men a good ten minutes. Finally
column8: with the boat tied up to another one
column9: they tie the nets
column10: with the catch still inside
column11: onto two stout pieces of wood
column12: and carry it up to a roadside stall where shoppers wait patiently for the nets to be unravelled and the fish put up for sale. Definitely the freshest fish ever!

column1: Back to the Kapaleeswarar Temple. The main feature is a typically South Indian gopuram (gateway)

column1: We were leaving Pondicherry and heading south west to Madurai. We woke early and walked to Hot Breads bakery to pick up some snacks (croissants and savoury rolls) for breakfast and lunch. We left Hotel Surguru in a minibus at 9am and headed to Villupuram Junction. We waited at the train station and jumped on the train as it slowed ‚Äì we only had two minutes to get on before it lurched off again. We had a six hour trip to Madurai ahead of us.

We shared our berth on the sleeper train with four Indian army officers who were very friendly. I started reading ‚ÄúStories told by the Mother II‚Äù which a fellow traveller had picked up at the Sri Aurobindo Ashram in Pondicherry. I put it down momentarily
column2: and one of the officers picked it up and started reading it. I had visions of never seeing the book again
column3: but he only managed a few stories before putting it down again. I‚Äôve realised that sharing between strangers is commonly accepted in India. We shared our snacks with them
column4: and they were very interested in hearing about our travels in India. One of the officers looked through

column1: all of Ren‚Äôs photos on her camera after she showed him a photo of the beach where I‚Äôd picked up my necklace/bracelets ‚Äì they liked them and wanted to know what I paid for them. They all agreed I got a good price.
We stopped at Tiruchirappalli station at around 1pm. We were half-way to Madurai
column2: so we jumped off the train to buy some chai (tea) from a tiny stall on the platform. We only had a few minutes before the train left
column3: so it was fairly stressful
column4: especially when everyone else from the train had the same idea. The chai was fantastic. We settled in
column5: snacked on our savoury rolls and enjoyed the ride. The army officers had got off the train
column6: and our birth filled up with new passengers (a small family and a single female) for the second half of the journey.

column2: and we weren‚Äôt prepared for what lay ahead. We jumped off the train
column3: made our way along the platform
column4: walked up a flight of stairs and suddenly found ourselves engulfed in a seething sea of humanity. We had turned into an overpass from the station to

column2: and it was claustrophobic. Everyone was going in the same direction
column3: and there was simply no way of stopping. We had our packs on (which made us heavier than everyone around us)
column4: and we literally flowed with the masses. I don‚Äôt remember walking ‚Äì we were just jammed into a mass of bodies that carried us along with them. We managed to point ourselves in the direction of the stairs on the other side of the overpass and finally emerged into the dusty streets of Madurai. An old Muslim man had been walking alongside me all the way
column5: and when he found out I was from Australia
column6: he decided to give me a history lesson on when Captain Cook landed in Botany Bay. I finally caught sight of Ren
column7: so we headed straight to the Madurai Residency Hotel. We checked in at 4.30pm
column8: dropped our packs and made our way to Sri Meenakshi Temple.

column1: We arrived at the temple at 5.30pm
column2: and this was to be a highlight of our trip to-date. We wandered around the outside and then headed into the temple itself. A festival was on at the time
column3: and there were a number of

column1: processions making their way around the long stone corridors. We nearly met our fate when a group of men carrying a large shrine of Krishna turned a corner where we were standing and lost their footing. Masses of people fell backwards and rammed us against a stone wall. The shrine (which was being held aloft by two long pieces of wood) tilted violently
column2: and I thought it was going to end up on top off us. Luckily
column3: the devotees carrying the shrine managed to right themselves
column4: and we lived to tell the tale.

column1: Ren lit a lamp for her father as we made our way counter-clockwise around the temple‚Äôs corridors (which may explain why the shrine nearly ended up on top of us
column2: because everyone else was walking clockwise). I loved this temple. There was something very calm and inclusive about the atmosphere inside
column3: despite the masses of people who we were continually rubbing shoulders with.

column1: As we wandered back to the hotel I picked up some postcards from an old man in the street. The back streets of Madurai were just coming to life at dusk
column2: and it was fascinating walking through them. We got back to

column1: the hotel and headed to the rooftop restaurant for dinner. We shared a selection of curries with our fellow travellers ‚Äì gobi aap ki passand aloo (cauliflower curry)
column2: dingiri mutter (mushroom and green pea curry)
column3: vegetable chettinad (spicy vegetable curry) and chana masala (chickpea curry)
column4: all of which were served with rice and naan (leavened bread cooked in a wood fired oven). It was fantastic and very
column5: very hot.

column1: As the wind picked up and the evening grew long
column2: we decided to go to bed... and that‚Äôs when the gastro struck. We‚Äôve been travelling together for many years now
column3: and we‚Äôve always carried Gastro-Stop with us
column4: but this was the first time I‚Äôve ever had to use it. Luckily
column5: it lived up to its name. We had a four hour bus trip to Thekkady in the morning
column6: and the last thing I wanted to worry about was gastroenteritis.

column1: It was a travel day and we had to stock up on breakfast and lunch items
column2: so after a very quick trip down to Hot Breads Bakery in Pondicherry
column3: we caught a minibus for the one hour ride to the railway station at Villupuram. The station

column2: so we walked around for a little while and bought chais (teas) from the station chai wallah (tea seller).

column1: Indian Railways is the largest employer in Asia
column2: and as much as I like seeing people employed
column3: the organiser in me couldn‚Äôt help but mentally streamline their systems as I watched passengers being put through multiple processes ‚Äì each handled by a different staff member at a different counter
column4: and each requiring a new queue.
