I'm increasingly realising that the preferred method of operation in India is that a particular job or task can only be performed by one person at a time - they don't seem to like the concept that the same person who checks your ticket can also stamp it and tick it off the ledger. I know it provides more employment to use more people than is really required
column5: but the inefficiency in time is significant and it is harder to maintain the quality of the product. Anyway
column6: back to our train trip.

column1: We were in second class 3AC sleeper carriages again for the six hour daytime journey to Madurai. It was an unexpectedly enjoyable journey. The windows were clear this time
so it was great to watch the Tamil Nadu countryside roll by
column2: and we were in a compartment with Indian Army Officers who wanted to chat. They questioned us about Australia
column3: our views on India and life in general. In return
column4: they answered all our questions about their work and lives. It seemed important to them that I felt safe in India
column5: and they asked if we‚Äôd had any security issues ‚Äì we hadn‚Äôt. One of the officers mentioned a tourist police phone number that I should ring if I had any problems (and he rattled off the number). I gathered that it had been a topic they had been briefed on as they all went into ‚Äòofficial‚Äô mode when talking about it
column6: and then visibly relaxed when I changed the subject.

column1: The Army officers were on a trip to Tamil Nadu to organise a recruitment rally. They loved hearing about where in India we had already travelled to
column2: and I showed them my photos of the beach at Mamallapuram because some of them hadn‚Äôt been to that part of India. However
column3: instead of handing my camera back
column4: one of the senior officers started flipping through all the photos

column2: asking for explanations of each one. It‚Äôs a good thing I didn‚Äôt have any ‚Äòpersonal‚Äô photos on that card! üòâ

column1: They were so involved in conversations with us that they very nearly missed their stop. Of all the conversations we had with them
column2: two gave me most cause for thought. Firstly
column3: the younger Officers (in their late 20s to early 30s) were very accepting of arranged marriages
column4: and were happy to let their parents decide their future partners for them. Secondly
column5: I was very surprised to learn that all their official paperwork is written in English
column6: even though all oral communication is in Hindi. They all spoke English to some level
column7: but were not very confident about it and were happy for the opportunity to speak it.

column2: the two remaining guys in our compartment decided to watch a DVD on their laptop... and turned the laptop around and the sound up so we could watch too. Kim and I rolled our eyes at the thought of watching a DVD on a train
column3: and a mainstream Hollywood one at that
column4: but we were hooked within minutes. I couldn‚Äôt tell you what the film

column2: but we were most disappointed that the guy had to get off the train before the film ended. The young family who got on next were more interested in arguing with each other than talking to us
column3: so I finally got some reading done.

column1: The only other excitement on that journey was that Lee and Andrew decided to get off at one of the stations to buy us some chais (a chai wallah hadn‚Äôt come through in a while)
column2: and Karni jumped out with them to hurry the process along as the train only stopped for two to four minutes at the smaller stations. It was a close call
column3: but they made it back just in time with delicious chais in hand. For reasons unfathomable to mere mortals like us
column4: the chai at train stations and on trains in India was so much more delicious than any other chai I‚Äôve ever tasted. The savoury rolls and pastries we‚Äôd bought at Hot Breads Bakery in Pondicherry were quite delicious
column5: and I immediately wished we‚Äôd bought more.

column1: There were two ‚Äòbest‚Äô parts of the train trip for me ‚Äì firstly
column2: all the wallahs (sellers) who appeared out of

column1: thin air as soon as the train started moving. The chai wallah clutched a tea urn in one hand and little cups in the other and for a few rupees we had hot sweet milky tea. Apparently the hot sweet thick coffee was very good too. The cold drink wallahs came next
column2: followed by the wallahs of hot food and snacks. It was a constant wallah stream through our carriage
column3: but none of them were pushy or rude. They were merely making a living and in the process
column4: making our train journey all the more comfortable. The second best thing for me was having such a fun and lively conversation with a group of strangers who were as curious about us as we were about them.

column1: We arrived at Madurai station around 4pm. I have never felt under siege by humanity before
column2: but I came very close when we stepped into the streaming crowd at this station. Once you committed to the stream
column3: you just got pushed forward by the momentum of the crowd until you were deposited outside the station. I could barely turn around (I had my pack on) to check on Andrew as we were propelled

column1: forward. We artfully dodged the rickshaw wallahs (rickshaw drivers) vying for business and walked for ten minutes across busy streets to our hotel. The Madurai Residency Hotel was a very clean
column2: standard business-styled hotel
column3: but with very little character. Although at this point of the trip
column4: I was badly in need of a fix of crisp white sheets
column5: and this hotel totally delivered.

column1: Madurai is an ancient city of over 2 million people. The Tamils have a recorded history going back to the 3rd Century BC
column2: which shows an unbroken Dravidian lineage that they are very proud of. My ancestors on Dad‚Äôs side originated from this part of Tamil Nadu
column3: and I suppose I should be proud of this ‚Äòancient people‚Äô legacy too
column4: but unfortunately this sort of ‚Äòracial pride‚Äô nearly always goes hand-in-hand with racial superiority. It can mean that marriages outside of the Tamil community (like my Mum and Dad‚Äôs) are frowned upon ‚Äì and I really don‚Äôt understand or have time for that sort of prejudice.

column1: That evening after confirming the dress code for the tenth time ‚Äì long trousers and shoulders covered for both men and women ‚Äì we left for the magnificent Sri
Meenakshi Temple. The temple was a short walk from our hotel
column2: and on turning a corner
column3: the distinctive brightly-coloured gopuram (gatehouse tower) and outer temple walls came into view at the end of the street. The street was blocked off to traffic
column4: and it was very strange (but quite pleasant!) to be walking along an Indian road without fear of being deafened by horns or knocked over by a speeding motorbike.

column1: Security was the tightest I‚Äôve seen for any tourist site I‚Äôve been to. After leaving our shoes and cameras at a nearby shop
column2: we were screened and patted down by guards ‚Äì there was a separate queue for women
column3: attended by female guards behind a curtain. Very sadly
column4: photography was strictly forbidden. I say ‚Äòsadly‚Äô because it was a beautiful temple and I would have loved to have some photographs to make sense of all the fast moving colour and movement we witnessed. Very strangely
column5: you could pay a fee to take your phone in and take photos with your phone camera. This baffled me beyond belief. It still baffles me.

column1: The Sri Meenakshi Temple is considered to be the most beautiful temple in South India. It
was originally built in the 7th Century
column2: but work continued until the 18th Century. The temple complex inside the wall is incredibly vast. To our left was an ancient banyan tree
column3: where childless women who wanted to conceive had hung brightly painted miniature cradles. Each of the Temple‚Äôs main entrances were arranged along the cardinal axes
column4: with the 50m tall south gopuram structure the biggest and supposedly most detailed. Each gopuram was covered with intricately detailed and brightly painted figures of gods
column5: demons
column6: humans and animals. They have only recently started painting the gopura in multiple colours
column7: so the colours were VERY vibrant. A part of me wishes they‚Äôd left them as they were. The complex has multiple shrines
column8: each in a square enclosure surrounded by smaller inner gopura
column9: and there is a sacred water tank enclosure and various halls that surround and connect the square enclosures.

column1: We had a very lovely local guide accompanying us
column2: without whom we would have lost our bearings within the first five minutes! We walked through the east entrance and entered a hall in which there were hundreds of white-clad men and women in colourful saris and other traditional dresses. We slowly made

column1: our way through lamp-lit corridors and mazes of dimly lit rooms towards the inner sanctum. The air was thick with the smell of oils and spices from burning lamps and incense sticks.

column2: very crowded with both local worshippers and pilgrims who had travelled from all over India. I watched a family walk past us ‚Äì the father was carrying a child of about 18 months who had just had her ears pierced and her hair shaved close to the skull. Her eyes were also heavily ringed with kohl (so as not to attract the attention of spiteful spirits by being too cute). I was told that she had just been through one of the first (of many) age-related Hindu ceremonies.
small oil lamps were being lit and placed in front of statues. There were many small stalls where we could buy the small oil lamps
column3: and I lit a lamp for Dad... remembering that he had told me this was one of the most beautiful temples he had seen. I agree with Dad
column4: this temple was one of the biggest highlights of the trip so far.

column2: the group got separated as a procession of priests and devotees coursed their way through the narrow hallway we were standing in. The priests were carrying a statue
column3: and the praying and chanting crowd was pressing in on them. Andrew and Brian bore the brunt of my weight as the crowd fell into me
column4: and I fell back into them ‚Äì pushing them into railings and a stone wall. The procession had reached a corner and couldn't all fit
column5: and then suddenly surged forward. Andrew and Damien were tall enough to see what was happening
column6: and they looked worried. However
column7: I could barely see what was going on
column8: as there was a sea of armpits in my face. The procession passed soon enough and we moved on to join the rest of the group
column9: but I can see how easily a stampede could have occurred in such an enclosed place when crowd numbers aren‚Äôt controlled.

column1: The Hall of One Thousand Pillars is a major attraction of the temple. It couldn‚Äôt be more colourful if it tried! I really loved the feel of this place. The pillars were all carved with different figures
column2: and my favourite were the

column1: yalis (mythical beasts with a head of an elephant and body of a lion). At one end of the Hall stood the figure of Nataraja (the dancing form of Shiva)
column2: dancing the cosmic dance.

column1: It would have been easy to spend much more than the two hours we had here
column2: watching the people lighting lamps and praying with such passion
column3: but I‚Äôd started to feel like I was intruding and had to keep reminding myself to stop staring. We retreated from the temple
column4: retrieved our shoes and spent a few minutes engaging in the obligatory checking out of pashminas and hand carved ornaments in the handicrafts emporium (where we‚Äôd left our shoes).

column1: Towards the end of our walk through the temple
column2: our local guide had questioned me about my heritage (almost everyone I meet in India seems to need to know this!)
column3: but unlike anyone else
column4: the only question he asked me was what I thought about the recent election results in Sri Lanka. I sidestepped the issue by saying I didn‚Äôt follow Sri Lankan politics
column5: but it seems he did ‚Äì in minute detail. I was given an impressive blow-by-blow account of the election and what he

column1: thought of where Sri Lanka was heading. He would have got along very well with my Dad. üòä
We walked back to our hotel and later met for dinner on the rooftop. We shared a few vegetarian curries of aloo gobi (potato and cauliflower curry)
column2: dingiri mutter (mushroom and green pea curry)
column3: vegetable chettinad (spicy vegetable curry) and chana masala (chickpea curry)
column4: with rice and naan (leavened bread cooked in a wood fired oven). The food was delicious and some of the curries were VERY hot. I had a small lapse in concentration when ordering drinks and ordered an iced tea
column5: which as its name suggested
column6: came chock full of ice. As refreshing as it looked
column7: sadly
column8: I just couldn‚Äôt risk having it. üòû

column1: Our quick walk through town that evening had given us a glimpse of masses of Hindu pilgrims
column2: hordes of circling rickshaws
column3: more poverty and beggars than we‚Äôd seen in the other towns and cities
column4: and lots of bazaars and street markets. But we were running out of time to explore more of Madurai.

column1: Our time there was even more compromised when the virus going around the group attacked Andrew in the stomach department
at 2am. We were certain it hadn‚Äôt been anything Andrew had eaten as we had shared all our meals. We were up until 5am
column2: at which point Andrew fell asleep. I had got the other bug (sore throat
column3: cough and cold) that was also going through the group... which turned into a fever later that day. So I spent the early part of the next day looking for more drugs for both of us.

column1: None of the pharmacies (called ‚Äòmedical shops‚Äô in India) I found were open or likely to open before we left Madurai that morning. You know you are travelling with good people when Rao kindly offered us his supply of Imodium (but we were well stocked with Gastro-Stop)
column2: and Chris kindly offered us her stash of re-hydration tablets (which we‚Äôd completely neglected to pack!). Damien finally found an open pharmacy and bought us more supplies to keep Andrew comfortable and hydrated until we reached the next hotel. Thanks heaps guys!

column1: We had known that getting sick was par for the course in India
column2: but I had been so sure that of the two of us
column3: I would have been the one to fall first with

column1: a stomach bug. I would much
column2: much
column3: much rather be sick myself than have someone I love get sick
column4: but I‚Äôm probably not alone in thinking that way.

column1: We had planned to go back to the Sri Meenakshi Temple that morning
column2: but sadly that plan didn‚Äôt work out. As for the city of Madurai
column3: while I think it represents the colourful and lively part of southern Indian culture very well
column4: it didn‚Äôt attract me very much. However
column5: given we only had one day there
column6: I don‚Äôt think I saw nearly enough of it to form a solid opinion... even though it certainly was an eye-opening experience.

column1: Next we enter the Western Ghats ranges and travel west into Periyar National Park in Kerala.

We left Mysore at 8.30pm the previous night and embarked on an 11 hour overnight train journey to Chennai. We sat and talked with two young students who were sharing our berth before settling into our bunks around 10.30pm. The gentle rocking of the train had me asleep in no time.
I woke at 6.30am and found some room on my bunk to catch up on my travel notes. We arrived in Chennai at 7am
column2: scrambled off the train
column3: negotiated the throngs of people pouring into Chennai Central and jumped into a minibus to begin our journey south. We were halfway through our south India travels
column4: and we were heading down the eastern coastline of this vast country. We‚Äôd barely left the train station before pulling into the Emarald Hotel for breakfast
column5: where we feasted on a buffet of pittu (steamed cakes)
column6: rajma curry (black pea curry)
column7: naan (leavened bread cooked in a wood fired oven)
column8: vadi (lentil fritters) and strong coffee. It was fantastic
column9: and just what the doctor ordered. We‚Äôd been travelling for 12 hours without a shower
column10: so we needed something to pick us up and keep us going.

column1: Chennai on this trip. We finished breakfast
column2: jumped into our minibus and headed to Mahabalipuram. As we sped along Chennai‚Äôs seafront
column3: I was amazed by the starkness of the beach and surrounds. It‚Äôs difficult to get a feel for a place when you spend so little time there. After driving parallel to the coast for about an hour
column4: we arrived at Hotel Mahabs and headed straight for the shower.

column1: At 11am we set out on a bike tour of Mahabalipuram‚Äôs local temples
column2: and to say the bikes were basic was a major understatement. We managed to ride all the way to the Five Rathas
column3: rode/walked to the Shore Temple and then rode/walked to Krishna‚Äôs Butterball. The chaotic traffic and masses of people made it impossible to ride more than 50 metres without stopping to avoid cars
column4: cows or children. We were still in the midst of the four day Pongal Festival
column5: and it was fantastic (yet slightly unusual) when I realised that we were the only foreign tourists to be seen. I loved the relaxed family atmosphere at the Five Rathas and Krishna‚Äôs Butterball
column6: but the walk to the Shore Temple to witness Shiva‚Äôs linga in the intense heat

column1: of the midday sun was all getting a bit too much ‚Äì I needed a beer.
We finished our bike tour around 1pm and wandered to the seafront for lunch. We made our way up some narrow stairs to the atmospheric Santana Beach Restaurant
column2: a rooftop restaurant overlooking the Bay of Bengal. The strong sea breeze gusting through this rooftop haven was very welcome
column3: as we‚Äôd overheated on the bikes in Mahabalipuram‚Äôs hot dry midday heat. We shared a fried calamari masala with chips
column4: and while Ren cooled down with a shandy
column5: I recharged with a cold Kingfisher.

column2: Lee and I decided to dive into the surf that was rolling in from the Bay of Bengal. We had to disregard the state of the beach and turn a blind eye to the bloated cat that had washed up just in front of us. The waves were good for body surfing and the water was incredibly warm. It was a great experience and very refreshing. As we walked back along the beach I picked up a necklace and a few bracelets from a beach seller ‚Äì I wanted something to remember my first Indian surf experience!

column1: We headed back to the hotel and lazed by the pool for the rest of the day. The afternoon sun was searing
column2: so we welcomed the chance to relax and cool down. I noticed a number of decrepit houses behind the hotel where small children were playing in dusty streets. Their poverty was evident
column3: and yet here was I lazing beside a pool in an affluent hotel only metres from their crumbling homes. The social divide has weighed heavily on my conscience since I arrived in India.

column1: We headed out for pre-dinner drinks at 6.30pm before walking to the Blue Elephant Restaurant for dinner. Ren opted for the vegetable noodles while I had the fish curry. The curry was hot and the fish was fresh ‚Äì straight from the Bay of Bengal. The food was fantastic
column2: and our beer was served in huge metal tumblers (alcohol wasn‚Äôt meant to be served
column3: so beer bottles were not to be left on the table). We finished our meal around 8.30pm and wandered back to the hotel in the balmy evening air. We were leaving Mahabalipuram in the morning and heading to Pondicherry
column4: so we decided on an early night.

column1: Even though we officially stopped in Chennai (formerly called Madras)
column2: it was just a stepping stone on the way to Mamallapuram (also called Mahabalipuram) which was two hours away by minibus. We arrived on the overnight train from Mysore at the crack of dawn ‚Äì well
column3: 7am ‚Äì but it felt like the crack of dawn. The Chennai train station was a mass of teaming humanity
column4: and it looked and felt like something out of a post-apocalyptic film. Masses of people were camped on the floor
column5: covered from head to toe in blankets
column6: and even more were trying to move around the sleeping bodies
column7: or simply hanging about. Everyone was waiting...clearly waiting for trains...but my tired mind‚Äôs eye thought it saw a more ominous motive. I needed more sleep!

column1: We headed to Emarald Hotel for a quick buffet breakfast. I thought I couldn't even consider having anything more than a cup of tea. However
column2: when I got there and saw the breakfast buffet
column3: I felt a ravenous hunger come over me. Guess who had steaming pittu (rice flour and coconut rolled into cous cous like balls and steamed in a cylindrical shape) with rajma curry (black

column1: peas in a thick gravy sauce)
column2: dosa (thin pancakes made from fermented rice and black lentils batter) with coconut chutney
column3: and a freshly fried egg with toast to go with their cup of tea? Of course
column4: the boys didn't let me live that one down. üòä

column1: Chennai was humming on that Friday morning
column2: even though (or maybe because) it was a public holiday for the Pongal Festival. The minibus took us through the city
column3: which was lined with advertising boards ‚Äì mainly for a heavily moustachioed man who seemed to be running for office. There was evidence of a thriving economy ‚Äì it is one of the Indian cities which has benefited greatly from the IT and Call Centre boom. The cars were flashy
column4: the hotels and restaurants looked upmarket
column5: the buildings were large and the gardens were manicured. The young women were noticeably more cosmopolitan in the way they dressed and the sari-ed women were in a minority. However
column6: the slums along the river were hard to miss and the whiff of sewerage was the worst it's been on this trip so far. But given that Chennai is the fourth biggest city in India (after Mumbai
column7: Kolkata and

column2: it's not that surprising.

column1: We drove along the foreshore where a sea-misty Indian Ocean was the background for a popular but drab beach front area. We continued on to Mamallapuram along a coastal road besieged with hotels. As we drove away from the big city
column2: I could feel the city hum starting to dwindle ‚Äì the shops got smaller
column3: the cars got older and the mammoth advertising boards decreased in size and number. However
column4: the humidity and temperature started to increase exponentially. The roadside became one long stretch of just-harvested rice fields
column5: which were now filled with grazing cattle and cranes fighting over the grains of rice dropped by the harvesters. I slept for most of the two hour minibus drive
column6: so I don't have much more to share about that journey.

column1: Hotel Mahabs in Mamallapuram was just lovely and right in the centre of town. The rooms were old-school
column2: but they were large and came with a welcome balcony ‚Äì and we promptly lowered the tone of the neighbourhood by hanging our laundry on it. We were surrounded by beautiful trees which unfortunately supplied a brilliant environment for mosquitoes
column3: so the mosquito repellent got a good

column2: and it is sold as being a laid-back town with nice beaches
column3: good restaurants and intricately carved architecture from the 7th Century. Modern day Mamallapuram is a tiny town
column4: mostly supported by tourism due to the group of World Heritage-listed stone temples in it. So as you would expect
column5: there are lots of touts about.

column1: We were supposed to wait until the heat of the day had subsided
column2: but Karni thought the weather wasn't too bad
column3: so at 11am we ventured out for a cycling tour of the World Heritage-listed collection of 7th and 8th Century temples and stone architecture. Our bikes looked like 1960‚Äôs models with loose handlebars and questionable brakes. Even though the round trip was only 7km
column4: I don‚Äôt ride very often and I wasn‚Äôt sure about riding through the town on an ancient bike...especially in traffic with trucks
column5: cars
column6: motorbikes
column7: cows and massive groups of people wandering around celebrating Pongal. But I had a sudden case of FOMO (fear of missing out) and decided to do it. I was also safe in the knowledge that Andrew and Kim were happy to shepherd me (thanks guys!).

column1: was at The Five Rathas (Five Chariots) which illustrates early South Indian Dravidian architecture. These are five monolithic structures
column2: each carved from a single piece of solid pink granite
column3: and each sculpted in a different style. There is a theory that this was part of a sculpture school and that they were scale models (based on wooden chariots) for full scale temples. A lot of literature refers to the Rathas as temples
column4: but they were never finished and therefore never consecrated.

column2: on the edge of the sea
column3: sat the Shore Temple. Given the complete lack of any recognisable road rules
column4: I found negotiating the streams of traffic a challenge. The only road rule at play seemed to be that whoever was smaller and/or blinked first
column5: lost (and that was me most of the time). Surprisingly
column6: it was more of a challenge navigating the meandering people than the traffic
column7: especially when we had to cross a market full of them to get to the Shore Temple. By now I was so hot that rivulets of sweat had begun to wind their way down my back
column8: and I was struggling to stay on the bike at such

column1: The Shore Temple was built with blocks of cut granite. The temple is a combination of three shrines ‚Äì the main shrine and a small second shrine are dedicated to Shiva
column2: while a small third shrine (between the other two) is dedicated to a reclining Vishnu. The pillars and carvings have sadly been eroded by the salt from high tides and occasional floods. There are numerous mandapams (carved pillars in front of temples) still remaining. There are theories that this temple was part of a ‚ÄòSeven Pagoda‚Äô complex
column3: and that all but this one have been eroded by the elements or submerged by the sea. We were on the shores of the Coromandel Coast of the Bay of Bengal
column4: and this area was hit by the tsunami in 2004. It is a World Heritage site now
column5: and the temple is protected by sea wall defences.

column1: Next we braved more crowds through another market area and congested roads to a massive open air bas-relief wall frieze known as Arjuna‚Äôs Penance (or Descent of the Ganges). The frieze is carved in amazing detail on two pink granite rocks with a cleft in the middle. A collecting pool at
the top of the rocks was designed to cause water to cascade down the cleft ‚Äì supposedly signifying the Ganges coming down from heaven. The carved scenes have many interpretations
column2: but the most loved theory is that it depicts Arjuna (a figure standing on one leg) doing penance for a favour from Shiva. The other common theory is that the figure is Bhagiratha doing penance to bring down the Ganges to earth for the prosperity and happiness of the people. Either way
column3: the bas-relief carving was beautiful
column4: especially the detailed depictions of kings
column5: holy men
column6: sinful men
column7: nagas (serpent gods)
column8: birds
column9: elephants and other animals.

column1: The Tamil people from this region were often referred to as the Venetians of the 3rd ‚Äì 8th Centuries. They travelled into the SE Asian peninsula spreading the Hindu religion as they went. As a result
column2: the carvings in the temples here are similar in style to those of Angkor Wat in Cambodia
column3: but not on the same mammoth scale.

column1: The big draw card of the area is Krishna‚Äôs Butterball
column2: a huge granite boulder that is precariously and improbably perched on a sloping rock face ‚Äì completely defying gravity. It was a pretty
and even though it has sat there for eons
column3: I didn‚Äôt completely trust that it wouldn‚Äôt suddenly dislodge itself and roll towards us like some sort of giant bowling ball (I read a lot of Asterix comics as a child). The lawns surrounding the area were full of big groups of families having lunch in the shade of the large trees. The day was getting hotter
column4: and by the time we got back to our bikes
column5: I realised the layers of sweat
column6: sunscreen and insect repellent on the exposed skin of my neck and arms had acquired a film of road dust. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever experienced ‚Äògritty‚Äô arms before.

column1: We cycled back to the bike hire shop and that was the end of the bike tour. As much as I was glad to be no longer riding in crazy public holiday Indian traffic
column2: it would have been nice to have had a longer bike ride ‚Äì perhaps on the network of quiet back streets that radiated off the main drag (rather than on the main road itself). I‚Äôm glad I didn‚Äôt chicken out of the bike ride and catch an auto rickshaw (motorised tricycle with

although I had one small moment of panic when a guy walked out in front of me (talking on his phone) and I swerved into a parked car. The guy happened to be the owner of the car and thankfully thought it was hilarious. What was more hilarious was that when I was telling Kim what that happened
column3: I ran straight into the back of Lee... Ah. Good times.

column1: Andrew and I don't like crowds much
column2: so we really should have avoided being in India during a festival. More to the point
column3: we probably should have avoided India all together! But in the hope of experiencing as wide a cross section of humanity as possible
column4: here we were.

column1: We walked to Santana Restaurant on the beach for lunch. While travelling in India
column2: we‚Äôd decided to be as vegetarian as possible
column3: but we were making exceptions with seafood in coastal towns. So for lunch I ordered masala calamari which came with chips! This was our first Indian-western fusion meal
column4: and I have to admit it was fabulous. I couldn‚Äôt believe I got a side order of chips
column5: but there you go ‚Äì it‚Äôs not all rice

column1: We were sitting on the top floor of the restaurant with a warm Indian Ocean scented breeze blowing through the open windows of the restaurant. From where we were sitting
column2: we had a good view of the beach below us
column3: including the passing parade of Indian families
column4: groups of young men and herds of cows. It was both cute and slightly weird to see that cows liked the beach.

column1: Given the restaurant only sold beers
column2: Kim and I ordered lemonade and made ourselves a shandy. Brian had never had one before
column3: and he seems to have discovered a new favourite drink.

column1: The beach wasn‚Äôt really set up for lounging about
column2: but Andrew and Lee wanted to swim in the Bay of Bengal
column3: so after lunch we found a space on the far end of the beach that wasn't occupied by cows or groups of young guys. The water wasn‚Äôt as warm as it looked
column4: but it was quite pleasant (although the water was warm to Andrew who is used to surfing in freezing Tasmanian waters). Andrew was persistently followed by a guy selling necklaces and bracelets
column5: and in the end Andrew relented and bought

column1: a beaded necklace and two bracelets. Initially I wasn‚Äôt happy about rewarding the persistent seller ‚Äì but the bracelets were quite cute. Cute enough that I stole one for myself. üòä
We walked back along the main street to the shady coolness of our hotel. There were the usual shops selling beach sarongs and trinkets
column2: but there were also a number of stone-carving galleries and workshops. However
column3: we didn‚Äôt shop as much as I thought we would ‚Äì we couldn‚Äôt be bothered fending off the pushy touts.

column1: I probably would have liked Mamallapuram a whole lot more (despite the stifling heat) if not for the disproportionate number of super-persistent touts and beggars. I think it was even more noticeable because it was a small place.
The hotel swimming pool provided a great hangout space for most of the boys
column2: while Kim and I reclined in the shade with an adult beverage delivered to us by Lee ‚Äì so spoilt! Damien and Brian had ended up in a lovely (honeymoon!) suite with a large enclosed balcony
column3: so we gathered there for pre-dinner drinks. I must have got a bit too much sun on the bike ride
column4: as I

column1: was feeling very tired and slightly hot and bothered. However
column2: an hour of sitting outside on a balmy night soon made me feel better.

column1: We had dinner at The Blue Elephant along the path to the beach
column2: which was well known for its seafood dishes. Andrew ordered a fiery fish curry. However
column3: given I wasn‚Äôt feeling 100%
column4: I ordered from the bland side of the menu ‚Äì fried vegetarian noodles ‚Äì which were surprisingly delicious and exactly what my stomach wanted!

column1: As we walked back from the restaurant
column2: I noticed that the town had a very different feel. The traffic had subsided
column3: the touts had gone home and the temperature was very pleasant for walking. This was more like the laid-back seaside town I had been expecting.

column1: This was a quick stop over in Mamallapuram with the main aim to visit the ancient architectural sites. However
column2: if we had stayed a few more days (and had been able to avoid the pushy touts)
column3: I think I may have started to understand what attracted so many western hippies here.

column1: Next we travel south along the coast to the former French colony of Pondicherry.

We were leaving Ooty and travelling north to Mudumalai National Park. We woke at 6.30am in our freezing bedroom and headed out for a warming chai(tea) on the street at our favourite local chai shop (Shri Ragavendra Bangalore Iyengar‚Äôs Bakery and Sweets). We jumped into our minibus at 9am and headed off on our journey to the small town of Masinagudi.
It was a very steep descent out of mountains
column2: and it was a fantastic drive. We had to negotiate 36 hairpin bends
column3: and there were countless signs saying how many car accidents had occurred on each particular stretch of road. A few signs even had a running tally of how many people had died. This wasn‚Äôt the best reading for those who don‚Äôt like steep drops without guard rails. Ren had banned me from watching a TV program called ‚ÄúWorld‚Äôs Most Dangerous Roads‚Äù before we came to India ‚Äì I can now see why! Luckily we had a fantastic driver who knew the road inside out
column4: and he drove very carefully (slowing to a crawl on some particularly tight corners). There was also hardly any traffic
column5: which made a big difference. There was one occasion when the

column1: driver did worry me. We were on a steep and narrow stretch of road when all of a sudden he pointed and said ‚Äúelephant‚Äù. On the other side of the valley ‚Äì possibly a kilometre away ‚Äì he had spotted a few wild elephants grazing on the steep hillside. He stopped on the roadside for us to take a few long zoom photos. Ren was so happy to see a wild elephant
column2: but I just wanted the driver to concentrate more on the road and less on the periphery wildlife!

column1: We had a short photo stop at the Bison Valley viewing point before continuing on to Jungle Retreat
column2: our accommodation in Mudumalai National Park. We arrived at 10.30am
column3: dropped our bags in the dormitory we were sharing with eight others and dived into the cold pool that a few goats were drinking from. We sat in the hot sun
column4: sipped cold beer and took in the stunning view of Mt Nilgiri towering above us. This place was so incredibly relaxing!

column1: We had a buffet lunch at 1.30pm that comprised vegetarian spring rolls
column2: spinach with dahl (lentils)
column3: rajma curry (black eyed beans in a thick gravy sauce)
column4: beetroot porail

column1: (beetroot stir-fried in mustard and topped with grated coconut)
column2: roast potatoes
column3: mutton curry (goat is referred to as mutton in India)
column4: fried chicken
column5: watermelon raita (savoury watermelon yoghurt)
column6: rice and chapatti. I had everything from the buffet and went back three times ‚Äì piglet! We finished lunch at 2.30pm
column7: headed back to the pool and bathed in the sun.

column1: Coffee and biscuits were served at 4.30pm
column2: and at 5.30pm we jumped into an open-top jeep for a two hour ‚Äòsafari‚Äô of the surrounding forested areas. ‚ÄòSafari‚Äô is being used loosely here
column3: because we didn‚Äôt leave the bitumen once. However
column4: we saw Indian bison
column5: wild boar
column6: monkeys
column7: birds
column8: sambar deer and spotted deer. There was a whispered possibility that we would see an elephant
column9: but that quickly evaporated when we saw how many other open-top jeeps were driving around with tourists on ‚Äòsafari‚Äô. On the way back to our idyllic Jungle Retreat we picked up some beer and apple vodka from a heavily fortified bottle shop in one of the local villages.

column1: At 8pm we sat through a presentation by one of the Jungle Retreat owners on the flora and fauna of the area
column2: and how they had regenerated

column1: the previous agricultural land over an 18 year period to create a forest.

column2: we sat down to a buffet dinner at 8.30pm. We had kofta curry (meatball curry)
column3: fish curry
column4: urud dahl (black lentils)
column5: onion rings
column6: boondi raita (tiny fried chickpea flour balls with yoghurt)
column7: steamed vegetables
column8: baby potatoes
column9: roast chicken and butter rice. It was unbelievably good!

column1: After dinner we sat around a small bonfire drinking beer
column2: whisky and vodka under the stars until 11pm
column3: and then headed to our 10-bed dormitory to crash. It had been a fantastic travel day.

column1: The next day we were leaving Mudumalai National Park and travelling north to Mysore. We woke at 6.30am
column2: shared the three showers and toilets in the ten-person dormitory and headed out at 7.30am for a cultural walk around the local village area. We walked to the top of a solitary hill where a shrine to Shiva had been built
column3: and it provided a stunning 360 degree view around the local villages. The view from the top of the hill was incredible
column4: especially the breathtaking view of Mt Nilgiri in the early morning sun.

column1: We retraced our steps back to Jungle
Retreat and arrived at 9.30am. We were hungry and breakfast looked fantastic. We sat down to idlis (steamed cakes made from fermented rice and lentil batter) with sambar (thin vegetable curry)
column2: masala dosa (a dosa stuffed with a creamy mix of lightly cooked potatoes
column3: onions
column4: green chilli and spices)
column5: banana pancakes
column6: eggs and coffee. It was incredible
column7: and just what we needed after a two hour walk. We reluctantly left Jungle Retreat at 10.30am and continued our northward journey
column8: this time heading for Mysore.

column1: We woke up much earlier than we needed to
column2: and the Ooty morning air was clear but cold ‚Äì perfect weather for an early morning chai (tea). We walked past people cleaning the streets
column3: children in uniforms heading off to school and merchants slowly opening their shops. We went back to the chai wallah (tea seller) from the day before and had a quick but delicious glass of chai while standing in the sun like all the locals. Back at the hotel
column4: we packed hurriedly and piled into two separate six-seater four wheel drive cars. We were heading to the foothills of the Nilgiris Mountains where we were hoping to spot

column1: some wildlife in the jungles of Mudumalai National Park.
After the long and winding road we'd used on our upward journey into Ooty
column2: we were now taking a shorter but steeper route down from Ooty - which had 36 hairpin bends on a narrow road! The good news was that the views were spectacular
column3: we had a great driver
column4: and our car had Lee
column5: Kim
column6: Damien
column7: Brian and us...we travelled really well together and were never short of a joke that usually had us in stitches.

column1: Around one of those hairpin bends
column2: we stopped at a lookout point for beautiful views of the valleys and mountains surrounding us. We also witnessed a large local bus charging down the hairpin bends as if it was the size of a scooter. It made us feel rather queasy on behalf of the passengers in there.

column1: As we descended further into the valley
column2: our driver suddenly excitedly pointed into a distant hill where a wild elephant was grazing. It took us a few minutes to see it
column3: so we were very impressed that our driver had spotted it. And as excited as I was to see the wild elephant munching its

column2: I would have much preferred that the driver's eyes were firmly on the road!
the surroundings changed from cool luscious green to hot and humid arid brown. We drove deeper into the jungle and passed a large arched sign that announced the beginning of Mudumalai National Park.

column1: After driving for around two hours
column2: it was early afternoon when we arrived at the tiny town of Masinagudi
column3: and turned down a track towards the Jungle Retreat adjacent to Mudumalai National Park. Set against the peaks of the enchanting Nilgiri ranges
column4: Mudumalai National Park was picturesque beyond words. It used to be the Mysore Maharaja‚Äôs private hunting ground
column5: but was brought into India‚Äôs Project Tiger in 1974
column6: and it‚Äôs now supposed to be one of the best game sanctuaries in India to observe diverse wildlife.

column1: At the family run Jungle Retreat
column2: we were greeted by Rhea and Smriti. Although simple
column3: the Retreat is stunningly positioned under the mountains
column4: built of local materials and in colours that make it blend into the surrounds beautifully. There was a bar and dining area
column5: recreational facilities
column6: a variety of accommodation including small cottages
column7: a

column1: few fabulous looking tree houses and a dormitory style block. We were in the dormitory area which was large and comfortable. There were adjacent shower and toilet facilities to our room
column2: but they were somewhat open to the elements.
there was a safety briefing to sit through. Given we were in the middle of a National Park
column3: there were no fences and therefore no way to stop wildlife from entering the Retreat. We were warned against walking between our dormitory and the other public areas after dark if we didn‚Äôt have a guard escort. The owners of the Retreat had set up motion-sensor cameras around the property
column4: and later that evening they showed us a selection of the images that had been captured
column5: including elephants
column6: leopards and wild boar (the most likely
column7: dangerous and unpredictable animal we would come across). In light of our safety briefing
column8: those fabulously isolated cabins and tree houses weren't looking so inviting now.

column1: The Retreat came with six family dogs and three cats. One of the tabby cats was extremely friendly and very talkative
column2: and she followed us around. At one point she made herself at home on

column1: Andrew's bed while we were getting dressed
column2: which made me miss Mia very much. Of the dogs
column3: there was 14 year old blind and deaf Gunda who just slept in the sun outside the dining room
column4: three very playful dogs (my favourites being Scooter and Spud)
column5: a very playful young puppy who didn't stop long enough for me to see its name
column6: and one black dog who didn't like hanging out with the guests.

column1: Before lunch there was time for some lounging about at the infinity pool built into the rocks ‚Äì the pool was so lovely looking that even I couldn‚Äôt resist sitting in it. The afternoon was hot and humid
column2: and the pool could have been easily mistaken for a mirage amidst the cacti
column3: spindly brush and sandy dry soil... with the mountains framing the picture. The local herds of goats and cows used the pool as a drinking pond
column4: which should have grossed me out
column5: but strangely it didn't.

column1: All meals at the Retreat were served buffet-style
column2: and they were all incredibly delicious. For lunch we had vegetarian spring rolls
column3: spinach with dahl (lentils)
column4: rajma curry (black eyed beans in a thick gravy sauce)
column5: beetroot

column2: and topped with grated coconut)
column3: rasam (sour tamarind soup)
column4: roast potatoes
column5: mutton curry (goat is referred to as mutton in India)
column6: fried chicken
column7: watermelon raita (savoury watermelon yoghurt)
column8: rice and chapatti. As mentioned in our previous blog on Ooty
column9: we had planned on being vegetarian on the inland sections of this trip. However
column10: the meat dishes looked so good and were being cooked by the Retreat's chef
column11: so we made an exception. My favourite dishes were the beetroot porail and watermelon raita with rice. Dessert was a trifle of sorts (without the jelly component).

column1: After lunch we went back to the pool and sat around before our afternoon safari drive. By the time we got into the three safari jeeps at 5pm
column2: it had started to cool down to a pleasant temperature. Having grown up in Africa
column3: it‚Äôs a little strange for me that my first safari experience was in India. We‚Äôd barely begun the safari when one of the jeeps had to turn back to the closest village as Francis had succumbed to a stomach bug. The first among the group to go down...

column1: Andrew and I were in a jeep with

column2: Damien and Karni. We were on the lookout for tigers and leopards but actually only saw Indian bison
column3: sambar deer (they are huge!)
column4: herds of spotted deer
column5: wild boar
column6: a little rabbit
column7: grey langur monkeys
column8: birds and fabulous old world trees. The best hope of finding a tiger was apparently to listen for alarm calls from animals in the park
column9: then stop the jeep in a likely place and wait silently in the hope that the tiger chooses to pass our way. I wasn't convinced by this method. Why would any self-respecting tiger choose to cross a road right near a bunch of safari jeeps with humans and their clicking cameras? It wasn‚Äôt looking good for tiger spotting. Despite not seeing a single tiger or elephant
column10: driving slowly around an Indian forest in jeeps was in itself such a great experience that I almost didn‚Äôt care. Almost.

column1: As much I used to tease my Dad about his chocolate brown safari suit from the 1980s
column2: I wish safari suits were still in so I could have sported one and gone on safari in style. But in this age of practicality all we needed were sunglasses
column3: a hat
column4: sunscreen
column5: water

column1: a warmer top for when the sun went down and the all-important camera. Foot wear was a non-issue because for the majority of time we were just sitting in our safari jeep. The open safari jeep was heaps of fun
column2: but also very cold on the drive back.

column1: We stopped in Masinagudi on the way back to buy some alcohol as the Retreat wasn't really big on carrying a lot of stock. When we got back to the Retreat
column2: a bonfire had already been lit. We sat in front of it with a drink until dinner was ready. Kim and I have found a revoltingly sweet vodka called Magic Moments which we have chosen to make our adult drink of choice in India. One of the other guests (from Hyderabad) played Neil Diamond from his iPod... it wasn't as cheesy as it sounds. Ok it was. But we didn‚Äôt care.

column1: Dinner was another buffet. We had kofta curry (meatball curry)
column2: fish curry
column3: urud dahl (black lentils)
column4: onion rings
column5: boondi raita (tiny fried chickpea flour balls with yoghurt)
column6: steamed vegetables
column7: baby potatoes
column8: roast chicken and butter rice. Dessert was banoffee pie! It wasn‚Äôt the traditional English dessert I had

column1: envisaged ‚Äì but it had the required elements of bananas
column2: toffee and cream.

column1: We continued to sit around the bonfire after dinner
column2: and were joined by Rhea from reception who eventually (and very politely) told us when we had to wrap things up. We had to get a guard to walk us back to our lodgings. Some of the group were already in bed
column3: so it was a case of being very quiet while we showered and got ready for bed - a bit hard to do when you've got the giggles. The cold shower quickly knocked all the giggles right out of me though. The cold shower had also made me wide awake
column4: so I lay in the narrow creaky bed for a long time trying hard not to be a wriggle pot and wake everyone up.

column1: The dogs barked a few times through the night which was a sign that there were wild animals around. The only other night-time excitement was when someone (who shall remain nameless) nearly ‚Äòaccidently‚Äô climbed into an already occupied bed on their return from the bathroom. We will never know the real truth. üòä
join a two hour guided village walk at 7pm. Andrew
column2: Damien
column3: Brian
column4: Francis
column5: Anja and I walked out of the Retreat gate before it was fully light. On the way I looked back towards the Retreat and the mist clad peaks of the mountain range behind it were just starting to glisten with the first rays of the sun. My favourite doggies Scooter and Spud accompanied the group and provided protection against the village dogs
column6: wandering cows and any other animals they deemed to be a danger to us. The two young guides who led us didn't say a single word
column7: so it was more an escorted walk than a guided walk.

column2: we were far enough from any city that the air was fresh (but smoky from an occasional cooking fire)
column3: and it was so good to be walking again. We made good time walking across fields and across villages
column4: but the pace slowed right down when we hit a very steep hill with a temple on top.

column1: At the top of the hill the view was fabulous
column2: but the little Shiva temple was closed. We sat in the shade of the temple and

column1: regained our breath when Andrew realised that one of the young guides had set up the binoculars a bit further up the hill on a rocky outcrop. In all honesty I was quite happy to stay where I was
column2: but eventually everyone drifted up there
column3: so I followed. How glad I was that I did! Scooter had hung back at the temple with me
column4: and now walked over and stood on the very edge of the rocks looking down at the vast plains of the National Park below us. It provided a photo opportunity for my favourite photo of the trip to-date.

column1: The walk proved to be a real highlight! We saw an eagle (or a similar looking bird of prey)
column2: several other exotically feathered things that I couldn‚Äôt name
column3: huge brightly coloured Malabar squirrels and a few monkeys. The two villages we walked through seemed to be geared towards cattle rearing and also had lovely fenced vegetable gardens.

column1: We eventually returned to the Jungle Retreat where people were just sitting down to breakfast. Some of the group had gone on a bird watching walk
column2: while others had skipped all the early morning activities.

column1: so breakfast was very welcome. I had eggs on toast and a banana pancake
column2: while Andrew had idlis (steamed cakes made from fermented rice and lentil batter) with sambar (thin vegetable curry) and a masala dosa (a dosa stuffed with a creamy mix of lightly cooked potatoes
column3: onions
column4: green chilli and spices).

column1: The setting and quiet beauty of the Jungle Retreat was fantastic
column2: and I would highly recommend this spot to anyone who wanted to have a low key jungle experience. I will miss the food
column3: the relaxing atmosphere of sitting around the pool and the family dogs and cats!

column1: Next we travel north to the city of Mysore in Karnataka.

column2: once again beating the 5.30am call to prayer. We had a long travel day (seven and a half hours) ahead
column3: as we were leaving Kochi and travelling north to Ooty (or Ootacamund as it appears on most maps). We sat down to a plate of dosa (thin pancakes made from fermented rice and black lentils batter) with coconut chutney for breakfast at 7am. Bowls of fresh bananas and watermelon were on the table
column4: and I had a pot of masala chai (spiced sweet milky tea) while Ren had a tea. It was a great start to the day.

column1: We left our Fort Kochi homestay (Kaliveedu Lodge) at 7.45am and headed to the Ernakulam train station for the first of our two travel legs to Ooty ‚Äì a four hour train trip followed by a three and a half hour bus trip. The train station was reasonably small and easy to negotiate. The train was dilapidated with basic toilets
column2: but we were lucky to be in a second class cabin with air conditioning. Wallahs (sellers) carrying coffee
column3: chai (tea)
column4: rice with curries and deep fried snacks were walking through the cabins selling their wares

column1: dosa with coconut chutney and pickle
and I acclimatised myself to their incessant yelling of ‚Äúbiryani
column2: biryani
column3: biryani‚Äù and ‚Äúchai
column4: chai
column5: chai‚Äù over the next four hours. We left Kochi at 9am and embarked on our long journey north.

column1: I grabbed a masala chai from one of the chai wallahs (tea sellers) at 10.30am and it was fantastic. The gentle rocking of the train was mesmerising
column2: and I began to drift in and out of sleep and in and out of the numerous conversations of people around me until all I could hear was the distant white noise of voices.

column1: We arrived at Coimbatore train station at 1pm
column2: jumped into a minibus and travelled 15 minutes to Sree Annapoorna / Sree Gowrishankar
column3: our lunch stop. It was a fantastic place
column4: and we had unlimited rice and curries for $1.70 AUD (the spicy dahl was the highlight). This is how I‚Äôd always imagined Indian food. We ordered the ‚ÄòSouth Indian Meal‚Äô
column5: which arrived on a large round thali plate with rice in the middle and a number of different curries in small metal bowls around the outside The curries were dahl (lentils) with ghee (clarified butter)
column6: sambar (thin vegetable curry)
column7: special kulambu (spicy dhal based

column2: rasam (spicy tamarind broth)
column3: kootu (mixed vegetables in dhal sauce)
column4: curd (yoghurt)
column5: lime pickle and rice payasam (rice pudding with brown molasses
column6: coconut milk
column7: spices
column8: cashews and raisins). The plate was topped with a gigantic appalam (pappadam). The waiting staff walked around replenishing each curry as soon you finished eating it
column9: so you didn‚Äôt get the feeling that you were close to finishing your meal. Your plate always looked like you hadn‚Äôt started eating. We were in a noisy rest stop on the side of a busy road
column10: and we were the only non-locals. We were in travel heaven.

column1: We finished the meal at 2pm and had to cross a very busy road to get to the minibus. We were crossing together and the majority of traffic had stopped
column2: but one rogue motor bike was speeding through on the outside lane and Ren (who was in front) didn‚Äôt see him coming. We screamed
column3: Ren stopped and the motorbike screeched to a halt only centimetres from her feet. Disaster averted!

column1: We jumped in the minibus and started the second leg of our journey to the hill town of Ooty. We passed through highly populated city areas until we
slowly transitioned into rural India. The traffic madness began to subside and less and less people lined the roadside. Mountains loomed in front of us
column2: and I knew we had a long and winding road ahead. We‚Äôd been travelling since 9am
column3: and I began to wish I was still on the morning train (train travel is far more comfortable than sitting in a minibus climbing a mountain road).

column1: We had a quick stop around 3pm before setting off on our final assault on Ooty. We had another two hours of this spectacular (and at times terrifying) ascent into the greenery of Tamil Nadu‚Äôs higher plateau. We met public buses driving at break-neck speeds and we passed slow trucks on blind corners with steep drop-offs and no guard rails. We also had to stop for a wild elephant who had settled down in the middle of the road. The traffic build up was incredible
column2: so a group of truck and bus drivers tried to persuade him/her to walk a few metres to the steep terrain off the side of the road. When our wild elephant finally decided to move
column3: we continued through palm and banana plantations as we climbed to

column1: the hill station of Ooty (which is 2240 metres above sea level).

We finally arrived at Hotel Nahar Nilgiris at 5.30pm. It was cold ‚Äì really cold ‚Äì and the hotel room was icy. I quickly showered and piled on as many clothes as I could manage. It was hard to believe that nine hours ago we had been sweltering in the morning heat of Kochi.
We walked to Hotel Alagapuri Bar for some very welcome pre-dinner drinks. This was without doubt
column2: one of the seediest bars I‚Äôve ever been in
column3: but it was fantastic. A friendly guy served our drinks and made sure we had finger snacks on our table. It was very dark inside the tiny bar (which was ironically called a family bar)
column4: but our eyes acclimatised and we recovered from the day‚Äôs travels with lukewarm local beer. We eventually headed around the corner to the ‚ÄòNon-Veg‚Äô Hotel Durga and ordered from the ‚ÄòVeg‚Äô Spice Restaurant menu
column5: where we shared an aloo gobi masala (potato and cauliflower curry) with naans (leavened bread cooked in a wood fired oven) and chapathis (unleavened whole wheat flour flat bread
column6: cooked on a dry skillet). It was fantastic.

column1: We walked back to the hotel in the cold night air and settled into the hotel lobby. A fellow traveller had some whiskey which we all shared
column2: but the night manager informed us that the consumption of alcohol was not allowed in the hotel
column3: so we wrapped up the night and headed to our icy cold room. It had been a long but enjoyable travel day
column4: and we were well and truly ready for bed.

column1: The previous travel day had taken its toll ‚Äì we slept in! We woke at 6.30am to a freezing cold room. We walked out into the brisk morning air and wandered around the streets of Ooty. A few locals were standing around a tiny street shop
column2: and they called us over. We had a glass of chai on the street at Shri Ragavendra Bangalore Iyengar‚Äôs Bakery and Sweets. They were very friendly and the chai was very welcome and warming. We headed back to the hotel for breakfast at Hotel Nahar Nilgiris restaurant. I had the set dosa (dosa with coconut chutney
column3: sambar
column4: tomato and coriander curries) with cardamom chai (cardamom spiced tea)
column5: and it was fantastic.

column1: minibus and headed to the Highfield Tea Factory in Coonoor. On our way were drove through a military training facility
column2: and I was intrigued by the mix of military and tourist advertising banners that lined the road. We arrived at the tea factory at 10am and wandered around the plantation before touring the factory itself. At the end of the tour we sampled a few tea varieties and picked up a packet of premium tea
column3: a bag of ginger sweets and a bag of sugared fennel sweets (often offered in a small bowl at the end of a meal). We jumped back into the minibus at 11.30am and headed to the Coonoor train station to catch what the locals referred to as a ‚Äòtoy train‚Äô back to Ooty. We picked up some samosas (fried conical pastries filled with spiced potatoes and peas) and masala chai on the platform while we waited
column4: and they were surprisingly good. We clambered onto the train at 12.30pm for our scenic trip back to Ooty
column5: arriving at Udhagamandalam station at 1.45pm. We walked to the entrance of the Botanical Gardens and had a lemon tea at Kashali Cafe before heading into the gardens. The gardens

column2: but they were tranquil and had a great family atmosphere. We wandered through the markets outside the garden gates before walking back to the main township of Ooty.

column1: We had a quick drink at our favourite family bar (Hotel Alagapuri Bar) before jumping into auto rickshaws (motorised tricycles with a passenger cabin) and heading out to dinner at the Fortune Resort Hotel. One of our fellow travellers (Damien from Ireland) was celebrating his 50th birthday
column2: so we picked up a cake on the way. Balancing a decorated cake on my knees in an auto rickshaw on a bumpy road with two other people is not easy. The resort restaurant was comfortable and plush. I had the tandoori aloo (potatoes stuffed with cashews
column3: green chillies and coriander and baked in a tandoor oven) and Ren had the kadai ke karishme (Indian cottage cheese
column4: mushrooms and mixed vegetables in spicy tomato onion gravy) which we shared with rice and naans.

column1: It was a cold trip back to the hotel in the auto rickshaw
column2: so we gathered in Damien‚Äôs bedroom for a whiskey
column3: as we were unable to drink alcohol in the lobby (which had an open

column1: fire). Turning 50 is a big milestone
column2: and it had been great to share it with Damien in Ooty.

column1: It was an early start in Kochi
column2: but as usual the various muezzins in the mosque minarets meant our alarm was not needed. We were leaving the hot and humid coastal city of Fort Kochi in Kerala and travelling north to one of India‚Äôs more famous hill stations
column3: Ootacamund in Tamil Nadu. Ootacamund or Ooty is one of the three hill stations in the Nilgiri ranges (Blue Mountains) and has much colder weather.

column1: The Kaliveedu Lodge breakfast of dosas (thin pancakes made from fermented rice and black lentils batter
column2: cooked on a griddle) with creamy coconut chutney and a dollop of spicy pickle was delicious. It was a bit of a rushed breakfast
column3: as I had been too tired to pack the night before and now I only had 15 minutes before we left for the station.

column1: Our packs were loaded onto a convoy of cars for the 30 minute trip from the Kaliveedu Lodge to the train station in Ernakulam
column2: which is on the Kochi mainland. We were catching a train for the

column1: four hour trip to Coimbatore. It was a Sunday morning and the station wasn‚Äôt overly busy at 9am. The train was already on the platform and we boarded straight away.

We travelled in the train‚Äôs second class with AC chair carriage. It was comfortable and clean-ish. Once the train had started moving the aircon kicked into overdrive and I had to do my best impersonation of an Eskimo with my hoodie and scarf to keep warm. What is with Asia's confusion with air conditioning and refrigerant??
The train was full of action ‚Äì there were wallahs (sellers) constantly walking up and down the carriage aisles offering chai (tea)
column2: coffee
column3: cold drinks
column4: vadais (fried savoury lentils fritters)
column5: biryani (dish of spiced rice and meat or vegetables) and other snacks. We were still full from breakfast so we didn't buy any snacks
column6: but I was very tempted. We bought a chai which was totally delicious and only 7 rupees for a small cup. After I caught up on my notes
column7: I napped for a little while as the train snaked itself into the hills. Between naps
column8: people watching and the wallahs with their calls of chai-chai-chai and kopi-kopi-kofffeeeee
column9: the trip

column1: We arrived in Coimbatore at 1pm and transferred to a small non-AC minibus for the three hour drive to Ootacamund. We first drove through the outskirts of Coimbatore and the roads were a concrete construction maze.
We stopped for lunch at a roadside restaurant on the edge of the city
column2: part of the Annapoorna chain. It was a vast cafeteria
column3: and the service was very quick. We all ordered the vegetarian thali meals
column4: which made us realise we'd been having the sanitised/tourist versions of it in Kochi. This was the real deal. A thali meal involves a large circular tin plate filled up with various versions of dhal (lentils)
column5: spicy vegetable curries
column6: curd
column7: pickles
column8: pappadams and rice. We were free to devour the dishes in whatever way we preferred (and devoured we did!). The unique thing about this meal was the waiters who walked around the restaurant
column9: constantly adding more curries onto the plate... and there was also a steady flow of rice. I‚Äôd read and heard of thali meals
column10: but no one had mentioned the free flowing food.

column1: Apart from having seafood and fish curries in Kochi (on the west coast) and Mamallapurum
(when we get to the east coast)
column2: we had decided to be vegetarian on this trip in India. When vegetarian meals are cooked so well
column3: it's so easy to be vegetarian. After that fantastic meal
column4: we continued our journey.

column1: We have been on many scary roads throughout Asia
column2: but comparatively I would have to say that one has not experienced the true meaning of ‚Äòterrifying‚Äô until one has travelled on the roads of India! The roads themselves are not in bad condition; it‚Äôs just that the drivers are beyond crazy! The minibus drove through small villages and farmlets as it made its way towards the Nilgiri Hills. The road started getting curvy
column3: and then turned into a tortuous series of hairpin bends up into the hills towards Ootacamund. The view was stunning
column4: but I kept my eyes on the road as the minibus wound back and forth
column5: overtaking trucks and jeeps on blind corners at every opportunity with an ever-present soundtrack of honking of horns. There was a large sign forbidding speeding around corners
column6: and it was dented and nearly bent in two
column7: quite possibly by a vehicle hurtling around that corner. Oh the irony. The trip was exciting

column2: downright scary and slightly sickening all at once.

column1: The trip was supposed to take three hours but took a bit longer due to the traffic we encountered when we had to stop for a wild elephant on the road. The poor elephant had probably been trying to cross the hilly road but couldn't due to the constant stream of traffic in both directions. By the time we got to the part of the road where it was
column2: it had gone down an embankment and looked stuck
column3: dazed and confused ‚Äì but was still munching away on some leaves. We also saw a lot of monkeys ‚Äì bonnet macaques ‚Äì who were casually strolling along the road
column4: seemingly not thinking that the cars and trucks were a threat.

column1: Ootacamund is commonly known as Ooty
column2: and when it was a British hill station it was known as Snooty Ooty (it is thought that the game of snooker was named and possibly even invented here). Ooty was a popular summer retreat in the time of the British Raj
column3: famous for exclusive polo gatherings and elite parties (thus the ‚Äòsnooty‚Äô in snooty ooty). At first glance Ooty didn‚Äôt seem to be

column2: with the usual crazy traffic
column3: unplanned streets and random concrete buildings in various states of construction. However
column4: there were spectacular looking tea plantations that dotted the surrounding hills
column5: and a cool ‚ÄòToy Train‚Äô (miniature steam train) that ran through the Nilgiri Mountains. There were also (surprisingly) many chocolate and sweet shops. The town‚Äôs sales pitch / brochures seem to focus very heavily on its old British Hill Station notoriety
column6: even though its street culture is decidedly Indian. We were in Tamil Nadu now
column7: but Tamil wasn‚Äôt the only language I heard spoken
column8: possibly because Ooty sits close to the three state borders of Tamil Nadu
column9: Karnataka and Kerala.

column1: We checked into our hotel ‚Äì Hotel Nahar Nilgiris
column2: which looked quite grand on approach. The rooms were very comfortable and large
column3: but given it was quite cold here with no in-room heating
column4: marble floors probably weren't the best choice of flooring in the bathrooms.

column1: After we checked in we both had to have hot showers to thaw after the sudden chill of climbing into the mountains. We met at the lobby at 7pm for dinner
column2: but we decided to go to dinner via a bar.

column1: Finding a local bar in Ooty was no mean feat. The first one we went to was deemed too seedy
column2: so we found ourselves at Hotel Alagapuri Bar
column3: where Kim and I were the only females in the whole place (even in the oddly named Family Bar area). We had far more pre-dinner drinks than we had planned on having
column4: and by the time we got to dinner at Hotel Durga we were all very happy campers. Andrew and I ordered from the ‚Äòveg‚Äô menu (from the restaurant next door) and shared an aloo gobi masala (potato and cauliflower curry) with naans (fluffy leavened bread traditionally cooked in a wood fired tandoor oven) and chapathis (unleavened whole wheat flour flat bread cooked on a dry skillet and then browned and puffed up on an open flame). The masala chai was one of the best we've had to date. This restaurant offered fantastic food in the most nondescript of spaces. We would never have thought to try it without Karni's inside knowledge. It was a most fabulous night with Karni
column5: Rao
column6: Damien
column7: Brian
column8: Kim and Lee ‚Äì the perfect way for us to celebrate Damien's birthday eve. We'd had such a

column1: good night that we barely noticed the temperature had dropped to about two degrees as we stumbled back down the hill to our hotel.

Damien had some duty free whiskey in his pack and he had the great idea of sneakily congregating at reception for some drinks. We ordered cokes to surreptitiously get glasses and then poured shots of Jameson whiskey into them. We felt like a bunch of teenagers hiding drinks from the adults. However
column2: we clearly didn't do a very good job
column3: because the hotel manager came over and informed us that the hotel lobby wasn't a licensed area and we'd have to move on. It must have been our raucous laughter and thigh slapping that gave it away.

column1: After a cold night huddled under two blankets each
column2: we met Brian in the lobby at 7am
column3: walked the streets and had a chai at one of the many shops lining the street. It was a very brisk morning and the locals were standing in groups wherever there was a sunny patch on the road. The chais were steaming hot and very welcome. We asked the friendly man at the chai shop where he would suggest for

column2: but none of his suggested eateries opened before 8:30am.

column1: We walked back to the hotel and joined Lee
column2: Kim and Damien for breakfast at the hotel's Garden Restaurant. I wasn't hungry and just opted for two cardamom chais (cardamom spiced teas). They were really delicious. Andrew had a dosa with the usual accompaniments of chutneys and sambars (thin vegetable curries).

column1: We were ready for departure as scheduled at 9am. There were two six-seater four wheel drives to take us around for the day. I was excited
column2: as it was the morning of ‚ÄòThe Ooty Tea Party Day‚Äô! Well
column3: I probably should explain ‚Äì we were checking out a tea plantation and factory and catching the famous miniature Toy Train from Coonoor back to Ooty... and given my love of Alice in Wonderland-esque fancy
column4: it seemed like a logical name for the day. Coonoor is another hill station
column5: but it looked more densely populated than Ooty.

column1: Our first stop was at a lookout in Wellington
column2: a settlement between Ooty and Coonoor. There were stunning views of the lush green valley spread around us. We got back into the four wheel drives and drove to our next stop

column1: the nearby Swarmy and Swarmy Tea Plantation and Highfield Tea Factory.
Before I write about the tea plantation visit
column2: I want to share something that had astounded me when I read it... India is the top consumer of tea in the world
column3: but this wasn‚Äôt always the case. While tea is native to the subcontinent
column4: it wasn‚Äôt until after the British had established plantations to supply the UK that the Indian tea plant was cultivated! Apparently for decades nearly all of India‚Äôs tea was exported
column5: and it wasn‚Äôt until the late 1800s that the Indian Tea Association was formed to promote tea drinking within the country. And they‚Äôve certainly done a good job!

column1: Wherever we have been so far
column2: we‚Äôve never been far from a chai wallah (tea seller) with trays of sweet milky tea in steaming glasses. They say that each Indian region has a different way they like to drink their tea ‚Äì here in the south they predominantly like their chai with just milk and sugar
column3: double brewed with a fistful of black tea. However
column4: influences from the northeast have brought in the masala chai (spiced sweet milky tea) which can be infused with all

column1: or any of the following spices ‚Äì ginger
column2: clove
column3: cardamom
column4: cinnamon and black pepper. I have also been told that in the north they have a ginger version that is finished off with a sprinkle of pink salt or threads of saffron. I really hope I get to try that!

column2: back to the tea plantation visit in Coonoor. Tea plantations are set out similarly to vineyards ‚Äì on steep hillsides so that there is adequate drainage. Tea plants are actually tea trees that are manicured to remain as bushes (similar to maintaining a bonsai tree but on a larger scale). Scattered among the tea bushes were white oak trees that absorb a significant amount of water during the wet season and release it in the dry season. The oak trees are also harvested for firewood.

column1: When we got there the tea pickers were having their morning break on the slopes close to the factory. They were sitting in the shade of the tea bushes with little silver tumblers of tea. They were very accommodating about being photographed. We learnt about white
column2: green and black tea
column3: including their differences
column4: benefits
column5: qualities and tastes. The factory machinery wasn't operating

column1: as they hadn't picked enough tea over the weekend
column2: but we still got a tour of the plant ‚Äì from sorting to drying to packaging the tea. In the depths of the factory a man was sitting on the floor in the packaging area
column3: and he was covered in the fine orange-brown tea dust that seemed to have settled on everything in the factory.

column1: Finally it was time to taste the products. Tea purists
column2: you may wish to avert your eyes. The teas came in plain
column3: masala (mixed spices)
column4: ginger or chocolate varieties. There was an expensive white tea as well
column5: but they weren‚Äôt handing out freebies of that one. The chocolate tea was surprisingly good (made by mixing cocoa into the leaves)
column6: but the masala tea and ginger tea were not that brilliant. We bought some black tea to take home with us for elevenses. üòä

column1: We were then dropped off at Coonoor Station for the Toy Train ride. There were several small blue carriages lined on the very narrow tracks
column2: looking as if they were waiting for the Fat Controller to arrive. Our little nephew who loves Thomas the Tank Engine would have been in heaven.

column1: We took advantage of the platform catering service... one beaming chai wallah was doing a roaring trade in drinks and food out of a little stall. I thought I was buying one samosa (fried conical pastries filled with spiced potatoes and peas) for 20 rupees
column2: but turned out I got a pack of five for 20 rupees! And they were delicious.

column1: The Toy Train is apparently usually packed
column2: but when the little blue train pulled into the station
column3: at least two carriages were completely empty. We settled into the hour-long ride to Ooty with one half of the carriage taken up by a group visiting from Hyderabad. We were as fascinated by them as they were of us
column4: but we stared less (I hope!). They asked to sit and pose for photographs with a few of us
column5: and in hesitant English one of the guys suggested that we should definitely visit Hyderabad because it was beautiful and hot ‚Äì 'no cold cold like this'.

column1: The train ride was unexpectedly a highlight of the day. This line is part of the Nilgiri Mountain Railway
column2: and the little train huffed and puffed and took us on a steep ride through

column1: forests and winding tunnels cut into the beautiful mountain side.

column2: the afternoon was pretty laid back. We were dropped off outside the Botanical Gardens where we had drinks at a cafe before we wandered around the grounds. I don‚Äôt wish to be mean
column3: but it was a bit of a stretch to call it a Botanical Garden (especially when I‚Äôd paid for a camera ticket and wasn‚Äôt inspired to take many photos at all). It would be very fair to call it a beautiful garden/park
column4: and there were many local families who had settled down on the lawns with picnics which gave it a very friendly atmosphere. We then explored the slightly smelly market stalls in the surrounding streets... where there were garlands of green and yellow bananas
column5: piles of carrots
column6: radishes and green mangoes
column7: and corn and raw peanuts ready for roasting on the open grills.

column1: We then walked back towards our hotel with a scheduled stop at Hotel Alagapuri's Family bar to have a few drinks for Damien's birthday. As usual a few drinks turned into quite a few drinks
column2: and we had to hurry back to get ready for dinner.

column1: Later that evening we boarded auto rickshaws (motorised tricycles with a passenger cabin) for the short but cold drive to Fortune Resort Hotel. It was set in a lovely old building with high ceilings
column2: chandeliers and grand staircases. The consensus around the table was that dinner wasn't as fabulous as had been expected
column3: but our vegetarian dishes of tandoori aloo (potatoes stuffed with cashews
column4: green chillies and coriander and baked in a tandoor oven) and kadai ke karishme (Indian cottage cheese
column5: mushrooms and mixed vegetables in spicy tomato onion gravy) were quite delicious.

column2: Andrew
column3: Brian and I had trawled a few cake shops until Karni found a suitably showy white chocolate cake for Damien's birthday. The cake came out of the restaurant kitchen with dimmed lights and candles ablaze. We were so happy to have been able to be part of Damien's 50th birthday in India
column4: and dinner at the hotel was a lovely way to finish our two day stay in Ooty.

column1: We had intended to go back to the Family Bar for drinks but it was closed
