column1: Fast facts about Mahabilipuram: "" Mahabalipuram is located right on the Coromandel Coast next to the Bay of Bengal. It was a well established sea port during the 7th and 10th centuries of the Pallava dynasty
column2: and has flourished accordingly.

column1: This city was actually the 2nd capital of the Pallavas. It was originally named after the rude
column2: cruel
column3: and arrogant King Mahabali who was killed during a fierce battle

column1: by Lord Vishnu at that location. It was named by the people more out of gratitude that the heartless king was killed there than out of respect upon his death for his leadership.
During the rule of the Pallavas
column2: new styles of art and architecture were pioneered. Mahabalipuram is where they tried and then exhibited their new artistic and architectural creations. As a result
column3: the area is brimming with rock-cut caves and numerous temples. In fact
column4: this region is often referred to as an open museum. Some of the temples were even carved out of one enormous rock rather than simply constructed out of rock. Not much pillaging has occurred here over the centuries
column5: since the wealth of the Pallavas was never flaunted
column6: so the temples are well preserved. ""

you know

If you want to read more on the temples

column1: The Shore Temple occupies a most extraordinary site at the very margin of the Bay of Bengal so that at high tide the waves sweep into it and the walls. For this reason their sculptures
column2: have been eroded by the winds and waves of thirteen centuries.

column1: The Shrines In The Shore Temple
There are 3 shrines in the Shore Temple. Two of them are of Saiva and the third is of Vaishnava
column2: with an image of Lord Anantasayi made of live rock. There are Vimanas over the Saiva (also spelt as Shaiv or Shaiva) shrines
column3: but none over the third; it seems to have disappeared with time. Built by Narasimha Varman II Rajasimha
column4: the maker of the Kailasanatha temple in Kanchipuram in the 8th century

column1: The rickshaw began as a two or three-wheeled passenger cart
column2: called a pulled rickshaw
column3: generally pulled by one man with one passenger. The first known use of the term was in 1887.[1] Now there are also the cycle rickshaws
column4: also called pedicabs
column5: auto rickshaws and solar rickshaws. Pulled rickshaws created a popular form of transportation
column6: and a source of employment
column7: within Asian cities in the 19th century. Their popularity declined as cars
column8: trains and other forms of transportation became widely available. Auto rickshaws are becoming more popular in some cities in the 21st century as an alternative to taxis because of their low cost.

column2: myself and seven fellow dancers travelled to Chennai for a four day night shoot. Chennai is a city in South India and the fourth largest in the country. As we flew in I could see that the buildings of the city were all different colours and fairly low in height - a nice change from Mumbai's maze of beige/cream high rise apartment blocks. On the drive from the airport to our hotel I also noticed there were loads of cows wandering around at the edges and sometimes on the busy roads. Unlike the black and white dairy cows I am used to seeing at home
column3: these were huge creatures with humps on their backs
column4: folds of extra skin underneath their necks and huge horns which were painted red. I have seen a few cows like this in Mumbai
column5: but here they seemed to be everywhere! Unfortunately
column6: as I was shooting a film song 6pm - 6am each night and then sleeping most of the day
column7: I didn't really get a chance to see much more of Chennai
column8: however the set we were working on was beautiful.

column1: Kanniyakumari is in the state of Tamilnadu. It can be included in the Madurai-Rameshwaram-Kanniyakumari circuit or perhaps easier option is to go via Trivandrum / Kovalam. From Kovalam
column2: the distance is just 90 Km but like most of the places in India
column3: the distance should be measured in time and not in kilometres. It takes three hours. We had omitted local sightseeing in Trivandrum to include Kanniyakumari.

column1: Vivekananda Rock is the main attraction of the Kanniyakumari. The name of the place is derived from the temple of ‚ÄòKanniyakumari‚Äô ‚Äì Parvati. Gandhi memorial is another place visited by tourists.

Island of Vivekananda Rock is about half a kilometre off the mainland shore (southern-most tip of India) and can be reached only through boat service run by the port administration. Mainly because it was festival season
column2: the rush was extraordinary with a queue of about 1.5 Km to the ticket window (Rs. 34 per person
column3: return fare). It took 3 hours in the sun to reach the ticket counter. Ticket can also be obtained without waiting in the queue on some higher payment (Rs. 169s ‚Äì official rate). The sad part of the story was

column1: not waiting in the queue but the fact that tickets at higher rate were available and we didn‚Äôt know. The information is not displayed anywhere except at the ticket counter ‚Äì which you reach only after waiting in the queue! It is not displayed even at the gate of the port. Communication with local people is very difficult as very few people speak or understand Hindi.
Apart from historical significance of the Vivekananda Rock
column2: cleanliness at the Memorial was noticeable in spite of thousands visiting the memorial on that day. There are several shops selling books and other memoires of Vivekananda. There is a meditation hall. Indiscipline of tourists was visible here. People just don‚Äôt understand the meaning or significance of the place they are visiting. Jostling and cell phone rings violated the atmosphere in the Meditation Hall.

column1: Opposite the Memorial is Kanniyakumari Mandapam. Here there is a rock with natural shape of foot print ‚Äì supposed to be foot print of Goddess Parvati who did tapasya at this spot to marry Shiva.

column2: on another Island
column3: there is a huge statue of Tamil poet and Philospher
column4: Thiruvalluvar.

Lord Siva is in the pose as performing Ananda Thandava (Nataraja) and left to the idol he is believed to be in continuous dance with his consort deity Sivakami Amman. A curtain covers this space which is known as Chidambara Rahasya
column2: parting the curtain during rituals represents removal of ignorance by revealing Lord‚Äôs presence.

column1: my first trip to Chennai was after the disastrous event at Bangalore and I arrived by an early morning flight and left for the guest house only to be told that I had been shifted to another guest house and of course because of the event the previous day I hadn't checked my mails so words were exchanged with travel desk but it didn't make much difference. In India we have a saying "" Whatever Happens happens for the best"" I'm not sure if it originated in India but we do believe in it a lot. the next guest house was this amazing house somewhere in the best locality in Chennai maybe altamount Road and it was beautiful. It was meant for the likes of the Chairman of the Company and here I was an assistant manager staying in it.

I left for the Park where the event was supposed to take place and our models had come from Bangalore along with the event organisers. column2: we took a quick walk through Soi Cowboy
column3: an area of Bangkok maybe 100 metres long with numerous bars on each side
column4: there must be 40 or 50 easy. Each one has Texan Cowboy style girls outside offering the

column1: usual things they do here. They aren‚Äôt too annoying like they can be in other places which makes the walk through not too painful. We had a drink in a British pub around the corner and then I headed back to my hostel.

First thing this morning I headed back to the VFS Indian Visa office to re-submit my passport. As I took it with me last week to go back to Cambodia I had to obviously hand it back in again for my visa to be granted. After this I went back to the hostel and got back into bed. I had no plans so figured I might as well.

I woke up maybe 3 hours later not feeling very well. I had a banging headache as well as starting to suffer from a fever. I was going from hot to cold very quickly and it was doing my head in. With no plans I decided more bed was in order. I popped over to the 7/11 to get some paracetamol to cure my head but this failed miserably.
I did nothing with the rest of
the day except to try and get better
column2: this however did not happen.

column1: The past 3 days I have summed up into one report as I‚Äôve done pretty much nothing. I went into the visa office on Thursday afternoon still feeling like death and after being caught in a mental thunderstorm wasn‚Äôt feeling any better about things. I was told my passport had not been delivered as it was raining which is a belter of an excuse. I managed to get there so there is no reason someone in a car or mototaxi delivering the passports couldn‚Äôt. I went back to the hostel to resume my meeting with my bed. I took more pain killers but these were starting to have further affects being upsetting my stomach
column2: my back and neck were also starting to ache at this point.

column1: On Friday I got my passport back
column2: visa all sorted at last and I went back to hostel to relax for a couple hours. Early afternoon I met up with my mate Greg
column3: a lad who now works in Bangkok but I went to

column1: high school with. I haven‚Äôt seen him since maybe 2005 since school so was good to have a catch up. We grabbed some lunch and spent the afternoon wandering around a number of Bangkok‚Äôs malls as they have air con and it was really hot out. My fever and headache‚Äôs had pretty much subsided by now but my neck was so stiff I couldn‚Äôt turn it and my back very nearly collapsed on a visit to the bathroom. My body felt completely broken. It‚Äôs pretty lucky I was on a lazy week as if I had things to do I‚Äôd have been in serious problems. Myself and Greg spent around 5 hours catching up and then I headed back to the hostel covered in tiger balm to try and relieve my neck pain.
I woke up on Saturday feeling better
column2: my neck and back were improved although still sore but I was feeling far better about things. I was online chatting to my mate Dave
column3: who I‚Äôve templed visited and drank heavily with in Siem Reap in mid March online and we were both in Bangkok so decided to meet up. We picked a MRT station and a time.

column1: I headed there at the time and so did Dave but somewhere along the lines we obviously ended up waiting in different places
column2: both assuming the place we were was the correct one. After an hour passed I headed back to the hostel. It was quite annoying that we never got the chance to meet up as we had a good time in Cambodia together
column3: but I was in no state for a session and I know that‚Äôs what Dave ended up having
column4: so I avoided having the temptation. I spent the evening in my hostel to avoid Songkran going on in the streets.

column1: Songkran is the massive water fight that happens in Thailand around the 13th/14th and following days every year to celebrate in the New Year. This is normally something I‚Äôd be up for although it does seem a bit of a daft event. After one bucket of water one is wet so after that one can‚Äôt get wetter so heads home and gets changed. At least in India at something like Holi and the coloured flour they get covered in you can change colour throughout the day etc and seems more interesting to me. Having been
ill I decided it was a decent idea to stay clear of this so stayed indoors. I spent the evening watching Liverpool on the tv so once I was bored stupid I headed to bed.

I lingered around the hostel today after doing a bit of shopping for a few pieces I needed. I then followed the formula 1 on the computer before heading out to Don Mueang Airport. I was to fly to Chennai in India
column2: formally Madras. Check in was amusing
column3: mainly for the fact that I reckon every other Indian person checking in was also checking in a 40 inch minimum flat screen tv. Now I have no idea what was going on here
column4: why this was happening but I imagine the guys loading the stuff onto the plane thought they were working for Samsung. This seemed very odd to me.

column1: The flight was fine and then I arrived. I realised on the plane that I had no money in my account and needed to get online to transfer some. On arrival in Chennai I then found out nowhere had wifi. This was a problem
I managed to get a price for a taxi and off we went. I got him to stop at an ATM to have a look at my account. I had just enough to cover a taxi and my room for the night luckily
column2: so I could get online and transfer some money. The hotel was pretty horrible and the room wasn‚Äôt ready
column3: this being 11pm at night
column4: also 2 doors down there were 8 men in a room having a curry sleepover it seemed
column5: there were also various old gentlemen walking around in just towels. I soon got into my room and locked the door and went to sleep
column6: I wanted out soon as possible.

column1: I woke up and checked out
column2: headed to the bus stop I was told to. The bus turned up
column3: I asked the driver if it was the right one
column4: he shook his head and drove off
column5: whilst another passenger waved at me to say no
column6: go away. Hello India. I was not feeling it at all. I headed back to the hotel and asked them to book me a taxi
column7: he quoted me a

column2: way more than it should be but I said ok and sat down. 30 mins later I was getting fed up
column3: I asked again and was told they didn‚Äôt order it because they thought I wasn‚Äôt going to pay it. The place was run by complete idiots. The guy arrived in a string vest to drive me into town
column4: he spoke no English but tried anyways
column5: which just frustrated me. We got there in the end after asking at least 5 people for directions and I checked in. My new room was actually worse than the last one
column6: my bed also being maybe 5 foot 6 inches max so my feet would have to be off the side
column7: great!

column1: I was in close proximity to the Chennai cricket ground which is my sole reason for being in India
column2: the follow the IPL for a month or so
column3: I have no other interest in India apart from to see the Taj Mahal and eat the food. I headed off to the ground to buy a ticket for tonights game. I asked the security guards where I could get one from
column4: they said maybe gate 3. I started walking that

column2: I struggle to believe that‚Äôs his real name) pulled up and stopped me
column3: asking if I worked for Chennai Super Kings (CSK). Maybe it was because I was in all sports wear and being white he must of thought I was part of the staff. Obviously this is not the case and I told him that
column4: I said I was after a ticket. He made a couple calls which looked promising then it fell through. I told him they‚Äôd said gate 3 to me so I hopped on his bike and he drove me round
column5: I bought my ticket and that was sorted. He then took me for a spin along the promenade of the beach
column6: this apparently being the longest/biggest beach in the world. From the promenade to the sea is easily over 100 metres
column7: huge beach. He was off to the cinema and I wanted food so we went to the mall and I got my first Indian food
column8: chicken biryani with rice
column9: side serving of more chicken
column10: other bits and a drink
column11: 200 rupees (¬£2.50) an absolute bargain. He then guided me the way back to my hotel. I

column1: went back got changed and headed to the match. Johnson was a class act
column2: we sat down whilst I ate and had a chat etc. He gave me his number so if I can be bothered to get a sim card will get in touch
column3: the likelihood of me paying for a sim card to do that are not so high though. Maybe I‚Äôll bump into him at the cricket.

column1: The match was good and the atmosphere unreal. It was sit where you like so plenty of people moved about. One guy sat in front of me at one point was dancing bollywood style every single ball
column2: if a boundary was scored he was on the chairs giving it absolute beans. I‚Äôve not seen that at home before and I spent most the match laughing away. The fans are brilliant
column3: it certainly adds something to the game.

column1: After this I wandered back to my hotel past many many cows and people asleep in the middle of roads
column2: and these are busy roads
column3: with people lying asleep on the sides of them
column4: while a cow eats away at what little belongings they have left. It‚Äôs a weird set up here. The place is very dirty and very poor. I am hoping all of India isn‚Äôt as depressing as here
column5: otherwise it‚Äôll be a long month. Off to Bangalore for some more cricket tomorrow.

column2: depois entranha-se.
sujas

column23: mulheres a carregar pesados fardos de brita num estaleiro
column24: o inistente condutor de rickshaw (Hello rickshaw?) de camisa beige

column1: Mistura viva de uma grande diversidade que fala
column2: mais ruidosa que mil buzinas e tuc-tucs
column3: mais picante que um caril
column4: mais colorida e entrelacada que as voltas de um sari
column5: mais cheirosa que o lixo fetido das ruas ou que sandalo ou canela. O que vi foi a Terra a gritar. Os aleijados
column6: as criancas
column7: os agricultores nos arrozais
column8: os pequenos negocios
column9: os templos
column10: os animais na selva
column11: a agua das moncoes o repique excitado da tabla - talvez a terra mais densamente povoada e mais diversa do planeta a gritar - VIDA!

column2: depois de devorar varios tipos caril ao pequeno almoco e deixar
column3: humilhada no prato
column4: uma tosta branca com manteiga.

column1: After nearly a month I am convinced of one thing. This country is bananas. Within the space of 10 minutes you can run through a series of emotions along the lines of extreme confusion
column2: hysterical laughter
column3: ‚Äòget me on the next plane‚Äô
column4: desire to punch someone in the face and ‚ÄòI am never leaving‚Äô. I am strongly considering having a t-shirt made emblazoned with the following phrases that seem to be all that is required for general conversation:

column2: simply:

column1: That is no to rickshaw after just getting out of a rickshaw
column2: no to hotel after have just walked out of the entrance to hotel where am clearly staying
column3: no to a picture with creepy Indian man. Endless uses.

column1: In other news we are very settled into our Ashwini life. It is amazing how quickly things which at first seem totally alien become routine-I daily have to remind myself that showering with a bucket whilst staring at mountains with a soundtrack of drums and prayer calls is not normal! Having said that have still not fully adjusted to the happy family of cockroaches living in the fridge‚Ä¶We also took issue with the toddler-sized dead rat directly in front of the hospital which we pointed out might be slightly off-putting to patients. This was followed by a passionate debate in our house about what to do with said rat. UK suggestion: throw it into the forest where it can rot away/be eaten. US suggestion: douse with alcohol
column2: set alight where it is
column3: if the bones aren‚Äôt burnt to ash crush them by hand. Indian suggestion: put in ‚Äòincinerator‚Äô which is actually oven owned by Irish doctor. UK suggestion wins. Go figure.

column1: We are still seeing some incredibly weird and wonderful medicine including a man who was wheeled in totally unresponsive
column2: head flopping all over the show
column3: after a huge night of drinking. We thought he was done for. Nandekumar casually finished his consultation and wandered over. He was convinced the problem was low glucose but naturally the machine to test this was out of battery so he just went with his gut and gave him some IV dextrose (basically sugar in vein) and it was genuinely like he had risen from the dead. Within about 3 seconds. Was incredible.

column1: It hasn‚Äôt all been miracles unfortunately. The most difficult thing we have found is watching people undergo procedures which without question would be done under general anaesthetic in the UK-this is just not an option here as they don‚Äôt have a resident anaesthetist or the resources. We saw a man with awful 2nd degree burns to his leg from a kerosene lamp who needed the necrotic
column2: infected skin removed. I shall spare you all the details but let‚Äôs just say if certain patients within the NHS saw what he went through they might think twice before moaning ‚Ä¶

column1: Han and I are doing a project suggested by Shyla looking into why tribal women have their contraceptive coils removed prematurely. The general conclusion seems to be that they take them out when they want another child (pretty reasonable really) but it has been so interesting to speak to the women about this subject which still a huge taboo. Basically the tribal women tend to be aware of three types of contraception: staying away from their men
column2: the copper coil and sterilisation. None that we have spoken to have ever had any formal sex-ed
column3: reproductive health or contraceptive education other than opportunistically when they happen to come to hospital or what their mothers tell them. We are going to try and convince Ashwini a bit more sexy health teaching might be a good plan!

column1: Life outside the hospital has been pretty idyllic. For our first weekend we decided to stay close by to make the most of our pretty stunning mountainous backyard. Well fuelled from our cooking lesson with Shyla (I say lesson-we chopped some onions and a few tomatoes which she somehow then morphed into three separate but equally beautiful dishes within the space of about half an hour) we headed off for what was intended to be a good day‚Äôs hike. Armed with an impressively accurate hand-drawn map from Shyla we headed
column2: as instructed
column3: ‚Äòpast the thatched huts
column4: right of the buffalo pen (containing 0 buffalo)
column5: keep the water tower on left
column6: find path through dense forest
column7: turn left and if you get lost
column8: which is likely
column9: ask for cinema shooting point‚Äô. We reached the final stages after about 20 minutes (think we have slightly differing opinions as to what constitutes a ‚Äòtrek‚Äô) so decided to venture a bit further into the forest and stumbled across a pretty magical clearing overlooking the valley with dozens of white butterflies flittering around where we spent most of the afternoon making the most of no-one else being around to expose our shoulders and
column10: shocking I know
column11: even a touch of knee.

column1: Last week the wonderful Mahesh-an Ayurvedic (the branch of Indian medicine which focuses on natural remedies etc) doctor took us on a school trip to Ashwini‚Äôs Tea Estate where we very trustingly smelled
column2: poked and ate various plants. Our favourite is a small fern-like leaf called ‚Äòtouch me not‚Äô which angrily curls up if you brush against it. We received a lesson in exotic fruit picking: for a mango all you need is a big stick and good aim whereas guavas require a tree climb and shake. The highlight of the day came as we reached the waterfall at the bottom of the valley where we swam (fully clothed
column3: woe betide any knee flashing)
column4: tried our hand-picked park shampoo and munched our chapattis. Paradise. We also had a very brief attempt at tea picking (I was sacked by my woman after approximately 45 seconds for my inefficiency). It is no easy task-they work 12 months a year regardless of heat/monsoon and earn 180 rupees (just over ¬£2) for an 8 hour day
column5: providing they pick at least 30 kilos of tea which is carried in a huge sack attached to a band around the forehead. My new appreciation for Tetley‚Äôs was cemented by a visit to the tea factory where
column6: in a bizarre attempt to be an ‚Äòattraction‚Äô
column7: they have strewn various model animals around the entrance including a dinosaur
column8: possessed-looking giraffe and-a natural choice in country with an average temperature of about 35 degrees- a penguin. Tea making is a hefty business involving multiple rollings
column9: grindings
column10: fermentings and sorting. Workers sweating away are however reassuringly informed by a sign on the wall that ‚ÄòGod is pleased to have put you in this position‚Äô. Sure they are delighted by this news.

column1: We were somehow engaged in 6.30am football sessions with some of the local boys. Which are complicated slightly by a goal-post eating dog. My contributions I have to admit were pretty limited to running at people screaming rather than any actual skill but felt pretty wholesome all the same.

We have also visited the local national park through which runs one of the main roads- people speeding past elephants on motorbikes is quite a sight! We took a trip on the safari-bus and saw more elephants (some not even chained to the trees)
column2: peacocks
column3: bison
column4: deer and a giant squirrel which are possibly the cutest animals of all time. We also went to elephant feeding where we were as much of an attraction as the animals. Though have to say we have all also fallen into the habit of staring at any white people we see-they are quite a rarity!

column1: Finally (and arguably most importantly) we have made some excellent new food discoveries the highlights of which are egg curry
column2: coconut pumpkin
column3: an apple shaped marzipan-like sweet and
column4: our newest treasure
column5: Special Avil Milk. It is hard to express in words the wonder of this concoction but I will try: layer of banana
column6: then grape and other various fruits
column7: followed by nuts and topped with a muesli style grain and all packed out with ice-cream. Not sure exactly what avil
column8: or in fact milk
column9: have to do with it but it is epic. I shall try an recreate it on return. It has to be tasted to be believed.

column1: We are spending our first placement with an organisation called Ashwini
column2: an organisation developed over 20 years ago essentially to provide healthcare and community development for the 25000+ members of the 5 local tribes. The hospital is now almost entirely managed and run by tribal workers
column3: as are their 8 area centres. In short it is everything an NGO should be-there is a huge focus on ownership by the local population which makes it as sustainable as possible. The hospital is small but well equipped (and being expanded as we speak by the most efficient group of builders I have ever seen in my life. A large majority of which are women. Though their wooden scaffolding held together with rope does look slightly death-inducing). Extension will be much appreciated by the staff as currently the operating department is in X-ray and the labour ward is in medical records! <br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column4: helvetica
column5: clean
column6: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" /><br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column7: helvetica
column8: clean
column9: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" />It is brilliantly run though very different from the UK. Confidentiality is not really a concept-people just wander in and out of consultations as they feel like it. They are also far more free and easy with their sedating drugs and the hand hygiene nurses would have a field day. The 6 of us sit in a line in clinic and take it in turns to variously prod patients-not at all intimidating! However the positives far outweigh the negatives-the patients clearly love the staff
column10: the services they offer are incredibly efficient and I like how the family are always around to care for their ill relatives-they care for them
column11: change the sheets
column12: keep them company. It is a lovely atmosphere.<br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column13: helvetica
column14: clean

column16: helvetica
column17: clean
column18: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" />In our first outpatient week (sorry non-medics!) I saw more than I have in months at a UK hospital including acute Gullain-Barre
column19: sickle cell crises
column20: hookworm
column22: lots of TB and more signs than you could shake a DOSCE list at. That plus 99% of the patients have diabetes. Which is not a surprise as they put sugar in EVERYTHING. Cat literally could chew the sugar lumps in her banana shake earlier this week. Everyone seems outraged when we ask for all of our drinks without. Very bizarre.<br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column25: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" /><br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column28: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" />The hospital is in the most stunning location in the Nilgiri hills-a sort of Indian lake district without the lakes-surrounded by tea plantations and farms growing all sorts of exotic crops we are gradually learning the names of. And probably eating. Hard to tell. We can watch the sun set over the mountains from our porch. It is just beautiful. There is also a small town called Gudalur about a ten minute walk away which is not so similar to the Lakes-very much India!-but has everything we need including fruit to balance out our 90% carbtastic diet!<br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column31: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" /><br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column34: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" />The hospital was largely set up by possibly the most inspirational couple I have ever met-surgeon Nandekumar and his gynaecologist wife Shyla. They trained the nurses 'as mini doctors‚Äô as that is what they knew-when other nurses first visited they were outraged that they could prescribe but not make the beds! They did their specialist training in the US
column35: living in the same neighbourhood as the Rockefellers (as in of the Centre fame) with the full intention of moving back to India to work somewhere where they would be able to give back to the community. They chose Ashwini and have made their life here because they believe so completely in the project and also because they have so much input into the system-as Nandekumar says better to be the head of a fox than they tail of a lion. They have built the most beautiful house about 2 minutes from the hospital. I want to live in it. Shyla is teaching us to cook so expect lots of delights on my return! <br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column38: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" /><br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column41: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" />We are staying in a lovely little guesthouse about 50 metres from the hospital which is rather handy. We have a cook called Mala who I genuinely think is fattening us up for the eating. Though have just found the fridge‚Äôs resident cockroaches so perhaps that will stem my obesity! Getting pretty nifty with the bucket shower again too. There are 5 of us from Bristol
column42: a medic from Leicester called Ali who fits in brilliantly as she is also crackers and a couple of other people who work nearby
column43: including a doctor called Viveck (spelling debateable) who we have tasked with teaching us Tamil. This so far consists of watching a non-subtitled Tamil film about a killer elephant. Not so convinced about the effectiveness of this strategy. <br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column46: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" /><br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column49: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" />On the subject of elephants had no idea how much of a menace they are. We visited one of the tribal villages where they have had to move houses and people seem to get trampled (or ‚Äòchapattified‚Äô as Nandekumar would say) on a semi-regular basis. We walked out to one of the families deeper in the forest who have only a thatched roof but no walls and are (understandably) worried as an elephant comes close to their house every night. At one point we walked past a group of pretty excitable dogs (becoming increasingly grateful I took the rabies jab hit!) and were told to walk quicker as ‚Äòthe barking irritates the elephants and they come and chase them away‚Äô at which point I asked
column51: if we were going to be trampled by an elephant at some point that day to which our Ashwini accompanier
column53: comfortingly replied after some consideration ‚Äòprobably not‚Äô. Found out earlier in the trip I can buy a baby elephant for 1 million rupees (about ¬£12
column54: 500). Swiftly going off that idea!!<br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column57: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" /><br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column60: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" />We really did not appreciate the extent of the wildlife here. Which is pretty thick as we are on the edge of a national park. So far-and the list is growing by the day-we have been told about the leopards (which ate Shyla‚Äôs dog)
column61: Cobras (for which there is no venom antidote)
column63: wild boars (who will gore you with their huge teeth and are known to chase the odd medical student) and
column65: giant wild squirrels (which as far as I know have no massive risk though chances are they have some kind of sword in their tails). Makes the cockroaches look like kittens! Shyla ans Nadekumar also own the biggest turkey I have ever seen in my life. It is about the size of a shed. Might take it round with me on a lead to fight off the leopards etc.<br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column68: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" /><br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column71: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" />Life outside the hospital is all very tranquil-lots of chatting (more often than not about bowels)
column72: book reading and mango shakes. We went to a wedding of one of the nurses in the hospital today. Well
column73: I say we went to the wedding. We turned up
column74: were served enough rice and curry to feed a small country followed by coconut milk rice pudding (epic)
column75: had many photos taken of us-seriously starting to feel like a celebrity
column76: have perfected my royal wave-and then left. No messing. The lack of alcohol results in a pretty civilised day!<br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column79: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" /><br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial
column82: sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px;"" />We are having a party in our house tonight (obviously entirely civilised) as Ali gets her Finals results. So far there is the 6 of us and 2 other guests. Think we need to make some more friends pretty quickly‚Ä¶

column1: Where to start. The food. Ahh the food. Definitely the highlight of the trip so far. It is out of this world-we are all definitely going to be very chapatti-fatty when we return. Getting very into curry for breakfast and perfecting the art of eating with no hands-is all in the thumb flick.<br style=""color:ÔøΩ font-family: arial

column21: one of the Southern Indian states which is pretty progressive compared to others in terms of infrastructure and education. After saying farewell to the Heathrow snow we had an uneventful journey (sitting down after the moving out experience was very welcome!) to Delhi. Where we became quickly very grateful for our three hour stopover as the bus ride was our terminal was basically on the other side of India. Luckily our pathetic faces got us a free ride as we did not yet have any money! We pretty quickly got hold of some though as we needed to buy a print out of our flight details before they would even let us in the terminal. After much faff we finally landed in Trivandrum. This is the state capital of Kerala and is
column22: as far as we can tell
column28: shops and tuktuks all jostle for space in a very dusty road with an indeterminate number of lanes. Many of the stalls line a small river which is quite simply full of the city‚Äôs rubbish which also collects in heaps at the end of most roads. It is such a shame as a lot of the buildings and streets are otherwise lovely. At the station we found the most incredible list of concessions I have ever seen-including 'girl scouts in uniform‚Äô

column67: after a ride in the tuktuk of the Worst Driver in the History of Time ‚Ñ¢ (seriously

column69: which we loved. We stayed in Fort Cochin which is the older part of town-a medley of British
column70: Portugese and Indian architecture and churches. After an authentic Indian Thali meal (grand price of 30p for all you can eat mystery delicious items) we sat by the lake watching sunset over fishermen reeling in their Chinese Fishing Nets-huge crescent shaped nets attached to wooden structures and pulleys. Is absolutely gorgeous. Stayed in a guesthouse with a very friendly manager who seemed to take a bit of a liking to me. After memorising my name ‚Äòfrom the passport-hello Jennifer Mary Dodds‚Äô-offered everything from bananas to whisky to use of his toilet just as we were about to leave

column2: then went back to the room to rest and avoid the heat. Later on

column10: and the first thing he said was that (a) the floor was very clean (false...) and (b) that's just where the laundry ladies put it and his job was only to fold the laundry (which he obviously had not done) and collect the money. Without any apology or attempt to rectify the situation
column11: he told us to wait

column2: it was poorly folded
column3: some of it was missing
column4: some pieces were still wet
column5: and he'd given us a few items of other people's laundry...at this point we were quite angry and demanded to speak with his supervisor

column1: We left early the next morning for the Chennai airport via the taxi we'd booked through the hotel. Crazy guy was up waiting for
us but wouldn't talk to or look at us...The cab ride was fine
column2: though

column11: since he'd been to the

column2: that there were still slums and bad areas

column9: of course

column1: Our next stop was the internet cafe

column1: trains and stations in the cities we're leaving from/headed to

column4: what berth we want

column6: as the train station is always crowded
column7: and
column8: if you don't have your act together

column1: Once we'd taken care of business

column3: in doing so

column1: (I wrote this about a week ago and have been meaning to edit it before posting it. However
column2: I have giving in to the fact that I probably won't find the time to do this. So hear it is in the raw...)

column1: It feels like everything is about to change.

column2: two of whom have been here the whole time I‚Äôve been
column3: are leaving. Three more leave next week. The tests that I have been teaching towards will be over in two weeks time (at least for my subjects); I will have an almost entirely new schedule starting a week from Monday.

column1: What grounding I have found here is feeling shaky.

All this change is happening about half way through my time here. How strange it is to think that I have been here for two months. It has gone by so quickly. So much has happened. And even stranger to think that I will be here for two more months. Especially as I cannot imagine what it will be like now that those to whom I have grow close will be gone and many of my classes will change.
I have been taught that every group follows the same pattern when they form. First
column2: the group forms and gets to know each other in a very basic way. Then the group storms: people test boundaries and conflicts arise. Next
column3: if the group is healthy
column4: they will normalize; boundaries will be established and conflict can be resolved when it arises. At this point
column5: the group is formed and functioning.

column2: because there are always people coming and going
column3: I feel like it is impossible to get normalize. I feel that boundaries are inevitably unclear
column4: that there isn‚Äôt an effective way to solve conflict. This instability makes progress feel unattainable.

column2: when my head is clear
column3: when I have slept enough
column4: when I take time to look up at the sky and down at the smiling faces of the kindergarteners asking me make an elephant noise‚Ä¶when I do this
column5: I feel excited about what is in store for me. I will have the opportunity to come close to even more students. A chance to meet new challenges inside and out of class. More time to be alone and read or walk or simply think.

column1: Enough clarity of mind to see the beauty of what has been and the opportunity of what is to come.

column1: It was a bright sunny morning around 10:00am we set are minds & told are rides ""KODAIKANAL"". We fueled our tanks
column2: geared ourselves up & took off. We were aware of two routes to Kodaikanal
column3: one via Pollachi-Pallani with loads of plane 'un-inclined' tarmac & the other via Munnar-Theni-Cumbum with plenty of 'inclined hairpins'. Infact we came to a conclusion that we head KODAIKANAL via the former route & return back via the latter one.

column1: The route to the border was more
of a plain track with very few challenging curves
column2: but the only challenging factor there was the scorching sun. As we entered Tamil Nadu
column3: it was a whole new world. We came across to see ""WINDMILLS"" stretched for acres of dry land. We literally dint see any of the human race for about an hour. After a while
column4: guess what...an old lady selling tender coconuts under a tree

column8: now
column9: heading to pallani.

column4: people dancing. We later enquired about it
column5: it seems it‚Äôs a ritual. By the time we drove for the next couple of hours we felt the coldness of the wind gushing through our helmets. We sensed KODAIKANAL is nearer.

column2: back in cochin its A/C rooms that are of demand
column3: here its the other way round.

column2: we took on the town on foot. Bought some 'drinking medicines' which were used to beat the cold in Russia... üòä .Meanwhile we also had our dinner.

column1: The next day we all got up together because of the intense cold climate outside. We had a quick bath & jumped on to our wheels. 'On the go' we had noticed a restaurant from where we had dinner last night. We had our breakfast
column2: geared up again & prepared to get amazed by the beauty of KODAI. We came across fog covered mountains & fog hugging forests. We took lot of pictures till our cameras ran out of power. After watching the mindblowing sceneries of KODAI for a couple of hours
column3: we noticed it was time to return.

column9: Rama
column10: Rama
column11: Hare. This was not easy
column12: especially for my Russian roommate
column13: to say. There I was
column14: standing in line moving a foot at a time
column15: chanting what might have been the correct words
column16: my roommate giggling because of her accent
column17: the Indian man behind me whispering instructions and questions about the States
column18: in a line that reminded me more of an amusement park than a place of worship
column19: in a temple we hadn‚Äôt intended to visit. I felt ridiculous. Then I felt guilty for feeling ridiculous. My light view of the scenario seemed somewhat disrespectful of the people in line praying.

column1: Finally we finished the chanting and the line picked up pace. We filed past minor shrines
column2: too quickly for prayer
column3: but slowly enough to put coins in the collection box. When we entered to main temple
column4: at first it reminded me of a mall or park. People milling about
column5: families sitting together eating. But then I heard the bells ringing from

column1: the ceiling. It was a beautiful sound
column2: but distant. We made our way to the shrines. Some people
column3: like us
column4: continued in the line past the shrines
column5: pausing only long enough for a glance. Others left the line to be closer to the deities. Crowds gathered around the brightly lit statues
column6: leaving their offerings and their prayers. Another shrine was not for a deity
column7: but for a religious leader
column8: presumably dead. People had left offerings there
column9: too
column10: and a man lay prostrate at the statues feet. I felt overwhelmed and uncomfortable. Prayer and spirituality are so deeply personally to me. I can‚Äôt imagine praying in such a crowed place. And I felt like a voyeur for being there when other people were.

column2: thanked out impromptu guild
column3: and made our way to the exit. In order to leave the temple
column4: we had to walk through several gift shops
column5: past countless collection counters
column6: and through a food court. After one of the gift shops
column7: we came to another shrine for the religious leader. I glanced down a hall to the left of the shrine that led to an open room. Sitting in the room was the

column1: man whose statue I was facing. The image of the man praying prostate in the noisy and crowed temple seemed even stranger to me knowing that he prayed to a living man
column2: who sat cross-legged on a lush pillow typing on his computer just a few feet below. Finally
column3: we returned to our shoes and cameras
column4: and then to the street to find a rickshaw back to the hotel. I still have not fully processed my trip to this temple
column5: but I know that it was surreal and that I do not have the focus to worship there. Or the tolerance for gift shops.

column1: (The photos are not of the temple
column2: as I wasn't meant to take pictures. There are pictures from the hotel
column3: the botanical gardens
column4: and elsewhere)

column1: The rollercoaster continues. So many frustrations and excitements
column2: misstep and successes to share. But in this post I will be brief. I think this story deserves an entry of its own.
eight of the older girls were interviewed by ABC/Univision. Another ASTEP volunteer and I were asked to help the girls practice for the interviews
column3: which were to be done over skype. I am so grateful I had the opportunity to do this. In talking about the questions they would likely have to answer
column4: I was privileged to know more about these incredible young women than I could learn in class. They were all very articulate
column5: expressing their thankfulness for the present and their hopes for the future. When I asked them what they want to do after they graduate
column6: they all spoke of going to college‚Äîremarkable when you consider that they will be the first in their families to finish high school
column7: if any education‚Äîand they all spoke of helping others with their education. I was amazed by the grace and gratitude each girl exhibited. There are few children in the States who will speak of their education as a privilege and responsibility. Hearing them speak made me proud of the school and excited to be here.

column1: One student said something like this when she was asked why she wants to study literature: ‚ÄúI love poetry
column2: because it helps you understand other people and their emotions. I can get to know a lot of different people. My parents really wanted me to study business or science. I want to prove that I can be myself <em style=""mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"">and be successful.‚Äù

column1: Later when she was asked what it means to her to be the first in her family to receive an education
column2: she said something like this: ‚ÄúThere are so many 'He's the first's. 'He is the first to the moon.' 'He is the first to win the contest.' There are so many times when a 'he' is the first. But 'She's the first
column3: ' is new and exciting. When I think about being the first to graduate high school and that I am a 'she' I am so grateful and excited. So excited. At first coming to school here seemed like a burden. I had to study all the time
column4: even when I went home I had to study. Because my parents expected me to do well. Because I was the only one getting an education. So I felt a lot of pressure. But then I realized that I was a snail and my education is my shell. It is heavy and I have to carry it everywhere
column5: but it is also my protection. What allows me to live.‚Äù

column1: Nous avons pris cong√© de la chaleur et les temples et nous sommes all√©s dans les montagnes.
Le bus local A/I nous a emmen√© a travers le mix habituel de belle route asphalt√©e avec lauriers et bougainvilliers au milieu
column2: routes de campagne a travers des villages pauvres pour monter les derniers 48 km sur une route de montagne en lacets serres serres tricotes en t√™tes d'√©pingle. La vue √©tait superbe et heureusement le chauffeur √©tait tr√®s bon et avan√ßait lentement. Car chaque fois qu'on rencontrait un autre v√©hicule dans une t√™te d'√©pingle nous entrions dans un incroyable ""pas de deux"" en changeant la direction avec l'autre v√©hicule. De quoi s'√©merveiller et s'exciter! Les Palani nous ont accueillit avec un parfum lourd et fruit√© absolument enivrant
column3: qui embaumait de ses efleuves l'atmosph√®re. Tout un changement des effluves pestilentielle qui parfument des fois les villes! On nous a dit que c'√©tait de petites oranges sauvages incomestible
column4: qui poussent dans la r√©gion. On en redemande!

column1: Kodaikkanal est une ville perch√©e a 2200 m d'altitude avec un climat agr√©able (+14C le matin
column2: +17-18C a midi) propice a la randonne. Nous avons fait une petite en compagnie de Sekar

column1: un indien tr√®s style qui nous a conduit sur un petit sentier d'o√π on a pu admirer les villages √©parpill√©s dans les montagnes ou les locaux cultivent du caf√© et du cacao. Car dans cette r√©gion le caf√© est tr√®s bon et tout le monde fabrique du chocolat maison avec des fruits et des noix (malheur a nos silhouettes car les filles ont voulu encourager l'√©conomie locale et ont donc teste plusieurs sortes!)

Les eucalyptus √©taient magnifiques et nous avons d√©couvert les premier rhododendrons fleuris! Leur rouge fonce s'agencait bien avec le jaune pale des mimosas et le lilas des jacarandas. Quelle belle randonn√©e!

T√¥t le matin nous sommes all√©s faire le tour du lac local (lac artificiel construit par les anglais) 5 km de marche. Antoine et Cornelia ont eu la chance de le faire 2 fois car il y a eu malentendu avec Huguette qui qu√™tait les oiseaux. Nous sommes tr√®s chanceux qu'Huguette a cette passion qui nous a ouvert un nouvel horizon: les oiseaux. Elle est tr√®s contente car elle a d√©j√† identifie pas loin de 60 esp√®ces locales. Nous le sommes aussi car c'est une belle d√©couverte pour nous!
On a quitte Kodaikkanal en bus pour descendre la montagne de l'autre cote
column2: toujours en lacets serres et ""pas de deux"" dans le t√™tes d'√©pingles et nous sommes entres dans une zone de ""elephant crossing""! Mais non
column3: nous ne les avons pas vu! Cependant l'indicateur √©tait d√©j√† quelque chose. Apr√®s 60 km dans les plaines nous avons recommence la mont√©e des Nilgiris: lacets serres
column4: paysages magnifiques
column5: pr√©cipices √©peurant. Nous sommes arrives a Coonoor
column6: petite ville de montagne a 1950 m d'altitude
column7: √©parpill√©e sur plusieurs collines. Adorable! Nous avions un joli h√¥tel avec cour int√©rieure et balcon (prot√©g√© contre les singes envahissantes) avec vue sur les plantations de th√©! Les gens sont incroyables
column8: souriants ils nous saluent partout! Nous avons fait des petites marches dans les collines avec plantations de th√© et les rues tranquilles envahies par les magnifiques plantes du sud: lantana rose-jaune-orange
column9: jacaranda lila
column10: drum-stick
column11: poinsettia et ponsetiana rouges. Les maisons dans les plantations sont des immenses manoirs avec colonnes et terrasses. Celles en villes ne sont pas moins √©patantes
column12: entour√©es des fleurs et hauts murs. En fait c'est une ville riche. Il y a des maisons pauvres et minuscules des ouvriers des plantations mais l'impression g√©n√©rale est d'une

column1: les locaux cultivent le cacao et le cafe
ville ais√©e. Il y a aussi un magnifique parc avec des arbres majestueux apportes de partout au monde.
L'Inde des montagnes est totalement diff√©rente de l'autre Inde que nous avons vu: propre
column2: fleuri
column3: en majorit√© chr√©tien avec une importante minorit√© musulmane. Les hindous sont quasiment invisibles. Le nombre d'√©glises est incroyable (de toutes d√©nominations: catholiques
column4: protestantes
column5: pentecostales
column6: adventistes
column7: etc) et il y a pas mal de mosqu√©es. D'ailleurs on entend souvent l'appel m√©lancolique du muezzin a la pri√®re. On a eu la premiere pluie depuis le debut

column1: Nous avons quitte Coonoor en train historique: un petit train-jouet ancien monte jusqu'√† Coonoor avec une locomotive a vapeur. A Coonoor on la change avec une locomotive diesel. On a donc pris ce train pour une heure de plaisir a monter a travers de petits villages de montagne jusqu'√† Oooty
column2: la reine des Nilgiris. Autre ville a 2200 m

column4: plus industrielle
column5: plus musulmane
column6: mais avec son charme. Son jardin botanique est le lieu de promenade des amoureux et des familles
column7: celui ou on a √©t√© envahis par des gens qui voulaient se faire toujours photographier avec nous!Et nous avons dormi a YWCA

column4: arriv√©e dans un autre √©tat. Et retrouvaille de l'hinduism car a l'entr√©e dans l'√©tat de Karnataka le chauffeur a arr√™t√© le minibus prive dans lequel nous √©tions devant un petit temple pour une puja
column5: sans doute pour remercier les dieux de nous avoir prot√©g√© dans la descente des montagnes. Ne manquez pas la suite!
