column1: Its been only couple of months since our last family holiday to south of Maharashtra.But then i had mandy scheduled in November during Diwali.It was good opppourtunity for yet another family outing.We discussed and concluded to go.After a few deliberations
column2: we zeroed out on Ooty & Mysore.Main reasons were seasons of the year.We wanted to experience the best winter of the season one can get in India and whats better than Nilgiry Mountains.Since air fare contributes maximum to your travel cost
column3: we fixed that first well in advance.The route was Mumbai-Coimbatore-Bangalore-Mumbai.In fact there is no alternate if you are visiting ooty & Mysore from Mumbai.Post that i searched for the stay and after a lot of research using Trip Advisor and other travelportals
column4: picked up below 2 which were slated as The Best in respective locations.

column1: I booked in advance by making some advance payments.Both proved to be right choices at the end!!After celebrating Diwali in first week of my mandy with family and Friends
column2: we started packing for the travel.But something untoward happened that we have never thought of.Local political party - Shiv Sena Supremo - Balasaheb Thakrey was

column1: declared dead on Saturday evening..1 day prior to our departure.Given his influnence on Mumbai
column2: it was but expected that everything in Mumbai will close down including taxies.I somehow managed to get the prints of our air tickets from Swapneel but till end of day there were questions on our local commute from home to airport.We called up Nikhil & Mai to help us.They incidentaly have just returned from their family holiday but in spite of that they offered their help to drop us to airport in case taxies are not running.Next day morning they came to our place but fortunately the cab driver called up and said he is ready to drop us to airport.We were relieved!!We safely reached the airport in time.We paid extra tip to the driver for his timely help.Affairs at the airport were running as usual but we had quiet a few passengers who were stranded at the airport for lack of ground transport!!Our flight was too on time.We had some snacks at the airport Cafe and boarded the 1150 am flight bound for Coimbatore.It was Sai's 3rd air travel.Last time she was bit restless so we were little nervous as to how she will react

column1: but she co operated really well.We kept her engaged on various things and she had a smooth ride..so did we.Coimbatore is a small town in State of Tamilnadu so the aiport was as expected small one with just 1 terminal.We got refreshed and contacted the taxi driver that we have booked with the Sun Valley Homestay.He was already there.In less than an hour after leaving Mumbai
column2: we were on our way to Conoor on the road.Coimbatore airport to Conoor is almost 3.5 hrs road distance.We picked up some bakery products as we decided to skip the lunch.Conoor is almost 4-5 thousand feet above sea level.Hence the road on top was thru ghats.Sai has tendency to vomit on turning roads but luckily for us
column3: she was sleeping.And good she was b'use these ghats have the most turns ..what they call as ""Hairpin bends""..almost in excess of 35.I dont know where else in the world or in india
column4: you have those many curves to reach a hill station!!

column1: By 430 pm we reached the Sun Valley Homestay.Last phase of the road there is undone hence approaching it in last stages raised questions about Sun Valley's stay.But all our doubts were put

to rest when we got down at their property.Actual property was no different & as picturesque as in their profile pictures.They greeted us with warm welcome and after quick check in we stepped into our room named ""Clarke Quay"". All the 12 rooms there are named after places/monuments in Singapore. May be Singapore is favourate place of owner.Rooms were big and had balcony.Plus they have made very clever use of mirrors so the rooms appears bigger than actual.Balnocy offers fantastic view of the surrounding mountains which appears like layers of cones.Tea planatation is what you see all around on nice slopes of the mountains. This to my memory is one of best views that i have had in india so far!!That day evening we spent in getting refreshed.Had breakfast
column2: explored the property & made plans for next 2 days in consultation with attendats there at Sun Valley.They can arrange for local site seeing plus car etc. We leveraged them and decided to explore Conoor & its suuroundings on day 1.After a good south indian breakfast
column3: we left at around 1030 am.Minimum itinerary was Dolphin's nose
column4: Sims Park & Tea factory.Dolphin's nose is a basically a view point on Nilgiris.One can see beautiful

column1: views of Nilgiris and some waterfalls if you come in Monsoons. Prominent among them was Katherine's waterfall which has a height of some 250 odd feet.One can see that from Dolphin's nose point.Road to Dolphin nose is pretty.Tea platations
column2: mist..you feel like you are in heaven.Plus decent cold in the air.Unfortunately for us
column3: that day there was lot of smog so we could see beyond a few feet for most of the time.Even view of Dolphin Nose was limited.But journey to & from there is one to remember!!By the time we finished those view points
column4: it was noon.We decided to break for the lunch.Our driver took us to one of the better place around.We had lunch at leisure and it was important so that Sai has some time to digest and is ok during the travel.POst lunch we stopped at Sims Park.Its the Botanical garden of Conoor and is less famous than its Ooty's counterpart but after being to both the places
column5: i would rate Sims Park higher simply b'use its better maintained than Ooty.I believe too much commercialisation deteriorates public places.Sims park is designed on a slope with trees & flowers from all over the world.It also has a mini pond

column2: Ooty

column1: with boating facilities.There is a nice little children play area.It offered us good relaxation after a good afternoon lunch.Tea factory was just a few minutes drive from there.Apparently its the only operational tea factory in the area which allows visitors inside for a tour.We took one which is offered as free by some of the volunteers there.That Volunteer took us the the whole tea making process from start to end with quiet a bit of details which were news to us.Like there is also something called ""White Tea""which is most premium form of tea & costs as much as INR 18k per kg in international market!!You can get it cheaper at the factory of course.They have a shop where one can buy all their produce at reasonable prices.At the end
column2: they allow you to explore their plantation and if you want can also click some pictures of you with your family that too in tradtional costume wore during cutting tea leaves!! Nice..isnt it!!On the way back
column3: driver drove us thru Wilington area which is basically the area occupied by Indian Navy as its training base.Like any other military area
column4: it was tidy
column5: clean and well maintained!!That was the last stop.We reached

column1: Toy Train from Conoor to Ooty

Sun Valley by 630.Had some freshly cooked snacks with hot tea before retiring to our room for relaxation.Dinner order was booked as soon as we arrieved that evening.And thats the norm at Sun Valley.They dont serve you stale food. They cook by order..fresh and delicious!!

Sunvalley management has also kept a local guide book in each rooms for help of visitors.We leveraged that extensively along with what we have researched.It has good info..somethings which you wont find on internet at times.Next day target was Ooty and surrounding area.It was not difficult to decide on that.You would visit 2 best places if you have only 2 full days there!on Day 2 we decided to give ourselves more time and asked if we could try the World famous ""Toy Train"" for one side journey.We were not hopeful as basis what we knew its schedule was not in our plan but thats where asking locals helps.There is a daily up-down service between Ooty & Conoor only of the same train.Last train from Ooty for Coonorr leaves at 6 pm.After realising this
column2: we altered our plans accordingly.We decided to cover key places in such a way that we can reach Ooty station by

column1: 530 pm.And it worked very well!!Ooty is apporximately 1 hr drive from Conoor but our first stop was ""Pykara Lake"" which is another 1 hr from Ooty.So it took us some while after leaving hotel to reach there.Pykara is a fairly big lake to be situated on mountain hill.Whats more it man made.Surrounded by moountain ranges all across a 20 mins boat ride can be great fun with family.In our case Sai is afraid of waters so we were not keen but luckily we got a co traveller from Mumbai who were running short by 1 person for a family package.The lady invited 1 of us sensing that both of us wont be able to make it with Sai.I went ahead.Meeting co passengers like her on travel is good!!From Pykara it was journey back to Ooty.On the way we stopped at 2 interesting places.One is called ""Shooting Hill"".A hill top with a valley view.Apparently preferred by many directors for film shooting.and its indeed beautiful!!Only pain is you have walk 15 -20 mins uphill so it can be tiring!!Next stop was ""Nilgiri Jungle walk""You can see Nilgiri trees all across while travelling in Ooty/Coonooro but tourist taxis will stop at this
place b'use may be its along the main road.Leads to a small lake where excess water from Pykara Dam is released.Contrary to Shooting Hill
column2: this one as reasonably steep slope.But best thing about this place is the tall trees and dense forest.Sun rays trying to space thru..beautiful..!!Here walking down was easy but coming back was difficult especially with Sai.But we somehow managed it.Now Sai was hungry too and was showing signs of that.So next we stopped for lunch at a city hotel.Was not a good choice.Exorbitantly expensive for not so delicious food.we just had sandwiches and left.That also costs us 200 INR which was definitely not worth it! Good thing was we saved some time on lunch and utilised it in our next stop which was Ooty Botanical Garden.More or less this features on each one's itinerary in Ooty and its good as well.Spacious..Some redeveloped structures at the entrance.But after exploring
column3: i found more hype than substance in there.Sims Park is anytime better.But had i not been here
column4: i would be able to compare!!Nam clicked best pics of me & Sai here..It was around 3 pm.We had couple of hours in our hand.Driver offered us few choices.His suggestion was Ooty

column1: Lake but we went for ""Thread Garden"".Reason was simple we have already been to Pykara.So instead of visiting another lake we picked up a place which showcases biggest variety of handmade flowers from all over the world made with thread.Its a unique museum of its kind in the world and has been pioneered by a Keralite.Using the services of some orphanges
column2: he has been able to put up a good show of man's skills which amuses you.Definitely recommended for all!!It doesnt take more than 15-20 mins there so we still had time.Thus we decided to make the most of it by visiting ""Rose Garden"".Good thing in small towns is all places are nearby.It was hardly 10 mins drive.We were not very optimistic about this place but they surprised us.Designed on slope like Botanical
column3: it houses rose varieties from all over the world including ""Black Rose""Fairly well maintained
column4: its good to visit in early evening as sun sets.Here again Nam took some beautiful pics of Me & Sai!!We had nice time and manage to finish exploring it just in time to reach Ooty station for catching Toy Train.Reguler class cost peanuts at INR 5 and first class ticket will cost INR

column1: 85 we took first class to ensure that we have good seats and better comfort.Some folks even suggested against it but after boarding the train we realised we have made righ decision.Reguler class was full of locals & student returning from their school.In first class we had only 5 passengers including 3 of us.Sun was about to set so we didnt enjoyed the beautiful views from the train for too long but whatever we could was good enough memory to take back.Lot of tunnels on the way.hats off to engineers who consructed this line in such a difficult hilly area and that too in early 1900's!It was dark by the time we got down at Conoor.It was good 1 hr journey.Driver met us at Station parking and he dropped us to hotel.

Two days in Sunvalley went really well and we were really pleased with the kind of stay & service that we got there!Sunvalley had a lasge tea estate adjusent to the property and since its co owned by the same guy who owns the homestay
column2: as a guest you are allowed to explore it any time..even cut some tea leafs and staff will make instant tea of

column1: it.So on the day of check out
column2: after packing out stuff we decided to experience the same.It was pleasant morning.Property looks nice from the estate too!Unfortunately Sai was not comfortable in the middle and hence we spent very short time there
column3: clicked a few snaps and came back.Staff of sunvalley was as courtious for our farewell as they were when welcoming us 2 days back.we clicked a snap with the staff and started our journey towards Mysore.we have hired their car services only for that.It costs us INR 3000.We left by 1030 am.Route was interesting!! First climb down from Ooty..then enter Mylapuram Forest before entering Bandipur
column4: both of which are known as Tiger Reserves.We were hoping for sighting some
column5: but only saw some deers and elephants who were omisticated.There are as many as 36 hairpin curves while climbing down from Ooty towards Mylapuram.Luckily for us
column6: this time as well Sai was sleeping!!State highway from TN to Karnataka was good.We instructed Driver to be slow & stable so journey was good except the food.Driver stopped at a roadside hotel which we didnt find good for food.This is the 2nd time
column7: it was happening with same driver.Caution for all is to ensure

column1: that you give clear instructions about your food preferance to driver's boss so that you get disappointment!It was around 415 pm when we stopped in front of Jade Garden hotel which we have booked for our stay in Mysore.Again thanks to tripadvisor.com.On the back of homely Sunvalley we were expecting similar experience at Jade but it turned out to be very commercial.No doubt hotel was good from food
column2: hygene
column3: facilities perspective but staff was not as people centric as we expected.May be language is a barrier!!Who knows? Check in was quick as i have booked in advance.Since it was early evening & we were still fairly fresh...plus nothing planned
column4: we decided to explore the neighbourhood.Ask for some guidance at reception and were told that there is Big Bazar few hundered meters away.There was no better shopping oppourtunity than this!And we capitalised on that.First we had some snacks at the entrance of Big Bazar and then went inn.To our luck
column5: we also met some localites of Mumbai who was serving there as staff and he helped us pick up some really nice clothes for Nam.Store was as big as you can get anywhere in Mumbai.Shopping was good and so was time spent.That night

column2: Mysore

column1: we ordered food in the room which we realised is the best option considering nusance Sai would cause if we have to go down to the Restaurant.We tried it first time on our travel there and felt it gave us what we should do going forward while travelling.Jade Garden had a travel desk attached to it.We made some basic inquiries with them and considering that there are autos which run thruout the city
column2: we decided to opt for that instead of expensive car hire for next day.

column1: Next day ie Day 5 of our tour & first day in Mysore
column2: we decided to visit top attractions ie Mysore Palace & Zoo at minimum and if time permits then few others.Palace was hardly 10 mins auto drive from the hotel.Fare INR 20.Mysore palace which boasts of being Mysore's identity is a heavily visted tourist spot especially for foreigners.And why not!Its a grand place and very well maintained too for all these years.Safety & basic arrangements were good.They also have battery operated cars for old/kids if anyone wants to hire them to explore the palace.Inside as well very well petroled by the guards
column3: Mysore palace has been the home of Mysore Dynasty

column1: for over 100 years.Its the clan of Vodiyaar's who has been ruling as Kings of Mysore till it became part of India during independance.Inside the palace you will see pictures of their family/their royalty ..typical of any King's palace anywhere.The Diwan E Aam & Diwane E Khas..their temples
column2: private rooms etc.And at the end it does makes an impression but folks like us who came from the land of Shivaji
column3: didnt found it anythinking g better than a grand old palace of a king b'use in the land of Shivaji
column4: Kings spent money on people & their welfare than their own.Good visit for enjoying the architectre of the old time as well!It took us around 90 mins to explore that.From there zoo was also hardly 10 mins drive.We hailed a auto & got down at the zoo.Now this was something intersting for us as its been years since we visited a zoo and Sai was also with us.We have read that Mysore Zoo is one of the best maintained in India so our hopes were elevated.We purchased the tickets ..some INR 30 per per person i think and got inn.After the entrance only you first get to see the tallest

column1: mammals ie Jiraffe's..from there you proceed to birds section before getting to see wild cats and other animals.Except birds
column2: all animals enclosures are cage free which is what you see abroad as well.Idea is to offer as natural view to visitors and also without compromising on safety ie they have big ditches between animal area boundry and visitors pathways.From all types of colourful parrots to Royal Bengal tiger to Rhino
column3: you have everyone here.Whats more they also have Cheetah and India's only Gorilla there.Its wonderful.Some enclosures no doubt need upliftment like the one for Rain forests animals..It sticks badly in there.Canteen also was ok.Few areas were under constructions but all in all it didnt let is down.Only problem was Sai was reluctant to walk hence we felt tired earlier than expected while exploring the zoo.Towards the end one can also see kangaroo's
column4: turtles
column5: crocs which was amuzing.It also has big anaconda enclosure which was crowd puller in snakes section.Black Swan is something we saw for the first time there.It was almost 3 hours + that we were walking and were dead tired.All 3 of us hence took a small nap on one the benches there for some time to revitalise.Overall it was nice experience to see all those wonderful animals and in a fairly well maintained zoo!!We left from there by around 430 pm and wondering what to do when we noticed the plaque advertising Wax museum nearby.Wd didnt had a clue about it but it sounded intersting.Karanji Lake was original choice but when we learned that visiting hours for Karanji Lake were only upto 5pm and Was museum is on the same way
column6: we decided to give it a visit.Its around 15 mins drive from Zoo towards Chamundi Hills area.we were little excited but all that excitement was washed away when we went thru that waz museum.It was nowhere close to what we expected.Its nice attempt.In fact somewhere inbetween guide also shares their disappointment over not getting recognised by Karnataka government but having recognition of Goa administration.May be we anticipated more!In some 20 odd rooms that wax museum mainly showcases musical instruments from many part of the world.Its a ok visit for ticket which is expensive than palace & zoo.Definitely worth a skip!!On the way back
column7: we were little unlucky to have met couple of wrong auto drivers.First one left us midway citing gas issues and 2nd one charged us little above.But at the end we reached safely back to hotel which was more important.That night also dinner was in the room.Like last few days we finished around 10 pm
column8: pattern away from what we have at home and went to sleep.

column1: Itineraty for next day involved places which were little far from the hotel
column2: namely Chamundi Hill and Vrindavan Gardens.A bird sanctuary on the way was also on the list.Musical fountains at Vrindavan were main attractions and it starts only around 7 pm so considering time & distance we hired a cab for the day for rent of INR 1000.First up was Chamundi Hills..Considered to be one of the most sacred places in India
column3: its believed that demon Mahishasur was killed by Goddess Amba on this hill.Drivers will also tell you some more local stories about the place & its legend on the way.Must say that roads to the top are steady and good.On top you get to visit Goddess Amba temple and see big stautes of Mahishasur & Nandi.These 2 along with Palace are often potrayed as iconic symbols of Mysore.There is car park few meters away from the temple.On the way you have small shops to pick up some local stuff.Temple on Friday is typically overcrowded but we were lucky to get only a few in the queue.We offered our prayers to local god & seeked her blessings.Temple is old but well maintained and has imprint of Karnataka style architecture.We left but not without clicking few snaps of iconic Mahishasur & Nandi.Our driver for the day was also a good guide and family friendly person.He was keen to share some local knowledge which helps us enjoy the day better.From there we stopped at Government recognised shop called ""Kavery Emporium"" in main city.Purpose was to buy ""Chandan"".Every second name of place/shop in Mysore will have ""Kavery"" in it for obvious reasons that its their main river and which is also in the news over dispute over its water sharing with neighbouring Tamilnadu.At Kavery we bought another dress for Nam & a small stick of Chandan.Its always better to shop Chandan from Govt shop over anything else.Crossing thru the roads of main city
column4: we then halted at ""Pizza Hut"".We have learned from our mistake in Ooty and have made it clear to Driver that we only wanted to eat at Pizza Hut if they have it there and our local professional knew where it was.He also took a halt at locally famous ""Mahalaxmi Sweets"" shop where we picked up local favourate ""Mysore Pak"" and some chivda.Chicken Pizza Meal at Pizza hut was stomouchfull so from there we continued our travel towards bird Sanctuary.Its a little off from the main Mysore-Bangalore highway but definitely a good stop over for those who enjoy being close to nature.Surrounded by farms & perched a little high
column5: this bird sanctuary has a small lake within and that lake has handful of islands which hundreds of birds have made their home.Small pathway to walk along the lake offers nice views and cool breeze in the shadow of high trees.It also has couple of observation decks for bird watchers.We could not locate as many varieties of birds as one would expect but it was nice lazy stopover post lunch in the lap of nature!Lot of butterflies to watch as well!It was around 4 pm now & per driver we were on time to visit world famous Vrindavan Garden.It was around 45 mins drive from Sanctuary.Its easily the biggest crowd puller in Mysore and you can make it from the parking area there.It reminds you of parking spaces in US.Can easily accomodate more than 2000 cars i believe.Tickets are reasonably priced at INR 50 in spite of being such a big crowd puller.Designed beautifully using the waters of Kavery Dam
column6: Garden hosts number of eyepleasing fountains which creates wonderful impressions on our mind.Water brings life & energy and when that energy springs from a fountain its a sight to watch!You have not 1 or 2 but atleast more than a dozen fountains all creating different designs in the air.There are 2 sides to the garden.One of the left is a step like structure which takes you on top of level of the gardens.There is a beautiful Krishna statue.View from top is simply amazing.Hats off to those who designed this.One has to be really fortunate not to have too many visitors there so as to have nice clean pics and we were sort of lucky.We were ahead of the group which consist of mostly school children.Only mistake that we did was to allow a starnger
column7: who was also slightly drunk to click our pictures.Not only his clicks were bad but we also ended up paying him 50 bucks for nothing.Lesson learned - Never give your camera to stangers!!

column1: In the early evening people start gathering by the musical fountain area which is on thr right hand side of the garden.It had high expectations from us but when we saw it actually
column2: it didnt turn out to be anything that exciting.Firstly the show didnt started on time and due to lack of commentary
column3: people were uncertain what to watch out for as novelty.We stayed for some time and then moved on as it was getting dark and it was out in open.By around 8 pm we came out and within an hour or so we were back at the hotel.That night as well we ordered the food in the room.Had food and went to sleep.

column1: Next day was the day of return journey to Mumbai.We packed our bags
column2: had breakfast and left Jade Gardens around 11.15 am.Our flight was from Bangalore which is around 4 hour travel by car from Mysore.We left aiming to reach Bangalore airport by 4 pm
column3: couple of hours ahead of our scheduled departure of 630 pm.Journey was long but Mysore-Bangalore state highway is good road.We kept the same driver as previous day so it was safe as well.This time we stopped at places of our choice for food and breaks.You have Mac & CCD on the way.We stopped there.Sai as well had a decent time.By 430 we reached airport.Checked in.There was lot of time.Me & Sai explored the airport playing around.BOught some books for self & Nikhil at Airport book shop.Fortunately the flight was on time as well.After a decent 60-70 mins
column4: we landed in Mumbai.Hired Meru at the airport and back we were in our sweet home.

column1: This was our 4th tour of the year 2012.We were indeed making up for the lost year in 2011.We are now really settling down in our own pattern of travel.Good stay
column2: good food
column3: leisure
column4: safety and comfort over anything else.Most importantly no rush for sightseeing.These changes were really making our travel a story to remember for long long time in our lives.Top experiences of this tour were -

column1: 1) Stay at Sunvalley Homestay - I doubt you will get a better choice in Ooty/Conoor.
2) Mysore Zoo visit - Its defenitely one of the better kept zoo's in India.
3) Toy Train journey from Conoor to Ooty in World Heritage sight.If possible make it in day time to enjoy surroundings.
4) Vrindavan Gardens - It can be better maintained but still has enough charm of its own.
5) SIMS Park in Conoor.Scores over Ooty Botanical Gardens.Both are same concenpts but Conoor's is better.
6) Walk in the Bamboo jungle in ooty.

column1: The over night train form Kerala to Chennai wasn't too bad considering the only tickets left were 3rd class. There was a teeny compartment with 6 beds three on each wall. It was cosy but quite good.
When we got to Chennai it was sooo busy at the station and it was huge so we couldn't find our hotel taxi. We ended up paying twice but hey
column2: we got there. Didn't really like Chennai much although I am really glad I went there to see the contrast.

column1: Stayed in the hotel most of the time though because going out was a bit of a hassel but the pool was dirty and really small. Inside the hotel itself was really nice though.

column2: none the less.

ils retournent volontairement nos sourires et nous avons toujours la cote avec eux car ils veulent souvent se faire photografier avec nous.

column1: Les routes dans Tamil Nadu sont assez bonnes
column2: verdoyantes
column3: voutees par des grands
column4: vieux arbres. Elles traversent des risieres et des cours d'eau
column5: passent a cote des etangs aux lotus fuchsia et des villages pauvres avec des maisons couvertes de toits de pailles. Les deplacements ne sont pas toujours aussi ""excitantes"" que notre premier volet
column6: car par apres on a eu des chauffeurs tres prudents.

column1: Heureusement la ville n'est pas aussi ""francaise"" que je la craignais. Nous habitions la partie tamoul
column2: dans une residence tres propre sur une petite rue tranquille. Tout est facile d'acces a pied. En arrivant
column3: Huguette a eu l'inspiration divine de nous conduire vers un temple hindu dedie a Nandi
column4: le taureau de Shiva. On est arrives juste a temps pour la ceremonie de ""lavage"": on verse plusieurs vase (en argent) d'eau sur le taureau
column5: par apres de l'eau avec de la poudre de santal (qui la rend jaune)
column6: et on fini par un autre lavage a eau. Des dizaines de guirlandes de fleurs embaumees sont

column1: ensuite arrangees autour du cou et des cornes de Nandi. Tout est baigne par une musique envoutante qui nous transporte. On se regarde heureux et apaises.

On continue par une courte visite a l'ashram de Sri Aurobindo (il a d'ailleurs construit un centre mondial de la meditation pas loin de Pondicherry mais nous n'avons pas le temps d'y aller car il faudrait rester plusieurs jours). L'atmosphere est florale et paisible. Le soir on retourne au temple de Nandi pour assister a la ceremonie de soir pendant laquelle on enleve les guirlandes de fleurs et on les donne en petits morceaux aux fideles.
On prend soin de notre estomac aussi car notre ame ne peut pas survivre sans nourriture terestre! A cote du bazar nous decouvrons un petit bui ou on mange de bons repas d'Inde du sud: pongal

column2: Nataraja. Si on etait venus en Inde juste pour voir ce temple et ca vallait le deplacement. Le complexe est immense avec
Antoine et fideles

column1: plusieurs temples dedies a d'autres dieux hindus et un immense bassin d'ablution. La plupart des temples datent du IXs mais les fresques ont ete rajoutees plus tard
column2: jusqu'au XVIIs. Nous visitons le complexe ebahis par la beaute et la finesse des sculptures et peintures. Mais quand nous entrons dans l'enceinte principale nos coeurs s'arretent emus! Un temple immense en carre

column5: les portes
column6: colonnes

column8: tout ce qui existe dans chaque temple est couvert par des plaques de metal cisele et sculpte!!!). La ceremonie du feu bat son plein. Des centaines de fideles autour de nous chantent. Nous vibrons au son des dizaines de cloches qui resonnent autour de nous. C'est dur a quitter tellement nous sommes ensorcelles! Mais nous revenons le lendemain matin pour assister a la ceremonie du matin et entrer dans le temple d'argent (Antoine torse nu) pour honorer Shiva. Il y a moins de monde mais l'atmosphere est aussi magique
column9: avec le chant delicat d'une femme a cote de nous
column10: la chaleur ensorcelante des feux et l'odeur enivrante de l'encens! Nous sommes conquis par Shiva.

column1: Cornelia entouree des fideles de Shiva
tous ces moments restent graves a jamais dans nos coeurs mais qu'il n'y a pas de phtotos car ce n'est pas un spectacle pour les touristes

column1: Today a group of German executives visited the school. They are some of the primary donors and came to meet the children and see the facilities.

These executives are from the same companies that sponsored the football (soccer) tournament to raise money for the school this past weekend. I am so glad that I went. It was wonderfully fun to support the students as they played and to ride on the bus home celebrating their victory. But the tournament had a strange feeling. I often felt like the students were asked there to perform. I sometimes felt like they were put on display. I suppose that this was helpful in raising money
column2: but the objectification of it got to me. I don‚Äôt think the kids noticed
column3: thankfully
column4: but the volunteers spent much of the day glancing uncomfortably at each other. I don‚Äôt know where the school would be without cooperate sponsorships
column5: but I wish it didn‚Äôt come at such a cost. I wish people could do good
column6: without parading their beneficiaries around.

column2: I was asked to coach the students that would be talking to the visitors. I felt uncomfortable agreeing to do this
column3: as

column1: I think that they should not be told what to say. Nevertheless
column2: I said yes
column3: knowing that I could direct them as little or as much as I felt comfortable. I am so glad that I agreed. It was fun to talk with the children
column4: to practice introductions
column5: and to practice asking questions to the guests. They laughed at my fake German accent (which I didn‚Äôt do for the guests) and I laughed at their riddles and jokes.

column2: there was a special assembly. The children sang. The adults spoke. And the flash of cameras lit the backs of heads. When one of the guests introduced himself
column3: he said that every time he returns to Shanti Bhavan he feels like he is returning to paradise.

column1: He is not the first to say this. Some of the volunteers have said similar things: This is like a tropical paradise. This heaven. If I filmed a movie of the book of Genesis
column2: this would be the Garden of Eden. When dance students visited a few weeks ago
column3: some of them said that Shanti Bhavan is better than the school they attended or that they wish they could have

column1: While I understand this‚Äîit is so beautiful here
column2: and the school is good and full of good feelings‚Äîsomething about these statements make me feel uncomfortable. When I see the running water
column3: the electricity
column4: the well-roofed buildings
column5: the tasty food‚Ä¶ When I see all this
column6: I can‚Äôt help but think of what is absent: the dung and palm shacks
column7: the garbage
column8: the crowded streets
column9: the children in the puddles. If this is heaven
column10: hell is certainly outside the gates.

column1: I am so grateful for this school
column2: and I don‚Äôt mean to demean the work being done here. It is a beautiful place is so many ways
column3: not just because there are blooming flowers in January. But I feel that to call it heaven or to wish that you attended is to deny the achievement of the school and the humanity of the people responsible for its existence. Perhaps more important to me
column4: I feel it denies these children their histories. These children have experienced more than I will in my lifetime. They have experienced more than a tropical paradise.

column1: I have been harsh tonight. A few nights ago
column2: my roommate asked me if I find it

column1: hard to be around people. When I ask her what she meant
column2: she said that I have such high morals and such high expectations of people that if she were me
column3: she would hate everyone. I had never thought about this. I certainly don‚Äôt hate everyone. If any one. While I was disturbed by things at the soccer tournament and things today
column4: I do trust that everyone present have the best intentions (perhaps with the exception of the commentator at the game
column5: but that‚Äôs another story). I hope that this trust is not replaced completely by these criticisms.

column1: I feel like I am becoming a contradiction to rival this country. Now that the shield of newness has lost its original strength
column2: I am on a roller coaster of emotion. When I am playing with the children
column3: or teaching
column4: or talking with the volunteers I feel elated. I laugh so much in my classes
column5: at meals
column6: and at odd times throughout the day. But then I will be overwhelmed by sadness. I have cried in classes hit by the horrors addressed in the literature of the day. Today
column7: frustrated for a series of reasons
column8: I cried when another volunteer simply ask me what I thought of the meeting. But then a few minutes later
column9: I will be overwhelmed by the joy of the children
column10: the beauty of the place
column11: the kindness of people around me.

column1: I am not unused to crying or laughing more than other people are
column2: but I feel less grounded. Being here has made me more acutely sensitive. Writing helps. So does reading. But before today
column3: I hadn‚Äôt really talked to anyone about my frustrations. I am so glad the volunteer ask his question
column4: though I am not sure he knew what he was in for.

column1: KANCHIPURAM - est la ville la plus sacree de l'Inde du sud et la 2e ville plus sacree apres Varanasi! On ne pouvait evidemment pas la manquer. Ville typiquement indienne
column2: chaotique
column3: poussiereuse
column4: avec traffic dementiel. On partage la route avec les vaches sacrees
column5: les sacrees motos
column6: les tuk-tuks
column7: les voitures
column8: les rickshaws
column9: les bicycles
column10: les chiens et les chevres! Pas de trottoirs! mais beaucoup de poussiere! Cependant
column11: les temples! Nous avons visite 5. Le premier
column12: Kailasanthar
column13: date du VII siecle. En dehors de la ville
column14: il se dresse au milieu d'un petit jardin paisible. Quel bonheur! Le mur exterieur contient 58 chapelles avec la figure de Nandi
column15: le taureau sur lequel Shiva voyageait. Les sculptures exterieures sont magnifiques
column16: gracieuses et detaillees. On attend 1 heure pour que la meditation qui se deroule a l'interieur finisse pour rentrer dedans. Pas completement
column17: car les non-hindus n'ont pas accces dans l'autel. Mais nous jetons un coup d'oeil sur le lingam noir du lord Shiva
column18: dieu de la destruction et de la reconstruction
column19: de la danse et du sex (car son lingam est venere dans tous les temples qui y sont dedies).

column1: Le lendemain on visite le temple Varadarajar. Dans sa cour une magnifique

salle de marriage avec 96 pilliers monolythiques avec des sculptures erotiques (c'est ca le mariage!) inspirees de Kama Sutra. Superbe! Precieuses explications donnees par un brahmin de 10e generation
column2: avec un brin d'humour et de debauche dans ses yeux!

column1: On a quitte l'apres-midi avec un bus local. Chauffeur suicidaire et assassin!!!!! Personne ne resistait a son claxon pousse au fond pour depasser tout vehicule dans son chemin. Pendant le depassement les vehicules venant en sens inverse etaient quasiment pousses en dehors de la route pour ne pas se heurter a notre bus! Si on n'a pas fait de crise cardiaque ce jour-la c'est qu'on a le coeur solide. Notre beau et jeune chauffeur de bus devrait devenir pilote de courses
column2: il serait excellent sur les circuits les plus fous!

column1: MAMALLAPURAM - on est quand-meme arrives saints et saufs! Ooouf! On meritait un repos. Nous sommes donc alles habiter a l'exterieur de la ville dans un ""beach resort"" appartenant au gouvernement de l'etat. Grand parc au bord de la mer
column2: arbres magnifiques
column3: un jardin de sculptures
column4: superbe piscine et plein d'oiseaux incroyables
column5: pour rendre Huguette extatique
column6: car elle est une grande amateur d'ornitologie! De notre chambre au premier etage

column1: d'une jolie maisonnette on voit et on entend la mer agitee. Malheureusement c'est impossible de se baigner car le tsunami a completement modifie la plage qui descend vertigineusement dans la mer et personne n'ose rentrer car les vagues et les courants sont tres forts. C'est quand-meme tres beau. Nous sommes chanceux car la temperature et tres agreable 30C le jour
column2: 20C le soir
column3: avec une brise permanente qui fait notre bonheur.

column1: On est venus ici pour les caves sculptees et les ""rathas""
column2: temples monolythiques erriges sur des plateformes commes des charriots. En plus
column3: il y a une immense roche sculptee ""La descente de Gange"" avec des animaux
column4: des personnages
column5: des scenes de vie
column6: hallucinante!Mais le clou de notre sejour a Mamallapuram est le festival de danse indienne! Chaque soir
column7: sur la plage
column8: devant un temple du VII siecle
column9: des spectacles de danse classique indienne se deroulent de 17.30h a 21h! Nous sommes combles! La musique (et les musiciens) sont aussi fascinants que la danse. Les danseuses
column10: tres belles
column11: sont habilles dans des magnifiques costumes colores et scintillants. Nous quittons la ville avec regret. On aurait aime rester ici encore une semaineüòä Mais la route des pelerins nous attend.

column2: Displayed: 7

column1: We attended the lectures in the morning with the Prasad students. The first one
column2: by Uma ma'am
column3: was about religion and the role it plays in society. It was a comfortable and meandering kind of lecture
column4: more of a discussion. At the end
column5: I didn't feel there had been much of a specific point
column6: other than just to open lines of communication.

column2: the second lecture
column3: by professor and cinematographer Sunny Joseph
column4: was about different kinds of space in cinematography. He showed some examples of films with these kinds of spaces
column5: like deep space
column6: ambiguous space
column7: flat space
column8: and limited space. I realize there is so much more to learn.

column1: At lunch I had butterflies in my stomach because Jayshree was coming with Nandini
column2: also in the film
column3: and they were going to see what we had made of their interviews. I was particularly nervous that the film is supposed to build up to the climax where she says she doesn't have children
column4: and she looks a bit like she's trying to keep up the mask
column5: and I was worried she would not like being publicly displayed like that.

column2: I just about swallowed my heart
column3: and it was clear that they were nervous too. Ours was the first to screen
column4: and I can't believe how fast my heart was beating. I feel like having a screening is like having an autopsy while you're still alive.

column2: they asked us to stand in front of the group. We each had to describe our experience
column3: and this is pretty much the last thing I wanted to do
column4: but it was probably something really important to do
column5: as well. It's no good to run from things that terrify you.

column2: in that moment
column3: I felt a tremendous appreciation for everyone and everything that had conspired to let me come here to do this project. Traveling and working on difficult projects are two things that jumpstart a person's self growth
column4: and the two together are pretty fantastic.

column1: Reading to children is one of the best things in the world.

column2: volunteers read bedtime stories to the elementary-aged students. Last week I read picture books to the kindergarteners. The OSA has a great collection. Where the Wild Things Are
column3: Blueberry Girl
column4: There‚Äôs a Monster at the End of This Book
column5: Rain Makes Applesauce
column6: and others. This week I was assigned to the 4th graders. Another volunteer told me that this grade always complained that they had heard the stories before
column7: so I decided to read Haroun and the Sea of Stories instead of several picture books.

column1: The first night they were skeptical. When I arrived and told them what I would be reading
column2: they cried noooooo
column3: demanding that I instead tell them a story from my childhood. I promised that they would like this book
column4: and told them that I was going to read it. They were‚Ä¶fairly quiet. Some were not very interested
column5: whispering talking to their neighbor
column6: until I reminded them to turn off their voices. At the end I ask them what they thought would happen next. They answered half-heartedly.

column1: I told the other volunteers about their response. They asked if I was going to go give in and tell them stories about myself. I told them that I was committed
column2: even if it meant a week of slightly frustrating evenings. Afterwards
column3: as I prepared for the next day‚Äôs lesson on Macbeth
column4: I wondered if stubbornness will turn out to be my tragic flaw.

column2: I arrived at the 4th graders dorm with Haroun under my arm. Some of them grumbled that they couldn‚Äôt understand it. Another said that she would explain it to them after. I told them that they <em style=""mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"">all can understand it without explanation if they listen. When I ask what we read the night before
column3: I was happy and (I must admit) surprised how much they remembered. Then I started to read. At first
column4: they were restless again. But as I read
column5: they became quieter and quieter. And by the end of the passage
column6: as tears streamed down my face (the opening of the book is a bit sad)
column7: the whole class leaned forward
column8: silently trying to catch every word.

column1: It was magic: Seeing them drawn into the story. Seeing them forget that they were supposed to be bored and uninterested. Seeing everyone in a room sharing an experience.
When they asked why I was crying
column2: I told them that it was because the story is sad at the beginning. But a more honest answer
column3: I realize now
column4: is that I cried because of the magic in the air. I felt so connected to the story
column5: to the children
column6: and to myself in those last minutes. And that feeling of connection was beautifully overwhelming.

column1: We are finished. Except I think we have to fix something with the credits
column2: but we are done. We met at 8:30 this morning
column3: and worked til maybe 7. Shweta had to leave at 6 because she had a show. She is a professional whistler and a singer. It was so painful today to cut more. I thought it was hard yesterday. We adopted a method
column4: between Raj and myself
column5: that when we disagreed
column6: when one of us left the room
column7: the other one directed Shweta to make the changes that we wanted. And if the other person didn't notice when they came back
column8: those changes stayed. We knew more needed to be cut
column9: it was just so hard to do it. I think this could be a slightly longer film. But directors always think so.

column1: Did I mention the most wonderful music composed for our film in FIVE MINUTES by the brilliant young Hanees? He is such a joy to be around
column2: and talented
column3: only 18 years old. And such good timing. The guy who was supposed to compose for us had gotten so drunk that he was hung over all day and didn't come to school. So Hanees composed this
column4: and a guitar guy just walked in the room and Hanees grabbed him
column5: had him play it twice
column6: recorded it
column7: and that was it!

column2: we got a new editor for a bit
column3: Manu. He is the only person I've had a bit of a hard time connecting with. I didn't like the titles he was making. They were too small and just popped up from nowhere. They felt disorganized. I said so. He said they were good. I asked if he always did it that way
column4: he said yes. I said
column5: may I just ask
column6: what if we do something else. He said no. I left the room for a bit.

column1: I thought it was an ego thing on my part. I am the director
column2: blah blah
column3: I want to do what I want. But when I was as objective as I could possibly be
column4: the titles he made looked bad. Raj agreed
column5: but Manu overrode him too. Finally
column6: Manu just left. We were left to edit on our own
column7: and though I felt bad
column8: the first thing we did was change all the titles to a lower thirds type that were visible on all the backgrounds.

column1: Tomorrow we screen! Jayshree is coming!
First I am so relieved that we've been given another day to edit! But I can feel the stress starting to set in with everyone. It is so so hard to cut at this point
column2: tensions are running a little higher than usual
column3: and we're all feeling it. Pradeep and Teja (producer) have been so kind and respectful
column4: just popping in once in a while to say hi
column5: Raj and Shweta have been dedicated
column6: especially Shweta! What patience! I get frustrated with Umila at times because she hangs out with all the different groups and people
column7: and just comes back and says
column8: ""Why did you cut the sound and put space? That is so weird. So she's just going to talk and then stop? It won't sound good."" And it is frustrating to try to explain basics like that when we're on a time crunch. I hope I'm being nice but I know my annoyance comes out sometimes.

column2: we have one more day. We stayed til 9
column3: so literally a 12 hour day. I am so into it
column4: and people keep saying
column5: just have fun
column6: enjoy yourself
column7: you can do films anytime
column8: but when will you be in India again
column9: with these people? Either I am a prude or anti-social or something
column10: but I really want to work hard on this project. I feel like every project I've done before never reflects what I was trying to do
column11: and part of wanting to go on this trip was to build up my confidence about filmmaking again
column12: because I felt that my last film was so crappy that I didn't want to continue trying to make documentaries. I need to work hard so that I know if I really just am not good enough to do this.

column2: how will we finish this by the end of tomorrow? It is not possible. I really like having a group for the purpose of working through ideas
column3: and having sounding boards
column4: but it takes so much longer to edit! I feel it will be worth it in the end
column5: but if it was me alone
column6: I would watch things again and again and again
column7: and Shweta needs only to watch things once. Then she wants an answer about which clip to use. Really? How does she store all that info. Add to this the fact that my dear Raj came super late and then left super early to work on ""The Making Of"" credit animation
column8: so I didn't feel like I could make decisions without checking with him. Our film was an hour last night
column9: and tonight it got down to half an hour
column10: so it's an improvement.

column1: We went to a restaurant nearby for dinner
column2: and I let the Indians order my food. I don't think there is anything I have eaten here that I haven't liked.

column1: Shrine offerings for sale outside of the temple

It has been a while since I‚Äôve written anything. I think this may be more of a weekend blog than a daily diary. (Just noticed that diary and dairy are so close in spelling.) So much has happened and I have so much to write about I don‚Äôt know where to start.
I feel more comfortable teaching. I am not sure how I will feel after a few more months
column2: but right now
column3: I could see myself becoming a classroom teacher in the States. At the beginning of the week
column4: I was really frustrated with the standardized test my 12th graders are going to take soon. The test leaves very little room for varied interpretation of the literature and some of the interpretations for with the graders are looking are in my view incorrect or at least incomplete. I was also frustrated because I felt like my students were so worried about the test that they weren‚Äôt willing to think for themselves. When I gave them a writing exercise
column5: they wanted be to tell them the right answer. But as the week went on
column6: I started to enjoy the challenge of leading them to the answer the test graders want

column1: without telling them what to write. I think I am getting better about asking questions to guild discussion
column2: but it is difficult. I remember great admiration the ease with which professors of mine directed conversations in class.

column1: Another volunteer arrived yesterday. She is from Puerto Rico and seems really lovely. With her arrival
column2: we have five nationalities represented in the staff. There are the permanent Indian teachers and volunteers from the States
column3: Russia
column4: Scotland
column5: and Puerto Rico (which I suppose is technically an unincorporated territory). It is wonderful to be in one place with people from so many countries. It is curious to hear people‚Äôs perspective on America and to hear about their norms and ideals. I have tended to resist the notion that people‚Äôs place is greatly reflective in their personality
column6: actions
column7: values
column8: and so on. Here this tendency seems absurd. Being here and talking with students
column9: teachers
column10: and other volunteers has shown me just how ‚ÄúAmerican‚Äù or at least how ‚ÄúWestern‚Äù I am. There is even a noticeable difference between the volunteers from the east coast of the U.S. and those of us from else were in the country. It makes me wonder how I would be

column1: different if I had grown up in New York
column2: Russia
column3: or India.

column1: Today we went into Hosur again
column2: but this time visited a temple on the top of a hill looking over the city. It was an interesting and powerful experience. When we arrived
column3: we had to remove our shoes and leave them near the gate. Perhaps what I remember the most clearly is temperatures and textures my feet moved over as we walked to and through the temple. The exterior of the temple was elaborate and colorful. The interior was dark and mostly stone. While I am glad we went
column4: it felt strange to be there
column5: especially as a tourist. It felt like a violation to be there just to look and see something new
column6: when people were there to pray. The people offering gifts at shrines or bowing before a deity seemed to be involved in such an intimate act (I think it seemed especially private
column7: because I am used to corporal worship). And there I was with my backpack and water bottle
column8: not sure of what I was supposed or not supposed to do.

column1: The temple felt like a contradiction
column2: though not an unfamiliar one.

column1: It was beautiful: the stones and shrines carved with care
column2: the bells chiming
column3: the smell of burning oil. The dim lighting
column4: the cold under my feet
column5: the echoing of footsteps and whispered prayers. This all made the place seem sacred. And yet. Guide rails like those in a museum prevented visitors from approaching the main shrines. Priests alone could go near. And as I was in the holy place
column6: feeling self conscious and unsure of proper decorum
column7: I couldn‚Äôt help think of all the labor
column8: resources
column9: and money it cost to build such a temple. I couldn‚Äôt help but think of the naked child I saw bathing near her shack just below the temple. I was revisited by an unease I have felt when visiting cathedrals. I appreciate the beauty and the sanctity of a shared holy place
column10: but I question the expense. When I exited the temple
column11: I was struck by the prettiness of the blue sky
column12: the pleasantness of the breeze
column13: the songs of birds. I wonder sometimes why we need temples when we already have all that on top of the hill.

column2: Displayed: 25

column1: We went to the academy this morning. Who knew that just leaving for 5 days would make returning feel like coming home? Pradeep had logged and captured our footage
column2: and Shweta was already at work naming the clips. Here we go! We were not allowed to do any actual editing until we had watched all our footage and submitted our final structure to the professors. Shweta hadn't seen the footage yet
column3: though she was there on set
column4: and since some group members didn't show up forever
column5: it was hard to get stuff done because I didn't want to step on anyone's toes and take too much creative control
column6: especially since I have a codirector.

column2: they accepted it
column3: and we went back to the editing lab. I was so happy that Shweta had asked in advance for the editing lab II
column4: which has much nicer computers
column5: and specifically for the computer with FCP instead of Avid. She knows both
column6: but she knew that I only knew FCP. We had the best best best computer
column7: and I love my group.

column1: The focus of the day for me was not what we actually did. Yes
column2: we visited the shore temple
column3: a beautiful limestone couple of monoliths
column4: with features that have been pitted and erased of detail by the harsh sea air. Yes
column5: it was beautiful. But for me
column6: the focus was that I had a small existential crisis triggered by an audiobook I listened to on the bus
column7: ""Beyond the Beautiful Forevers."" It describes the lives of people who live in the slum just outside the Mumbai airport
column8: which was actually ""founded"" by immigrants from Tamil Nadu
column9: who were construction workers working at the airport. One moment of the book I found particularly painful was the description of a little boy who worked as a trash collector. he'd then separate the recyclables. One day as he put recyclables into the machine
column10: his hand got caught
column11: and cut off. As he stood bleeding
column12: he didn't scream. Instead
column13: he apologized to the recycling plant owner. Apologized! And said
column14: ""Sir
column15: I won't complain. You won't have any further trouble from me."" WTF is wrong with this world.

column2: and then seeing our American students complaining about the A/C bus and substantial food
column3: while passing and ignoring a slew of beggars
column4: I felt sick to my stomach
column5: and not because of the food. Seeing other Americans is like seeing myself from an outsider's point of view. I feel so powerless to change what exists. I am one person
column6: and right now
column7: I feel like a leaf in a river. This river has been flowing for a long time. Who am I to judge its course
column8: and who am I to try and change it? But this river is a reflection of the social disease in our global culture. Money is power
column9: power is value
column10: the poor are considered worthless
column11: and everyone believes it
column12: even them.

column1: I want to return here in April
column2: after I travel
column3: and make another documentary.

column1: We took a bus for 30 min. (We joke that everything is 30 min
column2: but in reality is always longer.) We left our hotel in Pondicherry
column3: and arrived at Auroville
column4: the intentional community
column5: that describes itself as ""an emerging international township dedicated to the ideal of Human Unity."" A path led us past a self-cleaning water treatment system
column6: through trees
column7: with sections of shade built for comfort
column8: to this utopian villa of all kinds of people. I saw women in burquas
column9: backpackers with dredlocks
column10: locals in local clothing
column11: and elderly couples in sandals. We stopped in for a 10 minute informative video
column12: which had me chomping at the bit to get inside to magical golden globe half a km away
column13: start concentrating or meditating or whatever
column14: the interior of which is painted white with white carpet and white spherical insides and a big crystal in the center which has a beam of sunlight channeled and reflected onto it with a series of mirrors. Finally! Inner peace and success and focus
column15: at this idyllic center for all things good! We stopped
column16: as always for tea
column17: and headed out to the globe
column18: which is called the Matrimandir.

column2: I had a fascinating conversation with the Dr and a few others about the concept of eunuchs
column3: or hermaphrodites. They apparently have a bit of a supernatural or religious vibe about them. She explained that there is one day a year
column4: during which all the eunuchs get together and spend a long time preparing themselves
column5: purifying themselves
column6: and getting ready like they are getting married. Then on the day of this festival of sorts
column7: women send their husbands to them
column8: and they engage in a massive anal sex orgy. Yes
column9: women actually send their husbands to have sex with hermaphrodites. It is considered a blessing. The following day
column10: once the men have gone home
column11: the eunuchs grieve as if their husbands have died. It is considered terrible luck to come across a eunuch on this day of grieving
column12: and everyone avoids them.

column1: I was wondering about this concept of hermaphrodites
column2: because I know that in Thailand
column3: the kathooey is considered to have supernatural powers as well
column4: and is even considered as a third sex. They tend to have jobs as prostitutes in both countries
column5: but it is difficult to imagine how they can form loving lasting relationships.

column1: We arrived at the viewing point for the Matrimandir. We could not enter because we would have had to apply to go inside a few days beforehand. Still there were dozens of people
column2: foreigners and locals alike
column3: standing and sitting at the viewing point and looking across at the golden globe
column4: perhaps in hope of feeling some residual concentration from the crystal within the globe. The Dr spoke at length about religion in India
column5: and afterwards
column6: we sat in silent meditation. Some in our group were more interested in quoting movies they like
column7: and when this started to piss me off
column8: I tried to see it as just another distraction in this world
column9: and it is not the distraction's fault that I can't concentrate
column10: it is my responsibility to be strong enough to block out the distraction. In the end
column11: I had to ask them to be quiet
column12: and I tried to concentrate for a while more.

column2: we got in the bus and went to the Ashram that is connected to Auroville
column3: and I got some time to meditate there. I don't know if I like meditation
column4: but I think it's supposed to be good for you. And if my goal this year is to not worry
column5: maybe I could make use of this. While I was sitting there though
column6: I felt that I liked the Ashram a good bit better than Auroville. Even when I spoke with the Dr about it all during lunch
column7: she said that the problem with Auroville was a lack of good management. I myself didn't like that the locals seemed totally separate from Auroville
column8: even as it professed to be a utopia of no barriers. The Dr said that the locals who worked there didn't even really get the concept of Auroville. After a while
column9: neither did I.

column2: we met at the beach. Actually
column3: it was not a beach
column4: but a rocky shore
column5: but people were gathered there
column6: as people gather at any shore
column7: to look out at the water.

column1: We got on our bus this morning (which is emblazoned with ""GLORY TO JESUS"" across the front windshield) and headed towards Pondicherry. After 4 hours of travel
column2: we stopped at a temple
column3: though we didn't go inside
column4: so we could do some more shopping in the plentiful shops and stalls along the street. I got some tiny clay pots that you are supposed to put a bit of oil and a cotton wool wick
column5: so they can burn like they do in the temples.

column1: We got back on the bus for 2 hours
column2: headed for a river bank where we could apparently wade inside. However
column3: it turns out the bus driver took a wrong turn and wasn't able to take us to this particular riverside park
column4: because the bridge for vehicular travel was a few km back
column5: and the bridge ahead of us was intended only for motorcycles and very small cars and bicycles.

column1: Exactly as Vinit was explaining this to us at the front of the bus
column2: the bus lurched forward
column3: and we found ourselves testing the structural integrity of this 1km long bridge
column4: as well as the patience of people who couldn't cross from the other side until we had gotten all the way over. When I looked out the window of the bus
column5: I couldn't even see the guard rail
column6: I just saw straight all the way down to the shriveled river far below. When we looked out the front
column7: the entire bridge was hardly wider than the width of the bus
column8: and seemed impossibly long. This is not how I wanted to leave this world
column9: but there was nothing to do but hold on and hope.

column1: We did survive. Once we got to the park
column2: I saw the children's playground
column3: which is equally inhabited by human children and monkeys. Across the road is the river. We parked
column4: and we walked down to a place where the steps lead straight into the river. This is no Ganges
column5: but it was cool to see a river. The landscape of the river
column6: with its flat water and occasional patches of land in the middle
column7: was a welcome calm
column8: especially on such a high energy trip with many people.

column1: The Dr was the first in the water. She just dipped her feet in
column2: but it was enough to make me desperately want to get in
column3: heedless of the warnings about bacteria and everything else. I mean
column4: if a doctor is inside
column5: I can go
column6: right? A note about the Dr: we all love her. We have already discussed that we will do anything she tells us. Her supernatural abilities to give meds to the sick ones on our trip
column7: explain about Indian history and culture
column8: and shoo the lecherous men away
column9: have given her an aura of omnipotence
column10: which we all seem to respect. The Dr's husband is another story. His abilities are more limited to talking your ear off
column11: repeating himself
column12: and
column13: being hard of hearing
column14: not answering the questions that you actually asked. However
column15: he's also proving himself to be a bit of a rabble rouser and a mischeivous prankster. He goaded everyone for not going in the water
column16: saying that I was the only bold one. He convinced me to go deeper into the water
column17: up to my knees
column18: until the Dr started screaming at him from the top of the stairs.

column1: There was a round boat with a paddle at the edge of the shore (first step). Some people had caught fish and had left them in nets in the water
column2: I assume just to keep them alive. I picked one up
column3: for a picture
column4: and when I put it down
column5: the woman who owned these fish came shouting down the steps. Apparently I had put them down in a way that the fish could have escaped. I apologized
column6: and she was very gracious.

column2: I would never have touched that net. My tentancy when traveling is to air on the side of caution
column3: and not touch what isn't mine. But in a group
column4: I AM bolder
column5: and more rude. I suppose the same goes for most people.

column1: After all the things we've done and visited
column2: I would say that this stop was my favorite activity so far on this trip. These people we not expecting us
column3: they didn't try to entertain us
column4: they didn't try to sell anything to us
column5: they were just living their everyday life and were kind enough to let us visit.

column1: Asia ¬ª India ¬ª Tamil Nadu ¬ª Chennai ¬ª Elliot's Beach
YUPIII!!!! Nous sommes arrives en Inde saines et saufs! Il fait chaud et beau! Chennai ne nous a pas trop impressionne
column2: ville trop grande
column3: etendue et nous n'avons pas pu lui trouver l'ame. Mais nous avons vu notre premier temple dravidien et nous avons mis les pieds dans le Golfe du Bengal (chaud et agite!). C'est la que nous avons trouve plus l'ame de la vile car la plage etait noire de monde
column4: des locaux qui viennent passer la fin de la journee en bord de mer en piqueniquant et en se saucant dans l'eau.

column1: Mais nous avons eu notre petit coin de ""paradis"" car le hostel de YWCA etait dasn un jardin paisible et verdoyant au nord de la ville. Il y a des jolies batisses (gare
column2: mairie) de style plutot britannique. On avait hate de continuer la route!
Displayed: 5

column1: Today we woke up and walked nearby to a place to catch a bus to a village festival. There are already 17 of us
column2: but we were not the only ones going to this festival. There were two whole buses of foreigners going
column3: all from various organized tours.

column2: it was hot and sunny and so so bright. As we approached the village
column3: welcomers gave us yellow flower leis
column4: but instead of being round like our leis in Hawaii
column5: they had an extra appendage of flowers hanging. These are the kind of leis reserved for the Gods. They are offered in shrines
column6: and I learned that you are not even allowed to smell them
column7: because the first whiff is meant to be for the Gods. Why were we given these leis? Either 1) to mark us as tourists
column8: or 2) because God is in all of us
column9: and you must worship the God in everyone.

column1: There were dancers with the most elaborate makeup and costumes
column2: men on stilts with horse costumes as if they were riding horseback
column3: and drumming and music everywhere. We walked through the village towards to throbbing hub of action in the center
column4: but along the way there were so many festively dressed people
column5: I wanted to take pictures. And since this was a place where tourists are welcomed
column6: we were assured it was ok to take pictures. Narrow winding roads. Women and children poking out from every doorway. A man who I think worked for this whole production adopted me at some point because I kept lagging behind. He'd point out more things for me to take pictures of.

column1: In the center of the village was a space for performance in the round
column2: surrounded by various forms of seating
column3: from a thatch covered shady area with plastic chairs
column4: to the sun-beated concrete. There were entirely too many people. This village had exceeded its maximum carrying capacity by 300%. Everyone was hot and anxious for the performances
column5: and everyone with a camera was clammering for a good spot.

column1: First were the men on stilts with fake horses
column2: and following were women dancing with the same headdresses like the girls at the NGO
column3: a clown/magician who did some magic tricks that were much too small scale for most of the crowd to see
column4: though one thing he did was pull about a mile of colorful paper from his mouth. I enjoyed it
column5: but I was tremendously overwhelmed by the crowd and the heat. And also by the fact that several times local people were kicked out of their seats so that I could sit down. NO! That is not ok. This is their celebration
column6: and I am the visitor
column7: so I should get to squeeze in wherever I can
column8: but I should not be given special treatment. In some ways
column9: the whole thing made me feel like I was a celebrity
column10: but I was not sure what I had done to deserve such fame.

column2: they made us but those headdresses on and dance with them. Then they realized we were not coordinated enough to do that
column3: so they made us stand and get our picture taken.

column1: I eventually went back to the part of the crowd where there was shade and zero visibility of the ""stage""
column2: because I knew I was getting crazy sunburned. Some kids started talking to us
column3: and one got interested in my purell hand sanitizer that I have hanging as a keychain. They thought it was food. I showed them how to put it in their hands and rub the hands together and then
column4: to demonstrate that they are clean
column5: to smell the hands. This brought on an onslaught of child purell obsession
column6: which I could never have anticipated. Suddenly I was surrounded with children
column7: holding their hands out
column8: and I am sure they don't understand the purpose of it
column9: other than to smell different. How do you explain
column10: ""It kills 99% of germs"" to a village child in India? Especially when they don't speak English.

column1: There was some kind of theatrical dance in which two people had massive head-masks painted pink with blond hair. I imagined they must be some representation of british
column2: and I kept waiting for the beheading of one of them
column3: followed by cheers from the audience
column4: or something like this
column5: but nothing happened.

column2: we ate in a large room
column3: on the floor
column4: off of a banana leaf. We thought it would be a light lunch
column5: but I was stuffed at the end. Before we left
column6: they asked us to fill out a questionnaire about how they could improve the festival next year. WHAT? This festival is yours
column7: not mine! Do what you want to do! That was crazy to me.

column2: we went to the huge temple
column3: around which Madurai was built. It is so big
column4: that once you enter the first gate
column5: there is basically an entire city inside. Shops
column6: restaurants
column7: people's homes
column8: everything. We went to a rooftop to see some of the towers with the beautiful late afternoon light. A bunch of people were suckered into buying things at exhorbitant prices.

column2: it was already dark. We had been devoured by mosquitos
column3: and I got to see first hand some of the results of a culture that is sexually repressive. No sex til marriage is the official stance
column4: and a group of men wearing black from another temple
column5: which the Dr had warned us not to go near
column6: were practically foaming at the mouth. As they lined up next to us
column7: they each grasped the shoulders of the man in front of him
column8: as if they had to hold on to something to refrain from pouncing. Even inside
column9: as the Dr showed us statues of different goddesses with one hand
column10: she waved away the men with the other hand. She just told them in Tamil
column11: ""Go! Why are you standing there? You have seen enough!"" The men in our group took the responsibility of creating a barrier around us. This is doing little to foster my sense of feminist freedom. This is not a country where I feel I have much freedom. The only freedom I get is from the fact that I'm a foreigner
column12: and thus don't play by the same rules. But never going somewhere alone at night
column13: and accepting that I shouldn't
column14: and rarely going anywhere alone during the day
column15: is hard for me to swallow. I am accustomed to being able to go ANYWHERE alone.

column2: what a beautiful temple! It was built 2000 years ago
column3: and has never had a fresh coat of paint
column4: and yet the entire interior and exterior are so magnificently painted in brilliant colors. As before
column5: we were not permitted to go into the inner sanctum
column6: being non-Hindus
column7: but Vinit
column8: the Dr
column9: and Umila could go in
column10: so we
column11: exhausted by then
column12: waited near the entrance to the sanctum. I feel like we did too much in one day
column13: so I wasn't able to properly enjoy all of it
column14: and I didn't enjoy all of it
column15: but it's all part of the experience.

column1: There are drawings I've been meaning to mention
column2: in front of every doorway. They are done
column3: I think
column4: in chalk
column5: with white chalk for the borders and colored chalk as filled in color decoration. Originally
column6: they were done in rice flour. They were intended to keep bugs out of the house. But as time went on
column7: they became popular more for the decorative aspect.

column1: Today we got on our little tour bus (which we'll be keeping for the duration of our stay away from Chennai) and drove to an NGO. The bus ride was long and many of us fell asleep. I was glad to see a bit of the landscape
column2: outside of cities
column3: outside of expected tourism
column4: and just see everyday life
column5: if only from the window.

column1: The NGO is run by a Catholic priest who was a bit of an activist
column2: but got sick of the Church telling him he couldn't rock the boat
column3: so he started this NGO to create tomorrow's leaders
column4: who themselves will rock the boat. We had thought we were going to see an orphanage
column5: but a lot of the people there
column6: mostly girls
column7: were not orphans
column8: but from a poor family
column9: and this school gave them opportunities they wouldn't otherwise have. They were all of the lowest caste
column10: the Dalits
column11: once called ""untouchables"" but as the caste system has been morphing and changing and partially becoming obsolete
column12: the Dalits have begun to gather their strength and political power and there is now the equivalent of Affirmative Action
column13: and a certain percentage of all college acceptances MUST be Dalits.

column2: the priest himself spoke to us at length about his dream for this school. We were served chai
column3: and soon after
column4: a group of girls danced a traditional folk dance for us. One dance was with handkerchiefs
column5: and the other was with large headdresses that looked like jugs balanced on their heads
column6: and they would do all these things and never let the headdresses fall from their heads.

column1: We then saw the recording studio
column2: where many of these girls have recorded traditional music
column3: and apparently this is the best
column4: most sophisticated recording studio in Madurai. Several feature films have asked to use the recording studio
column5: and they have only given permission to films that either are about Dalits
column6: or star Dalits.

column1: We had been given candy to give to the children
column2: and none of us had passed it on to the children yet
column3: so it was getting all warm in our hands. We saw some older children in the computer lab
column4: and so we gave it to them. They played some music
column5: and the girls started dancing again. Rikki made a little friend in a girl who wanted to specifically teach her to dance. Later on
column6: we found out that these ""children"" that we had given candy to
column7: that we thought were so cute because they wanted to teach us to dance
column8: and had cute big dreams of being an aeronautical engineer
column9: were actually 20 or 21 years old! The moment I found this out
column10: I felt like such an idiot. How condescending I must have seemed! Why were we told they were children in an orphanage? Why were we given candy to give them? Why did they look so young?

column2: we drove to a Monkey Temple. There were 3 gates decorated in the same multicolored style of many temples
column3: and when we finally got to the top and parked
column4: we took off our shoes and walked up to join the long line of people entering the temple. Since I'm not Hindu
column5: I couldn't enter the inner part where people seemed to have some kind of water ceremony that looked like a baptism equivalent. As we stood
column6: all around us we could see real monkeys. Just like the one I had seen in Chennai with the old lady. I felt cautious about taking too many pictures inside the temple
column7: since it seems so voyeuristic and rude. One man shouted to me
column8: and waved his hand. I wasn't sure if I should respond
column9: because I figured he was going to yell at me. But when I looked over
column10: he vigorously demanded that I take a picture of him.

column2: we discovered that we could feed the monkeys
column3: so people bought bags of some kind of puffed rice
column4: sold specifically for that purpose. The monkeys are much more in the know than any of us
column5: and once they saw the bags
