column6: the bolder ones would attack the bag
column7: which was made simply of newspaper
column8: so it would burst and spill the contents on the ground. I got one to eat from my hand. Some of them were mean. Reflecting later
column9: I realized all of them were mean. Really cute
column10: strangely human
column11: but not friendly.

column1: I am writing from Shanti Bhavan
column2: a school in the Tamil Nadu region of India. It is very warm here. Although I miss seeing your snowmen and playing with you in the snow
column3: I must admit that I am glad that it is not below zero here. Instead it is warm
column4: but it hasn't been too hot. A pleasant breeze keeps me cool.

column1: There are palm trees and brightly colored flowers. A gecko sometimes finds her way into my bedroom
column2: which is neat. She eats the insects and is quite cute. Other people here have seen snakes
column3: but I have yet to see one. If I do
column4: I'll let you know.

column1: I think you would have fun playing with my students here. They like to play soccer and basketball. They have also taught me an Indian game I will teach you when I come home. You have to stack rocks while you avoid being tagged.
I don't think all of you would like the food. It is delicious
column2: but more spicy than many of you would like. If you think the salsa from snack is too hot
column3: than this food would definately be inedible. Even their breakfasts are spicy. I like it a lot
column4: but sometimes wish I could have a pancake with syrup.

column1: I hope you all had a wonderful winter break and are enjoying school. Although I am greatly enjoying my time here
column2: I miss you all and am excited to see you again.

column1: Keep your eyes open for a postcard in the next couple of weeks!
What a lovely weekend. I am grateful for the extra day (today is a holiday in Tamil Nadu). Not because I had too much to do
column2: but because I felt like I had to much to do. At the end of last week
column3: having jumped straight into teaching
column4: I felt a bit overwhelmed. Or at least behind. But after a weekend of exploring
column5: rest
column6: and planning
column7: I feel better about the direction of my classes and my place here at the school.

column1: I want to keep this post short
column2: so here's the skinny...

column1: Today was one of the volunteer's last day. This is her second time at Shanti Bhavan and she jsut visited a short time. It was lovely. One of the aunties--the caregivers to the students--dressed the volunteer in a beautiful sari. At assembly
column2: the children spoke about her and gave her a card. It was wonderful to see so much happiness and love. But it was strange in a sense as well. It was strange to see an end at what feels like a beginning. I can't imagine what it must be like as a student always having teachers come and go. I think for them it becomes routine. But it certainly isn't routine for the volunteers. Volunteers come here to give to the students
column3: to positively effect their lives. But I think it is the volunteer's whose life is really changed.

column1: Meals were fittingly delicious for such a special day: At breakfast
column2: fried egg and masala dosa--a crepe of sorts filled with spiced potatoes and onions
column3: and covered with curry sauce. Dinner was fairly normal--curry
column4: rice
column5: and a beet relish--but there was also fresh vegetables in yogurt. So refreshing to have something cold and simple. Although I have greatly enjoyed the food
column6: I have missed raw vegetables.

column2: I played basketball with the other volunteers and students. I don't know if I have ever had so much fun making a fool of myself. Afterwards
column3: my roommate and I listened to The Decemberists as we changed for dinner. It felt good to move and sweat and laugh at myself. I think that I have been thinking so much about my classes and about my experience
column4: I haven't been as silly as I want to be. From now on I hope to have a good serving of goofiness with my thoughfulness. And more music! I hadn't listened to music since I arrived
column5: and I realized as I sang along how much I have missed it.

column1: Mostly from my trip it to Hosur
column2: but a few from around campus.
Displayed: 22
by which I mean
column3: it got so foggy that it made surfaces wet. It was beautiful this morning but somewhat eerie. The fog deepened all the colors and everything was heavy. As the fog lifted
column4: it was as if the colors woke up after sleeping in. The soil is rust orange
column5: the foliage rich green
column6: and the flowers electric purples and pinks.

column1: It was a lazy morning as I watched the colors come to life. I finished some grading and planned for a class. After breakfast
column2: a group of us when into Hosur
column3: a nearby town
column4: by which I mean a city larger than Bozeman. It was my first time off campus since driving at night from the airport. We rode into town in auto-rickshaws
column5: bumping our way down dirt roads and slowly whipping our way through traffic. What a way to be introduced to the countryside and an India town. Along the road
column6: I saw families with two-year-olds on motorcycles (no minivans here!)
column7: trucks of caged chickens
column8: and a woman standing in front of her lean-to shack texting on her cell phone.

column1: Hosur was unlike any town I have seen. On our way from the shopping district to lunch
column2: when got caught in a traffic jam that would make anyone grateful for rush hour in the states. Cars against rickshaw against motorcycle against pedestrian. My roommate said that she could make friends with the person in the adjacent vehicle; they were as close to her as I was. As we lurched our way through the packed streets
column3: the my senses were bombarded. The smell of exhaust gave way to the smell of curry
column4: which was then replaced by the pungent flower garlands hanging from shop canopies.

column1: We browsed the stands selling clothes and a few volunteers bought school supplies. The fabrics were as vibrant as the city was fragrant. Textiles of very color imaginable stacked and hanging in the open shops. Although I would like some more Indian tops
column2: I didn‚Äôt buy any. I felt overwhelmed by the street-side setting. I don‚Äôt much like buying clothes in the first place; so having to choose without trying them on
column3: and with motorcycles and rickshaws zooming behind me was a lot to process. I think next time I go into town I will be more prepared for the experience. And hopefully able to be decisive without holding up the whole group.

column1: After shopping we went to lunch. Some of the volunteers have been here for quite a long time already; they have been craving anything that isn‚Äôt curry and rice. So
column2: we went to Pizza Korner
column3: the Indian version of Pizza Hut. In addition to the American style toppings
column4: they also had paneer
column5: corn
column6: and‚Ä¶curry. The pizza was tasty but different‚Äîslightly spongy and very sweet. We also each ordered dessert. Although I have been content with the sweet tea and a piece of chocolate a brought from home on occasion
column7: it was lovely to have ice cream.

column1: Next stop was the grocery store. Almost as congested as the streets at times
column2: the narrow aisles has held both the familiar and unknown. There was nutella
column3: Coca-Cola
column4: and cornflakes
column5: but also brands and items unknown to me. In addition to lotion and a small flashlight
column6: I bought ThumbsUp
column7: the Indian cola
column8: and an almond milk drink. (The cola was good
column9: a bit stronger than the colas in the U.S.
column10: with a slight bitter taste. The almond drink was too sweet
column11: but the flavor was nice). Across the street was a fruit market. I bought a few kokosan
column12: which I had tried earlier that day. It looks like a small kiwi crossed with a potato on the outside. Inside it is brown and fibrous. It is quite juicy and very sweet. I also bought a few teparee
column13: which look like large gooseberries and which I have yet to try. I am not sure how they will taste
column14: but I am excited to try something new.

column1: Then we returned to campus to grading and then dinner
column2: which surprisingly was pasta. They of course served rice and curry for those not interested in the Italian culinary experience
column3: not that the dish was terribly Italian to begin with. The red sauce was more of a sweet and sour sauce
column4: and the pasta had coconut in it. I certainly prefer the curry
column5: but it was fun to try. As one of the students I ate with played with his food
column6: he told me gratefully that tomorrow night they serve chicken (the only night of the week the children eat meat).

column1: It was hard for me to settle down at the end of the day. So much newness set my mind in a whirl. I wonder how long it will take before more of what I see feels familiar or recognizable than foreign. Can a person reach that place in four months?
An OSA who can tell me what a kokosan is
We left on the train to Madurai in the evening. We packed what we actually needed
column2: which it seems is a fraction of all the stuff we actually brought
column3: and piled into the bus
column4: and off at the nearby train station. We had all been so thoroughly warned about bag-slashers
column5: pick-pockets and all manner of thieves
column6: it seemed like everyone was preparing to see the ""real India."" In reality
column7: it was not a big deal. We even got to rest in an A/C room before the train arrived. This kind of separation from what the average person experiences actually frustrates me a lot. Yes
column8: A/C is nice. But we are already Americans
column9: and when I look to the Indian side
column10: I feel like they are judging the rich Americans for parading around in their country with money and demands and a sense of entitlement. And when I look to the American side
column11: I feel like everyone feels they are enduring a terrible misfortune because someone has a bug bite and someone can't buy a cold soda. If people want everything to be easy and comfortable
column12: what business do they have coming to a third world country?

column1: Our group was broken into three groups on different train cars. Ours was the only with no separating curtains
column2: which I actually liked because if somebody is coming
column3: you see them coming from a long way away. It was a triple bunk
column4: and the middle bed folded down during daylight hours
column5: to be the seat back of the passengers sitting on the bottom bunk.

column1: I find that I have much more patience with something like a lack of facilities
column2: than I do with people complaining about things that are not such a big deal. Cockroaches coming out of the cracks in the wall? They are tiny. I just killed them with my slipper. This is India
column3: so shut up and deal with it. You can't expect 5 star accomadation to follow you like a protective capsule everywhere you go.

column1: In the middle of the night
column2: when I had to go to the bathroom
column3: I wrestled with the idea because I didn't want to wake the person below me. Finally
column4: I jumped down and went to the next car
column5: where the bathroom is. Squat toilets on a moving train are a fun challenge. Figuring out how to flush them is even more fun. But when I was walking back to my own car
column6: I paused to look out of the open doors at the landscape. The doors are either ajar or wide open during the whole ride
column7: and when I say open
column8: I mean there is nothing keeping you from jumping or falling out. No protective bars or chains.

column1: The train had slowed a bit
column2: so I peeked out cautiously
column3: and then took hold of the yellow handles on either side of the door and leaned out to feel the wind and take a whiff of non-city night air. I saw people on the ground running toward the train. In the 3am darkness
column4: it was difficult to see them
column5: and I started to think I had imagined it all.

column1: Yesterday was our second and last day of shooting. It was only yesterday but it already seems so long ago. We were at the academy by 9:30 to meet our crew and the hired van. Raj Kumar and I had each prepared some questions
column2: and we got together and compiled a complete cohesive ordered list of questions for our main subject (Jayshree)
column3: her teacher-trainer
column4: and her best friend. I was not sure how to approach the more personal topics
column5: but I guess that's always the challenge: ask questions in a culturally and personally sensitive way
column6: and encourage open honest answers
column7: even in front of a camera.

column1: We got there just in time for tea
column2: and not long after
column3: we set up our equipment upstairs to interview the teacher-trainer. this woman is in her late 60s
column4: and the most lovely
column5: distinguished
column6: and yet casual lady you can imagine
column7: with her silver hair and rich green sari. Her presence commands respect
column8: and I automatically defaulted to calling her ""ma'am"" like the Indian crew memebers
column9: and yet she'd ask
column10: ""How do i look? Is my hair ok? I have no awareness of what I look like
column11: so let me know."" She chatted comfortably with me
column12: and off camera she agreed to tell me things about our main subject that she wouldn't on camera. This was fine. I'm not comfortable demanding personal information from her close friends
column13: and then projecting it publicly. But it gave me better insight about Jayshree.

column2: we set up in Jayshree's office
column3: and began the questions. Jayshree is open
column4: but not completely so. It's hard to explain
column5: like she has a public persona
column6: and she is so giving
column7: and clearly a bubbly person
column8: but there was a little she wasn't quite sharing. I felt so bad when I got to the question about asking whether she had children
column9: because I lost my place in the questions
column10: and there was a big pause. She answered well
column11: but it wasn't quite what I wanted. I struggle with the idea of how much I can ask the subject to repeat what they had told me before
column12: or to repeat themselves with complete sentences.

column1: Once we were finished with Jayshree's interview
column2: we interviewed the coordinator
column3: who is her best friend. We had only 6 minutes of tape left
column4: so it was slightly rushed
column5: but I think it will be nice.

column2: the crew got some lunch together. I think i've started to really get the hang of eating with only my right hand. Some of the crew is vegetarian
column3: and some aren't
column4: and when I asked about why
column5: they said that it is because of their caste. The highest caste can't eat meat. The lower castes can. This lead to a fascinating discussion about the residual caste system
column6: even if much of it is no longer an issue. In some places even now
column7: a marriage between people of different castes will result in killing the couple. But in our group
column8: Raj has a girlfriend (whom he intends to marry) of a different caste
column9: and Shriram has a girlfriend (whom he intends to marry) who is Christian. Also
column10: the original concept that caste would dictate profession and position in society is no longer in effect
column11: at least in cities. These students are here all studying together
column12: equally
column13: and they say that a person of a lower caste can get a higher position in society. And yet some aspects are harder to shake
column14: like whether or not they are permitted to eat meat.

column1: Outside of the restaurant was a woman with a baby monkey on a leash. We took her picture and gave her money. Yes
column2: I know it perpetuates this cruelty of trapping baby monkeys
column3: or whatever it is they do. But sometimes it's ok to experience things without trying to change them.

column2: with becoming-common sounds of honking and the van driver's indian music
column3: I had a strange but vaguely familiar feeling creep into me. It was happiness. Not relief
column4: not escapism
column5: not thrill
column6: but just happiness. The kind where you let go of some kind of fear and just enjoy the honest satisfaction of the moment
column7: the anti-thesis of stress. I feel that over the past 4 years I've been in NY
column8: the stress of my daily life has increased and bit by bit has taken over and paralyzed sections of my spirit. My one and only new year's resolution was to worry less. I can honestly say that I have worried less since this year started than i did in an averge work day last year in NY. And now
column9: here I was
column10: doing pretty much all the things i love to do
column11: simultaneously: traveling
column12: working together with people and learning from them in a very open environment
column13: and doing documentary work.

column1: We took a break for a while and met up later to go to a school-funded party event at a nightclub. At first only a few people wanted to dance to the mix of american and indian club music
column2: and the guys were told that men can't dance by themselves on the dancefloor
column3: it's for couples only. but once we had gotten into it
column4: there was no stopping the madness. It was a hilarious combination of demonstrating and copying eachothers' dance moves. Afterwards
column5: in the auto-rickshaw
column6: I had a nice conversation with (Essin?)
column7: who is Muslim
column8: about culture and religion. I finished off the night with a lovely heart to heart with janardhan. The level of awesome of some of these guys is sickeningly high. I had a frustrating interaction with one American student
column9: and he was there
column10: and when we were alone
column11: he said
column12: ""but that's part of life!""

column1: I've got to check out of the hotel in 10 minutes
column2: so it's time for this post to end. We'll be traveling to Madurai and Pondicherry until the 19th. More to come.

column1: A cow getting ready for the upcoming Pongol festival

I'm writing this entry as the sun slowly sets over Thanjavur on our last night in India. The locals are all engaged in a frantic rush of activity in anticipation for the upcoming three day harvest festival known as Pongol. People are stocking up on vast swathes of sugar cane and rice
column2: paints are being bought to decorate one's doorstep and cows are being washed down and having their horns painted in all sorts of vibrant colours.

column1: Having been on the move and engaging in various activities pretty well non-stop up until now
column2: we were all quite looking forward to the opportunity of doing very little and recharging the proverbial batteries. Thus
column3: we slowly made our way south from Cochi to spend a couple of relaxing days cruising the backwater canals of Kerala and doing exactly that ‚Äì very little.

column2: our boat seemed to be designed for just such a purpose and was one of the best crafts that we came across ‚Äì while most of the boats that cruise up and down the canals nowadays are made of fibre glass and steel
column3: ours
column4: the quite appropriately named
column5: if not slightly twee
column6: Dream Voyager
column7: was a beautiful

column1: barge made from imported Burmese teak and of the absolute highest quality. These boats were traditionally used as rice barges until some crafty local fella cottoned on to how much tourists would actually pay for a night on one of them and a massive industry suddenly exploded on to the sleepy Keralan backwaters. There are now apparently 500-plus such pleasure boats and as we pulled into what was literally peak hour on the main canal with barges back to back as far as the eye could see
column2: we inwardly grimaced at what could easily be a quite crowded and unrelaxing few days. However
column3: while most people just experience a day trip or overnighter
column4: Ann
column5: bless her
column6: had had the foresight and wisdom to book us in for two nights which allowed us the freedom to quickly move away from the main highway and into the quieter and much more remote canals.

column1: It was truly and absolutely blissful
column2: lying around in easy chairs or sprawled on pillowed day-beds
column3: reading and watching the countryside slowly drift by. Smaller canals branch off from the larger ones and little villages cluster on the edges
column4: poking out from the rice paddies. There are no

column2: and each house has a small canoe tied up out front for transport. Everywhere
column3: children frolicked in the water
column4: men fished from little canoes and the women did the washing by vigorously scrubbing and then smacking the clothes on large rocks
column5: the echoes of which continuously reverberated up and down the canals.

column1: The birdlife was magnificent and as the sun slowly set behind the paddies
column2: we relaxed over a beer and watched the eagles
column3: kites
column4: koels
column5: herons
column6: egrets
column7: terns
column8: cormorants
column9: bee-eaters
column10: cuckoos
column11: drongos
column12: swifts and of course the various species of the famous kingfishers for which India is renowned for
column13: swoop and dart by.

column2: if possible
column3: seemed to get even better as we were blessed with our very own Keralan masterchef who would begin chopping ingredients as the sun rose and continued in this manner for much of the day. He also had a delightful
column4: if somewhat disconcerting
column5: habit of hovering over us as we ate
column6: poised with dish in hand to top up any particular delicacy the moment the last remnants had been eaten. While obviously none of us complained
column7: it did have the result of meaning that we probably

column1: ate three times as much as was really necessary and it led to the quite comical yet equally perplexing issue of how to actually stop this bloke in order to prevent an ongoing and endless meal‚Ä¶
It was also lovely as we floated around to hear the various religious calls waft out over the water. A Hindu temple might begin
column2: and as that faded in the distance
column3: a mosque‚Äôs call to prayer would echo out over the fields. The local churches seemed to take the cake as they blasted out the Sunday morning psalms via massive speakers (eerily reminiscent of New Year‚Äôs Eve) so that you could literally hear it miles away ‚Äì a sort of Christian version of bringing the mountain to Mohammed I suppose.

column2: too quickly it was over and we ever so reluctantly disembarked and began a long day of driving up over the Ghats and back into Tamil Nadu and to the city of Madurai. From here on it was pretty well all about the temples
column3: the only differences being the size
column4: the number of faithful attending and the utter extravagance on show. The Sri Meenakshi temple is one of the three most

column1: Tom & Beth receiving the Bollywood treatement
important in India and we spent an amazing morning wandering around it
column2: taking in the massive gopurams that tower high over the complex and that are decorated with gods
column3: goddesses
column4: heroes and demons that are painted in bright
column5: vivid colours. (Apparently they are touched up every twelve years and the process itself takes over a year.) We were repeatedly mobbed by pilgrims - especially blond-haired Beth
column6: red-haired Tom and the towering 6ft 3 Jack
column7: a figurative giant who looms over the locals. It was wonderful to just chat to the various devotees (again
column8: occasionally about religion and life
column9: but mostly about the cricket ‚Äì India had just beaten arch-nemesis Pakistan in the last one dayer to finally notch up a win
column10: so the local mood was much more jubilant) and to just take in the ablutions
column11: prostrations and general devotions going on all around us. All through our trip
column12: we‚Äôve come across hundreds of pilgrims making their way to a particular temple
column13: mostly shirtless ones wrapped in black dhotis with smears of ash on their foreheads and with large bells dangling from their necks but also clusters of red
column14: yellow and green devotees
column15: all heading to a specific

column1: temple somewhere - apparently around forty to fifty million of them hit the road each year). In the modern 21st century
column2: most travel by bus
column3: but the really devout will walk at least a large part of the pilgrimage and the truly virtuous ensure that they fast for the preceding month and a half as well. As we passed over the mountains
column4: we‚Äôd spot clusters of these barefoot devotees slowly trudging along the side of the road
column5: patiently going about their religious duties‚Ä¶

column2: Muslims
column3: Sikhs
column4: Buddhists and Jains
column5: Hinduism is the driving force in India and is such an integral part of the everyday life here and we‚Äôve gradually learnt the very basics of the gods and goddesses and their countless incarnations. I won‚Äôt do the disservice of going into much detail where I would inevitably muddle things but generally speaking
column6: there exists the holy trinity of Brahman
column7: the creator
column8: Vishnu
column9: the preserver and Siva
column10: the destroyer and their consorts. Then come the hundreds of offspring
column11: aspects and so forth. An obvious favourite of the locals is Ganesh
column12: the chubby elephant-headed god whose purpose is to clear life‚Äôs obstacles and hurdles and whose representation

column1: is found absolutely everywhere - outside of houses
column2: under trees
column3: on the dashboards of buses and in countless other settings. While most gods have very strict instructions on how their temples are built ‚Äì pillars need to be thus high
column4: entrances facing this way
column5: and so on
column6: Ganesh is apparently pretty happy anywhere and requires very little in the way of absolute requirement
column7: apparently even quite happy sitting on the side of a grubby road in the monsoonal rains‚Ä¶

column2: we headed north into the little village of Kothamangalam in the province of Chettinad and to the wonderfully restored Saratha Vilas. Early last century
column3: the whole area was home to a host of rich Indian traders who made their fortunes trading and lending money across the British Empire and they had proceeded to build themselves these remarkably lavish mansions throughout the region. Inevitably they fell onto hard times and around a thousand of these decrepit and crumbling houses dot the landscape today. Saratha Vilas has been painstakingly restored by two French architects and decked out with wonderful local artefacts and icons
column4: and is an incredibly beautiful and peaceful retreat well off the tourist trail. We happily

column1: based ourselves here for a couple of nights as we explored the countryside
column2: visiting 6th century rock temples and the local tile-making village where we all stood astounded at the immense and complex skills of the local artisans as they created the most beautiful and elaborate tiles in mere moments. Of course Jane ‚Äòsuggested‚Äô we buy a set and thus I have the unenviable task of lugging these massive concrete based tiles around Sri Lanka.

column1: The region is also renowned for its large terracotta horses (quite interesting as we are yet to see an actual live horse in India) which are created for religious ceremonies each year and then deposited in a sort of horse graveyard where they slowly disintegrate back into the earth. It was actually a bit odd walking around the graveyard where these various headless
column2: legless and even generally bodyless creations linger on. However
column3: I was quite taken with these clay figures so this time I ‚Äòsuggested‚Äô buying one
column4: which Jane now has the pleasure of lugging around Sri Lanka‚Ä¶

column1: Our final days in India were spent in the neighbouring towns of Thanjavur (otherwise known as Tanjore) and Tiruchirappalli (otherwise
column2: thankfully
column3: known as Trichy) again

column2: including the biggest one in India where celebrations and festivals occur 320 days a year (except of course for the particular day that we visited)
column3: chatting to devotees and pilgrims and even being blessed by elephants. Peter had been recounting when they had previously been to Madurai and he‚Äôd been blessed by a giant pachyderm who he was hoping would remember him. Much to his
column4: and indeed all of our disappointment
column5: the animal in question was on his yearly 45-day retreat (as Tom grumbled
column6: that was more than he gets annually) to obviously recharge his batteries and give his poor
column7: overworked trunk a bit of a rest. However
column8: in Tanjore as we wandered through the gates of the temple
column9: we were fortunate enough to be met by a lovely elephant who proceeded to take our ten rupee note in her trunk
column10: hand it off to the mahout and then blessed us with a nice
column11: lingering kiss on the top of the head. Thankfully
column12: I splashed out as apparently a mere two rupee donation is but a brief peck
column13: denying the devotee the chance of a once-in-a-lifetime photo‚Ä¶

column1: Our final stop was to visit the shores of the Kaveri River
column2: which is the South Indian version of the mighty and holiest of holy Ganges. We‚Äôd paused here to witness the traditional dispersal of cremated ashes into the river and watched on as mourners with their heads ritually shaven sat with pates bowed as priests chanted blessings to ensure a safe passage of loved ones. Clouds of incense shrouded the area and bursts of colourful flowers dotted the pavement as families completed the process and sent their cherished ones on.

column1: And that is pretty much that. A huge thankyou to Ann who had spent countless hours organising and fine-tuning this wonderful trip ‚Äì full of great company
column2: beautiful places and wonderful experiences. And to those who may have pondered the wisdom of spending a fortnight with the in-laws in what can be a sometimes challenging country
column3: I can only say we‚Äôve had a truly amazing time and all got along much better then could ever have been expected.

column1: And an even bigger thankyou to the wonderful people we‚Äôve met on this trip. The locals have been so friendly and welcoming and ever eager to help out
column2: or just to pause and discuss life
column3: and of course
column4: the cricket. And while Tom and Beth now return home and Ann
column5: Peter & Jack board the train north
column6: Jane and I turn our sights south to Sri Lanka
column7: where we‚Äôll be swapping Ganesh for Buddha and the subtly flavoured curries for the eye-watering spicy ones. At least they‚Äôll still want to talk about the cricket‚Ä¶

column1: It took around 2 months for us to travel from the Indo-Chinese border in Sikkim (or near as dammit) to the Southern tip of India.
We left the majesty of the Indian Himalayas and ventured down to the plains at Siliguri. This is a major transition from pure
column2: clean air to diesel exhaust; from coats and jumpers to sweaty T-shirts; from friendly Nepalese and Tibetan folk to the more reserved
column3: but staring
column4: Hindu majority; from aging and overcrowded jeeps to
column5: er
column6: ancient and overcrowded buses. Somehow they seem much worse in the heat.

column1: My plan was to travel to Kolkata in 4 easy steps
column2: by bus.

column1: The first step was to the town of Malda
column2: chosen simply because it was on the way. Unfortunately our bus caught fire one hour out of Siliguri and we had to evacuate to the side of the road. A friendly fellow passenger took us under his wing and helped chuck our luggage on board as we joined the scrum for subsequent buses.

column1: Malda seems a fairly typical Indian city. Big
column2: loud
column3: chaotic
column4: plenty of cow dung. Adequate
column5: but uninspiring hotels and

column1: restaurants. It grew on me a little as I wandered the streets away from the highway
column2: where I bought a few essentials.

column1: After another stressful and sweaty bus journey we were chucked off at the side of the road in Berhampore. The town looked ok
column2: but we were disconcerted to find the bicycle rickshaw man taking us on a 45 minute trip down the hectic highway to get us to the recommended hotel. This hotel was nothing special
column3: although the restaurant was good
column4: located in a rotten area amongst the tyre changing and auto repair shops. There was nowhere to go for a walk without getting an unwanted lungful of diesel fumes.

column1: We wanted to go to the nearby town of Murshidabad
column2: which was supposedly rural and pleasant but after 20 minutes of standing by the roadside we realized that we were never going to be able to squeeze on any of the passing buses.

column1: We returned to the hotel and hired a taxi for the day.
This turned out to be a good move because Murshidabad was rural
column2: pleasant and spread out. We could not have got

column1: There were a few things to see
column2: the main one being the 'Palace of 1000 Doors' which was free to get in as ticket office was closed for Diwali.

column1: At this point our general feeling was that the places we were visiting were not worth the effort required to get there
column2: so we got up early to catch the 6am commuter train to Kolkata.

column1: We had to stand for about half of the 3 hour trip
column2: but at a ticket price of about 60p I still felt this was a bargain.

column1: Despite being Indias second biggest city
column2: Kolkata feels surprisingly un-chaotic and civilised compared to most Indian cities. There is enough room on the pavements and the hassle factor is much lower than expected.

column1: For many this is a palpable relief after the rigours of the road and so Kolkata is generally proclaimed as the favourite of the big four cities amongst travellers.
In fact there is not a great deal to see.
The Victoria Memorial is a splendid white marble palace built in the
dog days of the Raj. It houses a decent collection of paintings and statues and access to a internal balcony high in the domed chamber
column2: if you can find the stairs.
the Calcutta Museum houses a threadbare collection that has not been updated since the 1960's. It shows that napthelene alone cannot quell the ravages of time upon the taxidermists art.

column1: We rode the newly installed (ie - since I was last here) metro to the BBD Bagh area ostensably to look at the colonial era architecture
column2: but primarily to pass a few hours in the foreigners railway ticket booking office.

column1: The taxi ride to Howrah train station was not far
column2: but was unexpectedly expensive as the driver created an argument and then drove off without giving me my change.

column1: overnight train to Puri. I always seem to make the same mistake on overnight trains
column2: which is to have a good meal before boarding so that I don't need to carry any food. I invariably end up in a compartment with a friendly family who are loaded with snacks that they insist on sharing
column3: while I have nothing to offer in return. On this occasion there was copious peanut brittle and a peelable fruit that I have not seen before or since.

column1: We got a decent nights sleep
column2: arrived at about 7.30 am and headed straight for the Z Hotel.

column1: I had been looking forward to this.
The Z Hotel is a former maharaja's mansion which has functioned a a backpackers favorite for many years. The high ceilings
column2: thick walls and spacious communal area create a special atmosphere rarely found amongst budget accommodation. In 1990
column3: I stayed in their dormitory of 4-poster beds and it has remained in my memory ever since. That cannot be said for many places.

column2: we turned up and got a nice whitewashed room for 500 rupees (still cheap). At that point I

column1: did not realise how lucky we were because they were turning people away all the time. Talking to the staff
column2: it turned out that they had all been working there for 25 or 30 years so I would have met them when I came here before.

column1: I have to report that all is not well in Backpackistan. The Z Hotel have realised that if they install thick mattresses and air conditioning they can attract domestic tourists at 2500 - 3000 rupees a night. The conversion is currently underway.
The Z Hotel is away from the main area of Puri
column2: close to a fishermans village. After breakfast we walked along the beach to see what was going on. Not a great idea at that time in the morning. The fishermans village is not endowed with a sanitation system so the population pop down to the high tide line to evacuate their bowels of a morning. This is routine so they are not shy about foreign tourists paddling by. A glorious collection of turds lies under the boat eaves waiting for high tide to come and collect them.

column1: like a perfect moment to cut my toe open on a random piece of wire
column2: so I did.

column1: I am not criticising this waste disposal method. It is provided by nature and has been going on since time immemorial. However
column2: why the people choose to live amongst huge piles of their own domestic refuse was a bit of a puzzler.

column1: From then on we walked along the beach in the opposite direction. It was about half an hour to the main town which has a really good beach.

Puri has an important Hindu temple and many come on pilgrimage. There is a long string of hotels along the seafront and hundreds of Indian tourists and pilgrims cluster along the waters edge. It is interesting to watch those who have never before seen the sea. To many it is a holy experience.

Every Indian crowd leaves its own litter signature. Walking along the seas edge in the afternoon there was always a plethora of cups and packets. In the morning the shore was nice and clean. I was never sure if this was the waves sweeping away the evidence
or a secret army of litter pickers coming along and scavenging a few rupees from the recycling overlords.
A few steps along the crowds thin out considerably and I judged the waters clean enough to go surf diving a few times.

While we were there the Puri Dance Festival was taking place. We ventured forth one evening but found it difficult to get enthused about the entertainment. I think Indian dance culture has to be absorbed from an early age to be appreciated.
We eventually made our way to the temple
column2: the Jagannath Mandir. It is in a large compound
column3: closed to non-Hindus
column4: so we could only walk around the outside. The perimeter is a combination of vegetable sellers
column5: piles of vegetable waste and innumerable feral cows working their way through said waste. I have visited a lot of temples and this was the smelliest.

column1: A few km's along the coast lies the small town of Konark
column2: famous as the location of the Sun Temple. Built in the 13th Century the temple is a representation a huge stone chariot from a distance. Beautiful and impressive. From close up

column1: one finds a striking array of erotic carvings of people involved in all sorts of activities. Many of the carvings remain in excellent condition. The ladies represented are both busty and gymnastic. A worthy day out.
The Konark International Dance Festival was taking place. 'World class
column2: world class'
column3: enthused a local. Yeah
column4: but it's still dance.

column1: There was a friendly Indian guy named Rana also staying at the Z Hotel. He had a big car and one day gave a group of us a lift into Bhubaneswar
column2: the major town a couple of hours away. This is one of India's Temple Cities
column3: and we spent the day wandering around a number of temples from the 8th Century onwards.

column1: We then spent a couple of hours trying to find a 'don't miss' restaurant which
column2: it turned out
column3: had been subsumed by a new mall development.

column1: [News item: The Government is introducing fingerprint based bank accounts to enable the illiterate poor access to their welfare money. Unfortunately the fingerprint readers are unable to recognise about 50%!o(MISSING)f users due to the condition of their digits. Users are advised to apply
Vaseline to their fingertips before going to bed on the day before they intend to visit the bank].
It transpired that Rana ran his own travel business and was travelling around India in a hiatus between clients. He had a two week period in which he planned to travel southwards and
column2: yes
column3: he would be happy to give us a lift. Cushti!

column2: the forward planning between Puri and Chennai had been vexing me somewhat as it is a very large distance to cover with little of apparent interest on the way. Rana's offer was a Godsend.

column1: Before heading South he wanted to head North. He has been all over India
column2: but never to the Similipal National Park. We drove 8 hours to the adjacent town of Baripada and checked into a hotel. A park guide appeared
column3: looking for business and things started to go downhill as I discerned the word 'problem' appearing with some regularity in the conversation.

column1: It turns out that some Italian tourists had been kidnapped in the Park and held for a week by Moaist rebels. Foreigners were not now allowed in.

column2: said Rana
column3: 'we'll go to the Mayor'.

column1: There is a feeling that anything is possible in India
column2: so long as you talk to the right person.

column1: We made our way to the local civic offices.

column2: said Rana.

column1: 'Tell him how much trouble you have gone to to get here
column2: how keen you are to see the Park and how grateful you would be if he could see his way clear to helping us. Make him feel important and want to show his authority by letting you into the Park'
column3: he said.

column2: we were ushered into the Mayors office. A flunky stood behind his shoulder passing endless documents to be signed off as he spoke and listened.

column1: I couldn't get a word in edgeways as Rana launched into a spiel in their common language. There was some discussion before the Mayor finally turned to me.
'I am sorry I cannot allow you into the Park'
column2: he said. 'The rules have been made
column3: it is not for me to change them'.

column1: Having come up to speed on the Maoist situation I was not too disappointed.

column2: as we exited the compound
column3: ' lets give The Governor a try. You do the talking this time'.

column1: So we found ourselves standing outside the Gubernatorial mansion trying to get an audience through the intercom security system.
The Governor declined to see us.
The next day Rana and the guide went to the Park while we acquainted ourselves with the town (which didn't take long). He returned at 4pm having not seen a single animal.
'It's great if you like trees' he said.
We spent the night in the small seaside town of Chandipur. The sea here recedes 4km at low tide so there is either a
huge beach and no sea or a high tide and no beach. We witnessed both conditions.

The Chandipur Dance Festival was taking place. A young group of gymnasts were getting changed in some rooms adjacent to our dinner table. We had our photos taken with them doing handstands and then watched them doing their routine on the big stage by the beach.
The next day was a long drive south to Gopalpur-on-sea. This is an Indian version of the fading seaside town you can find all over England. We took a sea facing room close to the waters edge
column2: within earshot of the waves breaking on the beach. Linda killed the Worlds Biggest Cockroach in our room.

column1: We sat on the veranda drinking beer as the waves crashed in.
I woke up early and took a long walk along the best beach of the trip.
We could have stayed there a couple of days but Rana wanted to move on.

column2: helpfully known as Vizag. This accommodation in this city has a reputation for being either cheap and nasty in
or high-class and expensive along the beach road. Arriving by car gave us a distinct advantage here
column3: as we approached along the aptly named Beach Road and never got to see the city centre. The first few hotels we tried were either full or expensive
column4: but we soon found a nice place about 3 streets back from the promenade.

column1: The Young Ghandi Festival was taking place. Thousands of kids were dressed up as the old Ghandi
column2: with glasses
column3: false moustache and walking stick and then walked around for a bit. It was the first time that I've noticed a similarity between Mahatma Ghandi and Charlie Chaplain.

column1: It was Saturday night and the promenade was teeming with people creating quite a vibrant atmosphere.
We could have stayed there a couple of days but Rana wanted to move on.
Rana asked us to come up with a list of our top 5 all time songs for a play list he is creating.

column2: the 5 songs I provided were:

column1: I Live In The City by The Humans
As Long As I Have You by Elvis Presley
Sunshine On Neath by The Proclaimers
Bet you don't know all five.
The next day was a long drive to Ongole. We stopped for a KFC at Vijayawada
column2: where an overenthusiastic elderly lady beggar drove me into a low wall
column3: cutting my leg. I've needed plenty of antiseptic cream on this trip.

column1: Finally we drove down to Chennai. By now we had decided to bypass the city itself and Rana dropped us in the resort town of Mamallapuram a little further down the coast.
We had been in the car with Rana for 6 days and covered over 1500 kilometres
column2: yet he refused to take a single rupee from us for fuel expenses. We had bought him dinner a couple of times but he was not even comfortable with that. Beer he would accept.

column1: He runs a successful company providing adventure travel to sports enthusiasts from around the world:
The least I could do is

Driving at car level on the Indian highways was an experience in itself. I could write a whole post about some of the mad behaviour we saw. Behaviour that would be shown on the 6 O'Clock News at home is routine here. A lack of Road Sense and Common Sense combine to often lethal effect.
Rana loved driving. I think it was because it was like playing a video game in real life
column2: pitting your wits against the random and unexpected.

column1: Mamallapuram is a pleasant enough seaside town. The beach is nothing special but the town has developed its holiday niche mainly through being a short drive from Chennai. We didn't expect to spend 2 weeks there but the days slipped by and suddenly it was too near to Christmas to move on. We had a nice room with a balcony and an array of decent restaurants within a stone's throw.
This is another place with a collection of ancient temples. We only bothered with the free ones which are in a parkland area behind the main road. Also in this park

column2: a strangely named giant stone sitting at a precarious angle on a slope. It looks like it should roll away but of course it has been there for millennia.

column1: Christmas came and I was disappointed to note that none of the restaurants within a stones throw were offering a Christmas dinner
column2: although there were plenty of Westerners around. Thankfully a posh restaurant on the edge of town was doing a turkey dinner at a not extortionate price
column3: so we treated ourselves on Christmas Day.

column1: The restaurant was full - with Indians eating curry. We were the only white people there and the only ones having turkey.
We spoke with the owner. She was wondering what to do with all the turkeys she was going to have left over.
At least we got big portions
column2: and it was only mildly currified.

column1: The Mamallapuram dance festival was taking place. At least it was supposed to be. The posters said it started on the 25th December
column2: but when we and a few thousand other people turned up in the evening it turned out that a mistake had

column1: been made and it actually started on the 26th.
We missed this festival because on Boxing Day we were travelling to Pondicherry.
Pondicherry is a big Indian town with a beachfront promenade and a small French Quarter
column2: a reminder that even our cross-channel cousins once had a toehold in this land.

column1: It only took a couple of hours to walk along the promenade and inspect the French Quarter and I thought that was it. Knowing that accommodation was tight I had booked a few nights in advance
column2: so we were going to have to stick around.

Pondicherry was a town that reveals its treasures piece by piece and we found that each day we liked it a little more. I can't specifically say why. Nice soup and bread in one place. Excellent coffee in another. Tasty pizza with free garlic bread and chocolate brownie somewhere else. Hmm
column3: it's starting to add up now. Throw in some functioning wifi and we are all set up for a week.

column1: [News item: Following the national uproar about rape and the treatment of women in society
column2: the authorities

column1: in Pondicherry have made it compulsory for female students to wear overcoats.]
We were back on the buses. That was ok though coz buses in Southern India are a whole different ball game to buses in Northern India.

For a start there are enough of them to cope with demand so we are not crammed in; they are not so ancient so as to be about to die at any minute; the drivers don't think they should be representing their country at a Grand Prix; and the roads are made of smooth tarmac with upward rising speed humps rather than downward dropping pot holes (sample size = 3 journeys).
We got off the bus in Trichy station after a 5 hour bus ride. The station is surrounded by hotels
column2: one of which fitted the bill.
Trichy is an easy city to navigate as bus number 1 passes the main places of interest.

column1: The first of these is the Sri Ranganathaswamy Temple. Claiming to be the biggest temple in India
column2: the main entrance gate is 73

column1: metres high and can be seen from afar. It is difficult to tell where the town ends and the temple begins as there are streets and shops inside the temple compound.
The town is centred around the Rock Fort Temple
column2: an 83 metre high outcrop of rock thought to be one of the oldest on the planet. It has been geologically dated as older then the Himalayas. Humans have used it as both a fort and a temple
column3: hence the name. We climbed the steps to the temple at the summit
column4: providing views across the rooftops of the whole city.

column1: We didn't plan to stay long in Madurai
column2: so we took a room near to the out-of-town bus station and nipped in to visit the Sri Meenakshi temple on an autorickshaw.

column1: This is one of India's most famous temples. It is housed in a large square compound that has a magnificent tower at each point of the compass. Each tower holds a mass of carved and gaudily painted figures of Hindu Gods and mythical characters. It is mighty impressive.

column2: the town sitting on

column1: the Southern tip of India. The point is billed as the confluence of 3 seas: the Arabian sea
column2: the Indian Ocean and the Bay of Bengal. Astute readers may note that only one of these is actually a sea
column3: that's marketing for you.

column1: This is also said to be the only place in the world where you can witness sunset and moonrise on the same horizon.

There is a large rock (or small island) 400 metres out to sea where a revered Swami sat in meditation for 3 days in the 1870's. They built a temple on it in the 1970's which is serviced by continual ferries. Such is its popularity that the queues regularly stretch a couple of hundred metres into the thoroughfare.
On an outcrop nearby there is a 133 ft statues of Tamil Nadu's premier poet. One foot in height for every chapter of his master work.

A pink building surrounds the plinth where Mahatma Ghandi's ashes were held before being spread into the sea at this significant point. A strategically placed hole in the roof allows the sun to shine on the plinth only

column2: on his birthday.

column1: There are a number of other religious buildings and a bustling tourist market selling all sorts if nik-naks to the multitude of pilgrims and tourists that descend on the town.
Several churches and Christian shrines are dotted around. St. Thomas the Apostle landed here in AD52
column2: though the ball didn't really get rolling until the arrival of St.Francis Xavier in 1542. The church bell ringers need a lot more practice though.

column1: We experienced the variable climate from a 4th floor room with a balcony overlooking the Cathedral sized church and the sweeping coast receding towards the wind farm and nuclear power plant. Still lots of power cuts though.

column2: Displayed: 37
we got to the school at 9 because we had to present our formal script to the three heads of the program: Uma
column3: Hariharan
column4: and our own Vinit (from NY). I felt a bit apprehensive because while other groups were finalizing theirs
column5: we hadn't even started ours. We had talked about how we had to do it
column6: and then we had gone to a pub
column7: effectively eliminating any possibility of working on it. By 10
column8: we were wondering where everyone was
column9: all the other Indian students were working with their groups and only ours were absent. By 11
column10: we asked everyone to call them
column11: and apparently they were on their way. Finally two of them arrived at 11:30 and one arrived at 12. Another glorious miscommunication.

column2: Umila and I talked about our plan for the script
column3: even though it was difficult since I don't want to exclude peoples' ideas
column4: especially since I am co-directing with Raj Kumar. I came up with a basic flow
column5: but when Raj and the others arrived
column6: they had other ideas. We have such different sensibilities about things
column7: but I have to say
column8: it is such a difficult but rewarding process to work through this with anyone
column9: and even more so when my partners have such different cultural backgrounds and thus
column10: different artistic and conceptual preferences.

column2: we got to watch the footage in the editing lab. Pradeep was nervous because he had shot it
column3: but the rest of us couldn't wait to see it. We have about 80 minutes of B-roll. It was great! Umila took notes on every shot (216 in total) so that we could organize it into appropriate categories.

column2: as happens most days
column3: was a power cut. Power cuts are so common that it's almost just a routine reason to take a break for a few minutes. Some power cuts are only a few moments
column4: and others are for 6 or 8 hours. One of the students is from a region where there are only 4 hours of power a day. When we shot our b-roll
column5: there (just our luck) was a planned power cut from 9-5. We were there from 8-5. They have a generator
column6: but the generator created so much noise
column7: that it interfered with our sound recording.

column2: because I knew our group was not united on the main concept of the film. All of our interview questions seemed to be focused on the school
column3: or the subject's personality. In a previous conversation with Vinit
column4: I came to see that there had to be a much stronger focus on this woman's particular struggles
column5: or obstacles preventing her from doing what she wants. Now in the meeting
column6: I felt that even what we were saying was not really the story. The professors dismissed us
column7: but I was not satisfied. Plus
column8: I felt like I had just taken too strong a role in speaking
column9: and it is so difficult to keep things equal while still making progress forward.

column2: outside
column3: Vinit spoke with our group. As we were expressing more ideas about the film and more about our subject
column4: he suggested that the real story was a woman loves children
column5: and has no children
column6: but creates a family-like environment from a school. Ultimately her success is that she becomes the mother she could never be. I think we had already discussed this
column7: but we weren't able to articulate it. I didn't realize the significance of this until Vinit pointed out that in Hindu society
column8: grandparents are seen as gods. Not having children means losing a significant status in society
column9: and losing face. Basically
column10: it's a big deal.

column1: It's crazy that I didn't really get this
column2: and that my group members got it
column3: but I didn't know to ask them
column4: and they didn't know to mention it to me because it is such common knowledge in their eyes.

column1: I am reminded again and again that this process cannot be completed in some quick
column2: direct way. It is a rigorous churning of incomplete ideas
column3: bruised egos
column4: tentative suggestions
column5: sensitive insistence
column6: reluctant compromise
column7: and eventual acceptance. It is exhausting and deeply satisfying. And did I mention exhausting. Basically
column8: I love it.

column1: Evidence that potty humor is universal: Some of my fourth grade boys were sweeping the steps of the school (all the students participate in basic chores). As I walked past on my way back to the guesthouse where all of the volunteers stay
column2: they surrounded me whispering that I should tell one of the other boys a word in Tamil. They assured me that it was a sign of respect. Positive that they were up to something I told <em style=""mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"">them the word rather than directing the potentially offensive phrase at the innocent bystander. They immediately broke out laughing. Finally
column3: they told me
column4: the word did not in fact indicate respect
column5: but meant‚Ä¶ fart. I could hear their continued giggles the entire way from the steps to the door of the guesthouse.

column1: I am back to my room for a bit before my last class of my first week (although not a whole week). The schedule here is rigorous
column2: but I glad I started teaching right away. I think having a regular schedule
column3: goals and tasks
column4: and regular interactions with the other teachers and my students has helped me feel more at home than I expected to feel in the first week.

column1: The day starts at 6:30. The older students have prep time in which they finish homework and study. The younger students have PT
column2: when they play soccer
column3: basketball
column4: and other games. Today was my first time leading PT. It was a lovely way to wake up. The sunrises here are beautiful. A haze
column5: clinging to the thick trees
column6: settles over the lower land around the school. As the sun rises
column7: color seeps into the gray sky. The air is cool and smells fresh and earthy.

column2: breakfast is served. It usually has consisted of a grain like rice or (today) ground wheat
column3: a curry sauce
column4: and an egg. The fried eggs are especially tasty. Slightly sweet
column5: which is a nice match for the curry. Nothing has been terribly spicy
column6: in fact not as spicy as some of the Indian food I‚Äôve had in the States
column7: but it is certainly spicier than what I usually have for breakfast. There is also tea or coffee
column8: both with lots of milk and <em style=""mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"">lots of sugar. It is like dessert. Like if you melted ice cream and heated it up. I miss my strong coffee with a pinch of sugar
column9: but the sweetness of the drinks is nice since there isn‚Äôt dessert.

column2: there are three class periods
column3: followed by a morning tea. The children drink tea and sweet lentil porridge. Morning tea is followed by a daily assembly. The school recites a beautiful
column4: non-sectarian prayer
column5: and
column6: on Fridays
column7: sings the Indian national anthem. Then some of the older students present news stories from around the world. After hearing the stories
column8: the other children are encouraged to ask questions. On morning
column9: when students had few questions
column10: Dr. George
column11: the founder and head of the school scolded them telling them the importance of forming opinions and of thinking critically about what they read and hear. Although he is much sterner with the children than I am
column12: it is clear how much he loves them. He has earned their respect not from fear
column13: but from love and high expectations. After the news
column14: Dr. George speaks. He speaks to them candidly about problems at the school and around the world. All of the students
column15: even the young ones
column16: know about the recent rape in Delhi. The last several days
column17: assembly has been a time at which students could ask questions and process the horrible event. In a meeting
column18: Dr. George told me that it must seem shocking to me
column19: but he believes the children must know about the entirety of the world if they are to live in it. To protect them
column20: we must inform them. I appreciate his devotion to the students and his belief in their ability to understand more than many.

column2: the students return to two periods of class before lunch. Both lunches and dinners have been delicious. Almost always
column3: there is rice and curry again
column4: but also tasty side dishes like carrots with finely shredded coconut
column5: fennel
column6: ginger
column7: and red pepper. Also
column8: beat and onion salad
column9: a green bean coconut dish
column10: and a flat bread somewhere between the naan I‚Äôve had in the States and tortillas. After lunch
column11: there are three periods before afternoon snack. In the afternoon
column12: the older students have PT
column13: while the younger students complete their homework and do chores. From 5 to 6
column14: the students bath and relax. Before and after dinner
column15: the older students study and the oldest have more classes. After dinner
column16: the young ones get ready for bed and a volunteer reads them a bedtime story. The older students study until the power goes out around 9 or 10.

column1: When I write it all out
column2: it makes me feel a bit better about being so tired at the end of the day. We have a long weekend as the region is celebrating a harvest festival (in January!!!). I hope that by the beginning of next week I will be better rested and have a better sense of the direction I want to move with my classes.

column1: My 12th graders are preparing for a huge standardized test. Imagine the SATs
column2: except it is more important as that is the only academic component of a college application
column3: and it is more knowledge based. When I arrived
column4: the Vice Principal told me that the 12th grade was struggling with writing. While they might know the information
column5: they weren‚Äôt able to communicate it in an organized and effective way. Over the last several days we have practiced how to construct a topic sentence
column6: present evidence
column7: and explain analysis. It was frustrating at first and I felt out of my dept. I have never taken a class about how to teach writing. I have not even taken a writing class
column8: as I tested out of my freshman level writing course. Moreover
column9: because of the test for which they are preparing is so important and so different from American tests
column10: I am worried that I will teach them to write an answer that will not get them the best grade. But as I have gotten over jet leg and as I have gotten to know the students and test better
column11: I feel more capable of the task. It has been good to have a goal and a challenge. I feel excited for class
column12: excited to find ways to help them understand. It is such a great feeling when one of my students repeats a metaphor I used the day before. I am proud (and amazed) that I thought of something they can remembered.

column1: My 11th grade class is not quite as focused
column2: as they do not have a text bearing down. It has taken me longer to find structure for my lessons. A low point of my week was when a student fell asleep. I know from my years of being a sleepy student that this is not necessarily my fault
column3: but I still felt embarrassed and inadequate. Hopefully within the next couple of weeks I will find a way to connect with them and wake them up.

column1: My theatre classes are fun and crazy as expected. There are many students and the room is small. But what could be better than pretending to be a gorilla with a bunch of laughing children
column2: even if it is difficult to quiet them down for instructions. I only wish I had the classes more regularly. I don‚Äôt feel like I know them yet
column3: but I suppose that will come in time.

column1: It is night now‚Äîa while since I started this entry‚Äîand I am back in the school building
column2: so I can post this on the internet. No internet in the guesthouse. I look forward to walking back after closing down my computer. The air will be cool and soft. Insects will buzz
column3: but bite surprisingly little (only three bites so far!). And I will look at the stars. Have I mentioned the stars? They are breath taking. Although not as many as in Montana
column4: they are still bright and clear away from lights of any city or town. The big dipper sits differently in the sky
column5: but is still the big dipper. It makes me happy to think that in less than 12 hours everyone back home will be looking up at the same stars. I look on the giant wall map
column6: which hangs in the main room of the school building
column7: and I can‚Äôt believe the distance I have covered. But when I talk to the children
column8: who are so much like the children at home
column9: and when I look at the stars
column10: home feels so close I could blow a kiss and you catch it.

column1: All the good teachers I have had

Today we had the opportunity to shoot b-roll at the monessori school. Umila and I met the rest of the crew at the street where they had rented a van and picked up all the equipment at the academy. It took us 20 minutes
column2: since it was about 5 kilometers away. On the street
column3: just like yesterday
column4: we passed auto rickshaws crowded with people
column5: oxen
column6: pedestrians
column7: bicyclists
column8: and everybody was simultaneously trying to occupy the same space. Entire families on a moped. Five people in a rickshaw. I'm surprised there aren't more accidents. But since no one is going too fast
column9: it kind of works out. It's like how water appears to be one thing
column10: you don't see it as separate molecules
column11: but as a liquid whole
column12: the same goes for the traffic here. It turns molecular people into liquid traffic. As crazy as it kind of is
column13: all the constant noise and jostling is oddly calming. You might almost feel
column14: as you are thrown this way and that
column15: that there is no way that you are in control of your own safety
column16: let alone your entire life
column17: so you may as well just relax and enjoy the ride.

column2: but fruitful day. Taking 3 people to go see the location is totally different from taking 7
column3: plus camera and sound. It was never easy to crowd all 7 of us behind the camera while somehow remaining unobtrusive to the classroom
column4: and forget about it when the academic coordinator arrived. He was quick to explain that he has been in the tv industry
column5: doing news
column6: for years. every time I passed him
column7: he'd stop me to give a lecture on how to shoot as little as possible
column8: cut them off if they aren't saying what you want
column9: only take the shots you need
column10: hurry up
column11: don't waste time or film
column12: shoot from here
column13: do this
column14: do that
column15: ask them the question that will give you the exact answer you want. i respected him
column16: but i just have a different philosophy about how to get the subject to open up. i found it difficult to work with him looming around like a hyperactive vulture.

column1: we got so much b-roll. it was so hot. we had to shut off the fans whenever we filmed because the sound of the fans was distracting
column2: so we just pretty much sweated our balls off from 8am to 5pm when we finished. i kept being surprised that it was ok for adults like us
column3: who were pretty much strangers
column4: to just walk into a school and play with the kids
column5: even picking up and swinging around the toddlers. how is this ok? how is no one suing me?

column1: when we got to the older kids
column2: we shot b-roll in one class
column3: and when we went to shoot in the next class
column4: the students from the first class (about 8 of them) all scrambled to pick up their desks and chairs and drag them into the next class so that they could be filmed again. i suppose some elements of this documentary are going to be staged. Raj asked a girl who was drawing
column5: to draw a building and name it with the name of the school. He directed a bunch of students to run into the entrance holding hands with our interviewee. I think it's just fine
column6: but my tendancy is always to just shoot what is there. I don't know if that makes me a purist or if it makes me a wuss.

column1: Tomorrow we will review our footage and prepare for our interview on saturday. tonight I'm meeting everyone for dinner. Then much needed sleep!

It is about six in the morning. I wanted to finish some lesson plans and write this before the day began. I have been quite busy and already feel about bit behind. I expected the school building to be empty for the next half hour (the students start their day at 6:30)
column2: but some of the older students are already studying.

column1: I am sitting in the dark to conserve electricity
column2: which is limited. The school is largely powered by solar power; but as that does not fully support all the needs
column3: they are still reliant on the electrical infrastructure
column4: which is extremely expensive and unreliable. I am happy that I have found it so easy to adjust to brushing my teeth
column5: finding clothes
column6: and grading papers by flashlight. The easy with which I can live without constantly flipping the light switch makes me guilty for the amount of energy I use in the States. However
column7: if I weren‚Äôt at the school and were living on my own I think I would find lack of electricity much harder. Because the electricity is constantly turning off
column8: it isn‚Äôt possible to keep perishable food in the volunteer‚Äôs refrigerator.

column1: Last night I was finally hit by jet lag. I think that for the last two days I have been so busy and excited to be here that I didn‚Äôt feel tired. I was fighting to stay awake in our volunteer meeting last night
column2: which was embarrassing and frustrating. I so grateful for them‚Äîthey are a time for volunteers to talk about problems
column3: brainstorm
column4: etc‚Äîbut I didn‚Äôt feel like my brain was up to the conversation. After a night of sleep
column5: I feel better.

column1: The nights gets quite cool. I sleep with just a sheet
column2: but at times think I‚Äôd be comfortable with a light blanket. Through my window pours India music (I think the security guards play it after the rest of campus has gone to bed). I hear birds singing and the thwack of palms slapping together in the wind. If it weren‚Äôt for these sounds
column3: I might forget I am in India as I drift in that place between wake and sleep. I had prepared myself for everything to be different. Here at the school I have been struck by what we share‚Äîa beautiful thought to be struck by. But
column4: I think that I if I get a chance to travel into the nearby villages I will be hit over the head with the differences.

column1: This contrast between the familiar and the new is indicative of India
column2: I think. The place is a contradiction in so many ways. When I arrived at the airport
column3: I was surprised by who western it felt. It looked much like the Paris airport I‚Äôd just left. It was not even hot enough to make me fully understand that I had come so far. But as we drove (on the left side of the road). Indian music played over the radio. My driver had a miniature figuring of ‚ÄúMonkey God
column4: ‚Äù he told me
column5: on his dashboard. We made our way out of Bangalore
column6: onto a winding
column7: two-way highway that passed through towns and villages of varying size. We passed big houses with gates in front
column8: tiny mud huts
column9: stray dogs
column10: shops with brightly painted gates pulled down in front for the night. And lots of shrines. Every village had multiple shrines
column11: some beautiful and elaborate
column12: some small and plan. But all lit. Bright lights
column13: in a place where electricity is so unreliable
column14: shined on the deities. The car ride was stunning and immersive; the two hours zipped by as I tried to take note of everything I saw
column15: all that was familiar and new.

column1: When I arrived at the school
column2: it was pretty much
column3: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs your room. See you in the morning.‚Äù At first this surprised me. I felt a bit at sea
column4: fumbling around in my dark room
column5: trying not to wake my roommate. But as there was not electricity at the time and as it was three in the morning
column6: any other conversation or introductions would have been silly.

column1: My room and roommate are both lovely. The room is comfortable and clean. The roommate
column2: a Russian woman about my age named Masha
column3: is warm
column4: fun-loving
column5: and thoughtful. I feel lucky to be in such a nice room with such an nice person.

column2: my‚Ä¶ I just realize that my battery is about to die. I can‚Äôt plug it in during the school day as it drains the solar power. So I will have to sign off with many typos presumably as I have not even read over what I am about to post. There is so much more I want to write. So much more that has happened in just two days. I guess I will have to wait until tonight.

column1: P.S. I have yet to see a mosquito.
Chennai - Mahabalipuram - Puducherry - Kumbakonam - Madurai - Periyar - Kerala Backwaters - Kochi - Trivandrum-Kovalam

27. Dez. 2012 - Ankunft in Chennai nach langem Nachtflug (Wien - Dubai - Chennai). Immigration in Indien ziemlich langwierig. Wir steigen in den wartenden Bus und fahren durch Chennai (ehemaliges Madras). Indien empf√§ngt uns mit der vollen Wucht seiner Gesch√§ftigkeit und Menschnmassen. Die Stra√üen sind viel zu eng und st√§ndig verstopft. Alles Leben spielt sich neben der Fahrbahn ab. Menschen in bunten Gew√§ndern gehen ihren Gesch√§ften nach
column2: hektische Motorradfahrer f√ºhren viel zu viele Passagiere vom Kleinkind bis zu Frauen im Sari auf dem Sozius. Busse und LKWs fahren aufeinander zu
column3: um im letzten Augenblick doch auf die richtige Seite auszuweichen. Wir besichtigen die katholische Kirche St. Thomas
column4: die Grabkirche des Hl. (ungl√§ubigen) Thomas
column5: der hier ab 52 n. Chr. missioniert hat. (Hier im S√ºden Indiens gibt es viele Christen

column1: 28. Dez. 2012 wir fahren in die alte Pilgerstadt Kanchipuram (eine der 7 heiligen St√§dte Indiens)
column2: wo wir den ber√ºhmten Vishnu-Tempel (Kamashi-T.) besuchen. Wir sind mitten unter Massen von Pilgern (Frauen in bunten Saris ebenso wie tradtionell gekleidete M√§nner oder Bettelm√∂nche - die Sadhus)
column3: die in fr√∂hlichen Prozessionen Vishnu und den vielen Nebeng√∂ttern

column1: ihre Ehrerbietung erweisen. Am Nachmittag zur√ºck in Mahabalipuram besichtigen wir ber√ºhmte Monumente der indischen Steinhauerkunst von riesigen Ausma√üen. Die f√ºnf Rathas (UNESCO Welterbe - aus gewachsenem Granit gehauene riesige Schreine in Form von Prozessionswagen)
column2: und das riesige Steinrelief (27 x 9 m) und der Shoretempel werden von so vielen indischen Besuchern heimgesucht
column3: dass man sich wie auf einem Jahrmarkt vorkommt.

column1: 29. Dez. 2012 - Wir fahren mit unserem Bus nach S√ºden
column2: nach Pondycherry. Die ehemalige franz. Kolonie genie√üt als Unionsterritorium Sonderstatus. Die Altstadt ist von franz√∂sischen Kolonialbauten gepr√§gt und an der Strandpromenade im Stil der Cote d¬¥Azur versuchen einige Lokale franz√∂sisches Flair zu verbreiten. Ein gro√üer Teil der kolonialen Stadt ist im Besitz der Ashra-Sekte (""Hari-Krishna"")
column3: deren Gr√ºnder Sri Aurobindo hier ein Mausoleum besitzt. Kolonialzeitliche katholische Kirchen sind ebenso wie die Moscheen im muslimischen Viertel von regem Leben erf√ºllt. Die indischen Stadtviertel sind genauso hektisch wie √ºberall
column4: besonders eindrucksvoll der lebendige Shiva-Kult im hinduistischen Tempel.

column1: I have always been terrible at saying goodbye. I envy the people who know just what to say
column2: and just when people will neither be too happy nor too sad to see you go. My special breed of social anxiety has always led me to err on the side of caution and bow out too early (don't want to overstay my welcome) and wordlessly (don't want to bother everyone or steal attention).

column1: But there is no hiding this time. It helps in some ways to have a set time of departure
column2: so everyone can be prepared for it. On the other hand
column3: though
column4: I often get this sense from the students that I am abandoning them. I feel that some are already beginning the process of pushing me away. (They've been through this many times before
column5: after all.) In light of that
column6: the week has been filled with one goodbye after another
column7: with events and moments that I wish I could either keep or change. I keep thinking
column8: ""I don't want my last interaction with this child to be me disciplining them
column9: or
column10: ""Why can't I hold onto this moment a little longer? It's so perfect...""

column1: really started for me with the German Party. We had to prepare four songs for this Christmas Party thrown by a group of German companies in Bangalore--SB sends its choir every year as a thank you to these companies
column2: which are some of its biggest funders. There were a lot of stressful factors
column3: and a lot of instances where students didn't come when asked
column4: and so preparations got tense. But then there were also these beautiful moments
column5: like when Prathibha (who wasn't even going) asked me
column6: ""Miss Lynn
column7: why aren't you wearing a fancy dress?"" When I replied
column8: ""This is all I have
column9: she arranged with Vinceya for me to go to the girls' dorm and try on some of their outfits. I ended up in this traditional sparkly pink outfit
column10: and all in all it fit pretty well
column11: if it was a bit long.

column1: And then there was the stress of preparations for Sports Day and Christmas (celebrated on December 12 and 13 at SB
column2: respectively). My students
column3: being the eldest
column4: were given many many many responsibilities for these events
column5: so trying to have class with them this past week has been a little bit like herding cats.
