column1: And to top it all off
column2: I decided to have a project presentation day on the last day of classes
column3: and (as is only natural) most of them did not do their project work in advance
column4: so they had to scramble around these other events.

column1: For any of you who did Track and Field Day in elementary school
column2: that is basically what Sports Day boils down to
column3: except you should probably add a cupful of Olympics to the recipe. The students are separated into four teams (yellow
column4: red
column5: purple
column6: and green)
column7: and spend days practicing their marching and preparing for soccer
column8: basketball
column9: and long-jump competitions. At the beginning of the ceremony proper
column10: there's a marching event
column11: as well as a lighting of a torch and raising of the four flags. There was a small platform where all of the volunteers and Miss Beena sat to watch the events. From that vantage
column12: we had a perfect view of the track where the youngest did relays. I think my favorite relay was one where the preschoolers had to run to a plate
column13: eat a biscuit
column14: and run to the finish line. There was one particular preschooler who didn't quite grasp the

column1: idea of a relay and laconically nibbled on her biscuit long after the rest of the students had finished. My second favorite was the twelfth graders jumping up to try to catch rolls strung on a rope above them (they could only catch it with their teeth
column2: creating this hilarious fish-like effect). But eventually we the teachers were roused from our seats to compete as well. I was part of the yellow team
column3: and the teacher/staff competitions included two games. In the first
column4: we were each given an animal name and released to find our partner of the same name
column5: but only using animal noises and actions. I ended up being quite the forlorn cow
column6: because my partner gave up early and so I was left alone in the middle of the field mooing. The kids enjoyed it
column7: in any case. The second event was shaving balloons
column8: and the yellow team immediately selected Peter to represent us (as a male
column9: he has far more experience
column10: right?)
column11: but we came in last anyway. All in all
column12: it was a fun day
column13: though. The red team ended up winning both the marching and overall titles.

column2: though
column3: Christmas was a struggle

column1: because the main event was a concert. I decided early on in the week that the choir would be fine singing through a couple of carols without much rehearsal (...more on that in a moment)
column2: so I focussed in on my individual and group voice lessons. There were many last-minute rehearsals
column3: many concessions made from all parties
column4: but also many smiles during this crunch time. One group in particular
column5: a quartet of ninth-grade girls
column6: was a pleasure to work with because they loved their song so much. I can't blame them
column7: as it was ""At the Beginning"" from Anastasia
column8: and I have very fond memories of that song from my childhood. I was also very excited to see how Cathy did
column9: as she was singing a solo: ""Listen"" from Dreamgirls. She has this naturally rich-'n-husky voice
column10: and we worked really hard to release it. I remember one particular rehearsal this week when I had tried telling her in various ways that she needed to relax her throat and sing from her diaphragm
column11: and nothing seemed to help. Then
column12: suddenly
column13: we did an exercise and she looked at me with these wonderfully bewildered eyes and said
column14: ""That time I could feel

column2: right here
column3: and she pointed to her stomach. ""Is that right?""

column1: Except for lighting issues (which are almost a given at SB--our limited electricity leads to a lot of back-up plans)
column2: the concert went over quite well. I was so proud of my individual students
column3: and even though the full choir hadn't had much time to practice their carols with me (I was more focussed on German Party the week previous)
column4: they did well. Then
column5: at the end
column6: four preschoolers came onstage with packages labled
column7: ""Mr. Peter
column8: ""Miss Ally
column9: ""Mr. Sachin
column10: and ""Miss Lynn."" She had been alluding to a surprise for the past week
column11: but I had no clue what to expect. So we each went to our respective child and opened our packages. At first
column12: I had no idea what was going on
column13: as it was a CD case taped to a box. Then
column14: upon closer inspection
column15: I discovered that it said
column16: ""A Shanti Bhavan Christmas"" on the cover
column17: and Lizzy started playing a recording of children singing Christmas carols. Apparently
column18: for the last two weeks
column19: the choir had been secretly recording themselves singing carols (no wonder they did so well)! The box contained a frame

column1: with a picture of two of the preschoolers. I hope the kids could see my melted heart seeping onto the floor.

column2: we had a fine dinner of fries and mac and cheese
column3: which is quite the treat! But before we could eat
column4: the eleventh graders had planned a dance-off
column5: and my name was drawn with Tom
column6: Lizzy's father who was visiting. We actually ended up winning third place
column7: and I think we shocked quite a few folks with our dance...commitment. Our prize was a Fozzy the Bear book
column8: so we donated it to the school.

column2: these last couple of days have been a bit heartwrenching. Last night
column3: I stayed up ""late"" with the eleventh and twelfth graders in the school building. Gayathri was doing some special mehndi for me
column4: which took many hours but turned out beautifully
column5: and Lizzy was playing mafia with the others. It was good to finally spend some time outside of class and choir with them. I wish that had been a possibility earlier. Another SB tradition (aside from last-night mehndi) for those departing is to sign students' autograph books. I managed to do this last week for the eleventh and twelfth graders
column6: but it is likely that more will trickle to me during my last hours here. I have also left a poem for my two English classes
column7: based off of ""A Prayer for My Daughter"" by Yeats (one of the pieces they have studied). I am hoping they won't find it until after I've left
column8: because I don't really want to talk about the sentiments I expressed in it. On the flip side
column9: I gave my students a ""Happy Book"" to sign for me. Some readers here may be familiar with the concept
column10: but for those of you who aren't: A Happy Book is a notebook where each person gets a page upon which they write or draw a list of things that make them happy. It's a wonderful way to remember others
column11: and it can brighten a sad day simply by reading a page or two.

column2: the four of us who are leaving (Ally
column3: Peter
column4: Lizzy
column5: and I) were all given fine speeches and cards. Cathy spoke about me
column6: and although the other teachers had three or more students speaking about them
column7: I felt like the most honored teacher in the world. She talked about how I encouraged her to sing from her heart and not be afraid of mistakes in voice lessons
column8: and how I encouraged the English classes to speak their minds (and
column9: more humorously
column10: how I always kept the students on track
column11: even when they tried to distract me). The personal way in which she spoke let me know that I have made an impact
column12: even if it was just a small one upon her.

column1: I feel so blessed. These students mean the world to me
column2: and although I'm heading home
column3: I have every intention of circling the globe again. They're family
column4: after all.

column1: So after we finished our volunteering in the South it was time to get back on the road and head for the mountains. The first stop was Madurai for one night
column2: we got up at 5 a.m to experience the temple there
column3: which was a little haunting with the chants at that time in the morning but a great experience.

column1: After Madurai we went to Kumily/Thekkady
column2: which is a great place for treks and a wonder round a tiger reservation which we did in the afternoon. From Kumily we took the maddest bus journey I have ever exprienced to Munnar! we got onto the bus at 6 a.m with banging Indian music being played and flashing lights! it was a 6 hour bus journey through mountains
column3: tea plantations and TIGHT corners as we wound our way up through the mountains
column4: we still had white knuckles by the time we got to our hoemstay!

column1: We took a moped and rode 60km up and down through the mountains of Munnar for the day to a hill station up in the clouds. The ride was brilliant and refreshing! we spent time walking round the tea plantations and stopping off at view points
to take in the open mountain views.
We have been in Ooty for 5 days now
column2: been out on a moped for the day and now just chilling and taking a break from the travelling (I know it must be such hard work!!! ;p ) we have spent a total of about 30 hours on buses in the last week or so up through the mountains at a cost of next to nothing and it has been the best way to see what the other side of India has to offer . . . Next we will be in Hampi
column3: see ya then üòä

column2: Displayed: 11

column1: We have spent time in the rural villages of Tamil Nadu and seen how they use their homes as factorys for weaving
column2: making pots from clay and also teaching.

column1: We visited a village where the trade is weaving. We were invinted into these peoples homes to see how it was done. It was amazing to see how the machinery to weave was built within theri homes and the engineering that goes into making a saree from scratch. We also visited homes that produced clay pots from locally sorced clay. Although payment is not massive it is a long tradition of work that is kept within the families of the villages.

On one visit to a village we met with a women who was head of the village. She showed how to make traditional henna from leaves ground on stone by stone with water. The mashed up leaves are then placed on different parts of the body and left for about 15 minutes before washing off. The henna lasts for about 15 days! check the pics out üòä

column2: Displayed: 5

column1: Gimme Five!! with the kids from salt pan area
Since working with the children we have also been out to see what life is like for the salt pan workers and how womens groups forged through the help of SCAD help their communties grow.

Salt pan workers work near the coast on salt farms. The work is hard and the days are long. Salt water needs the right climate to dry out leaving the salt behind it takes about 30 days for the whole process to end and if there is rain it can all be destroyed in no time. The salt pan workers have to skim the salt from the fields and load it into piles and them bag it ready for shipping. They work 7 days a week from 6-1 in the afternoon and then after they have had dinner for hours in the evening. Women get 150 rupees (about 2 quid) and the men 180 rupees (just over 2 quid) per day!!!! SCAD has helped the salt pan workers to devise ways to combat debpt they have worked up with the owners of the salt plains through womens groups saving 5 rupees a month for a year and building it up until they loan each other
money without having to pay the owners whose interest rate is about 30%!! SCAD has also develpoed schools here for children to gain education and not have to work on the plains
column2: children as young as 7 were working on the plains before this!

column1: We also saw the great work that womens groups do in the villages. They have a house they all meet in and discuss whats going on. They decide if a child can take a loan from them to go to higher education. They also help people grow kitchen gardens to grow their own food and make business by weaving . . .

column2: Displayed: 6

column1: At the school with the kids

So we have been at the volunteering project now for 2 weeks. So far we have worked with the kids at the school for children who are mentally challenged as well as with the children from the gypsy camps. It's really good to see how eagar they are to learn and how confident they are around us and when performing. We were 'guests' to one of their school celebrations where they performed dance
column2: singing and playing instruments as well as reciting something in Tamil
column3: which we couldnt understand but they did with great ease and confidence. The great thing about what SCAD do is to give the womens groups in the villages money to loan to kids who want to go to higher education
column4: for disabled kids this is free but for abled children they loan the money and pay back with little interest and the money goes straight back to the womens group to be used again for another kid who wants higher education
column5: this is to give the children the feeling that they ARE paying for their education and not just getting it through hand outs. It's hard not to say that if some children from our country saw

column1: how hard these people have to work for education it would perhaps make them realise how lucky they are! but thats another disscusion for the pub! üòä

column2: I have been in India for over two months
column3: and I still feel like I am floundering at times when it comes to ""common"" courtesy. I mean
column4: obviously there are certain rules of politeness that apply to all peoples
column5: but I have often found myself reacting negatively to something which is completely acceptable in India
column6: or doing something that we would find acceptable in America but is absolutely wrong in India.

column1: Of course I knew that there would be differences in polite proximity
column2: and differences in how queues are handled (I cannot count how many people have budged me in line because I left two feet of space between myself and the person ahead of me). But there were also things that I did not expect: being followed by the hotel owners in Hampi (see ""Humming in Hampi"" if you have no idea what I'm talking about)
column3: different head gestures
column4: removing (or not removing) shoes
column5: bargaining
column6: and different exclamations
column7: to name a few.

column1: For those of you who will be interacting with me my first couple of weeks back from India
column2: be warned: I have picked up new mannerisms. One of these is what I am terming the ""okay gesture."" It can be very confusing to someone who does not know this gesture exists
column3: because it most closely resembles a head-shake
column4: but is used at times when Americans typically would nod or not do anything. It often accompanies the word ""okay
column5: and basically shows neutrality toward the subject at hand. It was explained to me on my first day by Cathy
column6: a 12th grader
column7: when she replied to a request with
column8: ""Okay"" and the okay gesture
column9: and I responded
column10: ""So
column11: not okay? You're giving me mixed messages."" I have since been working to re-wire my gut response when I see the okay gesture (No
column12: although this student scowls when he does the okay gesture
column13: he is not disgreeing... Although this staff member sounds angry
column14: the okay gesture means she is actually showing assent...). For instance
column15: if a student asks me if they can be excused to go to the toilet
column16: I'll say
column17: ""Yes
column18: you may
column19: but use the okay gesture to accompany it because I'm not THAT adamant that they go use the toilet. On the flip side
column20: when I ask my students if they understand something
column21: they may respond with the okay gesture to assure me that they think they grasp the concepts
column22: but that that revelation is not overly exciting.

column1: When it comes to the question of whether or not to remove one's shoes
column2: I am still in the dark. As a tourist
column3: the general rule of thumb is: take them off if you see other shoes at the door. Of course
column4: that doesn't always work. For Diwali
column5: I went to a saree-distribution ceremony (in which all of the maintenance staff received gifts from The George Foundation)
column6: and I decided to remove my shoes because I saw many pairs of shoes at the door. But when I got inside
column7: Ms. Beena immediately called out in horror
column8: ""Lynn! Don't come in your bare feet!"" and I had to scamper outside to get my shoes back on before taking my seat with Lizzy and Peter. Apparently all of those shoes belonged to the maintenance staff
column9: and everyone else there kept their shoes on. But
column10: in general
column11: that hasn't been a problem elsewhere. In Hampi especially
column12: it was accepted that one removes one's shoes at the door of any shop or restaurant (as long as the restaurant did not have a dirt floor). But there were also places that surprised me
column13: like in Hyderabad. Peter and I had to take our shoes off to go into a particular museum gallery of prints
column14: and then again when we entered a room with an Egyptian mummy. We speculated that the latter had to do with the dead remains
column15: but the only explanation we could think of for the first gallery was that the room contained several Quarans.

column1: Bargaining is something that always feels uncomfortable for me. I've gotten better at it
column2: especially with rickshaw drivers
column3: but it really goes against the grain of my upbringing. Especially when I am bargaining for a handicraft from the artisan him- or herself
column4: I feel like I am insulting their time and effort. In general
column5: though
column6: they seem to be content once a deal is struck. The only time I have seen an artisan blatantly refuse to bargain below a certain price was with a painter in Hampi. And
column7: to be perfectly honest
column8: we had seen the detailwork and time he put into each piece
column9: and if I had put that much time into something
column10: I would also refuse a low offer--whether or not it was the off-season. But before now
column11: I never understood the power of walking away. Sometimes it works
column12: sometimes it doesn't
column13: but this tool alone has saved me from many outrageously overpriced rickshaw rides. I like to imagine that I'll be able to use this skill when I make my next big purchase at home. (Car salesmen in 10 years
column14: watch out!)

column1: One of the other things I have had to get used to are different exclamations. Only now are these beginning to rub off on me
column2: as I only hear them when someone is frustrated or distressed (which is happening more now that term exams are approaching). The most common exclamation is a drawn out
column3: ""I-o!"" (pronounced ""aye-OH""). I was shocked when I first heard this because it is so similar to some of the original exclamations used in Medea. For those of you who do not know
column4: I directed Medea last spring with the Meiningens Student Theatre Group
column5: and the translation we used included many of the original exclamations (so
column6: instead of the Nurse crying the melodramatic ""Woe!"" to the heavens
column7: she cries ""Yoh!""). In rehearsal
column8: the actors worked hard to instill emotion into such unfamiliar phrases
column9: and it never occurred to me that something similar was used in contemporary times. I'm trying to incorporate it into my speech
column10: because it seems to fill that gap that Americans only fill with sighing or huffing
column11: but it still comes out rather clunkily--much to my student's amusement
column12: I'm sure. I may not pick this one up fully
column13: but I appreciate its expressiveness.

column1: The long and short of it
column2: I suppose
column3: is that although I sometimes struggle to communicate clearly
column4: I am always learning!

column1: I know I promised that my next blog was going to be about different adventures in communication
column2: but I guess that one will come next.

column1: Today is the last Saturday before the big end-of-the term push
column2: and the tension is palpable
column3: especially with the upper grades. So--as I am apt to do when I feel deadlines and stress looming ahead--I intentionally took part of the day off to enjoy myself. But instead of going into Bangalore with everyone else (believe me
column4: I'll be going into Bangalore plenty of times in the next three weeks)
column5: I decided to stay at SB and get some mehndi.

column1: It is almost a rite of passage for volunteers to have mehndi done for them by the students. Mehndi is the Tamil word for the English henna (or
column2: really
column3: I should be writing this vice-versa--I'm pretty sure the Tamil word came first)
column4: and is a red-brown paste that
column5: when applied properly
column6: dyes your skin for around 2 or 3 weeks. It is sold in cones
column7: like those used for professional-quality frosting
column8: to ease application and therefore allow for complex designs.

column2: a seventh grader who is taking voice lessons from

column1: My lovely tattoo artist. Some people say that we look alike if we wear our hair in the same style. Hopefully
column2: I will get a picture and let you decide.

column1: me. We decided to settle in the music room
column2: where it was quieter and not as sunny. Several other students filtered through as we went
column3: offering advice and company. Janani
column4: another 7th grader
column5: played with my hair for quite some time while Shilpa worked. Janani taught me how to make my hair look longer by putting it in a high ponytail
column6: but leaving a small clump out at the nape of the neck. That way your hair looks at least four inches longer. I asked her what would happen if I tilted my head to the side
column7: revealing the clump of hair
column8: and she pursed her lips like an exasperated artist and said
column9: ""You have to just...keep your head straight."" Others who dropped in were very interested with my mini toolkit
column10: which I had removed from my bag for the scissors. And others busied themselves with my music.

column1: For those of you unfamiliar with the mehndi process
column2: it is a long one: Applying the detail-work for just my palm took over half an hour
column3: and then you have to let it dry. After you let it dry
column4: you have to re-moisten the ink with sugar water (I have no

column1: idea why). Then you have to let it dry again. And then you re-wet it. And let it dry. Eventually
column2: you rub the paste off and the dye remains.
when you have a group of children getting the sugar
column3: they get about five times what is needed. And
column4: when that happens
column5: they sacrifice themselves and eat the excess. I felt it was my duty to take on some of the burden as well
column6: but I was at the disadvantage of having hands covered in drying mehndi. So
column7: Thulasi
column8: who understood how much I hate to shirk my duties
column9: spoon-fed me my portion.

column2: it was nice to just spend time with the students
column3: and talk about non-school related things. After I scraped off all of the dried paste
column4: I had to dive back into writing term exams
column5: which are due to Lizzy tomorrow morning. But now if I find myself getting too stressed
column6: I can distract myself for a while with Shilpa's lovely designs.

column2: Displayed: 5

column1: These are two of the 8th graders with whom I went birdwatching.

I walked into my 12th grade class today and my students had written the following on the board: ""Happy Thanksgiving Miss Linn ! Thank you for: -Teaching us -Sharing your talent."" It warmed my heart.
It didn't occur to me when I planned this trip how much I would miss Thanksgiving with my family. Here at SB
column2: the American volunteers have had a lot of conversations about the gastronomical losses: no turkey
column3: no stuffing
column4: and certainly no green bean casserole. At least for me
column5: this is a kind of fa√ßade. It is far easier to discuss the food that I'm missing than to discuss the overheated kitchen
column6: the cat's chirps (she would love some of that turkey)
column7: the smell of applecrisp
column8: the pile of still-cold jackets
column9: and the Simon and Garfunkel playing in the background. And food is definitely an easier topic than discussing the laughter
column10: the cribbage victories and losses
column11: the warmth of being with so many people in such a small place
column12: the hugs
column13: and the security. No gifts to worry about. No decorations. Just a secure sense of ""us.""

column1: But I've traded all of that in this year
column2: for better or worse. I figured that since
I am so grateful that I can reach for a good book (and nutella).

column1: I'd be home (and recovered from jet-lag) in time to celebrate Christmas
column2: I would have plenty of opportunity to enjoy my family and friends. But Thanksgiving is beautiful in its simplicity. I'm sure this is a claim that will make many-a-cook scoff. (""Have you ever tried to cook a whole turkey?"" they may ask. To which I'd reply
column3: ""No
column4: but I've tried to cook around a whole turkey."" If you've ever been to a holiday in my mother's kitchen
column5: you'd understand.) But
column6: honestly
column7: how often do we actively gather simply to give thanks for what we have? For me
column8: at least
column9: not often enough.

column2: although (or maybe because) I am gathering with a new and different family this Thanksgiving
column3: I wanted to share a list of things I am grateful for
column4: both at home and here in India
column5: and in no particular order.

column1: 1) My families: One night at dinner
column2: upon asking how many siblings a girl had
column3: she smiled and said
column4: ""I have a younger sister."" I was about to ask the next child at the table when the girl continued
column5: ""And I have her and her and her and him..."" as she pointed to each

column1: Doesn't it look a bit like a pink porcupine?
child at the table. Then she looked at me
column2: and smiled a wonderfully toothy grin. ""And now I have you. All part of my Shanti Bhavan family."" I love that attitude
column3: and cannot help but think of how many different families have supported/adopted/tolerated me over the years. In case I don't say it enough: Friends
column4: old and new
column5: you mean the world to me.

column2: my teacher's
column3: and my students'. I lump this all together because
column4: quite frankly
column5: I'm grateful for our capacity and desire to learn and discover. I went birdwatching with the 8th-grade girls yesterday and was pleasantly surprised by how excited they were to stand at the edge of the lake (really just a pond right now) and look at egrets and ducks through binoculars. They were yelling
column6: ""Look! Look at that duck! It's so cool!"" and I realized that
column7: yes
column8: ducks are cool
column9: if you look at them closely enough. And
column10: as we were walking
column11: I noticed this georgeous set of crepuscular rays (those thin rays of light that looks a bit like a spotlight from God) and told the girls. Immediately
column12: they were asking me what crepuscular means
column13: and how to spell it. Throughout the rest of the walk they would occassionally check with me that they were saying it correctly. I am so thankful to not only constantly be learning
column14: but to also be in a position where I can regularily engage the curiosity of the next generation.

column1: 3) Food: It has to be on here. Whether I am scooping up rice with my fingers and a piece of chapatti or I'm balancing salmon on the back of my fork
column2: I am so glad to experience so many varieties of food. My horizons are ever-expanding: I used to be very wary of spicy foods
column3: and now I eat it comfortably every day. I didn't have any idea what gobi manchurian or poori or real chutney was--all I knew was a sweet and sour mango chutney--but (look out
column4: world!) I'm now determined to learn to make them
column5: too. And that leads really well into:

column1: 4) Diversity: I didn't appreciate it much until now
column2: but the world would be SO BORING if we didn't have such a diverse set of cultures. There's so much I didn't know I didn't know
column3: like how there are trees with flowers that look like pink porcupines. Or
column4: how male friends in India feel comfortable holding hands. Or
column5: how the custard apple looks like something you put in your closets to keep moths away but is actually quite edible. And
column6: while I'm on the note of diversity
column7: I wanted to express my gratitude for how many wonderful ways there are to express oneself. Sure
column8: I'm teaching the students choir and drama
column9: but there's also the little things--new gestures and mannerisms that I am excited to add to my own repetoire. (Don't worry
column10: there will be a more specific blog on this
column11: coming soon.)

column2: before I came here
column3: told me that I was ""brave"" for doing this. I don't know how to quantify brave
column4: but I can tell you that I am not nearly as brave as those people who travelled long distances before me. I'm lucky enough to have instant access to those I love through the internet. I'm also lucky to have a journey that lasts only slightly over 24 hours each way
column5: and solar power on the path as I go back to my room every night. I'm lucky to be staying in a place where I can get water through plumbing even in my second-floor room. I'm lucky to have rickshaws and cars that can take me into Hosur and Bangalore every now and again to get supplies and a different sort of meal. I don't know what this says about me
column6: but had these assurances not been in place
column7: I doubt I would have chosen to come here. So
column8: I'm thankful for them because they have afforded me the opportunity to experience India.

column1: There's much more I could write
column2: but the list could go on for cyber-miles (yes
column3: I made that up). So
column4: suffice it to say that I am so thankful for each and every one of you
column5: and I wish you all the happiest of Thanksgivings.

column1: Our trip to Tirupati was made possible by reducing one day at Port Blair.
Tirupati-Balaji is the temple of Lord Krishna or 'Govindaa'. One of the busiest and richest temples in India.

column2: we took a taxi to Tirupati from Chennai. Chennai to Tirupati and back is possible in one day (~ 20 hours) but it is better to be on a safer side and keep two days (at least one and half days).

column1: Distance from Chennai (airport) to Tirupati is 180 km and from Internet we had learned that it will take about 3.5 hours. It took us almost six hours! Road from Chennai to this famous temple is practically non-existent. It is under construction (God Balaji only knows since when...) and will take another couple of years to complete. Such delays can totally disrupt your tour planning. We had expected to reach by 3 pm and we reached after 5 pm.

Main temple is on the top of the hill. At the base is the town of Tirupati. The climb takes 30 min through excellent road (16 km). Roads for going up and coming down are different that makes them safe.
Darshan at Tirumala are in three categories:
(3) Queue for Rs. 300/-. On different days of the week the queue for Rs. 300/- opens for different hours. In this queue
column2: Lord Balaji gives you appointment at a fixed hour and you don't have to wait in the queue for more than 3 hours. You can rest in your hotel room and come at the appointed hour.

column1: Free Darshan are open round the clock.
Reaching Tirumala (top of the hill) at 5 pm made all the difference. Tickets for Rs. 50/- were closed and so also the Rs. 300/- quota. Rs. 300/- quota would open at 9.00 am next day.
Lord Balaji wanted us to meet through the common man's route. And we didn't have a choice.
We joined the Free Darshan system (yes it should be called a 'system'üòâ at around 6.15 in the Vaikuntham Queue Complex. After half an hour of terrible jostling and pushing
column2: we passed through the security gate and we were directed in to a big CAGE. They call it HALL. It is a stepped room with metal grill walls on all four sides (hence I prefer to call it cage). It was cage (hall) no. 9. There are more than such 30 cages. Each cage can accommodate nearly 400 devotees. To our surprise
column3: as soon as we entered the cage
column4: every one (who was experienced) spread out their sheets of clothes and prepared to sleep. Before we could understand anything
column5: the cage was full and it was locked from outside!

column1: There was a huge TV screen showing the activities in the Sanctum sanctorum live. Some privileged neta was performing pooja and priests were chanting shlokas in local language.
On the notice board was written: Time of sitting: 14th November
column2: 6.40 pm. Expected time for Darshan
column3: 15th November
column4: 9.00 pm! We were explained that sometimes it takes more than 24 hours of waiting in free darshan.

column2: there is a mechanism to temporarily leave the cage by registering at the photometric registration system. We missed it because the announcement was made in local language.

devotees woke up and rushed to the back of the cage to collect their portion of daal-rice served free by the temple. The cage filled with the aroma of daal-rice. We prayed to be saved from some daal-rice dropping on us! Everything became quiet after some time.

column1: By 10 pm it became very cold and we didn't have extra clothes to protect us. We were without dinner and had very little water. We were looking for the volunteers to unlock the cage and take us out. We had almost decided to quit - without Darshan.

At 10.30 whistles started blowing and suddenly it became clear that our lot will be taken for Darshan. Devotees ran pushing each other and chanting 'Govidaa'. We passed through a maze of queue system for next hour. On the way
column2: there was another queue system for collecting coupons for 'laddus'.

column1: Finally we reached the main temple around 11.30. There we didn't have to make any effort to move forward. We simply floated through the main temple with the help of pushes from the more devoted devotees. Our Darshan part was over in less than a second
column2: after waiting in the queue for 5 hours.

column1: Queues didn't end there. We were to go to another building where 'laddus' were handed over in return for coupons. Can you imagine who were doing this job? More than 20 India's top leading Banks!! I am at loss to understand what they were doing and why? Why banks were involved in laddu distribution?
The entire Darshan ritual ended at 12.30 past midnight.
The TTD (Tirupati-Tirumala-Devasthanam) must be given full credit for making all possible efforts to maintain order and provide as much facilities to the visitors as possible. In the cages
column2: huge ventilation systems were working efficiently. It never felt congested or smelly. Toilets were clean and dry (a big surprise!). RO drinking water was available. Volunteers were poilte and courteous. The problem is with the devotees: their number and their behaviour. Inspite of having 33 crore devatas (Gods) as per Hindu mythology
column3: Lord Balaji has to take such a load! HE is available 24x7. Number cannot be restricted - we were also a part of those thousands. But the behaviour! Every devotee wanted to go ahead of the other! There is no shame in fighting to go ahead of others in the temple.

column1: Next on the agenda was to search for room to stay at night. None were available. All the accommodations are managed by the Temple authority and are booked in advance.

We decided to climb down the hill and stay in some hotel at Tirupati (there are many there). But no! It would not be possible before 3 am. Road to go down remains closed from 12 midnight to 3 am. After spending few hours in the car
column2: we proceeded to find a hotel at 4.30 am to rest for a few hours before proceeding to Chennai to catch return flight to Ahmedabad.

column1: You have to be a true devotee to visit Tirupati again.

So after Alleppey we caught a train to Trivandrum and stayed at the YMCA for a night. We managed to find a hotel that served a cool beer and ended up watching the start of the Diwali festival and fireworks from the rooftop of the hotel (I told Jess the fireworks had been planned in advance for her! Smooth ay! üòä ) We then caught a train to Tirunevelli where SCAD is based while Diwali Festival was still in full swing . . .

We have been here for two days and there is a lot to take in. SCAD helps people who have been cast out of society for lots of different reasons. I could not believe the size of the campus! It‚Äôs like a massive university campus that houses a polytechnic
column2: college
column3: engineering college
column4: nursing college
column5: facilities for young people with learning and mental difficulties and a 14 acre plot of land used to grow plants and trees for the purpose of organic farming that is shipped out to local farming communities.

column1: We visited a gypsy camp where they have developed a school to give the kids a chance of education
column2: there were some characters there and

column1: the kids sang for us. We then visited a village where people with leprosy live. Before this people with leprosy were seen as outcasts and in one story we heard how a woman had been shut out by her husband and kids and left to fend for herself!

Today we have worked alongside people in the physiotherapy and speech therapy ward. We have spent time with children from the mental health ward too and got to know them. Their English is brilliant and there are some real characters there who are really friendly and just want to get to know you. There is a young girl there who was found abandoned at a bus stop and became an elected mute due to what happened to her before SCAD took her in
column2: she communicates through different vocal sounds
column3: is always smiling and has adopted Jess üòâ

column2: Displayed: 6

column1: These are real flowers and greens!
This week is the ultimate of holiday weeks in India
column2: and let me tell you: Shanti Bhavan certainly knows how to throw a party! We only have two days of school off (November 13 for Diwali and November 14 for Children's Day)
column3: but the celebrations started on Saturday
column4: and I cannot express how lucky I feel to be a part of them.

column1: First off: Children's Day. One of the best holidays I have ever experienced. It's officially on Wednesday (on Nehru's birthday)
column2: but we celebrated early so staff members could participate and still go home for Diwali. I wasn't quite sure what to expect
column3: going into Saturday. There was a lot of prep-work: For weeks in advance we (the volunteers and staff) would hold little secret night ""meetings
column4: which were actually short
column5: overheated
column6: often candle-lit rehearsals. We were expected to put together a performance of some sort
column7: with choreographed dances
column8: songs
column9: and skits. We handmade a card for each of the 200+ students. We chipped in money to buy a bag of chips for each child.

column2: but I think I initially approached the whole idea of Children's Day in a very American way. As one
whenever she asked her mother why there wasn't a Children's Day in the US when there was a Mother's Day
column3: her mother would reply
column4: ""Every day is Children's Day."" I thought it was a cute idea
column5: and one that I could get behind
column6: but I couldn't help but also feel that we were working every day for the students
column7: and after especially long days with them
column8: it was sometimes difficult to motivate preparing extra entertainment for them.

column1: But the thing about a school like Shanti Bhavan is that
column2: no matter how much energy teachers may put into helping and caring for their students
column3: there is never enough love to go around for each individual student. Much of the time students have to depend on each other for individual attention
column4: and although that is good in its own way
column5: it is also important for the adults to remind the kids that they are willing to do anything--even to be extremely silly onstage--for their students
column6: because they love them. I cannot express how the youngest children's eyes brightened when they saw the cards with their names on them. They carried those cards with them for the rest of

column1: the day and asked various adults to read and re-read the form letter inside.
The performance was a wonderfully eclectic mix of traditional and hip-hop dance
column2: skits (in English and in Hindi or Tamil)
column3: and song. All of the adults--even the graduates
column4: visiting during their semester breaks--helped out in some way. I ended up dancing in the volunteers' rendition of ""Gangnam Style"" and ""Bare Necessities"" (which I choreographed)
column5: singing ""I'm Not That Smart"" from 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee
column6: and doing a brief bit in a teacher's dance. I also acted in a skit where all of the volunteers pretended to be the students and Ms. Beena
column7: the Vice-Principal
column8: was the teacher. I was the whiny child who bellows ""Mi-i-i-i-i-i-iss!"" every time I felt some injustice occurred. I also threw in the occassional ""PJ!""
column9: which stands for ""Poor joke!""
column10: but is often used in completely innappropriate contexts (like when students feel something is unfair). There was also the pencil-sharpener
column11: the arguers
column12: the jellyfish
column13: and the sleeper. Needless to say
column14: the skit ended with Ms. Beena giving us all ragi-ball for dinner (the common punishment here for misbehavior). The kids loved it (one of the 11th graders fell out

column2: I hear).

column1: At the end of the day
column2: we watched Brave
column3: which is SO much better when you're watching with children. The best part was the fact that Merida
column4: the main character
column5: says the phrase
column6: ""It's unfair!"" a dozen times
column7: and that was another phrase we used frequently in our skit. So the students really enjoyed those moments.

column2: the Festival of the Lights. The day has been a relaxed one; the students had virtually no responsibilities
column3: so I spent time singing in the music room with Vinceya
column4: a senior
column5: and Pushpa
column6: a graduate. Brinda
column7: another senior
column8: played piano for us. Vinceya is one of my voice students (and English
column9: of course)
column10: and although she cannot read music
column11: she has a good ear and a fine
column12: soprano voice. I look forward to seeing how she develops in the next month as we work on some Phantom of the Opera together.

column1: The rest of my day was spent reading
column2: sorting my belongings
column3: and taming my sticky attempt at curled hair. The first two I managed just fine by myself
column4: but the latter required some help from Cathy
column5: another senior. Apparently
column6: women

column1: are expected to wear ""new sarees"" for Diwali
column2: but I did not want to because past volunteers have singed their sarees on the firecrackers (not to mention I would have to borrow a saree). So
column3: instead
column4: I promised to make myself look as nice as possible with what I had. Well
column5: what I had was bobby pins and some hair spray some other volunteer left
column6: but I soon discovered that the hairspray was crappy. My hair feels goey. But Cathy was gracious enough to french braid my hair very nicely and turn a mess into something fancy.

column2: at 6:30 p.m.
column3: we all gathered to see a couple of dances (learned today from music videos
column4: I believe). And then we went to the dining hall
column5: which the intrepid 11th graders had decorated and re-arranged. Little lanterns were everywhere
column6: leading to a beautiful display in the center of the hall. It was so beautiful
column7: seeing everyone moving in their sarees and fancy kurtas in the firelight. I tried to take a few pictures
column8: but then Sebastian
column9: a 7th grader
column10: asked if he could use my camera. This is common
column11: and likely the best way to get really good

column1: pictures at SB. He was the first of three students who borrowed my camera over the night. I'm not sure who took which pictures
column2: but I am certainly grateful for them all.

column1: Dinner was coriander rice with potato
column2: and dessert was a gelatinous sweet. Then
column3: the ""crackers"" were taken out. Not only sparklers and loud firecrackers
column4: no
column5: but also what appeared to me like sure instruments of death. There were flat
column6: round crackers that you lit and then spun so it would send sparks in a whirl over your shoes. There were ""flowerpots
column7: which sent fountains of sparks ten feet high. The field behind the dining hall was thick with smoke and children
column8: and I now have a new understanding of Civil War battlefield imagery.

column1: In general I stayed out of the chaos
column2: but that made me anxious
column3: too
column4: because I was there to be with the kids
column5: and how can I connect if I remain aloof to one of their favorite days? So
column6: when Gayathri
column7: one of the 11th graders
column8: asked if I wanted to light a flowerpot
column9: I agreed. Heck
column10: I'm in India
column11: right? Why not? So she goes off to find a lantern with which

column1: I can light this monstrous cracker (it's a cone as big as my hand)
column2: and then we find a clearing in the field. I tried to light it
column3: but although the top caught fire
column4: it went out before anything happened. So
column5: I tried again
column6: with the same result. At this point
column7: I'm really nervous--what if there is no wick left and my hand explodes off when I put the flame to it?--but the kids seem unconcerned
column8: and tell me to try a third time. ""Hold the flame there until the white comes out!"" they told me. Apparently
column9: ""the white"" means a warning flash of foot-high white sparks. Upon seeing this
column10: I ran back with my lantern
column11: and I only momentarily glimpsed the red and green of my flowerpot going off. And
column12: of course
column13: since my back was turned
column14: a spark landed on me. The kids seemed impervious to the sparks (or maybe they just were good at avoiding them). I'm satisfied to report
column15: though
column16: that both me and my clothes came out of Diwali fully intact
column17: without any scorch marks. Success
column18: if I do say so myself.

column1: I think my favorite moment of the night
column2: though
column3: was the small fireworks show at the end. For five minutes
column4: the chaos stopped
column5: and everyone in the field looked up into the sky. Two girls were standing on chairs next to me
column6: and for every single one
column7: they whispered
column8: ""That's beautiful."" These fireworks weren't huge or specially designed or very colorful
column9: but it was the best display I've ever seen. How often does a person get to see so many people that she loves appreciating
column10: in awe and stillness
column11: something that they love? That's the image that I'll always remember about Diwali.

column1: We reached Coonoor on a cloudy noon in the last week of October. It was drizzling over the valleys but not raining. We three (my wife
column2: son and myself) checked in Hotel Vivek where we had booked a room thru net. It was slightly interior to the main roads
column3: situated in upper Coonoor near Upasi at Figure of 8 Road and after calling the hotel we could locate the place. There was a restaurant also in the premises called Green Field and we had our lunch there.

column1: Coonoor is a calm and quiet place where there is no crowd
column2: rush and noises unlike Ooty. You can spend a lazy day here for sight seeing or simply walking thru the greenery or visiting the view points and the park.

column1: After the meals we first visited Sims Park
column2: the botanical garden which was around two kilometers from the hotel. Though we feared the rain would spoil the day
column3: fortunately there was no further rainfall. It is a large park spread over acres of land having full of flowers and variety of plants and trees. Many of the trees are very old and rare. There is a lake

column1: inside the park where one can go for boating. We spent almost two hours there wandering thru the meadows.
In front of Sims park there is a junction
column2: the road from Coonoor town goes in two opposite directions
column3: one leads to Kotagiri and the other towards Willington Cantonment area. There are a few small fruits and vegetables shops and tea stalls located in the junction. Opposite to the park stands the famous Pasteur Institute
column4: producing anti-rabies vaccine. However now-a-days it is not open to the public for visit. There is a narrow road parallel to the park which leads to a tea factory where production process of tea can be witnessed and various types of tea can be purchased by the visitors. Since we have already seen the same in Munnar we didn‚Äôt opt for this destination.

column1: Then we planned to have a rounding thru lower Coonoor. It is more crowded as the Coonoor municipal bus stand
column2: market etc are situated here. There are a number of shops congested in this area. There is one vegetarian hotel Sri Lakshmi near to the bus stand. There are a few bakeries such as Crown Bakery

column1: New Indian Bakery (two branches). As we heard about the tasty biscuits available in these bakeries we shopped in the New Indian Bakery
column2: had some coockies and varkies (a snack available in Ooty
column3: Coonor hill stations). The latter seemed to be ordinary
column4: but if you had the experience in your childhood
column5: of tasting those simple but tasty biscuits displayed in the glass jars in your village shop
column6: you would definitely like these biscuits too.

column2: consisting full of small pathways where you will lose the direction and the way behind you
column3: as the narrow paths are countless and cross cutting and crowded also. A large number of tiny shops and stalls selling fruits
column4: vegetables
column5: grocery
column6: cloths
column7: leather items
column8: and a lot more are seen in the market. Viewing from the main roads outside the market you may not guess the complexity inside the market. Hence it would be a nice experience to enter into and to exit this place!

column1: We then planned to head towards Lamb‚Äôs Rock
column2: a view point about 7 kms far from Coonoor on the way to Dolphin‚Äôs Nose
column3: another view point situated 12 kms fom the

column1: town. As it was not a sunny day and it was already evening we had to drop the idea of visiting Dolphin Nose which would be covered by fog by the time we reach there. Hence we moved to the Lamb‚Äôs Rock.
It is a beautiful viewpoint on the rocks surrounded by large trees and plants which create the atmosphere of a small forest. There are two walk-paths
column2: one to climb uphill and the other to come back. On the top there is a pillar
column3: steps are provided so that one can easily climb the same and have the scenic beauty of surrounding valleys and mist spreading here and there.

column1: Since it was nearing twilight we started our return trip to the town. It was getting very cold and we came back to the hotel for dinner without further wanderings.

Next day morning after breakfast we went near Sim‚Äôs park and drove towards Wellington. It is a Cantonment Board area where the Defence Services Staff College is situated and also a picturesque location. Green meadows are flood on both sides of the road. There is a Golf club by the side
of the road. We spent some time there to take a few snaps.

Coming back to Sims park junction we drove a few kilometers towards Kotagiri area. This was also a route with nice sceneries. On the way we found a small temple on the uphill side of the road which was named ‚ÄòChinna Tirupathy‚Äô as it was Sree Venkiteswara Temple. We had a visit there and felt a nice atmosphere there. Interestingly the poojary (performer of rituals) of the temple was a young fellow who had his MBA done and was undergoing management consultancy as told to us.
There was a water fall called Law‚Äôs falls near to Coonoor
column2: however on enquiry we have been advised that in the rainy time it would be slippery and hence not approachable. The other water falls which we heard was Catherine falls
column3: which was situated in Kotagiri.

column1: As it was nearing noon we went back to the hotel. It was time to check out and go for our next destination. The time we spent in Coonoor was swift and awesome nice and we bid farewell to this scenic township
column2: Sayanora!

I'll admit that this entry has a cheesy and almost nonsensical title
column3: but I didn't want to say ""Raiders of the Lost Arts"" because
column4: according to Dictionary.com
column5: raider is ""a person who seizes control of a company
column6: as by secretly buying stock and gathering proxies."" (Okay
column7: that's definition #4
column8: but in any case
column9: raider is not an appropriate term for the atmosphere I want to create.) So
column10: I am justifying my title choice by pointing out that my students are both literate andartistic
column11: sometimes even in the same class (like today
column12: but more on that later).

column1: Sorry I haven't been writing too much
column2: but classes have been busy
column3: and I have been gathering materials to show all of you what's been happening. Basically
column4: these past couple of weeks have been marked by the resurgence of the arts in my life (and the life of Shanti Bhavan). They (the arts) returned with a vengance
column5: and I have to admit that at times they have already kicked me in the tush. This is what I've been training for
column6: what I CAME for
column7: and it's still proving to be more challenging than teaching English. But I think the rewards will be double-fold

column2: but here's the choir.

column1: It started with the unsteady return of theatre classes. We had a couple before these past weeks
column2: but International Day of the Girl-Child made it nearly impossible to keep a regular schedule. Originally
column3: I wanted to have two groups: 8-12 grade and 4-7 grade. But the 8-12 graders didn't come
column4: I think because they would be missing PT (the only time they get to play outside). And the 4-7 graders? It's a MASSIVE group of about fifty kids
column5: so I split them up instead
column6: but even twenty-five is hard to handle because my theatre class is scheduled right after their academic classes. I am flattered that they choose to do my theatre class
column7: but the 4-5th graders especially lack focus at that time. A couple weeks back
column8: we gained a new volunteer
column9: Rebecca
column10: who is also a theatre artist
column11: and I immediately recruited her to help me because I had already held the first class (with all fifty students
column12: heaven help me!) and knew that I needed support. It runs far more easily with her
column13: and the kids are more responsive with two sets of eyes.

column2: here's what we're doing: I am really interested in exploring the basics of devised theatre with the students (a theatrical method of creating a performance that is used by the Children's Theatre Company Theatre Arts Training program quite a bit). We invited students to come in with folk-tales that they have heard and tell the folk-tale to the class. Then we broke into groups and during the next class put together small skits based on the folktales. The ultimate goal is to pick a folk-tale and bring everyone together to make the folk-tale come to life. Depending on the 6-7 graders' interest
column3: we may then play around with the story
column4: asking and answering questions onstage that are left unsaid in the text. I'm looking forward to creating a piece
column5: and I hope that this may help them get beyond their various ""blocks""--whether it's fear/derision of the opposite gender
column6: or embarrassment
column7: or lack of collaborative experience.

column2: too
column3: started these past couple of weeks. Cathy and Vinceya
column4: two of the dedicated choir seniors
column5: maintained the choir while there was no teacher. I'm not sure how long this teacher-less period was
column6: but I get the feeling that they are grateful to relinquish the class to me. They are still wonderfully helpful--I am still struggling with non-11th and -12th grade names
column7: and so they act as my extra eyes when it comes to keeping everyone on-task. This is very much appreciated
column8: especially because I am asking a lot more of the students than they are used to. As far as I can tell
column9: they have not done harmonies in years
column10: if ever. So
column11: I'm starting them on a simple Jay Althouse arrangement of ""Homeward Bound"" (not the Simon and Garfunkel
column12: but similarly folksey) with two parts. It is slow-going
column13: especially with only two 45-minute rehearsals a week
column14: but they are starting to pick it up
column15: which is exhilarating. I've also started to teach them solfege exercises
column16: and soon hope to add warm-up songs with built-in harmonies (thirds and fifths). I've been told to start anticipating Christmas
column17: so I'm thinking of buying them (with my remaining fundraised-money) ""Carol of the Bells"" or some other simple Christmas piece with enough copies for each of them to actually see the music. I also need to find something German
column18: apparently
column19: which is tradition for the Christmas party.

column1: I'm also really excited to say that I will be starting an Advanced Choir this weekend
column2: which will be exclusively for the 11th and 12th grade choir folks. AND I will be starting four private and two small-group lessons on the side. I cannot express how anxious but delighted I am to have this opportunity. Some of you
column3: my readers
column4: may have noted that I recently put up a Facebook status that said
column5: ""...Maybe I want to become a music teacher."" Maybe it's just the ""newness"" of the experience
column6: but I feel invigorated when I leave choir rehearsal
column7: and I hope that my students are enjoying their little victories as much as I am. I was recently helping one of my choir students with her vocabulary in morning prep (which is basically study hall)
column8: and she came to the word ""vivacious."" She looked at me and as her homework dictated
column9: put it into a sentence: ""Miss Lynn is a vivacious teacher."" In a situation where I can't really poll the people I am serving about my effectiveness
column10: I am taking that as a sign that I'm doing alright.

column1: I've tried to pull the arts into my classroom
column2: too
column3: and this week a lot of that effort came to fruition. You see
column4: in English
column5: I am teaching under the idea that there are three levels of literary analysis: Level one is the gut reaction; level two is the critical analysis
column6: and; level three is applying the literature to the world. We have been working steadily through piece after piece at the first and second level
column7: and today I introduced the third. For my 11th graders
column8: this came while we were studying Walt Whitman's ""I Sit and Look Out."" Here is the text
column9: for those of you who have never read the poem:

column1: I sit and look out upon all the sorrows of the world
column2: and upon all

column1: I hear secret convulsive sobs from young men
column2: at anguish with
remorseful after deeds done;
in low life
column3: the mother misused by her children
column4: dying

column2: gaunt
column3: desperate;

column1: I see the wife misused by her husband--I see the treacherous seducer
I mark the ranklings of jealousy and unrequited love
column2: attempted to be

column1: hid--I see these sights on the earth;
I see the workings of battle
column2: pestilence
column3: tyranny--I see martyrs and

column1: I observe a famine at sea--I observe the sailors casting lots who

column2: to preserve the lives of the rest;

column1: I observe the slights and degradations cast by arrogant persons upon

column2: the poor
column3: and upon negroes
column4: and the like;

column1: All these--All the meanness and agony without end
column2: I sitting
column3: look

column2: hear
column3: and am silent.

column1: I was unsurprised but slightly disappointed by the anthology's choice of using this
column2: of all of Whitman's poems. Sure
column3: I'll admit that teaching the sensual ""Song of Myself"" would have been uncomfortable with my students (who titter when I ask if someone had fallen ""in love"" or ""in lust"")
column4: but why does the alternative to sexuality always have to be painful and depressing pieces? My students agreed that they were sick of all these disheartening poems
column5: and so we decided to re-write the poem
column6: and ""Please
column7: with happy things"" (as MK
column8: one of my students
column9: put it so eloquently). Each student wrote a line about what they see in their lives
column10: and then we combined them. Of course
column11: there was a disagreement regarding whether to show a progression from the negative to the positive or to intermingle the two
column12: but we split the class according to preference (which actually turned out to be according to gender) and ended up with two beautiful pieces. Here is one
column13: entitled ""We Sit and Look Out
column14: written by the four gentlemen of the class:

column1: We sit and look out upon the bittersweet world of pain and sorrow overpowered by love;
We look at the outside world and see slavery and poverty;
We see a priest performing his rituals while a beggar sits right in front
column2: begging people for money to live her life;

column1: We witness gunshots in response to the voice fighting for a cause greater than our own;
We see a father playing with his children
column2: forgetting his sorrow and troubles;

column1: We hear laughter as the children are entertained by the things they love;
We see a small plant no bigger than a pinky become a big
column2: undefeated tree;

column1: We sit and observe a brother caring for a sister
column2: showering love upon her;

column1: We see the world changing for better or worse cause;
All these‚ÄîAll the nightmares and sweet dreams are the things that make up human life.
Have I mentioned recently how much I love and admire these young people?

column2: after we completed our poem
column3: we also had a brilliant period of comparing Whitman's piece to Simon and Garfunkel's ""Sound of Silence."" We must have listened to the song five or six times
column4: and by the end we were all singing and creating venn diagrams and generally feeling very literary. And then I got to repeat the process with the 12th graders
column5: but with a short story called ""The Fly"" and Mumford and Son's cover of ""The Boxer.""

column2: a good day to end a good couple of weeks.

column1: P.S. The video uploader is being difficult right now
column2: but I do intend to upload a small snippet of drama class for your viewing pleasure.

bumpy ride we arrived at the train station. Outside was a cow with the biggest horns I have ever seen in my life! He can't have been comfortable carrying those round on his head! We entered the station and were shown to the upper class waiting room to use the bathroom if we needed. We walked into the waiting room and the stench of stale urine hit us hard. We bravely continued
column3: knowing we faced a 13 hour train ride where the toilets would probably be worse. In the toilets we peered into the cubicles and recoiled in horror. We had seen more western toilets than I expected
column4: and we had also used squat toilets
column5: but this was a tiled room with a tiny little hole in the corner
column6: how on earth do you wee into that! needless to say we didn't go any further. We decided against joining the locals in walking across the tracks to get to the other platform and used the footbridge. Once over we were in a sea of Indians
column7: how all those people fit on one train I don't know
column8: although this is India and they are the

column1: masters at sharing personal space! We were told that we were sat in approximately the right position for our carriage
column2: g15 but there was no guarantee that's where it would stop. There was a family of sixty all piling on in the same area and the train only stops for a limited time so when it does arrive we should run and get on any carriage and then worry about where we should be. I looked from my hundred kilo rucksack to Shaz and back again in disbelief... He wanted me to run... With that! We got ready
column3: but obviously the train was late and unable to read Hindi we had a couple of false starts. When it was time to go we sprinted a few meters up the platform
column4: implying he is a gentleman Planty hung back making sure all the girls got on
column5: as the train pulled away I still couldn't see him in the madness and I just walked forward blindly! We found our seats
column6: I found Planty and then we sat and took in our surroundings. The train was split into bays with 6 to a bay
column7: the other side of the walk way was space

column2: everything was open
column3: I expected separate cabins but that was not the case. Plus Indians take so long to settle! Seriously how many times can you walk up and down the aisle? Our bay sleeping 6 consisted of two bench style seats that we sat on but also doubled as beds. A top bunk and a fold out shelf to really squeeze us in. There was little to no leg room sat down. We braved the toilet
column4: deciding they had to be the best they'd ever be as it was the beginning. We got there and there was an Indian woman stood in the queue. ""Indian Indian"" she proclaimed. We just looked blankly
column5: later we realised she meant these were the Indian squat toilets
column6: the western were the other end. However we got a waft of the western one up the carriage and decided that because the Indians probably don't know how to use the western one properly and we were nearly certain using the squat one we weed straight onto the tracks
column7: the Indian was probably the most hygienic! After taking it in turns to go and hold the door for each other as it

column1: had a tendency to swing open with the motion of the train we stumbled back to our group. After putting our pjs on and getting comfyish the guys played a few games of would you rather that included licking the train windows and disturbing the guy opposite who was the loudest snorer I have ever heard and the girls cringed in disgust. The train staff started bringing round food that we had all opted out of
column2: (except for one who had eatern like a local from day one and suffered the consequences) being told Pringles and oreos were much more substantial for dinner. after about an hour of them walking round with different shades and consistancys of green goo and proclaiming what they were at the top of their lungs
column3: the only noise was us laughing and the snoring guy
column4: the rest of the carriage fell into a sort of stupor. We decided it was time to attempt a sleep so we put down the shelf beds and crawled into our spaces. The only way to lie was with bent legs so your feet didn't go over the edge. For this reason the tallest went at the top. I got

column2: once in you couldn't sit up
column3: or move around. For 30 rupees you could get a clean sheet
column4: pillow and blanket. We opted out having silk sleeping bag liners that we had bought especially for the journey
column5: at first I was jealous of the pillows and blankets

I was prepared for a sleepless night however I didn't wake up until the train attendants woke the whole carriage individually shouting things like ""veg cutlet"" ""omelette"" and ""chai"" (the latter must have gone past at least 20 times!)
