column5: our driver went a couple of meters and then stopped to grab his breakfast
column6: by which point I had made up my mind
column7: I didn't like Mumbai at all! We drove through a narrow market
column8: I knew this was not the slums but it wasn't far off. It was muggy and smelly and alive with people going about their daily lives
column9: right there in the street. As the streets bettered I became more and more relieved about where we were staying! The hotel seemed ok at first glance. They had a greeter and the reception looked fairly modern. They had a table in the middle of it which also served as a fish tank
column10: possibly made for goldfish and not the carp that were in it
column11: but still! We were told our rooms were not ready and we were to be given one between 14 people to freshen up and leave our bags. We had a particularly nasty breakfast in a 1960s style restaurant. There was salt in the orange juice and tea was served in

column2: then a briefing
column3: before being given 10 minutes to remove the dust from the Jeep ride and god knows what from the train ride and make ourselves presentable for a day sightseeing. The room we were given was to be someone‚Äôs room for the night
column4: it had to be the smallest room in the world
column5: with a tiny Indian sized door
column6: beds that wouldn't look out of place in a nursery and a bathroom that had seen a good few guests! Needless to say I couldn't wait to see our room!

column1: We all got into taxis for a day tour of Mumbai. our driver showed us some places including the uni
column2: the beach (which is apparently a massive party place but the sea water is toxic)
column3: Mumbai's famous train station which was beautiful and nothing like the dive we had arrived into. We also saw the Gandhi museum. this was in a former residence of his and was fantastic! it was free entry and charted his life with pictures
column4: correspondence to people including Hitler and Tolstoy and there was a room with different scenes depicting pinnacle points in his life
column5: acted out by little dolls.

column1: went in not really knowing much about Gandhi
column2: I knew he was famous as a peace maker and human rights activist but I didn‚Äôt realize how much of his life he spent campaigning for the poor
column3: or how many countries he visited. The museum was an eye opener to say the least and we were that impressed we even made a donation! we also stopped to look over Mahalaxmi Dhobi Ghat- where they all do their washing. Particularly for the train that runs past (remember the 30 rupee sheets?) it is washing on an industrial scale! Everywhere are massive troughs (1026 to be precise) of washing being beaten and scrubbed
column4: everywhere massive washing lines are hung with rows and rows of linen and clothing. I have seen it before on TV but is one of those moments that can never be properly experienced until you see it first hand.

column1: when planning our day we had opted for a tour that included a visit to the slums
column2: I hadn‚Äôt wanted to do this. I was worried about safety
column3: however I knew that this was something you should really experience to put life into perspective. by this point I trusted Shaz

column1: completely and knew he would not let us endanger our safety. so agreed to go. We pulled over at the side of the road and went down a narrow street. All of us walked single file through a maze of houses and then back out again. All together we were in there about five minutes and that was really enough. We had actually visited a richer part of the slums. These were buildings where people lived and made pottery to sell in the market. We saw a potter at work on a potters wheel
column2: his level of skill was incredible
column3: each pot was identical and he sculpted it from a lump of clay in about four well practiced hand movements. Although we had not truly seen the slums (we were told it was too dangerous to go any further) it was still an eye-opener. Peoples lives are so intertwined and everything is done in the street. If I lived in that close proximity to neighbours back home i'm not convinced it would work the same way as here!

column1: After we left we stopped on an overpass to look at where we had just been. It was a very smelly
sea of blue tarpaulin and satellite dishes
column2: it was horrifying to imagine living like that
column3: however the irony is many second generation
column4: educated
column5: white collar individuals live there
column6: having been raised in that environment and sticking to family and tradition. On leaving we were approached by a woman in a sari begging
column7: only when she spoke she was certainly a man. On referring to the lonely planet guide book I discovered his tale is probably sad
column8: being a 'Hijras' he was an outcast
column9: socially frowned upon and quite possibly had had a traumatic life.

column1: We were happy when the driver dropped us at the gateway of India and said his bit was finished. Primarily because his taste in music was dire (think very screechy woman meets Bollywood) but also partly because this was part of Mumbai that is actually beautiful! The gateway is massive and imposing and was built to commemorate king George v 1911 royal visit to India. It is also flanked by a Taj hotel which is a gorgeous
column2: ornate building. We had planned on getting a boat over to Elephanta island but that proved difficult because of the crowds of people
column3: the fact that the ticket

column1: sellers were just guys mingled in with the crowds and when I pulled out a wad of cash it turned out I had managed to only bring out 10 rupee notes (around 11p a note) this doesn't stretch very far (even in India) We borrowed money from Louise and hopped on a boat just as they decided it full
column2: we squeezed in and stared in awe at the retreating gateway and then to naval ships
column3: fishing boats
column4: an expensive yacht and some freight ships. A few ships later and a fair distance from land we wondered where on earth we were going! It was taking ages and we were on a time limit. When we finally arrived we had to walk across 5 boats and up a jetty. To Plantys disappointment we had not come to see elephants
column5: but rock temples!

column1: Elephanta island takes its name from a stone elephant that used to sit in the port. However it is most famous for its rock temples
column2: dedicated to lord Shiva. They are basalt caves carved into the rock with huge carvings of the god in different scenes adorning every wall and pillar. They are believed to have been created

column1: between AD 450 and 750 and although they are crumbling they remain impressive!
We made it to the base of the hill were there was a bar
column2: from there was a steep climb along a narrow path with sellers on either side
column3: whilst members of our group went the toilet we stood and ate some crisps whilst being midered by a very irritating goat! On setting off up the path a monkey ran across and jumped onto the wall beside
column4: he sat aggressively screaming at us
column5: everyone backed off and a local began motioning to a member of our group to give him her can of coke
column6: we stared in disbelief as the guy took her coke and gave it to the monkey who proceeded to run up a tree with it and drink it. This put a member of our group off going any further and Planty gallantly offered to stay in the bar with her
column7: I however made the sweaty journey up the hill to the temples. They were impressive
column8: we have seen a fair few temples over the last couple of weeks and these were some of the most impressive. They are similar to the pyramids

column1: in the sense that you just stand and wonder how on earth people managed to create such impressive structures. On our way down another monkey ran at us as someone was carrying a bottle of sprite
column2: he threw it and the monkey ran off with it triumphant. We couldn't wait to leave this island and its crazy junk food obsessed animals. Even the cows were pushy and they are normally the most placid of creatures! The sea was getting rougher as we departed and we kept getting drowned in spray! Although we were filthy
column3: the sea was like the rest of Mumbai.. Dirty and we huddled together in the middle of the boat trying to avoid the murky cholera water! We rushed back to the hotel with under an hour to get ready
column4: our taxi driver basically gave us a guided tour of Mumbai which we had already done that day. He also offered one of the lads drugs and then changed his price once we got to the hotel. When we finally got rid of him we grabbed our bags and dashed to our room. We were in 309
column5: we walked up and down the corridor with all our

column1: luggage going from 308 to 310 round the corner wondering were our room was! Obviously it was the door with no number on that was different to all the others! Our room was actually impressive! Flat screen TV
column2: rain shower (the water wasn't hot but we didn't even have a shower in ranakpur)
column3: it must have been refurbished recently. We quickly washed and met downstairs for dinner. We were going to Leopolds for dinner
column4: a massive tourist trap it is known for its shady gangster past
column5: 3L beer and being a target in the 2008 terror attacks on Mumbai. Behind where we sat was bullet holes in the wall serving as a constant reminder of the tragedy. Furthermore the guy with the massive gun on the door prevents it from happening again! Leopolds also served beef ‚Äì the first I had seen in India
column6: I had a steak burger and in true Indian style it was really spicy! This is after all a country where they eat curry for breakfast
column7: lunch and dinner.

column1: From there we went to the gateway of India to see it all lit up at night. All the way there and for most of the
way back we were followed by Mafia owned begging street kids
column2: one even had a money tin
column3: I also got the impression they were not above a little pickpocketing either! After many no's and a couple of go aways
column4: even a torrent of profanities from Planty they still persisted
column5: it wasn't until a policeman shouted at them they left.

column1: The next morning we decided to brave the streets of Mumbai over the hotel ‚Äúrestaurant‚Äù for breakfast. However this turned out to be no easy feat
column2: the safety of a McDonald‚Äôs was too far so we set off looking for an alternative. We saw the others in a coffee shop and they warned us not to eat anything with cheese in... which was everything
column3: so we tried a bakery
column4: they only sold cake
column5: the previous night I had a dessert called ‚Äúchocolate ecstasy‚Äù it was amazing and the bakery sold them
column6: we purchased two thinking it would be a substantial breakfast item! Over the road was ‚Äúwrap express‚Äù probably a little more wholesome than a calorific sugar overhaul we headed over to it. We never saw the wraps so cannot comment
column7: however I can comment on the express bit
column8: it

column1: was a lie! We stood for 10 minutes watching them mess with a gas cylinder
column2: we knew they hadn‚Äôt started our wraps yet and had to get back to the hotel so said we would just buy our drinks and leave. That in itself took another 10 minutes and included questions such as ‚Äúwhat is your mobile number?‚Äù ...not a chance!

column1: We scoffed our chocolate and set off for Mumbai airport. In the taxi the driver asked if we liked music. I recalled the horror we listened to the previous day but before I could protest we were blasting out Indian dance music. He was a funny one
column2: I could see him looking back at us in his rear-view mirror and laughing at our horror every time he had a near miss of slammed on
column3: especially when another taxi nearly crashed trying to overtake... that was apparently hilarious! When you get stuck in traffic in Mumbai beggars come up to the car
column4: we had people trying to sell us books
column5: souvenirs and there was a girl
column6: no older then 14 carrying a baby with a really bad skin condition asking for money. It was horrific! We were told by

column1: our guide that she could very easily be treated in a hospital
column2: however the girls were gang owned and she could earn more money in that condition. It was heartbreaking!

column1: We checked in our luggage and passed through security unhindered except for the shopperholic ladies (Planty will give his opinio of them shortly) who had taped up a hammock they had been carrying round since Delhi so it looked suspicious and got scanned as a potential weapon! On the other side of security was a KFC! After an unsuccessful mornings forage us westerners where at it like moths to a flame! I was had by the ‚Äúupgrade your drink for only 10 rupees‚Äù ad
column2: it looked like green slush
column3: I should have noted Plantys new rule of never order anything green as it turned out to be a sort of salty mango jelly concoction
column4: yum! I even attempted to palm it off on someone else but to no avail. The best was Shaz though
column5: he had to ask someone what to order as he had never had KFC before
column6: bless!

column1: The flight was pretty uneventful and Goa airport was a dump! We were welcomed by a cloudy sky
(not conforming to our 2 day beach plan) and a sign saying merry Christmas. There were also plastic figures of Hindu gods and a half naked Gandhi everywhere
column2: making me double take constantly.

column1: We got in a taxi with an orange Ganesh and two plastic crocodiles on the dashboard. We asked the driver what the recent weather had been like
column2: optimistic this was a brief hiccup..... ‚Äúrain‚Äù was our only response. Failing conversation we turned our attention to the radio. This was our first indication we were in an area of India we were unfamiliar with. The radio elsewhere had been quite traditional Indian music
column3: some drivers had been partial to some Indian dance/trance but Goa radio was the worst! It was a combination of annoying jingles and hits ranging from ‚Äúthe locomotion‚Äù to ‚Äúcall me maybe‚Äù. Furthermore these were interspersed by really dramatic adverts about how if you tremor you should film yourself and take it to the local hospital for analysis
column4: and ensure you don‚Äôt have any standing water as it breeds mosquitoes from the national vector programme
column5: it was just weird!

column1: More bemused and a little traumatised by the radio we began looking out of
our windows and absorbing the scenery. I went from not wanting to look because of the threatening grey sky to being mesmerised by how lush and tropical Goa appeared
column2: in addition the damp air gave it a misty
column3: sleepy feel
column4: like the inhabitants were waking up to a new day (although the day was nearly over). It was a sharp contrast to the dust of Pushkar and the pollution of Mumbai
column5: even the main roads were meandering rural lanes and despite the grim sky I really felt on holiday. We arrived at our destination
column6: the ‚Äúalor resort‚Äù was not much of a resort
column7: we were shown to our room which was obviously back out the hotel
column8: past a gaggling congregation of locals and through a rusty gate next to someone‚Äôs washing. Our apartment was huge
column9: four bed for the two of us
column10: but I wouldn‚Äôt count that as praise. I‚Äôm still trying to work out which was worse
column11: this or Delhi
column12: oh and you had to walk through the shower to get to the toilet again.....

column1: Again we had very little time to get ready for dinner
column2: we rushed down to find most of our group sat drinking beer

column1: at ¬£1 for a large bottle most had decided they like Goa already! The cheap beer continued in the restaurant. In Goa the trend is to bring out the fresh catch of the day so you can pick something that takes your fancy
column2: I decided that as we were in Goa I would be adventurous and go for a stuffed masala crab with a side salad. The salad was amazing
column3: I'd been craving one for weeks and the crab was far too much hard work for very little food. It started raining whilst we were in the restaurant
column4: only it doesn‚Äôt rain in Goa it pours! I‚Äôve never seen anything like it! After eating and when the rain had eased slightly we waded to a bar. It was buy one get one free on beer making it 40p a bottle
column5: the same applied for some of the spirits which were by far not small measures. Goa was so weird
column6: we had become used to dressing conservatively so I had put on a maxi dress but all the local girls were in hot pants and mini dresses
column7: we had literally gone from one extreme to another! Shaz had also warned us

column1: about them saying they have a few drinks and go mental! I was watching one in the bar toying with two young men and no sooner had I mentioned it she turned her attention to the locals playing pool with Rick and Planty. Shaz was over in a flash warning us about her but she soon moved on. The whole thing was so strange. Indian women are not like that! They are conservative and demur
column2: not absolute tarts and it was sad to see the majority behaving like that. Conveniently at half time in the Liverpool match it was time to leave. We also had an early start
column3: with a breakfast meeting planned for 8am.

column1: Breakfast we pushed the boundaries and had a fry up style breakfast. OK the bacon was streaky and crispy and I couldn't even tell you what animal the sausage came from
column2: but there was not even an essence of masala or chilli so it was good! From there the plan was to go to old Goa and then to a spice farm to see the elephants. We got to a church in old Goa
column3: had a look round and then went to go further.

column1: We could feel a change in the wind ""oh it feels like it could rain"" said Planty
column2: and then it did! We ran for cover but it took us around 30 seconds to get drenched through. We made it back to our taxi and told him we'd seen enough of old Goa and to go to the spice farm. It was the same driver with his orange Ganesh
column3: surly attitude and Goa FM. He didn't even flinch when four soggy westerners bundled into his taxi and told him to basically skip all of Goa's history and culture and find the elephants. He just obediently drove. When we arrived at the spice farm the weather was beginning to ease. After a cup of hot lemon grass tea we were shown around the plantation. This was a collection of all the different herbs
column4: spices and fruit the Indians harvest. Unfortunately I didn't pay much attention as the humid wet weather had brought the mosquitoes out to play. Possibly the most memorable quote of the whole trip came from the guide at this point:

column2: they are organic mosquitoes so don't have malaria""

column1: supposed to reassure me?? An insect the size of a bee is stealing my blood but its ok
column2: because it won't give me malaria. The huge big itchy lumps I had for days all over the backs of my knees weren‚Äôt a problem whatsoever! Furthermore it is tradition that after leaving the plantation they wash with lemon grass in the stream. The tourist alternative is to have it poured down your back. Already wet and a little cold with itches all over from imaginary mosquitoes... I was not impressed! After the tour was a buffet. It was quite a good spread considering our rustic surroundings. It was quite spicy
column3: but then we were on a spice farm! We were also given a shot of Fenny
column4: the local coconut spirit to try. It was rancid! We picked bananas straight from the stem which were the tastiest bananas ever
column5: by this point we were feeling a little stung that we hadn't seen any elephants
column6: that was after all what we came for! We asked at reception and they told us we had to get our driver to take us round the back of the farm
column7: we did and pulled up at the

column1: dodgiest looking set up. There were three elephants stood half asleep. The big male had his tusks tipped to remove the sharp ends. The other two
column2: a female and a juvenile were next to him
column3: all had a chain around one foot but freedom to move. There was a price list to one side with bathe
column4: ride or feed and that was pretty much it! We went for bathe then followed the elephant and its trainer through someone‚Äôs back garden and into the spice farm.

column1: She settled in some murky water and we were given coconut shells and told to go in and scratch her with them. She lay on her side with her head fully submerged and only the end of her trunk showing. We scrubbed her back
column2: her head and then down her trunk. The trainer got us to put our hands over her trunk whilst she blew air. It is so powerful! She had the most beautiful intelligent eyes with massive dark eyelashes. I fell in love with her immediately! We gave her some space whilst she sat up and then were told to climb up her back leg and sit on her back. I felt
she was so huge! But she was also really laid back! We sat there whilst here trainer shouted to her to spray us with water. We got absolutely drenched through. She was also able to predict him
column3: filling her trunk before she was asked. When we got down it was Rick and Amanda turn and then we left. As we dried off she stood up and started grazing the trees and spraying water on herself. The trainer was helping her wash and scratching her face
column4: they obviously had a very strong bond which was reassuring to see. It had been by far the best experience with a wild animal I have ever had. It was natural and she got as much enjoyment from the interaction as we did. I would go as far as to say it was my highlight so far.

column1: After a well needed shower we were out again this time we were having a look at the beach. The weather had managed to clear up but down at the beach it became evident it was going to rain again. The beach was absolutely full of locals. It looked like the prime
meeting point. It was like a where's wally for tourists
column2: in fact all the beach sellers made a beeline for us!

column1: It had began to rain and we had spotted some of our group sat in one of the beach bars
column2: we quickly joined them and ordered a beer off the waiter who clearly wasn't on this planet. We began taking in our surroundings
column3: Bob Marley and Jimi Hendrix posters adorned the wall
column4: the ""DJ"" was playing every song by Pittbull ever made... Repeatedly and it was frequented by young Indian men. If we had any doubts as to the not so hidden agenda of the bar
column5: these were quickly forgotten when the shifty eyed waiter offered Rick a shisha and then feigned offense when he asked for no drugs. Since Planty was out of clean clothes and the ones we had sent to be laundered wouldn't be returned until the next morning I offered to go and buy him a top for the evening. This was met with much enthusiasm by the other girls and we made a swift exit. We didn't have much time to browse as we had evening plans and I quickly chose a striped

column1: polo t-shirt for ¬£2.50. We estimated how long it would take the boys to finish their beers and timed it just right so we didn't have to sit back down. I was greeted by an excited Planty ""the man with the BBQ has a baby shark can you take a picture of me with it please"" he proclaimed in one breath
column2: I tried to argue the ethics of taking an animal out of the gene pool before it has chance to breed
column3: but before I knew it I was stood taking a picture of him with a dead shark and then listened to him moan about how his hands stunk of fish all the way home and tried to get everyone to smell them! After the quickest change known to (wo)man we were out for our final group dinner. I couldn't believe that was our last one. However we definitely went out with a bang! They brought out the fresh catch and we didn't pay much attention to it. Planty typically opted for the most expensive thing on the menu
column4: I chose a kingfish steak on the basis that I don't eat fish very much but being in Goa I

column1: should and I know I like tuna and swordfish steaks. Mine was nice
column2: but Plantys was amazing! On the recommendation of the waiter he had abandoned his fish and prawn concoction and gone for the tandoori red snapper
column3: part of the fresh catch. I'm sure he will fill you in on the details
column4: however I must say I helped him eat it! I had some amazing chocolate creation for dessert. During the meal we had passed round an envelope to give Shaz a parting gift. He went out for a cigarette and we all followed. Planty being the master of spouting rubbish spontaneously gave a speech about how wonderful Shaz had been that had people in tears. I was very proud!

column2: Planty who had over indulged slightly needed to go back to the hotel. We got a taxi which proved to be the slowest journey ever. It seems Friday night is party night in Goa and everywhere was packed. It was a relief to return to our less than pleasant hotel!

column1: The plan for the next day was to check out hire mopeds to check out the other beaches north Goa has to offer.
Mopeds are the mode of transport in Goa
column2: and in India over the last two weeks we had many feats involving mopeds carrying different things including whole Indian families including mother holding tiny baby
column3: goats
column4: chickens and panes of glass. Also we had seen school kids zipping around on them... How hard could it be? We paid our ¬£2.50 for a days hire and set off. Our first incident occurred when we were going down a dirt track. I felt Planty tense and his legs went out to stop
column5: I think he misjudged how to turn. This shook me and the next turn I completely panicked making him have to slam on again
column6: he shouted at me and when we met up with the others at breakfast
column7: both times were my fault! I sulked for most of breakfast
column8: partly because I could not stop shaking and I had been portrayed as a wimp and partly because it had begun to rain.. HARD. There was no way I was getting back on that thing in the rain. We toyed with our options
column9: go shopping (my suggestion) go to the beach anyway because were only going to get wet (Plantys) and the

column1: one that eventually won- take the moped back and just go to our next place. We said goodbye to our group
column2: perhaps not as emotional as it could have been as I was preoccupied about getting back on the death-trap
column3: I don't think either of us enjoyed the journey back to the hotel and its safe to say mopeds were not my favourite mode of transport whilst in India
column4: but we tried it! We managed to leave the hotel pretty much straight away
column5: we were reliant on Shaz one last time to sort our taxi and we parted with him telling us if we need anything whilst in India or if we ever return to not hesitate to call
column6: but soon after the realisation that we were once again on our own hit us. Its not that we don't enjoy each others company
column7: its just a lot more daunting when there is two of you. We had become so dependant on Shaz and there is no way we could have done India without him
column8: well we could but I would have been a nervous wreck by the end of it! It was so good to just immerse ourselves in India

column1: and not have to worry about the logistics. Being alone I was back playing the responsible one and I had enjoyed not having to. About hour and a half later we reached our second hotel. We had debated whether to keep our booking for the south Goan hotel as we only had one night there and were leaving early next morning. We had been told it was hours away and we had really concluded it wasn't worth it! However it wasn't that far
column2: if we hadn't had the worlds slowest taxi driver and got lost the journey would have been minimal
column3: however it felt like we were in a completely different country! The hotel was beautiful! There was complimentary drinks
column4: toiletries and you could see all the way to the bottom of the pool! The bathroom had a separate shower cubical and you didn't have to walk through it to get to the toilet! We dragged ourselves out of our luxurious room and down a palm tree lined path to the beach. The long white sandy beach was desolate. There were lifeguards and a few local fishermen but you could lie here forever. The sun was shining and the stark

column1: contrast to north Goa was overwhelming. We relished the peace and quiet and just strolled up the beach
column2: enjoying the moment. The only hassle we encountered were a couple of older ladies who were selling jewellery but seemed a little more interested in us then anything. Everyone seemed friendly here. The life guards said hi as you walk past
column3: people stared but it was with curiosity whereas in north Goa it had felt slimy and intimidating. We stopped at a beach bar
column4: the menu stated the salad was washed with mineral water so I had a Caesar salad
column5: Planty was on the beer but my new favourite drink was fresh lime soda
column6: basically for 40p you get a lime and soda made with fresh lime not cordial
column7: massively refreshing sat in the sun! Every fruit juice is made fresh in India. You order pineapple juice
column8: its a pineapple in a blender
column9: watermelon juice
column10: orange and so on! All for the price of a beer which is cheap anyway! We sat in the bar
column11: looking out onto the beach talking about how much the rest of our group would love it. It was so strange
column12: 15 days ago we had met

column1: as complete strangers but now it was strange to be apart. We had spent every waking moment with them and it was strangely quiet
column2: and come to think of it conversation was abnormally tame! Walking back we met a bouncy mongrel who evidently wanted to play
column3: she play bowed and wagged and barked then ran off into the sea and back again
column4: the game quickly became Planty kicking water at her and her running off into the sea and then back for more. Soon she stopped and watched us as we continued to walk. It must have been a territory line. Its been hard not touching the dogs here
column5: we are both so soft over them
column6: and she was the worst. we just wanted to take her home! Back at the hotel there was time for a quick dip in the pool before dinner. Dinner was again good food but I think Plantys red snapper was still to fresh in his mind for him to properly enjoy it!

column1: When my alarm went off at 4.30 the next morning I thought it was a joke! Instead of going back to sleep I sat and thought about why it was going

column2: which was lucky because we were catching a flight to Chennai that morning! Our hotel arranged a taxi and we made it to the airport in around 30 mins. We were flying air India
column3: our flight to Goa had been with spice jet so we had slightly higher expectations for air India
column4: even the terminal put a stop to that! It wouldn't have looked out of place in a museum
column5: ""exhibit a is a replica of the first passenger airport
column6: as you can see nothing was electronic
column7: even the numbers on the check-in desks had to be changed by hand""... You get the idea! The plane was carpeted and patterned with an orange-brown- red design and we were sat behind the worlds worst group of idiots! I remember on one of the flights browsing the in-flight magazine and reading an article about the 10 worst ways to irritate your fellow passengers
column8: these ticked all the boxes! They asked for extra food after it had been brought round
column9: midered the flight attendants for coffee and their seats were back from the moment the cabin crew had finished making their take off checks until even after we landed.

column1: Putting the seat back irritates me
column2: I can't help it. If they ask politely I can tolerate
column3: however if they just throw it back
column4: put their hands above their head and get in my personal space I get annoyed
column5: especially when you have leg room fit for a toddler! He didn't even get the hint of a few well placed kicks
column6: or the fact that we were not quiet in our criticisms of him
column7: when the one in front of Planty followed suit I thought Planty might burst! Finally when we had landed he did
column8: as I was trying to grab our belongings from the floor
column9: he proceeded to dramatically throw his chair back and then push it when he found it wouldn't go any further because it was meeting my head! He seemed surprised when Planty objected to his girlfriend having a seat bashed across her head... We both stared disapprovingly as we left the aircraft!

column1: we decided on another prepaid government taxi service from the airport and for ¬£3.50 you can't really complain. We paid and them were quickly ushered towards a taxi
column2: it was the same black and yellow monstrosity from Delhi... Come back to haunt

column1: us! However this one didn't smell of goat
column2: it just had a lovely brown floral pattern on the floor
column3: ceiling
column4: doors
column5: seats... Every surface in the cab in fact was floral! From the rear-view mirror hung an elaborate mix of tassels and key rings with Ganesh on them and a display of dead flowers and more statues of the elephant god covered his dashboard. The guy who's job it was to allocate taxis pestered for a tip
column6: we refused saying we had no money
column7: because we found him rude bur then ensured we tipped our taxi driver double (the look on his face said he knew our game) our arrival at the hotel was bizarre. We had booked five star because it was cheap and I thought it would be good to go from Dubai to basic backpacker accommodation to luxury
column8: and ok I may have been sold by the pretty staircase in the pictures
column9: but I wasn't expecting this! Before our taxi entered the premises a guard had a metal detector in the boot. We walked in the doors through the metal detector and were greeted by marble and chandeliers and good morning sir
column10: madam. We had bottles of

column1: water and cold towels handed to us

column4: but that's all I remember. We were seated overlooking Chennai
column5: I was slightly disappointed with Chennai if i'm honest

column7: whereas the big cities are a segregated into the mega rich and those struggling to survive!

column1: Anyway our meal was definitely a fitting goodbye to India
column2: just when you think you're safe and nothing completely bizarre can happen
column3: it does! Our waiter drove me mental
column4: he needed permission from us to breathe! I know he must have been trained in that manner but seriously! He

column1: brought drinks over ‚Äúcan I open it‚Äù we finished a drink ‚Äúcan I clear‚Äù the same applied to when we finished eating
column2: we asked for the bill ‚Äúshall I get you the bill sir‚Äù he was exhausting! Also if you had a sip of water he was straight over pouring more into your glass
column3: he just hovered for the whole meal! We ordered starters and mains
column4: what we should have ordered was just a main and noodles or rice! Both the starter and main were exactly the same size and consistency
column5: just different meats and sauces and my starter came with Plantys main and the waiter was spooning bits of it onto our plates
column6: insisting we share dishes. Planty had prawns and mushrooms
column7: two things I hate! Afterwards we went into the hotel bar and had a beer. This was the first place I had seen kingfisher on draft. These too gave us more snacks. They will literally have to roll me through customs if I eat any more. My plan for India was to get ill and lose loads of weight
column8: in fact I had begun to believe it inevitable
column9: everyone gets the dreaded ‚ÄúDelhi belly‚Äù don‚Äôt they? No

column2: I ate so well in India and I‚Äôve gained weight which was really surprising.

column1: The next morning we waved goodbye to this amazing country. Our hotel said bye with a complimentary box of south Indian sweets (an acquired taste). We had tried to book a taxi again but failed
column2: i'm sure Planty will go into the colourful detail so ended up travelling to the airport in a hotel car with ‚Äúaccord metropolitan‚Äù splashed up the side. We definitely began our trip to Sri Lanka in style

column1: Shaz's favourite motto was ‚Äúembrace the bizarre‚Äù and with India I certainly felt we embraced
column2: squeezed and extracted every ounce of bizarre they had to offer! Every new town was a different level of strange and no two days were even remotely the same. India took us out of our comfort zones and really showed what we are capable of. I don't ever think my comfort zone will shrink back to what it was and I think I‚Äôve learnt a lot about valuing experiences over possessions. I've really struggled to describe India

It's International Day of the Girl-Child!
For those of you who do not know
column2: today (Thursday
column3: October 11
column5: is the first International Day of the Girl-Child. This is an UN-sanctioned holiday
column6: celebrating the importance of educating young women throughout the world. If you are in the United States
column7: odds are that you haven‚Äôt heard about it
column8: or
column9: if you have
column10: it was in passing and had no major impact on your daily life. At Shanti Bhavan
column11: however
column12: we (volunteers
column13: teachers
column14: and male and female students) have been preparing for weeks to put together a celebration worthy of TV.

column2: SB has partnered up with Intel (yes
column3: THAT Intel)
column4: who wanted to show its support for girls‚Äô education in India. Therefore
column5: they have helped us prepare a big shindig
column6: with speeches and entrepreneurship classes for the older girls and the presentation of a new song (written by the lovely Lizzy to the tune of ‚ÄúLean on Me‚Äù) sung by the girls in the choir. They even allowed my eleventh graders some time to present art projects inspired by the idea of ‚Äúeducation for all.‚Äù These events are going to be videotaped
column7: and then eventually (according to my

column1: understanding) be used for Intel promotions. I am quite excited to be part of this celebration
column2: because I feel that it recognizes a deep need in society
column3: and while in India
column4: I have seen evidence of the gender disparities.

column1: I write this entry with some level of wariness
column2: as I don‚Äôt want to be that traveler who draws drastic
column3: ignorant conclusions based on some choice encounters. You should be aware
column4: therefore
column5: that the information I write here is based on a month‚Äôs exposure to the Indian culture
column6: and is therefore not nearly as nuanced as it could eventually be. I feel compelled
column7: though
column8: to bring out certain observations (both my own and other volunteers‚Äô) regarding gender relations in India. I do this because SB is unusual in its dedication to education for everyone
column9: and at times even its students struggle with gender equality because of the gender expectations of the society.

column2: I‚Äôd like to point out that
column3: as a white woman
column4: I am an outlier. Depending on the situation
column5: I am treated both ‚Äúas a woman‚Äù and ‚Äúas a man.‚Äù For instance
column6: when riding on public transportation
column7: Indian women ideally sit next to a relation

column1: Babu working on his group's sculpture: ""The Statue of Liberty.""
or another woman. When given the option between seating a white woman or an Indian woman next to a man
column2: the bus official will always choose the white woman (because then the Indian woman can sit next to her). However
column3: whenever possible
column4: the bus officials will seat white women next to other women (or white people). I have also noticed this when people would stop us to take pictures with us. One man
column5: who wanted to take a picture of Peter and me with his wife and son
column6: insisted that the wife stand next to me instead of the son
column7: but some younger folks don‚Äôt take those precautions.

column1: As I mentioned before in ‚ÄúHumming in Hampi
column2: ‚Äù there was a distinct lack of women celebrating at the Ganesha Immersion procession. What I didn‚Äôt mention before was their eyes. They were gathered together at Virupaksha Temple
column3: watching the festivities from behind a fence (not built for this purpose
column4: mind you
column5: but a barrier all the same) with a haunting darkness in their expressions. In my English classes
column6: we read a poem called ‚ÄúAn Old Woman‚Äù by Arun Kolatkar that has the lines: ‚ÄúYou look right at the sky./ Clear through the

column1: The sculpture's right half is uneducated (carries a dustbin and a frown); the left half is educated (carries a book and a smile).

bullet holes/ she has for her eyes.‚Äù And that‚Äôs the sort of thing I saw in their gazes. It made me feel like a traitor or a schoolyard bully‚Äîthat I was taunting them with my privilege to dance. In retrospect
column2: I wish I had stood next to them
column3: talked to them
column4: instead of giving in to my rhythmic (or
column5: rather
column6: arrhythmic) impulses. I can‚Äôt help but wonder what they were thinking
column7: seeing all of these foreign women participate in their ancient celebration
column8: when they themselves cannot?

column2: one of my coworkers
column3: spent the week off in Kerala
column4: and she went through several rural villages
column5: visiting friends and their relatives. One of these friends even agreed to bring together a group of men from the village to answer her questions. She asked things about their lifestyle
column6: about their quality of life
column7: and about the infrastructure of the area. At some point
column8: she got onto the topic of alcohol
column9: and the men started talking about how they worked all day and would often go drink in order to decompress. Stephanie
column10: who knew that rural women are not allowed to do this
column11: asked
column12: ‚ÄúWhat about the women? They work hard

column2: too. Don‚Äôt they deserve the same thing?‚Äù The men responded by saying that that wasn‚Äôt what a woman should be doing. Then Stephanie started asking about gender
column3: and the men became uncomfortable
column4: saying that they had to focus on fixing the caste system before they could fix gender relations. Then
column5: when asked what would happen in women ruled the world
column6: the men‚Äôs response was very telling
column7: ‚ÄúThe women would punish us for what we‚Äôve done to them.‚Äù

column1: One thing that may strike a person in rural India is that women always seem to be ‚Äúdressed up
column2: ‚Äù even when they‚Äôre working in the field. They wear their colorful
column3: beautiful saris and gold nose piercings and earrings and necklaces. To the American eye
column4: it seems strange
column5: but upon further thought
column6: I realized that they were wearing their wealth. Many rural folks do not have access to banks
column7: and the gold would not be safe in a poor Indian home (if there is a structure at all‚ÄîI cannot tell you how many tarp-homes I have seen along the sidewalks in the city). So
column8: they wear what they own
column9: and
column10: in effect
column11: are forced to display what they are

column1: I have noticed that a woman‚Äôs appearance in India is highly valued. As in the United States
column2: ads are inundated with products meant to improve women‚Äôs looks. You have the usual shampoos and creams and what have you
column3: but you also have things like skin whitener
column4: which really gets under my skin (excuse the pun). I know that this is also a product in the United States
column5: and I am equally disgusted by it
column6: no matter where it is. Watching movies in India
column7: I am struck by how many of the popular male actors are darker than the female actors. Looking at the mixture of faces at SB
column8: I am struck by how beautiful all of the girls are
column9: and yet how some of them are going to go into the world and be considered less beautiful because they were born with darker skin. That is a problem that the boys will never have to face.

column1: I can see evidence of these various forms of social oppression
column2: even at SB. The girls are often quieter
column3: and have less self-confidence than the boys. In one of the first papers I assigned‚Äî‚ÄúWhich character in Macbeth do you most admire?‚Äù‚ÄîI was amazed at how many girls said Lady Macbeth. They commented on her power
column4: ‚Äúeven‚Äù over a man
column5: and discussed how important it was for them to have ‚Äúcontrol.‚Äù In class
column6: conversations that would have been purely informational in the United States become jarringly real. For instance
column7: I was lecturing yesterday about Edgar Allan Poe
column8: and started (as I often do) with his life history
column9: including the information that he married his 13-year-old cousin when he was much older. There was a bit of a strange pause after I said that
column10: and then one of the boys asked
column11: ‚ÄúThey do that in the United States?‚Äù I assured him that they used to
column12: but it is very rare now. He paused
column13: then replied
column14: ‚ÄúThey do that in India
column15: you know.‚Äù

column1: How is a person supposed to respond to something like that?

column2: on International Day of the Girl-Child
column3: I am struck by how wonderful these students are
column4: and how lucky they are. This blog includes their art projects
column5: and a couple of their presentations
column6: in hopes that they can tell you about their experiences in their own words. There is hope for equality
column7: and this is just the beginning.

column1: It was an early winter morning. I was on a smoke break with my friend and colleague Ben. After a grueling night shift this smoke discussion had to be something interesting. I like this guy because his information and knowledge are quite authentic which is missing amongst most of my office colleagues. We were discussing about Pondicherry and the forgone French cultural surroundings. Suddenly
column2: I heard the name ‚ÄòTharangambadi‚Äô for the first time from Ben. He is a Christian guy and regularly pays visit to The Velankini Church. He said that Tharangambadi was between Chidambaram and Karaikal. I knew about these two places for their own cultural receptiveness however never heard of Tharangambadi before.

column1: I am no longer a young lad now
column2: almost crossed 35 years of my life. The more my ‚Äògrey hair‚Äô growing in numbers
column3: the more I am trying to become a ‚ÄòJack of all trades‚Äô. Thanks to the world of internet. After reaching home
column4: at least I had some food for thought. Upon researching
column5: found a lot of interesting details about Tharangambadi.

column1: Tharangambadi means the ""place of the singing waves"". It is a small village in Nagapattinam district
column2: 15 km from the Port Town
column3: Karaikal

column2: Danish East India Company formed their settlement here and named this place as ‚ÄòTranquebar‚Äô. A factory (commercial settlement) was opened and a fort
column3: known as Fort Dansborg
column4: was built by a Danish captain named Ove Gjedde. This fort was the residence and headquarters of the governor and other officials for about 150 years. It was a Danish colony from 1620 to 1845
column5: and in Danish it is still known as Trankebar.It was very interesting information indeed. I heard about other Danish Colonies in India
column6: like Port Blair and Sreerampore in West Bengal however Tharagambadi was rather unknown to me. Years passed by
column7: I was looking for a chance to visit this place. Finally
column8: when I decided to visit Thirunallar temple
column9: somehow I found Tharangambadi was closer by. But
column10: again the time was too tight to visit this place. Nevertheless
column11: as I decided
column12: so no way looking back.

column1: It was around 11 am and I was hovering around the bus stand of Kumbakonam. I was looking for a bus to Tharangambadi. After a few failed enquires; I found that it was either busses don‚Äôt ply from Kumbakonam to Tharangambadi or people here in
Kumbakonam were not aware of this place. I was really in a big disguise on what to do next. Suddenly
column2: there was a guy who came forward and rescued me from this hullaballoo. As per his suggestion
column3: I was supposed to take a bus to Mayiladuthurai from here and from there I would be getting plenty of buses to Tharangambadi. Without wasting any more time
column4: I boarded a bus which was ready to go to Mayiladuthurai. The ride from Kumbakonam to Mayiladuthurai was usually a ride through small villages and towns. It was 35 km and the bus took more than an hour to reach Mayiladuthurai. It was a small town and nothing much to describe. I looked at my watch
column5: it was 12:30pm and I knew that I didn‚Äôt have much time left. I checked with a few local folks but didn‚Äôt get a convincing answer about the buses to Tharangambadi. I waited for more than 45 minutes. I saw one bus arrived but before I could get my foot on that bus
column6: it was all filled up. The next bus didn‚Äôt show up in 30 minutes. It was 1:30 pm
column7: I was really tensed. Finally
column8: I just walked

column1: out of the bus stand and found a couple of taxis were parked outside. I fixed one of them for Rs. 700/-. The guy would drop me at Thirunallar via Tharangambadi. Mayiladuthurai to Tharangambadi was around 30km so it was not a tough deal. The guy‚Äôs name was Muthu
column2: seemed to be nice fellow. We started from Mayiladuthurai in next 10 minutes. The ride was just beautiful. Tall trees
column3: dark tar road with a lot of twisting turns and curves.

column1: We took no less than 45 minutes to reach Tranquebar. As mentioned earlier
column2: it was a small village with not many settlements around. We entered the Danish Colony after crossing a big gateway. Wow ! it was a different world. It seemed
column3: I was in some foreign country enriched with historical buildings. In next 5 minutes
column4: I was in front the Dansborg Fort which I have longed to see for years. It was a Sunday
column5: so as expected a few locals were enjoying the weekend evening. I paid Rs.5 for entry ticket and Rs. 30 for still camera.

column1: I walked in. Just next to the main entrance
column2: there was a small stone on the right which describes what

column1: Tranquebar was all about. This fort was constructed in 1620 though it had been reconstructed several times. The rampart wall is a fairly large four sided structure
column2: with bastions at each cardinal point. A single storied building was constructed along three inner sides of the rampart
column3: with barracks
column4: warehouse
column5: kitchen and jail. The rooms on the southern side remain in good condition
column6: but the rooms on the western and northern sides have been substantially damaged. On the eastern side of the fort
column7: there was a two storied building facing the sea. It was the main building of the fort. The vaulted lower storey served as a magazine and a warehouse
column8: while the vaulted upper storey contained the church and the lodging of the governor
column9: the senior merchants and the chaplain. The sea on the eastern and western side protected the fort. I decided to take stroll from left to right. This is actually a small fort. If you would expect an ‚ÄòAgra fort‚Äô or a ‚ÄòJunagadh fort‚Äô you would be surprised. This fort has a small museum which bestows a few mementos of the bygones. I found a small canon was placed overlooking the sea which seemed never been fired.

column1: It didn‚Äôt take more than 30 minutes for me to explore this fort but the fort had something which was dragging me to visit again and again. Locals claimed that during the devastating Tsunami in 2004 this fort had a close shave. I walked out and found a few fishermen were busy doing their daily business. A couple of colorful boats were sleeping at the shore. One Young Turk was watching me for sometime as I was clicking snaps. Upon asking
column2: he requested me to click one snap with his friends. His name was Ramu and he earns his living by catching fishes around the coast of Tharangambadi. I walked to the left side of the beach and found a small temple. I knew that this temple was partially damaged during Tsunami and had been reconstructed recently. I was clicking around and did notice one villager was offering his mid day prayer. His name was Chiniyan. I stroke up a small chat with him.

my grand father all of them were born here‚Äô

the god saved himself but didn‚Äôt save others. Nothing will be left. The daemon will swallow everything one day like my wife

column5: 000 people were washed away in this area during Tsunami
column6: 2004 but I never expected I would meet up someone who had seen his beloved flooded away.

why you should be sorry? Whatever

column1: I was desperately looking for a place to sit. His words had me moved far away from this place. It was really too difficult for me to digest his ‚Äòhard truths‚Äô. They believe in ‚Äòthe show must go on‚Äô life and have faith in this small ‚ÄòMasilamani Nathar‚Äô temple still. After spending another 30 minutes on that temple
column2: I decided to wrap my day for the day. I was not willing to click any further. I saw one lady was selling some snacks but unfortunately there was no one to buy. Her blunt look definitely told a story of struggle and survival. I was really feeling scared to talk to her. The people here lost everything what they weaved for years but nobody stopped dreaming. The fishing boats still venture early in the morning. The sun rises everyday showering the first ray of light. The Dansborg Fort stands still witnessing ‚ÄòThe singing waves‚Äô for past 300 years. Tranquebar was Captain Gjedde‚Äôs dream and would remain standing tall for years. Chiniyan walked into the horizon
column3: the snacks selling lady left home for the day but the fort stood still with a smile. Tharangambadi is really ‚ÄòThe

column1: town of the singing waves‚Äô but there‚Äôs no one to listen. All the listeners are sleeping deep into the ocean.
Buses are not that frequent from Mayilladuthurai which is 30 km away but Karaikal
column2: which is just 15 km away is a better option. Taxis can be hired from both Karaikal and Mayliaduthurai. They run on ‚Äòto and fro‚Äô rates and rates are more than a fixed one with lesser chances to bargain.

column1: There are very less options to stay at Tharangambadi
1) ‚ÄòBungalow At The Beach‚Äô was an old Governor‚Äôs Bungalow which is about 4000/- @ night.
2) TTDC runs a small hotel @ 800/- for a double bed room.
3) ‚ÄòThe Gate House‚Äô is another Old Heritage Danish Bungalow which was converted into a hotel and would charge you around Rs 3000/- per night.

I decided to write this blog because I had the following conversation in my head:
Lynn
column3: you‚Äôve been at Shanti Bhavan for over a week. You‚Äôve surely fallen into a routine by now!

column2: gosh
column3: I guess I have.

column2: Lynn
column3: what is that routine?

column2: I‚Äôm sure glad you asked. Let me tell you‚Ä¶

column1: An average day at SB starts around 6:30 a.m.
column2: when the youngsters have PT (like PE). Three lucky volunteers get to encourage (/plead with/chase) the children around the PT field before doing stretches. Then they are basically free to do as they will until breakfast at 7:30. I‚Äôve been taken under the wing of the fourth and fifth grade girls
column3: who like to play games like ‚Äúlangori‚Äù (a game a bit like jenga with a pile of rocks that you try to knock down then rebuild) and ‚Äúchicken run‚Äù (a tagging game where the person who is ‚Äúit‚Äù hops on one leg). Earlier this week
column4: I fell while playing chicken run and scraped my knee and elbow for probably the first time since middle school. Feels a bit like a

column2: Mushy Rice
column3: Tea)

column2: breakfast is served in the open-air cafeteria. I often take a bath after PT and go to breakfast late. For the average American
column3: breakfast can seem overwhelming. Unless we‚Äôre having pancakes
column4: the food is rich with spices and ingredients (rice
column5: vegetables) that the volunteers automatically categorize as ‚Äúdinner.‚Äù But the masala chai tea served with breakfast
column6: tea
column7: and snack is wonderfully sweet and creamy
column8: with the same consistency as hot chocolate. I could live off of the stuff.

column1: After breakfast is the first three classes of the day. I have both of my main English classes at this time (1st and 3rd period). Depending on the day
column2: I will also have an additional period for these classes later in the day. My busiest day is Fridays when I teach for six of the eight class sessions.

column1: Afternoon tea and assembly follow. Assembly is always an adventure
column2: with a mish-mash of presentations and announcements. It always starts with a universalist prayer
column3: followed by a small skit performed by the 3rd-5th graders. These skits are my daily dose of cute
column4: as they are meant to teach the nuances of the value of the week.

column2: and had some winning moments such as when one little boy explained that we can compromise when we play
column3: so ‚Äúdon‚Äôt worry
column4: be happy.‚Äù Assembly also includes a group of older students giving ‚Äúthe news for today
column5: ‚Äù which includes local
column6: international
column7: science
column8: and business news. After the news
column9: questions
column10: and announcements
column11: Vice Principal Miss Beena rises and says
column12: ‚ÄúGood morning
column13: ‚Äù to which the whole school replies
column14: ‚ÄúGood morning
column15: Miss Beena.‚Äù Needless to say
column16: the whole affair is very formal.

column2: we have two more class periods
column3: then lunch. Followed by three more class periods. After I finish that (around 3:35 p.m.)
column4: I have until 6:00 p.m. to do as I please. My mission today? LAUNDRY! But wait a second
column5: world! This isn‚Äôt just any ordinary laundry. This is hand-washed
column6: hang-dried
column7: electricity‚Äôs out in the building laundry! In other words
column8: I won‚Äôt know how clean my clothes are until later. Electricity outages are frequent‚Äîyou can expect it to go on and off at least three times every 24 hours. We use the electricity for so little here: lights
column9: charging computers
column10: and ceiling fans
column11: but when it‚Äôs dark
column12: or your computer is out of juice

column1: or the weather is unseasonably hot (as it has been here in the past couple of days
column2: with little rain or air-movement)
column3: you become acutely aware of how much you depend on electricity to make your life comfortable. Even right now
column4: I‚Äôm racing against the clock because my computer is nearly dead and there‚Äôs no telling when the power is going to surge back to life.

column2: I have to supervise prep
column3: which is basically study hall. Then off to supper
column4: then off to a fifteen-minute story-time with an assigned grade. This week I was given the fourth graders
column5: which is a rowdy but loveable group. They are fascinated by the snake-light I use each night
column6: and ask me about my clothes or my jewelry or my education. Today one noticed a picture of my cat
column7: Cleopatra
column8: attached to my backpack
column9: and asked me about her. They also act as if they‚Äôre really picky about the books read to them
column10: but today I brought along Millions of Cats (Millions and billions and trillions of cats) and Are You My Mother? and they were totally into it.

column2: after all of
I get an opportunity to write to you
column3: and show you pictures
column4: and check my email (some habits die hard). This next week is a break
column5: so I will be traveling a bit and I hope to have lots of fun stories to share by the end of the week! Take care
column6: and happy Friday!

column2: Ally
column3: and Stephanie on our way to Hosur (via rickshaw)

column1: Today was my first excursion day into India! Ally (my roommate)
column2: Stephanie (co-worker)
column3: and I traveled by auto-rickshaw to the small city of Hosur. Most of the drive was beautiful
column4: with vast landscapes and a sunny day. People were walking by with their goats
column5: cows
column6: and donkeys
column7: and people were sitting on their stoops doing chores. I spent most of the ride trying to catch images that would have been gorgeous if I knew when to press the button on my camera while we rushed by the subject of interest.

column1: When we arrived in the city
column2: though
column3: my senses were rattled by the noise--in India
column4: you use your carhorn to communicate every possible message
column5: from ""Get out of the way"" to ""I'm passing you"" to ""How you doin'?"" to ""I'm coming around this blind corner!"" And in a city with traffic
column6: I cannot understand how anyone knows who is honking at who. It's a panic attack waiting to happen.

column2: we started at this lovely restaurant called Janani. It turns out that Stephanie is quite the linguistic socialite
column3: and she quickly endeared herself with the waitstaff by practicing her Tamil and asking for phrases. They actually approached

column1: us to ask if they could take a picture with us with their phones. This was my first experience of ""celebrity"" as Stephanie called it. In general
column2: it did sort of feel that way. The waitstaff were very excited to have Americans in their restaurant
column3: and some children would speak to us in English and smile. But
column4: then again
column5: some people stared
column6: some took pictures
column7: some scowled. I'd argue that it wasn't ""celebrity"" as much as just plain ""otherness.""

column2: our rickshaw driver took us clothes shopping
column3: and we bought several very cheap kurtas (tunics
column4: 100 rupees ($2) each) at a street vendor before moving onto a bigger store that sold full outfits. Sadly
column5: I had little success at the bigger store because the ensemble that I had my heart set on was only made in size 2XL and could not be tailored for me. But I will have plenty of opportunities to search for a new favorite
column6: so I figure I'm in no hurry.

column1: When I'm in street-walking mode abroad
column2: I tend to avoid eye contact and look stern
column3: as if I know exactly what I'm doing. Because of this
column4: I wasn't as aware of our

column1: celebrity"" as my friends. It was impossible to ignore the fact that we were of interest
column2: though
column3: when a beggar woman grabbed my sleeve tightly and tried to keep me from going to the rickshaw. I hate to think about how harshly I had to pull away from her
column4: and how loudly I had to say
column5: ""No!"" I had been warned that beggars could be aggressive
column6: but I was shocked by how desperately she clung to me. The problem is
column7: if you give something to one beggar
column8: you are swarmed--Stephanie had experienced this in the past the hard way. But I can't help but wonder if I maybe should have given her the coconut water I had just bought at a grocery store.

column1: I again tried to take a lot more pictures on the way back to SB
column2: with some success. And about 5 minutes from SB it began to rain. It came in the open sides of the rickshaw
column3: so by the time we reached the gates
column4: all four of us (including the driver) were yelling and laughing
column5: which was a wonderfully refreshing way to end the trip.

where I live

column1: Although I love to keep people's anticipation high
column2: I feel that it's about time I introduced you all to Shanti Bhavan. After all
column3: as of 3:30 a.m. tomorrow morning
column4: I will have been at Shanti Bhavan for 48 hours!

column1: First impressions are hard to express because there are so many battling for the page right now. So
column2: some quick basics (Minnesota-style
column3: if you will):

column1: The weather here is very pleasant
column2: and very dry. It's supposed to be monsoon season
column3: but I have yet to see a drop
column4: and other volunteers who have been here longer said it has been a while. But the temperature is comfortable day and night
column5: and I am indoors for most of the day
column6: so no sunburn yet!

column1: The food is suiting me well so far. A couple of things have caught me off-guard
column2: but in general it is not very spicy at all. For right now
column3: at least
column4: I enjoy all of the rice!

column2: bugs are not that bad at all. The worst part is the gnats
column3: which tend to hover at the periphery of your vision when you're trying to talk to someone. Oh
column4: and then there's that spider who

column1: decided to hang out in my bathroom (no worries
column2: I caught it in true spider-tarian (like humanitarian
column3: right?) fashion).

column1: I have been placed with the 11th and 12th grade English classes
column2: which is very exciting for me. The students are responsive and thoughtful. I have one student who
column3: after initially asking me point-blank how ""The Red Wheelbarrow"" by good old William Carlos Williams could be any good
column4: decided that it was a representation of the sun. Good stuff. I am also working with a very small elective literature course which has proven a bit more of a challenge for me--Those students have to study the poetry of this Hopkins guy that I've never heard of and whose poetry (to me at least) seems bland. And doing poetry stuff one-on-two feels more like grilling than teaching. Any good pointers on how to make analyzing poetry fun for two students
column5: please send it my way!

column2: now for a general idea of how my life has gone since my airplane ride:

column1: I arrived at the Bangalore airport at 12:30 a.m. on Sept 12. I got through customs and everything pretty easily. And
column2: after some initial searching among the hundred

column1: or so cabbies waiting for jet-lagged customers
column2: I found mine
column3: who was a pleasant man maybe in his early thirties. We made some small talk during the 2 hour drive
column4: but I generally just watched the city/landscape. We went through some pretty dingy-looking places
column5: and I could not tell you how many stray dogs were almost ran over by my taxi
column6: but I made it safely to Shanti Bhavan and was immediately swept up to my room where my roommate
column7: Ally
column8: was fast asleep.

column1: These past two days have been a bit of a whirlwind. I didn't experience any jetlag
column2: thank goodness. I can't imagine how I would have functioned if I had! I was told my class assignments
column3: and immediately brought up to introduce myself to my classes. Apparently
column4: the students I'm teaching have been missing an English teacher for a little while now
column5: and they just spend the hour in their homeroom when no teacher is there for them. So I introduced myself
column6: got their names
column7: and asked them what they were studying. Both groups are studying the same material--In 12th grade
column8: Indian students are expected to take a large test called the Indian School Certificate (ISC)

column1: and both grades are working toward that eventual test. What this means
column2: however
column3: is that the 12th-graders are reading the exact same material they read last year. Luckily
column4: I have been given permission to supplement with other pieces so that they don't get bored out of ther minds.

column1: I have been told that I will soon take over the choir
column2: and probably work on presentational skills with students once I get settled in. I'm looking forward to working with all ages
column3: and to getting to share the arts.

column1: The students here are very talkative and bubbly
column2: and they are very curious. One of the questions I am asked a lot is if I have any siblings
column3: and after that what are my family's birthdays! They have a very structured day
column4: with PT (equivalent to PE) at 6:30 a.m. and classes from 8:30-3:35. Of course
column5: in between there is tea
column6: then assembly
column7: then lunch
column8: and immediately after classes is snack. And then more PT time. And shower time. And then prep
column9: which is basically study hall. Then Supper
column10: and right back to prep (for the older ones) until 9:30 p.m. I can't imagine having that structured of a day

column1: every day except Sunday. But I guess that's just the college in me talking--I'm not used to being told where to go all the time anymore.

column2: this is a beautiful place
column3: with lots of energy and life to it. I hope to take some pictures of the kids (or let the kids take some pictures--they LOVE to do that) tomorrow
column4: but Friday is also my busiest class day
column5: so no promises. In any case
column6: Ally and I (and possibly other volunteers) are planning on going to Hosur this weekend. It is about 30 minutes away and seems to be a pretty nice place from what I hear. I'm hoping to come out with some traditional long tops
column7: as I always feel so frumpy when I stand next to the Indian teachers. Looking forward to it!

column2: off to lesson planning (and making poetry fun)!

Cet homme est franchement extraordinaire. Lui parler nous amene deja a etre beaucoup plus conscient de qui nous sommes vraiment et surtout A SE PRENDRE BEAUCOUP MOINS AU SERIEUX (je mets les majuscules surtout pour moi-meme üòâ) Il me parle des ecureils
