column1: India must have more adverts per square mile than any other country in the world
column2: certainly more than any country I have visited anyway. Indian towns are filled to the brim (and often well over the brim) with a sensory overloading array of billboards
column3: posters and signs
column4: you will often even find advertising painted on the side of peoples homes. Every centimetre of space seems to have been claimed by advertising
column5: nothing but nothing is sacred. One of the things that has most surprised me is the amount of advertising that is dedicated to cement. Cement is perhaps the most heavily marketed product in India
column6: I would even hazard a guess that there are more adverts for cement than there are for mobile phones
column7: Bollywood films and soft drinks combined. There are countless cement brands and you will find adverts for them in every town
column8: village
column9: wall in the middle of nowhere and also continuously on radio and TV. I have even noticed a few programs on Indian television are sponsored by cement manufacturers! This plethora of cement advertising struck me as strange initially but I guess it‚Äôs not that strange when you consider that India is a country which is

column1: This is a photo from google and not my own
column2: I forgot to take photos here!

column1: advancing/growing rapidly and a country where most construction is generally done by the property owners i.e families build their own homes. The only type of advertising that is more numerous than cement advertising is political advertising
column2: which is so abundant in quantity it is both disturbing and laughable. You literally cannot drive more than 20 metres in any town big or small without seeing some form of political advert
column3: often the same one you saw a few metres down the road. The sight of a (usually ugly) politicians giant face looking down at you can feel a bit Big Brother-esque at times
column4: surely advertising in such quantities is not only a wasteful use of resources but also bordering on propaganda. I‚Äôm sure Goebbels would approve.

column1: Sorry got a bit side tracked there
column2: back to the case in hand.

column1: Pondicherry was the governing and administrative centre for the handful of tiny colonies France used to control in India
column2: the town is now famous for its Gallic influence which is visible in the towns design
column3: it‚Äôs architecture and customs. Despite not belonging to France these days
column4: (control was relinquished in 1954
column5: Rough Guide
column6: 2011) the French still keep a high

column1: As you can tell by my minimal and rubbish photos there was not much to see in Pondicherry!
commission here as well as various government buildings connected to for example trade. It all feels a bit like the French are trying desperately to hold on to some remnants of past glory
column2: but now have nothing more than the tips of their fingers on the prize. Give it a rest France
column3: the days of empire are long gone.

column2: if not a little dull town. The first few blocks by the seafront contain some nice looking French colonial style buildings and the streets in this section are noticeably less chaotic and chocked with traffic than the blocks that follow behind (which are just like any Indian town i.e complete madness). There is little to do in Pondicherry but it is a pleasant enough place to wander for a few hours. We were all however very excited about the opportunity to eat an actual beef steak
column3: beef is a very rare commodity in largely Hindu India but the French influence in Pondicherry means that cow is very much on the menu here. No I can thank the French for something other than Daft Punk! Peter and myself visited supposedly the best restaurant in town
column4: Le

column1: This is a photo from google and not my own
column2: I forgot to take photos here!
to try the towns ‚Äòlegendary‚Äô French cuisine. I had a sirloin steak with a blue cheese sauce
column3: I asked for my steak rare and it came out blue (how very French)
column4: fortunately I don‚Äôt mind my steak raw. The sauce was a little salty and thick but still worked well with the steak
column5: the fries that came with the steak were fantastic
column6: really fantastic in fact
column7: the side salad was limp and fairly pointless. Overall I enjoyed my meal but was a bit underwhelmed considering the restaurant was supposedly the best in town and the cost of the food here was dramatically higher than the other restaurants in town.

column1: Other than being famous for being a French enclave Pondicherry is also famous for the Auroville Ashram
column2: which is actually based 12km outside of town. The ashram is actually more like a commune where people from all over the world come to live life an ‚Äòalternative‚Äô self sustaining life style (and smoke lots of pot). I didn‚Äôt actually get the chance to visit Auroville as you have to book in advance which I didn‚Äôt realise beforehand
column3: it‚Äôs a real shame I couldn‚Äôt go as I‚Äôm sure it would have

column1: This is a photo from google and not my own
column2: I forgot to take photos here!

column1: been a fascinating experience. There are however signs of Auroville all over Pondicherry
column2: for example most of the people wondering the streets look like they are Auroville hardcore meditators (and Auroville hardcore pot smokers) and many of the hotels/hostels/shops in the city are owned by Auroville and staffed by Auroville devotees. I would love to visit an Ashram one day to see how I found it
column3: I suspect I wouldn‚Äôt get on with it very well and would probably get really bored but still I would like to give it a go one day.

column1: We left Pondicherry the following day and headed to our next destination Mamallapuram. Supposedly most people visit Mamallapuram to see its famous temples
column2: especially the shore temple which is built close to the sea and as such has been weathered and smoothed in a unique way by the salty sea air. For us cultural neanderthals however the main attraction was the beach
column3: restaurants with WIFI and for the girls (stereotypical but true) the touristy clothes
column4: jewellery and curios shops. The temple was ok
column5: but it was so hot when we visited that none of us wanted to spend much time there. The beach
column6: which I would describe as fairly average
column7: was littered with signs of the local fishing industry (boats
column8: nets etc) and was backed by scruffy palms
column9: grass and restaurants. While it was not the prettiest beach
column10: it was still a beach and we were pleased to be by the coast again
column11: especially as we had anticipated the beach in Mamallapuram would be an open human toilet rather than something usable. I started my day by indulging in a rather large Thali lunch which was pretty good but not outstanding
column12: I then spent the rest of my time exploring the town
column13: frolicking in the sea and even doing a little bit of shopping
column14: well trying to do shopping
column15: but in reality failing miserably. Apparently the traders of Mamallapuram only sell really awful Peter Panesque trousers in colours that would make even a blind man cry.

column1: The real big event for the group in Mamallapuram however was the farewell party we would hold in the evening for those that would sadly by leaving the tour tomorrow. Unfortunately it was not to be a night of good food or quick service for that matter either. Things started off badly when the waiter tried to sell us fresh fish at quadruple the rate we had paid in Varkala and at a price which would have even seemed a dear at home. In the end we didn‚Äôt buy any fresh fish as the waiter would not reduce the prices below a ludicrously inflated rate
column2: it was a foolish strategy on the restaurants behalf as we are a group of 20 and would have purchased a lot of fish if the price was right. Following this incident I was a little annoyed and apprehensive about what was to come but not to the point of serious concern
column3: at this point they still in mind had plenty of time to come good
column4: the food will probably be great I told myself. I decided I would order the seafood platter which at 450rps (5.50 gbp) was comparatively expensive but with a line up of grilled fish
column5: prawns and calamari served alongside vegetable fried rice I thought it would be worth the higher than usual outlay
column6: especially as tonight was a special occasion. After placing my order I went downstairs to give the parents a call using my newly acquired telephone credit. It was really great talking to Mum and Dad
column7: for various reasons it had been difficult to phone home prior to this point so it was really nice to finally be able to have a long chat and hear the news from home. After a 45 min chat to the parents I returned to the restaurant to find that no food and only a few drinks had been served
column8: half of us were still missing our beers
column9: how hard can it be to open a few beers? What on earth had they been doing for 45 mins? This was starting to become ridiculous and I was starting to get seriously hangry (hangry = when you get angry because you are so hungry
column10: thanks for this one Jenny). Apparently the restaurant had run out of cold beer despite Jenny (tour leader) warning them earlier in the day that 20 of us would be coming in and wanting plenty of drinks. I did eventually get a semi cold beer (I‚Äôm still not sure where it came from) and my seafood platter after well over an hour‚Äôs wait and after some people had already eaten their whole meal. When my plate arrived I felt close to tears
column11: what was this plate of misery and despair doing in front of my eager eyes
column12: surely this could not be mine? Very quickly my despair turned to anger
column13: I had hit boiling point and began to physically shake with rage. Never before has the gap between expectation and reality been starker
column14: I had been sold a deluxe BBQ fishy dream and had been served a diabolical monstrosity a sewer rat would steer clear of. On my plate were 3 badly burnt prawns that tasted of carbon and two pathetic and sad looking tiny fish which looked and smelt like they were probably already past their best in the Jurassic period. I did foolishly try a nibble of the fish and as expected it was truly rancid. My calamari and vegetable rice had obviously been so embarrassed by the state of the prawns and fish that they decided not to show up at all
column15: can‚Äôt say I blame them. I‚Äôm not a massive fan of complaining in restaurants and typically take the British view that it‚Äôs best to smile and pretend everything was great
column16: don‚Äôt want to cause a scene now do you. However occasionally something annoys me so much that I have no choice but to make a formal complaint
column17: tonight was justifiably one such occasion. I called the waiter over and pointed out the missing items (calamari and vegetable rice)
column18: the hideously black carbonised prawns and above all the dangerously gone off fish. In my most forceful and serious voice I told the waiter that I wouldn‚Äôt be paying for my meal and wouldn‚Äôt be having any of his funny business telling me otherwise. I did offer however to pay 100 RPS for the prawns as I had eaten them by this point
column19: they were disgusting but I was bloody hungry. The waiter of course didn‚Äôt agree at first but I wasn‚Äôt going to be overruled
column20: this food was not only terrible but also potentially dangerous. I can feel the rage building up inside me just remembering the experience! In the end they agreed to only charge 100 rps
column21: which was still too much really. I didn‚Äôt order anything else as I wasn‚Äôt convinced the kitchen could prepare it in less than 5 months and even then who knows what I would actually get
column22: maybe a putrefied rat curry? Sonia did however very kindly share her Chicken Tikka curry and rice with me so I did at least have something to line my stomach. Sounds like the night from hell right? Especially when you consider it wasn‚Äôt just me who had a bad food experience. However
column23: for some reason halfway through the night the beer
column24: wine and thus good times started flowing. One of the waiters bought round 2 bottles of just about drinkable local rum which he shared with us
column25: encouraging us all to do shots that were so large they made you gag a little. We had forgotten about the dreadful food and prior terrible service and were now very much having a great time. I have come across a few instances in India where an establishment is very much better at being a bar than a restaurant
column26: this was certainly one such case
column27: as was Rock and Roll in Varkala. So after a very unpromising start things dramatically improved and we all ended up having a really cracking night. It was in the end a fantastic farewell party for a fantastic group of people who really did deserve a good send off.

column1: It was a late night in the end
column2: some of us headed off to bed at the rather unsociable hour of 03.00am
column3: tomorrows early start would be a challenge. Maybe that last kingfisher strong wasn‚Äôt such a good idea........

column1: The drive from Mallaparum to Chennai was not a particularly long one
column2: but we had left early as the truck needed repair work done on it in a garage in Chennai and thus needed to get there as early as possible. This normally would have been fine
column3: but given that we were (most of us anyway) hideously hungover from the previous nights farewell party
column4: an early start was most unwelcome. Already this was starting to be a bad day. Today was always destined to be a sad/bad day however as it was leaving day for many great people whom I had come to know and love. Today we would be saying a sad farewell to the legends that are Sally
column5: Sarah
column6: Bill
column7: Carol
column8: Colin
column9: Marge and Luciana
column10: as well as my very good friends Peter (room buddy for 6 weeks) and Sonia. Upon arrival however my mood was picked considerably by news that Chennai had an American Dinner which served bacon and sausage for breakfast
column11: get me a tuk tuk immediately
column12: I‚Äôm there! It took around 10 mins to get us from the hotel to the dinner
column13: although this felt much longer with the heavy weight of anticipation hanging over us. After 10 torturous minutes we arrived
column14: upon arrival I jumped out of the tuk tuk and excitedly ran to the entrance of the dinner
column15: hooray it was bacon and sausage time! With great anticipation I went to open the entrance to the dinner only to then be confronted with the grey shutters of despair
column16: OH NO! The dinner was closed and the lack of human activity inside and out made it look like it wasn‚Äôt opening any time soon. Dejected and secretly very close to tears I/we decided we would come back later for dinner and head to KFC instead for breakfast (because you can‚Äôt beat 3 pieces of greasy fried chicken at 10.30am
column17: unless it‚Äôs 3 pieces of greasy bacon and sausage of course).

column1: I literally did nothing in Chennai
column2: I did not go to explore the sights
column3: I did not go to any museums
column4: I did not go shopping
column5: hell I didn‚Äôt even go for lunch. There is apparently little to see in Chennai (not that I could tell you if there was anyway) and to be honest after several days on the go and the previous nights heavy partying
column6: I was keen to have some time to just sit around
column7: sleep and indulge in some much needed slothfulness.

column1: At 17.00 it was time to say goodbye to my very good buddy Sonia
column2: it was an emotional farewell and we were all (myself in particular) sad to see her leave. Sonia I wish you the best of luck in your exam
column3: you are being missed. Shortly after Sonia‚Äôs departure it was time for our pre departure meeting with the new people who were joining in Chennai. I hate it when a leg finishes and a new one starts
column4: firstly and perhaps most obviously because you tend to lose people who have become really good friends
column5: in this instance two of my closest and some mighty fine others. Secondly though I hate it because you have to meet new people and I‚Äôm always scarred that the new people will be complete assholes and will hate me. I‚Äôm not really sure where this fear comes from as on each occasion the new group members have been really great and within 48 hours (or less with beer) we are getting on like old friends. However it is a problem that plagues me and I do find it a real shame that I tend to view the thought of meeting people I don‚Äôt know with negativity and dread
column6: which in itself is strange as I tend to get along with most people at least reasonably well. Anyway I‚Äôll save the psycho analysis for a professional when I have a break down in later life..... Peter made a poignant and valid observation saying that he felt sorry for the new people joining in Chennai as they would have to try and blend into a group of people who had known each other for up to 8 weeks (6 weeks in my case). That certainly put things into perspective and made me realise that my concerns and worries were not only trivial but also rather self indulgent. As it turns out (as it always does) the new people were great
column7: we had an English couple
column8: a solo female traveller from Norway
column9: a scots man (better not say British)
column10: a Australian gentleman and two English men join us. Once again I was the only bloke under 40 on the truck
column11: however I wasn‚Äôt to bothered by this as I had come to realise in recent weeks that being the only young male on a truck full of interesting and beautiful girls isn‚Äôt too bad at all <span>:-)

column1: After the pre departure meeting we met with the remaining people from the last leg and headed off for our final supper. Once again we headed towards Sparky‚Äôs American Dinner only this time we were really
column2: really hungry and really
column3: really looking forward to a burger. I won‚Äôt beat around the bush. Yes
column4: once again it was ******* closed. Oh great. As it turns out Sparky‚Äôs had been closed down for 2 weeks and would be closed for another 2 weeks for renovations. There were accusations made within the group that the tuk tuk drivers knew Sparky‚Äôs was closed but took us anyway so that they could make a fare. Whether this is true or not I cannot tell you
column5: I can tell you however that the tuk tuk drivers did make a double fare as upon finding Sparky‚Äôs was closed we headed straight back to a restaurant on the same road as our hotel
column6: make of that what you will. We did eventually get some food and very good it was too
column7: unfortunately we were all a little terse after the Sparky‚Äôs experience and perhaps also because our restaurant of choice did not sell beer. As such
column8: our farewell meal was not perhaps as jovial as well had all hoped
column9: still it was a great meal and it was nice to spend some time together before the inevitable sad goodbyes. My final goodbye of the day and perhaps the most poignant was to my ex room buddy Peter. We had become close over the past 6 weeks and formed a perhaps surprisingly close friendship
column10: something I‚Äôm sure neither of us would have anticipated on day one. For me it had been a real education learning that age does not necessarily have to define your personality and outlook on life. Peter is as sharp
column11: witty
column12: carefree and up for it as anyone I know of my own age and was often much more up for doing/trying things than the ‚Äòyounger‚Äô people on the tour. Peter I hope you are enjoying smoking your Cuban cigars at your free will and I hope plans for your summer of sailing are progressing well. I look forward to joining you in the Adriatic for a stint in 2013 if I don‚Äôt see you sooner.

column1: Its been a while since I last wrote but I've ben very very busy doing nothing at all.
After leaving Kovalam I popped up to Trivandrum which is only a few miles up the road to catch a flight to Chennai (Madras). Spent the night there but didn't really do alot except eat
column2: drink and sleep. Durring the day there was a huge march/demo on the main road outside the hotel. Not sure what it was all about but quite a few people were carring big pictures of uncle Joe Stallin

column1: Had an uneventfull flight from there up to Chennai but only passed through on my way an hour down the coast to Mamallapuram. I had planed on a few days there before moving on but I really liked it and am running out of steam a bit so stopped for ten days in the end. Its only a small place large village rather than a town and is famous for the five rathas (temples carved out of solid rock)
column2: rock carvings
column3: Krishna's

column1: butter ball and local rock carvers.

I'd seen most of the sites in the first few days so spent about a week just wandering around watching the carvers at work and lounging in the garden of the place I was staying reading and watching the resident troop of monkeys up to no good. Had to be carfull not to leave anything unattended or the next thing you know theres a monkey up a tree wearing your Y fronts on his head.
The only downside to the place was the constent power cuts. Its a big problem in tamil nadu so the torch i bought with me was worth its weight in gold.

After leaving mamallapuram it was a quick trip through Chennai again for the flight to Mumbai for the last few days before flying home. I had my name called over the tanoy at the airport as secruity weren't happy about something. Luckily they just wanted to search my hold luggage
column2: had visions of the old rubber glove and the inability to sit down for a week!!

column1: So thats it for another year will see some of you in a few days and will continue with the blog in December

column1: Weird temple at Southern tip - Looks like it was designed/inspired by Disney World
Today marked two important symbolic events. One
column2: we visited the Southernmost point in India
column3: yey! Two
column4: it was the halfway point for our trip
column5: boo! (well it was yesterday in truth but that ruins the symbolism of today). I should also note that this will be published well after the day in question
column6: so the date of publishing is not the same as the day referred to above.

column1: The Southern tip of India is a fairly unremarkable place
column2: much like Lands End is a fairly unremarkable place
column3: in fact I imagine many countries extremities despite being major tourist attractions are actually fairly unremarkable
column4: if not just plain boring. The Southern tip does have a few things going for it however. Firstly it is the Southern tip of India which is in itself an achievement. Secondly being the Southern tip it is surrounded by water which is handy because it is bloody hot
column5: even though it was technically ‚Äòwinter‚Äô when we visited
column6: it was still about 37 degrees. Thirdly Jenny (our TL) designated today a tuna sandwich lunch day
column7: yey! Now that may not sound very exciting to you
column8: but when you rarely get to eat a decent western style sandwich

column1: More cases of animal abuse in India
(with actual mayo!) then the thought and taste of some tinned tuna
column2: a bit of cheap mayo and some warm cucumber seems like a real luxury. It‚Äôs actually quite nice that you come to view things like a tuna sandwich (and a hot water shower) as a luxury
column3: it‚Äôs nice to appreciate and get excited about things that you would normally be so blas√© about.

column2: we dipped our feet into the water
column3: ate (devoured in my case) tuna sandwiches
column4: admired the odd statue of Tamil saint Thiruvalluvar that is built on an island just off the Southern Peninsula and shooed off an army of very persistent hawkers who were selling the crappiest looking fake pearl necklaces I have ever seen.

column1: We left the Southern tip around 14.00 and headed towards Madurai arriving around 17.30ish. For the past few weeks I had almost forgotten we were in India
column2: Kerala is a wealthy state with low levels of poverty and we had been staying in small touristy resorts which were somewhat disconnected from the day to day life of ordinary Indians. However
column3: Madurai (the second largest city in the state of Tamil Nadu) brought home

column1: Walkting towards the water at the Southern tip
with a bang that we were still very much in India. The experience was somewhat reminiscent to the initial culture (and noise) shock I received when arriving in Delhi. Madurai is over populated
column2: noisy
column3: smelly
column4: manic
column5: chaotic and did I mention really bloody noisy? But
column6: in a way it was nice be back in the chaos
column7: we had been sheltered for the past few weeks and it was to feel like we were travelling through real (whatever real means) India again. Upon arrival me and my soon to be ex room buddy (boo!) Peter went for a beer (he really is a bad influence!) at a cheap
column8: working mans drinking establishment. It was a pretty grim place but interesting in it‚Äôs grimness nonetheless. We were pretty sure drink would be cheap here given the owners obviously weren‚Äôt paying much for the upkeep of the premises
column9: or the upkeep of the refrigerators for that matter judging by the warmness of our beer. Sure enough when the waiter asked us for 150 RPS for two beers (about 2GBP) we felt very happy at the price. However upon receiving 150rps from us the cheeky bugger said ‚Äúno
column10: no it‚Äôs 450 rps‚Äù
column11: to which

column1: Cooling off at the Southern tip

we said ‚Äúno bloody way you cheeky ****‚Äù. Ok we didn‚Äôt actually say this but we certainly made it clear we would not pay 450 rps (about 5.50 GBP) for two beers. Beer ranges in price but typically you pay between 75-150rps (1-2 GBP) per beer
column2: this greedy **** was trying to charge us 225rps per beer which is more than we paid for beer in Indigo one of Mumbai‚Äôs best and most expensive restaurants. We refused to pay more than 150rps per beer (still too much really) and then left a little pissed off but ultimately more concerned about dinner
column3: lunch had been a long time ago and we were hungry.

column1: Tomorrow we would be visiting Madurai one of India‚Äôs oldest cities and indeed one of the oldest in South Asia (or so the Rough Guide claims)...........

column2: Displayed: 5

column1: View of Meenakshi Sundareswarar Temple approaching from a nearby street
I would like to start today‚Äôs entry with a little gloating
column2: never a good way to start I know. I‚Äôm sorry to start off in such a rude manner but I‚Äôm afraid it really must be done. I would like to let all of you in cold
column3: wet and windy Britain know that to this date it has only rained once since I arrived in India and I don‚Äôt believe we have had a single cloudy day. Yes your right
column4: I am a smug ****. The one time it did actually it did so at night so we didn‚Äôt even get wet
column5: no surprises for guessing where it rained
column6: my favourite Indian town ever (not)
column7: Cochin. Would be wouldn‚Äôt it. Anyway it‚Äôs pretty damn amazing that in over a month I haven‚Äôt seen a drop of rain or even anything but a blue cloudless sky
column8: thank you India. Commiserations to all of you at home.

column1: I was super tired waking up in Madurai
column2: maybe it was the long drive the day before
column3: maybe the 4 bottles of Kingfisher strong or maybe the post Varkala hangover finally kicking in. Whatever it was I was not the only person feeling it

column1: The west gate at Meenakshi Sundareswarar Temple

people appeared to be tired and in a foul mood. Not perfect conditions for what would be a long day with 3 temple viewings. Our long suffering but ever patient tour leader Jenny had a particularly torrid time in the morning by having to deal with an unusually uncooperative group before later getting her foot run over by a motorbike. I was very impressed that Jenny didn‚Äôt make a big deal about it at all and just got on with her job/day. It must be tough in these situations to maintain your professionalism
column2: I really admire Jenny and other tour leaders as they really do have to deal with so much.

column1: We were in Madurai to visit the Sri Meenakshi- Sundareshwarar temple
column2: one of the busiest and largest in South India
column3: the Rough Guide describes the temples gopuras (pyramid like structures) as ‚Äúthe greatest man made spectacle of the South‚Äù. The temple is dedicated to both Shiva and Meenakshi who were married and lived in Madurai from which they ruled the Pandya kingdom.

column1: The temple was surrounded by a large pedistrianised area
column2: the first (and probably last) I have seen in India
column3: it was heavenly! The temple complex

column1: is to use a much misused/overused word (often by myself)
column2: epic
column3: epic in both size and stature. The four gates to the temple are each topped by large
column4: brightly (some may say gaudily) coloured and intricately carved gopuras) which contain carvings of 1
column5: 001 gods related too or incarnations of Shiva/Meenakshi. The gopuras are spectacular
column6: the carving is not only extraordinarily intricate but also impressive in it‚Äôs sheer quantity
column7: I imagine the gopuras took a very long time complete (we were probably told how long but I have forgotten
column8: apologies
column9: C- try harder next time). Madurai temple is very much a working temple and was full of local and non local worshippers
column10: apparently around 15
column11: 000 people visit the temple every day. It was probably the most spiritual temple I have visited in India
column12: it felt like an Oasis of calm in a town/country of craziness. The temple was full of chanting worshippers (some
column13: including women
column14: with fully shaven heads) and holy men who often appeared in a trance like state. The spirituality and devotion of the worshippers was really quite moving
column15: it felt like a privilege to glimpse people worshipping in a temple which was obviously of great importance to them.

column4: although I guess we have been spoilt and a little overloaded with temples on this tour and in all honesty temples aren‚Äôt of massive interest to me. On another note we didn‚Äôt have a guide for the Trichy temples which probably didn‚Äôt help endear me to the temples.

column1: Ruth and I woke at 3.30am and were checked out and in a cab to the airport by 3.45am the trip at this time of the morning was fast and hassle free. We both leave from the same terminal at Delhi Airport which is a real bonus. On arrival we checked in Ruth's bags for her Singapore flight then lodged mine for Chennai which took significantly longer. I then walked Ruth to passport control we said our semi sad farewell as I know she is keen to go home and then watched her through the glass until she moved beyond and out of sight.

I then headed to domestic departures (where I met my girlfriend LOL) and made my way though having a few moments panic when I forgot to retrieve my small pack after putting it through the scanner. I was almost at the gate when I realised so I sprinted back to where I left it and was accosted by security who began lecturing me
column2: not really necessary as I felt stupid as it was. I then headed for my gate
column3: I was the only one there when they started boarding
column4: but soon the plane began to fill

column2: the last person on was sitting in front of me
column3: first he tried to jam a huge bloody bag into the luggage rack which crushed everyone else‚Äôs belongings and then he immediately laid his seat back. I napped a little on this flight so it was soon over and I had swapped the chilly madness of Delhi for the humid madness of Chennai.

column1: When I disembarked I messaged Padraic to see if he was in Chennai or already in Madurai
column2: fortunately (for me) he had been bumped from a flight and was sitting in the lounge so I joined him there and spent the next four hours drinking beer
column3: eating little sandwiches and muffins and chatting. Finally at 2.30pm we boarded a small forty seat aircraft and banked out over the ocean heading for Tamil Nadu's second largest city.

column1: Madurai is a surprisingly peaceful and a very clean city (compared to those in the North)
column2: I saw very few cows and dogs and the ones I did see appear to be in much better condition as well. We were met at the airport by our new driver and visited the fantastic five hundred year old Tirumalai Nayak

column1: Palace that had been partially and tactfully restored. The Mariamman Teppakkulam Tank (artificial lake) with a pretty temple in the centre was our next destination it is generally dry and used by the local kids as a cricket pitch but due to a recent festival we found it full of water and finally the massive and gaudy Sri Meenakshi Temple it is by far the most impressive Hindu temple complex I have seen and a World Heritage site. We walked around the temple for sometime taking snaps it was surprisingly clean inside and the complex was very interesting although I was disappointed to see a temple elephant that looked in poor condition.
It was then on to the hotel I had pre-booked
column2: unfortunately there was no room for Padraic so the driver took him somewhere else. We caught up for dinner on the roof later
column3: the food was quite good but the mosquitoes where menacing.

column1: The next morning we were packed up and on the road by 9am
column2: the driver had over slept (as they do) and I wasn't happy so I let his boss know about it and he soon arrived and we began the long drive

column1: to Ooty. The traffic here is light
column2: the sky is blue
column3: there is little garbage strewn about and the cows don‚Äôt appear to be eating plastic
column4: I am truly amazed. The weather is also dry like Adelaide so I am in my element.

column1: We drove for five or six hours arriving in mountainous Coonoor in the Western Ghats around 3.30pm the last hour in the mountains was extremely picturesque and I saw a different species of Langur monkey which was a bit of a surprise. On arrival at the station we booked tickets on the toy train to Ooty (Udhagamandalam)
column2: all the first class tickets were booked out so we had to put up with cattle class
column3: fortunately it was a short trip and not very interesting I must admit I had expected nicer views. Ooty is a hill station set up by the British in the early 1800's as a cool summer haven
column4: and it is easy to see why
column5: it is pleasant here and although it has grown since the days of the British it hasn‚Äôt lost all its charm with many a pretty church. Padraic and I wandered down to the main part of town for

column1: dinner I grabbed some drugs for my stomach and some great homemade chocolate which they sell everywhere. We stopped for a pleasant dinner before returning to the hotel.
The next morning we moved on to the National Park at Mudumalai it was a short drive
column2: so we had most of the day to wait till we went into the park in the late afternoon
column3: so we just watched the cricket in the lodge's entertainment area and enjoyed the relaxing natural setting
column4: there are quite a few monkeys here and some pretty birds.

column1: At 3.30pm we headed for the park where we were loaded on a noisy old bus and driven around for about thirty minutes and saw nothing
column2: this of course made me extremely angry so I tried to find another way to get in and see another tiger
column3: unfortunately there is no other way
column4: and they rarely see any major wildlife here. We then watched some villages bathing their elephants in the river before returning to the lodge.

column1: Driving directions to Madurai is simple.Drive towards Electronic City and you are on NH7.Drive straight on NH7 - the road goes straight to Kanyakumari passing through Salem Madurai. Madurai is about 450 Kms from Bangalore it will take maximum 5.30 hours.The road is 4 lane you have to cross 7-8 tolls and shell out Rs 500 till Madurai.I was able to manage 120Km/hr till madurai with small breaks did Bangalore Madurai in 4.30 hrz.

1 hour we lost in Madurai city to find out directions for Rameshwaram.Madurai to Ramehswaram is 180 kms and its 2 lane NH in very good condition but you cant mantain the same speed you did Bangalore - madurai.Another 3 hrz to to Rameshwaram.
Rameshwaram is a small laid back temple town of religious importance- wrong

column3: 1 side its Indian Ocean other side its Bay of Bengal.You can see 2 different colors mixing into 1.1 day you can easily spend on the beach and 1 day visit temple.

column1: This was my 2nd trip to India. A very short trip indeed.
We arrived in Chennai International Airport and our pre-booked vehicle was waiting for us. We had a grand welcome from the hotel (Ambica Empire) - presenting us with garlands üòä

The check-in was quick and we got settled in our room. The weather was very humid and staying in an air-con room was a neccessity. We had hired a driver to bring us around for our trip. We had lunch (typical south indian Thali) and it was absolutely delicious and cheap!

column2: we did the usual touristy stuffs:

column1: (3) MGR memorial (both my parents were fans of his movies)

column2: we arrived into Kancheepuram where we stopped by a store/factory and the owner showed us how Kancheepuram (famous worldwide) silk is being made. Horn blowing while driving is like some form of tourettes here and no amount of signs is going to change that.

column1: Ooty's nice and warm in the day but can get very chilly even cold at night. Despite this nowhere seems to have any heating so in the restaurants at night everyone is sat there in thier hats and coats. Ooty town itself is ok but nothing special. Like most places Iv'e seen in India there seems to have been very little thought put into town planning/building. So Ooty sits like some grubby
little scar of concreate boxes and open sewers surrounded by fantastic countryside. All rolling hills
column2: tea plantations and mist cloaked forest. Its a shame really you just have the feeling it could be so much better.

column1: I spent most of my time there out of town and up in the hills which was fantastic except i need a better set of legs.
Apparently it used to be called ""snooty Ooty"" back durring the days of British rule as all the rich colonials used to decamp up here when it got to hot down on the plains.

It was the festival of Pongal while I was there which from what I could gather is a sort of harvest festival. All the cows were spruced up to look their best with a quick wash and painted horns. Sugar cane seemed to be big on the menu with everyone taking bags of it home and some places hanging it outside. The cleaning ladies at the guest house all drew designs outside the door which I took a rather rubbish picture of. Out of Ooty I saw a few elephants also all done up in their finery which would have made
a nice picture but I was tearing by at break neck speed on a bus at the time.

So all in all Ooty town I could take or leave but the surrounding countryside is great for walking and if you've got a wooly hat the climate is perfect. And if you do make it here kabab korner is great for tandoori of any kind.

Said at the begining that i was now in Ooty which I was when I started writing this but have now moved on again and arrived yesterday in Fort Cochin in Kerala which at first look is just my sort of place. More about that next time.

column2: large restaurant with an excellent buffet featuring a wide variety of Indian foods both vegetarian and non

amusements were doing a desultory business. The beach wasn‚Äôt as crowded as I expected. We walked up to some long
column2: narrow fishing boats with their wooden anchors stowed ‚Äì possibly drag anchors. For the most part

Folk art carved panels depicting the life of Jesus reminded me of the church of the Black Christ in Panama. The church was more brightly lit than any I had ever seen

column2: Marina Beach

column1: I have now left Mysore where I had a great time. Its my favorite city so far.

While there I visited the railway museum which my guide book said was very interesting and well worth half a day. I'd say it was a little bit interesting and well worth half an hour. Never trust the books.

Also had time at the Maharajas palace which was very interesting. Its a little bit of a walk from the gate where you pay to go in and entrance to the palace. Security is quite tight and before they let me in they put my bag through an x-ray machine saw the camera in there
column2: no photography is allowed inside
column3: and I was pulled to one side and told to go back to the main gate and drop it off at a locker. I gave the guard my best ""you've got to be joking look"" slipped him ten rupees with a promise to leave it in my bag and I was in. Once inside I was confronted with a thousand other visiters all snapping away merrily right in front of the guides who took not a blind bit of notice. I bet it

column1: didn't cost them all ten rupees.

The palace is huge and only part of it is open to the public which is a good job or it would take all day to get round. Its all a bit over the top as far as decoration goes but was well worth the vist.
Had a very nice day out at Mysore zoo. I've been to a lot of very badly run poor zoos in asia but this was a very good one. More monkeys on the outside of the cages as inside.

After a few more days of general wandering I booked a mini bus from Mysore up to Ooty in the Nilgiri hills. It was an early start of what turned out to be a not very good day. I was the first pick up but was assured it would only take 20 minutes to pick up everybody else. It took 2 hours which put me in a bit of a grumpy mood as it wasn't a very comfortable bus. The driver was a lunatic who kept trying to overtake when there was clearly no chance of making it. After a few near death experiances I felt
the need to let him know that if he tried to kill me again we'd be having more that a few words.
It was meant to be a direct trip of about four hours but an hour after leaving Mysore we stopped for breakfast
column2: then stopped again to look at some goats then only a few miles from our destination we stopped again for an hour at a lake so everyone could go for a boat ride. I was not best pleased and had a right moan at the bloke in charge. I think the idea was that we'd all get bored and take an auto rickshaw the last few miles into town but stuborness had taken over so I sat it out. Finanly we left for the last little bit of the journey and got within less that a mile of our drop off point when we stopped for lunch!! At this point I went into a purple headed rage which wasn't helped when I was told it was only a five minute walk to where I wanted to be which begged the question why didn
column3: t you drop me off first. As i was close to getting chucked

column1: off the bus anyway I gave up and walked the last bit. So my four hour day had turned into an eight day and I had turned into a miserable old bugger. Oh well I suppose they can't all be good days.
Only been in Ooty for a day so nothing to tell you yet except it gets very cold at night due to the alltitude and I've had to dig my jumper out of the bag for the first time this trip.
Not sure yet where I'm going next but will let you all know when I get there.

column1: The Dancing Nataraja is an important symbol of India. This statue is in the hotel lobby.
Our 24 hours plus of airports and airplanes wasn‚Äôt so bad ‚Äì I forced myself into a kind of sleep after dinner on the way to Frankfurt. On the way to Chennai I had several genuine naps
column2: interspersed with looking out the window. The sky was clear over most of the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea. As we went over the Caucasus Mountainsby the Caspian
column3: I finally disturbed my seatmate to get at my camera in the overhead compartment. Just caught the end of the snow capped ridges as the sun set. The pattern of weather was obviously from the northwest as most of the snow was on that side of the mountains in a scene of white and greeny-gray
column4: deepening as the sun set into an orange rim.

column1: The night was deeply black when we arrived in Chennai at about a quarter to midnight. After waiting in the long lineup at immigration and then collecting our luggage
column2: we stepped out into florescent-lit darkness
column3: punctuated by the many horns of the many cars meeting the many passengers. After a few minutes
column4: we walked through the chaos understood only by the Indians to our full-size bus
column5: which drove into the fairly quiet streets of Chennai. First impressions were of lots of one-to-three-storey concrete buildings
column6: all shuttered for the night. I was surprised that there was no unusual smell to the air as there is in Africa.

column1: Our hotel (Vivanta by Taj Connemara) greeted us with garlands and juice. Lovely honey-coloured marble and modern rooms. To bed about 2:30 a.m.
The tour guide moves in for the kill...

column2: for lack of better descriptors (can someone please forward me some new adjectives other than amazing and incredible? I use these words far too often when I blog!)
column3: amazing and comforting. As I mentioned in the last posting
column4: Kerala is really home-y to me and it was nice going back to a couple places that I had been before and sharing them with Mom. We went immediately from Kannur to Fort Cochin
column5: an old colonial-ish town on the coast that I went to once when I was here last time. It's pretty un-India in that there is less traffic and noise than usual and there are lots of old churches and Dutch and Portugese buildings instead of temples. I left Mom to sightsee on her own for the first day since I had pretty much seen everything and I took the day to work on a correspondence course that I'm taking while here (this was a terrible idea on my part ‚Äì but one that I am resignedly sticking to!). The following day we went on a backwaters boat tour to see some of the countryside that Kerala is famous for.

column2: it tastes better than it smells!""

but we had a great guide who was really funny and kept hitting on my mom all day ‚Äì and I kept telling him that I was going to tell my dad about it but the guide just laughed. He is also apparently an Ayurvedic (traditional Indian medicine) doctor so he was taking everyone's pulse and telling them about their health. We took a boat and cruised around the backwaters
column3: these long
column4: interconnecting rivers that function as watery highways that people still use for commerce and for getting around in the remote parts of the state. We also got to drink toddy
column5: which is a local moonshine brew made from the sap of coconut flowers
column6: and smells really bad but tastes good! It ferments throughout the day so that at night when I went to have a little nightcap I loosened the lid of my bottle
column7: the cap shot off and hit the ceiling of my room! I ended up not drinking the rest...

and Santha
column3: my ‚ÄúIndian Mum‚Äù
column4: who is hands-down the strongest woman I know. Those of you who read my blogs from last time I was here will know the story (hahaha but you can always go back and re-read it if you need refreshing!)
column5: but the short version of it is that Santha is married to an abusive husband but can't get out of the marriage and in trying to help other women and serve as an example she is working for the women's organization
column6: Sevika Sanghom
column7: that I volunteered with last time I was here.

column1: The whole train ride to Thiruvalla my stomach was doing flips
column2: partly because I was excited but also partly that Santha had only gotten the email that we were coming the day before and I didn't want to be a burden on her or interrupt her weekend. The second we saw each other on the train platform though
column3: we broke out into huge smiles and ran towards each other
column4: me dropping my bags all over the place
column5: and just gave each other the hugest hugs
column6: laughing and crying at the same time. It was amazing to me that

column1: years (almost to the day) that I had first arrived in Thiruvalla and met Santha
column2: I was able to come back and visit her again. It also meant the world to me that I was able to introduce my mom and Santha to each other
column3: both of my Moms
column4: living half a world away from each other. It turned out that she had declined going to her cousin's wedding and picking her husband (who is a monster) up from the hospital so that she could come meet our train
column5: but it didn't matter to her because
column6: in her words
column7: ‚ÄúIt feels like my daughter is coming home‚Äù. Yup
column8: the tears were really going at that point!

column1: We spent the afternoon visiting and getting caught up on all of our news ‚Äì she showed me pictures of her new granddaughter
column2: I showed her photos of my family
column3: we went for lunch and tea
column4: and we visited a bunch of the places I worked at
column5: in particular the old age home where
column6: astonishingly
column7: a few of the older ladies remembered me and even knew my NAME (I basically did not stop crying the entire time I was there hahaha!!)

column1: Let's talk about how painful it was to walk back UP the cliff after a day in 40-degree heat!!
and visiting the home for special-needs girls where I worked
column2: as well as the girls' orphanage. I was really excited to hear that some of the girls are off doing higher education
column3: one of them
column4: Asha
column5: is at school for fashion design and another
column6: Manju
column7: is at teacher training school
column8: and it made me so happy to know that they are getting the chance to do what they might not have been able to do if they hadn't come into the organization.

column1: Mom and I stayed at the volunteers' flat and cooked a delicious dinner (well I cooked) of dhal
column2: chappati
column3: bhindi masala and kozhukattai (which is a rice dumpling stuffed with coconut and jaggery and I am sure I have mentioned it before because it is pretty much the best dessert I have ever had)
column4: and Santha complimented me on my cooking and how good it was which made me happy since she was the one who taught me and it was good to know that I still remember everything! It was a really short visit
column5: just overnight
column6: but it was still so special. It felt amazing to go back and visit the vegetable market
column7: the

column1: As you can tell from Barry's tears
column2: we made quite an impact on them! Awesome couple to hang out with.
even just the internet cafe
column3: the places that were a part of my daily life for 2 months while I was going through a period of really intense personal growth and exploration
column4: and being in Thiruvalla brought back so many happy memories of learning how to do the simple things
column5: like laundry by hand every night and cooking from scratch every evening and getting water from the well and all these things that I had to do while I lived there that I had never done before
column6: but that taught me a lot of patience (ahem
column7: a trait that I am still working on and probably still will be working on for the rest of my life!). Seeing Santha was also really special
column8: this woman who is my role-model and someone whose spirit is so strong and so unable to be dominated by her horrific husband
column9: who unfortunately she is still living with but who still continues to threaten to kill her and who continues to have affairs with other women
column10: right in the house. She has not and will not stop fighting against the hand that she was dealt in life and it was so comforting to see

column2: ever.
2 years later
column3: she is still dreaming big about starting up a little farm and community for women where they can escape and live in peace away from abusive marriages.

column1: After visiting Thiruvalla we went to Varkala
column2: a reeeeeeeeeeally touristy beach resort that
column3: again
column4: I had already been to but that was awesome to see again. Our room had a big balcony with a hammock (Pashu
column5: if you are reading this one
column6: the hammock was much MUCH stronger than that in Kudle (plus I was in it by myself) so it didn't break
column7: but even if it had there was a railing on the balcony so I couldn't have fallen off) and a BATHTUB
column8: which I hadn't even seen since I left Canada
column9: and I was reminded and thankful again for the perks of travelling with Mom
column10: who I have decided is no longer allowed to go out shopping on her own because she has no bargaining skills whatsoever and paid way too much money for a purse and shirt. So now shopping is supervised üòä . We spent the majority of our time in Varkala on the beach with a nice couple we'd met in Fort Cochin

column2: Barry and Kelly
column3: who were hilarious
column4: doing a lot of swimming and reading and walking on the beach
column5: and of course having one terrifically epic dance party that featured a middle aged Indian guy doing the splits on the dance floor! It was a very relaxing 2 days but I was getting antsy eating non-spicy food (one of the downers of hanging around in major tourist hotspots) and so we left for Kanyakumari after 3 days.

column1: Kanyakumari is on the tip of India
column2: where the Arabian Sea
column3: Indian Ocean
column4: and Bay of Bengal all meet and where a ton of spiritual stuff has happened
column5: making it both a pilgrimmage spot and a tourist destination for Indians. It was a weird blend of this very holy temple to the goddess Devi Kumari
column6: who from what I gather was a virgin who seduced Shiva by dancing or something like that (I may be getting this mixed up with Meenakshi
column7: whose temple in Madurai we visited yesterday
column8: who was born with 3 breasts but an astrologer told her father that upon meeting her husband the 3rd breast would disappear; she fought a big war against Shiva's

column1: These kids were actually REALLY sweet
column2: but we realized that if we stood in one place for too long we risked never being able to leave due to the sheer number of pictures being taken!

column1: army in the north of India and when Shiva himself came down to see who this goddess was who had beaten back all of his soldiers
column2: her 3rd breast disappeared and they got married)
column3: mixed with a bunch of souvenir shops selling mobiles made out of shells that really could have been equally as at home in south Florida. I loved it though
column4: there was something really powerful about being at the end of the country
column5: looking out at the sun rising in the east
column6: with absolutely nothing but open
column7: wildly crashing ocean before you (I'm sure no one will be surprised when I said it brought tears to my eyes
column8: followed quickly by lots of laughter as about 35 people wanted to take their photos individually with me). We also went out to the Devi temple on the ocean
column9: where her footsteps from her dance are said to be
column10: and I can honestly say that there was something REALLY moving about that place
column11: too ‚Äì when I visited the Mount of Olives in Jerusalem and the spot where Jesus was said to have ascended into heaven
column12: I felt some really powerful energy there too and it was similar to

column1: Am I a total loser if I find wind turbines beautiful? Hahahahaha!
what I felt at the temple in Kanyakumari ‚Äì whether or not a goddess really did dance there and whether or not there really was a Jesus who went up into heaven
column2: I can't say
column3: but I do know that I was hit with the same feeling of the place being really
column4: really sacred and special.

column1: We went by train to Madurai
column2: where there is
column3: as I mentioned above
column4: a huge and gorgeous temple to the goddess Meenakshi and the god Shiva
column5: and it is on this train that I saw thousands upon thousands of wind turbines
column6: looking like big white birds spinning in the sky
column7: and that made me so happy
column8: and also made the single. lone wind turbing at Toronto's waterfront look pathetic by comparison! As usual the train was a full-sensory experience. South India in particular is absolutely gorgeous
column9: with the palms
column10: rice paddies
column11: mountains in the distance
column12: and it is just so lush and verdant and fertile that it fills you up with so much positive energy. Travelling by train right now is also a unique experience due to the sheer number of pilgrims going to Sabarimala
column13: which is a holy place in

column1: The unbelievably intricate and gorgeous statues on the entranceway to the Madurai temple.
Kerala that is worshipped by devotees of Ayappa
column2: the son of
column3: incidentally
column4: a gay union between Shiva and Vishnu (well
column5: sort of ‚Äì the gods wanted to test Shiva to see how good he was at resisting temptation
column6: so Vishnu got all dressed up like a beautiful woman and went to seduce Shiva. The plan backfired though
column7: because apparently Shiva is NOT good at resisting temptation
column8: and a son was born of their get-together
column9: Ayappa) (please also note that my re-telling of the Hindu stories
column10: legends and history is approximate and subject to my own interpretation of things ‚Äì I told the story of Kali to Chris
column11: a British friend of mine who really IS well-versed in Hindu philosophy
column12: and he burst out laughing at what I had come up with). Sabarimala time sees millions of men dressed in black
column13: barefoot and carrying packs of food
column14: clothes and blankets on their heads
column15: walking and taking the train to the temple that apparently gets almost as many visitors as Mecca!

column1: So the trains are crowded but no less fun and intense
column2: the food is still as spicy as ever and we are leaving tomorrow for Mumbai
column3: where I

column1: My favourite statues in the Madurai temple for sure: Shiva and Meenakshi having a dance-off!

fully intend on finding a role in Bollywood that is a step up from my last role in a commercial with Deepika Padukone and where my mom can make a little pilgrimmage of her own to some of the places mentioned in the book Son of the Circus by John Irving (another excellent read).
p.s. I have had numerous hilarious exchanges with rickshaw drivers wanting to take us to a place where they get a cut from bringing business to a hotel. It is of course frustrating
column2: but always makes me laugh because of the absurdity of conversations I wind up having. A typical exchange with a commission-seeking rickshaw driver looks like this:

column1: Me: ‚ÄúWe would like to go to the New College Guesthouse‚Äù

column2: New College Guesthouse.‚Äù
Sree Devi Guesthouse.‚Äù
we want to go to New College Guesthouse. No Sree Devi.‚Äù
Sree Devi Guesthouse is very good price. We go there.‚Äù

column1: I realised that I have to hurry up a little bit because my friend Sepp from Kiel wants to visit me in Chennai in about 3 weeks
column2: and if I want to fulfill my plan of going to the very South of Inida it are still 1500km.

column1: Because the days in India are quite short also the distances I make are not so big. Before India it was no problem to ride more than 100km a day. But here I havent made more than 100km in one day except the one day without luggage where I took my MP3 player. After the night at the beach in Goa I decided to make 100km again. And I made it. I was going to the Cotiago Sanctuary in the South of Goa. And it was really nice. I havent seen any leopard or so but it was an awesome silence and nice jungle I was wandering in. So on 31.12. I already was leaving Goa again. Since the alcohol is so cheap in Goa that I bought a bottle of Cashew schnapps. I realised that after the last puncture I have lost my air pump. I couldnt believe it
column2: how could I

column1: lose my air pump? So I bought in the next town a new pump. It is a really big one! But it is working very fine.
My battery of my bordcomputer was quite empty at least it said so. I changed the battery and it isnt working at all anymore. But dont worry
column2: the stop watch is still working so I can stop my daily riding time. And the distances I estimate by my maps and the road signs. So you still can enjoy my statistics üòä

column1: New years eve I was celebrating with the schnapps and mango nectar. I was awakened by loud biting aunts in the entry of my tent. Unbelievable that they were so loud. But luckily
column2: my tent was closed and they couldnt come into my tent.

the next state after Goa I just cycled through. Although I was on a National Highway the road was often very bad. And the more I was coming to the South the more noise was on the street. I was often listening to music so it was a bit better. Here the mosquitos are also much more present than in the first days in

column1: Maharashtra. I was surprised to have no problems with mosquitos there but now I have to hurry up every evening to build up my tent to flee away from them. However
column2: n the tent is it often very hot and I am sweatening a lot. I start sleeping without any sleeping bag but during the night it is getting colder so that I have to crawl into it.

column1: Some news of my companions: Bert from US cycled in Israel Jordan
column2: Egypt
column3: Indonesia
column4: Malaysia
column5: Thailand (with some flights in between) and is now back at home. Chris and Meint made it from Teheran over Turkmenistan
column6: Uzbekistan
column7: Kyrgyzstan to Kashgar in China with the cycle. But for both it was too cold and Chris took the train to Beijing and Meint was flying to Nepal where he spent a month as backpacker. I think Chris is continuing to Australia as far as possible with bicycle.

column1: After three days I came into Kerala. Again a different language
column2: different people. The men are often wearing wrap-around skirts. You see again many mosques and women in black clothes. Even the letters are completely different from the devangari alphabet. So I have agaion

column1: no idea what is written on the signs. I often must think of Europe
column2: also with a unique currency and no passport controls at the borders
column3: but different cultures
column4: different languages
column5: different countries.

column1: I got again many spots as in Serbia for example
column2: I thinkl it is from the heat and the effort. But they have gone again after a few days.

column1: Sometimes I made a rest at a beach. Very nice beaches
column2: often without any person there! But in general it is very crowded along the coast in Kerala. My RoughGuide says it is the most denelky populated region in hole India. And I feel it! There is no place where you can be alone for a few minutes. And then the horrible noise of the crazy honking of everybody. I have no problems with the smell
column3: the chaos
column4: the litter
column5: the heat
column6: mosquitos
column7: ... but the noise I cant get used to it. In the evening I had many problems to get a sleeping place. The towns or villages or whatever along the road didnt stop. I was happy when I found a green area in the middle of a town where I could stay. And it

column1: is funny that in such places I was mostly not disturbed the whole evening
column2: night and morning
column3: although all people could see me.

column1: In the middle of Kerala at the coiast there is a little enclave
column2: Mahe
column3: belonging to Puducherry
column4: another very little state. There were many alcohol shops so that I allowed myself a bottle of wine. That night I stayed at a beach. Some locals came and stared at me without saying something or made some fancy movements with their hands that I didnt understand. I thought the one guy wanted to have some food of me. After a while a bigger group came to me and one said to me that there are often snakes. Everywhere snakes! Even at the beach. They showed me a place where no snakes can come to. I tried exceptionally to sleep without a tent but that was a fault. The mosquitos annoyed me muchso I couldnt sleep. At one o'clock or so the police came
column5: wanted to see my passport and was asking what I am doing there. Thei said it was not so safe there
column6: that there are some thieves. I nevertheless wanted to stay there and they said

column1: okay but dont complain tomorrow at the police. No problems with any thieves but many problems with the mosquitos!
One evening when I couldnt find a sleeping place I was riding in the night. Was not so bad as I thought and it was quite nice not to have the hot sun. But that was the only evening I did this
column2: else I ride only in the daylight.

column1: Some days it was really hot
column2: it reminded me to the hot days in Turkey. I just went from one juice shop to the next and tried nice fruit juices and shakes and ice creamsüòä

column1: In Kottayam I decided to go directly to Tamil Nadu and not make the longer way to Trivandrum and then backj to Chennai. The time was getting too close. I had to cross the ghats I was making 1000m elevation in one day. I dont know if I had such steep mountains so far. There were tea plantages everywhere where I also decided to sleep. I thought there was a nice meadow but suddenly my feet were completely sunk in mud. Nice! But I found a dry place to stay. In the night it
was extremely raining. Once a guy came and said something like Buga
column2: buga
column3: beega
column4: Caruba! Probably Malayam
column5: the language spoken in Kerala. I said ""sleep
column6: sleep""and made the corresponding handsign. ""Buga
column7: Baruga!"" I answered the same and he was going away. And for this conversation I had to open my tent
column8: that everything got wet! After a while the same game with another person. But then they let me alone. The next morning I was awakened buy one of the guys at 7am and he showed with hand signs that I should not stay there. He showed in a direction where maybe a hotel was. But now I didnt need any hotel anymore
column9: so I left the tea plantage.

column1: I was going to the Periyar Sanctuaryat the border to Tamil Nadu. First I missed it and I was riding down with much speed to about 400 m altitude. There I was said I am already in Tamil Nadu and I have to go back. Again upwards
column2: maybe 400m. 10 min. down
column3: 1h up...I was a bit disappointed because I couldnt go into the park with my bike. The normal way is to take a boat trip or to take

column1: a tour guide which you had to book in advance. The second alternative sounded better
column2: but another day staying there I wasnt going for that. So I took the touristical boat trip. And as I thought it was quite boring. Of course
column3: the animals are running away by such a noisy boat going along the lake. When the staff said: ""Look
column4: a deer!"" Everybody was getting to his feet and making pictures. But from a big distance we could see two elephants and wild pigs and a buffalo. Next to the boat we have seen two otters. An Indian tourist group m
column5: ade much fotos of me and my bike. Maybe I was the most interesting being they have seen in the park üòä

column1: Tamil Nadu I liked much more than Kerala
column2: not so crowded and you easily find sleeping places üòä In restaurants the food is served on palm leaves
column3: very cool! In the days I arrived here there is a festival
column4: especially celebrated in the countryside. As far as I have understood are the cows celebrated. They are often coloured
column5: their fur and their horns. And in the villages there comes from big loudspeakers loud music
column6: with a

column1: very bad quality. I often was awakened by this music.
My two tent bars are broken now. Now the tent is a bit unstable there is little space inside and it is not drying so easy. But it still works. Hopefully I can get it fixed in Chennai!

One day I was staying at a lake. One guy asked me where I want to go now and I said I want to look for sleeping place. He was discussing something with another guy. I said:""For example here!"" Because I liked this place and was annoyed of their disussion. They found it quite funny I think that I want to stay there and said:""I like this place!"" They said something about cold
column2: mosquitos
column3: snakes
column4: but no reasons not to stay there with my tent. They phoned to some friends and aftyer a few minutes the half village was watching me pitching my tent up. Every newcomer was greeted with the words:""...I like this place!..."" accompanied with some laughter. Didnt know that this sentence was so funny... The next morning when I got up a guy saw me and he whistled to the village that everybody could join

column1: the morning show of the strange crazy foreigner that likes that place.
I went to Puducherry in a bar restaurant. It was noon
column2: but it was very full and loud and all people drinking. I had two beers and a little snack there. I was a bit drunk. I think I am not used to drink anymore. In the near I was also in the sea
column3: seemed to be a famous beach by the locals. But it was funny that they just stood around. Not like at us
column4: where everybody is lying at a towel or so. Only few were in the water
column5: mostly little children. However
column6: that didnt keep me from having a nice refreshing bath.

column1: From Puducherry I followed the coast to Chennai. I had a little misunderstanding with Sepp
column2: I thought he will arrive at Friday night in Chennai
column3: but it was on Sunday night. So I had suddenly 2 more days where I was quite lazy
column4: was often in an internetcafe and wrote some diary.
